title: Splenic infarction
description:
CT abdomen (left upper quadrant; with IV contrast; axial plane) of patient with history of atrial fibrillation and acute left upper quadrant pain

A sharply demarcated hypodense area (green overlay) is seen in the medial spleen (S). Capsular enhancement is preserved.

The finding represents a splenic infarction. Infarctions may be single or multiple and typically appear as hypoenhancing or nonenhancing lesions, often wedge-shaped. Imaging features can vary with stage. Acute infarctions may appear heterogeneous and contain sites of hemorrhage. Chronic infarctions may disappear or liquify and become cystic. They may also result in parenchymal scarring, seen as splenic volume loss and distortion.

A: aorta; C: colon; L: liver; red overlay: splenic artery

title: Mesothelioma
description:
CT scan of the thorax (transverse view)

The right lung appears hyperdense with circumferential pleural thickening.

This radiographical appearance is typical of a mesothelioma alongside a right unilateral pleural effusion.

title: Heliotrope rash
description:
A confluent macular, erythematous rash is visible on both upper eyelids with concurrent periorbital edema.

This is a characteristic finding in dermatomyositis.

title: Herpes zoster
description:
Numerous grouped vesicles are visible on dermatome T1/T2, exclusively on the left side. Some vesicles appear hemorrhagic.

This appearance together with its typical distribution pattern along dermatomes is typical of herpes zoster, which is caused by the reactivation of the varicella zoster virus.

title: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
description:
Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

title: Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes
description:
Petri dish containing a growth medium (trypticase soy agar supplemented with defibrinated sheep's blood) that has been inoculated with Streptococcus pyogenes.

The yellowish halo surrounding the bacterial colonies indicates complete degradation (beta-hemolysis) of the red blood cells in those areas.

Beta-hemolysis is a characteristic feature of S. pyogenes.

title: Advanced chronic venous insufficiency
description:
Left lower leg

Typical features of chronic venous insufficiency, including purpura jaune d'ocre, atrophie blanche, lipodermatosclerosis, and an active venous ulceration are present.

There is impaired microcirculation of the vessels due to venous stasis. The findings indicate CEAP class C6 disease.

title: Chronic lumbar compression deformity
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

There is a chronic compression deformity (red dimension line) of the L4 vertebral body, with displacement (red overlay) toward the spinal canal beyond the posterior vertebral lines of L3 and L5 (white dotted line). Exuberant anterior osteophyte formation is visible at L3–4 (red dotted lines).

title: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of esophageal tissue (H&E stain)

Nests of neoplastic squamous cells with nuclear atypia (yellow overlay) surround prominent keratin pearls (green overlay). Components of nonkeratinizing basal-like tumor cells can be seen as well.

This carcinoma is moderately differentiated and keratinizing.

title: Echinocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; medium power magnification)

There is a mixture of normal erythrocytes, with a uniform, smooth, and rounded surface (blue dashed circles), and erythrocytes, with numerous, evenly spaced, thorny projections (blue circles). These cells are referred to as echinocytes or burr cells.

Echinocytes can occur as a result of oxidative or colloid osmotic stress. They may also be an artifact resulting from prolonged storage of blood samples.

title: Innominate rotation dysfunction
description:
ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

title: Contrast-enhanced ultrasound of hepatocellular adenoma (hepatic adenoma)
description:
Ultrasound liver (contrast-enhanced; top: early arterial phase; bottom: portal phase) of hepatocellular adenoma

A solid mass evaluated with contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) shows a pattern of centripetal filling. Peripheral enhancement (yellow overlay) in the early arterial phase is followed by homogeneous enhancement (blue overlay) in the portal phase.

CEUS allows for the real-time assessment of liver vascularity and has been found effective for characterizing benign liver lesions. Hepatic adenomas are hypervascular and show centripetal or mixed filling. On delayed images, they may show sustained enhancement or mild washout.

title: Hepatic mass
description:
Ultrasound liver (oblique plane) of patient with hepatic metastases from colon carcinoma

A dominant hypoechoic mass (yellow overlay) shows heterogeneous echotexture and an irregular margin. Other hypoechoic masses (blue overlay) are also seen posterior to this mass. Biopsy proved that all of the lesions are colon carcinoma metastases.

title: Kaposi sarcoma on heel of HIV patient
description: The purple-bluish lesions, seen on the heel of this HIV-positive patient, are multiple Kaposi sarcoma. The lesion on the left side is elevated, while the other lesions are patches. The causative agent is HHV-8.

title: Tinea corporis
description:
A round, well demarcated erythematous lesion with central scaling is visible. The border is raised with several pustules visible.

These features are characteristic of tinea corporis.

title: Lobar consolidation
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with a history of bacterial pneumonia

Opacification of much of the right lower lobe parenchyma is the result of air space consolidation. Pulmonary vessels are obscured and patent airways (air bronchograms, white dashed line) are seen. Consolidation extends to the major fissure (green overlay).

Parenchymal opacification can be caused by fluid or solid material. Major causes in the acute setting include pneumonia, aspiration, edema, and hemorrhage. In the chronic setting, the main causes include invasive adenocarcinoma and alveolar proteinosis.

title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma (WHO grade I)
description:
Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)

Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

title: Surface anatomy of the lungs
description: ICS: intercostal space

title: Catabolic pathway of amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine
description: The amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine share a common catabolic pathway. At first, phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase. This enzyme requires the cofactors tetrahydrobiopterin and dioxide. Tyrosine is then converted to 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate by tyrosine aminotransferase. The aromatic ring of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate is cleaved and the product is converted to fumarylacetoacetate by isomerization. Fumarate and acetoacetate are then produced by hydrolytic cleavage. Subsequently, acetoacetate can then be used to form acetoacetyl-CoA.

title: Quadriceps tendon tear
description:
Left: MRI knee (PD weighted (Fat Sat); sagittal plane)
Right: X-ray knee (lateral view)

MRI shows a quadriceps tendon tear (red overlay) accompanied by extensive hyperintense fluid (indicated by green arrowheads), including a joint effusion. The radiograph shows some soft tissue thickening in the suprapatellar region (green overlay) and a small calcification (yellow arrowhead).

title: Pulmonary aspergillosis
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

title: Microcolon and bowel perforation in meconium ileus
description:
Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileus

Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.

Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.

Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

title: Maltese cross sign
description:
Polarized light micrograph of lyotropic liquid crystals

These Lα liquid crystals have a characteristic Maltese cross appearance (examples indicated by green overlay) under polarized light. Fatty casts from urinary sediment have the same appearance under polarized light.

title: Menstrual cycle
description:
The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

title: Diagnostic approach to nipple discharge
description:
DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

title: Measles rash
description:
Photograph of a toddler

There is a generalized erythematous maculopapular exanthem. Some confluence is visible (e.g., on the upper thighs).

title: Mechanism of action: asthma medication
description:
B2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol): relax bronchial smooth muscle and induce bronchodilation

Theophylline: inhibits phosphodiesterase (PDE) and the conversion of cyclic-AMP to AMP, resulting in anti-inflammatory and bronchodilatory effects

Mepolizumab (monoclonal antibody): binds to interleukin-5 and prevents binding to its receptor on eosinophils resulting in reduced eosinophil activation.

Omalizumab (monoclonal antibody): inhibits the binding of IgE and, thus, the activation of mast cells, basophils, and dendritic cells

Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., cromolyn sodium, nedocromil): block the IgE receptor on mast cells preventing degranulation and histamine release

Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., ipratropium bromide): competitively inhibit postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle resulting in bronchodilation

Leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRA; e.g, montelukast): counteract the pro-inflammatory effects of leukotrienes by blocking the leukotriene receptor on bronchial smooth muscle

Inhaled/oral corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, prednisolone): inhibit transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), resulting in an anti-inflammatory effect

Zileuton: inhibits 5-lipoxygenase, resulting in reduced leukotriene production

title: Miliary tuberculosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The image shows a granuloma with necrosis in the center (green outline), a surrounding layer of immune cells such as macrophages (B), and a peripheral layer (C), which consists of epitheloid cells. A giant cell (A) can also be seen.

This is the typical histopathological appearance of a caseating granuloma, which is seen in tuberculosis.

title: Ewing sarcoma
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Vaginal epithelium
description:
Photomicrograph of vaginal tissue (azan trichrome stain; ~150x magnification)

This image shows the eosinophilic, stratified, nonkeratinized, squamous epithelium of the vagina. The epithelial cells accumulate glycogen in granules. In the desquamated cells, the glycogen is broken down to lactic acid by natural vaginal flora.

The lamina propria is rich in collagen fibres that stain blue. The white, seemingly empty areas are most likely vessels running through the lamina propria.

Characteristically, there are no mucous glands.

title: Microstructure of a lymph node
description:
Photomicrograph of lymph node tissue (toluidine blue stain)

Left image (overview, low magnification): The B-cell zone (B) consists of several lymphoid follicles (here, three secondary follicles can be seen) with a light germinal center (yellow overlay) and a darker margin (red overlay).
The T-cell zone (T) is homogeneous and mainly contains naive T lymphocytes and high endothelial venules (HEV; black box).

Right image (cross section of an HEV; high magnification detail of black box): HEV (lumen: asterisk) enable lymphocytes in the circulation to enter lymph nodes. The endothelium of HEV is characteristically cobble-shaped with round cell nuclei.

title: Leukocoria
description:
Photograph of a patient with retinoblastoma

The left eye shows the normal retinal reflection, whereas the right pupil appears white (leukocoria or white pupil). This phenomenon occurs if light (e.g., during an ophthalmologic examination or flash photography) is not reflected by the retina but by intraocular lesions such as tumors.

Leukocoria is a typical early symptom of retinoblastoma.

title: Skin changes in chronic venous disease (1/2)
description:
Lower legs of a male patient with chronic venous disease

Areas of shiny purpura and yellowish-brown skin pigmentation are visible on the distal lower legs and on the dorsum of the feet. There are white, coin-sized atrophic plaques (atrophie blanche) medially above the level of the ankle.

title: Cardiotocogram (CTG) showing late decelerations
description:
The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). These are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.

title: Pulmonary nodules in simple silicosis
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of exposure to silica dust

Numerous bilateral small nodular opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) < 10 mm diameter are seen in all lobes but show an upper zonal predominant distribution.

Nodules in simple (uncomplicated) silicosis can be diffusely distributed; however, they often predominate in the upper zones of the lungs, particularly in the superior and posterior portions of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

title: Measles rash
description:
Multiple maculopapular blanching and partially confluent patches are disseminated over the head, neck, and back of this young patient.

These findings are consistent with a desquamating rash, which can occur after fading of the first erythematous exanthema, caused by an infection with the measles virus.

title: Councilman body
description:
Photomicrograph of a hepatic tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

There is heavy necroinflammatory activity in this hepatic lobule. The hepatocytes show reactive changes, including prominent swelling (exemplary green outline). Several apoptotic hepatocytes (also known as “acidophilic bodies” or “Councilman bodies;” examples indicated by yellow outlines) are visible.

These findings are typical of inflammatory changes consistent with an acute viral hepatitis (in this case hepatitis B exacerbated by hepatitis E coinfection).

title: Cardiomegaly in Ebstein anomaly
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a neonate with Ebstein anomaly

The cardiac silhouette is markedly enlarged. Prominent convexity of the right heart border (green line) is the result of caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle and tricuspid regurgitation. The central pulmonary arteries (green arrowheads) and aortic knob (red arrowhead) are diminutive in appearance. An endotracheal tube is present, along with an umbilical venous catheter and nasogastric tube.

Radiographic findings in Ebstein anomaly may vary with the severity of the condition.

title: Herpes simplex keratitis
description:
Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

title: DRESS syndrome
description:
Erythematous, maculopapular lesions can be seen in a homogeneous distribution across this child's arm and upper chest (morbilliform rash).

In DRESS (Drug Rash/Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms) syndrome, this rash usually occurs after 2–8 weeks of drug treatment.

title: Cavitary lung lesion
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.

title: Acute acalculous cholecystitis
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with right upper quadrant pain and elevated WBC count

Inflammatory fatty stranding (yellow overlay) surrounds an enhanced thickened gallbladder wall, which is consistent with cholecystitis. Inflammation also involves the adjacent duodenum (blue hatched overlay) and hepatic flexure. The liver shows heterogeneous enhancement with reactive hyperemia (examples indicated by red overlay) adjacent to the gallbladder. The gallbladder is not dilated, and no calculi are seen. There is no intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation.

Additional CT findings include free peritoneal fluid (blue overlay), colonic diverticula (examples indicated by green arrowheads), small hypodense liver lesions, fat-containing umbilical (green arrow) and left inguinal (white arrow) hernias, and bilateral atelectasis or scarring (examples indicated by red overlay) in the lower lungs.

title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)

A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

title: Mechanism of action of viral vector-based COVID-19 vaccines
description:
The vector-based COVID-19 vaccines are based on various recombinant adenoviruses (e.g., the chimpanzee adenovirus in AZD1222 by AstraZeneca, or the human adenovirus type 26 in Ad26.COV2.S by Janssen).

The recombinant DNA of the vector virus codes for the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is synthesized by the host cell. The spike protein is then either processed and presented via MHC-I molecules or exocytosed. Exocytosed spike proteins are taken up by phagocytes (esp. dendritic cells in muscle) and presented via MHC-II molecules. Presentation of the spike protein fragments via MHC-I and MHC-II leads to the development of a specific immune response against the spike protein.

title: Alopecia in secondary syphilis
description:
Various irregular, partly well-circumscribed patches of nonscarring hair loss are distributed over the patient`s scalp.

Form and distribution are consistent with the moth-eaten pattern resulting from inflammatory responses in the hair follicles that is characteristically seen in secondary syphilis.

title: Telogen effluvium
description:
Head of a patient 5 months after bariatric surgery

The frontal (a) and the left side (b) of the scalp show a diffuse, nonscarring loss of hair. This appearance is caused by premature shedding of hair follicles in telogen phase (resting phase).

Telogen effluvium can be caused, for example, by stress such as a surgery or severe febrile illness.

title: Left upper lobe pneumonia 2/2
description:
X-ray chest (lateral view)

Marked opacification of the left upper lobe (UL) is accompanied by volume loss; the major fissure (red line) is located anterior to its normal position (indicated by dashed line) and the left lower lobe (LL) is hyperinflated.

title: Hepatic candidiasis (disseminated candidiasis) in PAS stain
description: Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

title: Follicular thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

A partly encapsulated (capsule marked by hatched blue overlay) thyroid lesion comprised of follicles of varying size and shape (blue overlay) can be seen. Focally, this lesion displays a capsular invasion (yellow overlay), which is diagnostic of follicular thyroid carcinoma.

title: Malar rash
description:
Hyperpigmented areas measuring approx. 3–4 cm are visible over the patient's cheeks with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

This appearance is suggestive of a malar rash, which is typically seen in lupus erythematosus.

title: Hemorrhagic erosion in erosive gastritis
description:
Endoscopic view of the stomach

A circular, hematin-covered erosion surrounded by a halo of fibrinous exudate is visible on the erythematous mucosa of the pyloric antrum. Several smaller erosions are also visible.

title: Horizontal tear of the medial meniscus
description:
MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

title: Colonic mucosa
description:
Photomicrograph of the colonic mucosa (PAS stain; 350x magnification)

The colonic mucosa is composed of the following layers:
– Simple columnar epithelium (visible as tall, pale-staining cells with basal basophilic nuclei)
– Numerous straight glands, known as crypts of Lieberkuhn (white overlay), which are predominantly lined by goblet cells (stained deep pink)
– Lamina propria (red overlay) located between the crypts of Lieberkuhn
– Muscularis mucosa (between green arrows)

Part of the submucosa (green overlay) containing blood vessels (example indicated by black arrow) and lymphatics is visible.

title: Trachea
description:
Photomicrograph of a tracheal biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Cell layers (from top to bottom):
– Mucosa: ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells, resting on lamina propria, which contains elastic fibers and connective tissue
– Detail: cilia (example indicated by green overlay), nuclei (examples indicated by white arrowheads), goblet cell (examples indicated by orange overlay)
– Submucosa: numerous seromucous glands (black arrow) and smooth muscle cells with lamina propria underneath
– Hyaline cartilage: chondrocytes and lacunae surrounded by an extracellular matrix (grey overlay)
Adventitia: loose areolar tissue (white band on the bottom right)

title: Respiratory epithelium with goblet cells
description:
Photomicrograph of the respiratory mucosal tissue (Azan stain; 600x magnification)

Ciliated epithelial cells are visible (white dashed line) with motile cilia projecting from the apical surface (arrowhead). The dark band under the motile cilia consists of densely arranged basal bodies (red overlay), which act as anchoring sites for cilia microtubules. Goblet cells (green overlay) are scattered throughout the epithelium and secrete mucins. The small round basal cells (example outlined in black) are responsible for cell regeneration.

title: Parenchyma of spleen
description:
Photomicrograph of a spleen tissue specimen (azan stain)

Left: The white pulp (circular areas of brighter red) and red pulp (pale red making up most of the image) of splenic parenchyma are clearly distinguishable. The white pulp is composed of the periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths (PALS; green shading overlay) and the lymph follicles of the spleen (green outline overlay). Arterioles can be seen the center of the PALS (blue overlay).
The red pulp is composed of the splenic cords (pale red tissue) and the venous sinusoids (small white areas within pale red tissue; highlighted at left edge of image with black overlay). Trabecular veins can be seen at the center of the image (blue overlay and black arrowheads).

Right: high magnification of an arteriole with surrounding PALS (green shading overlay). The lumen of the vessel (black arrow) contains the endothelial cell nuclei (red overlay). The other elements of the vessel wall are the media (red overlay) and the connective tissue of the adventitia (blue overlay).

title: Fallopian tube
description:
Photomicrograph of a section of the fallopian tube (H&E stain, approx. 650x magnification)

The fallopian tube has a single-layered epithelium consisting of two cell types. Ciliated cells appear wide and light (red overlay), they move the ovum away from the ovary and towards the uterus. Peg cells appear darker and narrower (white outline), they secrete nutrients for the ovum.

title: Geographic distribution of Chagas disease (prevalence)
description: Chagas disease is an infectious disease that affects more than 8 million individuals worldwide. The highest prevalence is in Central and South America. The vast majority of patients with Chagas disease in the United States are immigrants from Central and South America (> 300,000 infected individuals). In the US, vector-borne transmission of the disease is very rare; transplacental transmission or transmission via blood transfusion is more common.

title: Tinea pedis
description:
Pronounced, well-demarcated erythema with scaling is visible between the third and fourth toes.

This appearance is typical of tinea pedis, which typically manifests with severe pruritus.

title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
description:
MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

title: Keratoacanthoma
description:
Upper body of an older female patient

A 1x1-cm round, erythematous nodule with a central crater is visible on the anterior chest wall. Keratoacanthomas arise from hair follicles or squamous cells of the skin. The main feature differentiating a keratoacanthoma from a squamous cell carcinoma is its rapid growth (keratoacanthomas tend to develop within a few weeks).

title: Structure of skeletal muscle fibers
description: Skeletal muscle cells are elongated, multinucleated cells filled with myofibrils. There are numerous mitochondria located between the cells, which ensure a supply of energy for contraction. Myofibrils are surrounded by the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), which include the longitudinal tubules (L-tubules) and terminal cisterna that form a cufflike structure around the myofibrils. T-tubules, which are invaginations of the sarcolemma, are located between the terminal cisternae and allow electrical impulses to travel to the SR. Two terminal cisternae and one T-tubule form a triad, which is located at the transition between the I-band and the A-band.

title: Lymphadenopathy
description: A swollen superficial cervical lymph node is visible below this patient's right mandible.

title: Paget disease of the breast
description:
An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

title: Hepatic hemangioma
description:
Ultrasound liver (transverse plane)

A homogeneous hyperechoic lesion (green overlay) with a well-defined margin and no hypoechoic halo can be seen. There is slight posterior acoustic enhancement (white area). This appearance is characteristic of a hemangioma.

Most hepatic hemangiomas are hyperechoic. However, they can appear hypoechoic, particularly when on a background of hyperechoic hepatic steatosis. If surrounded by a hypoechoic halo, a hyperechoic hepatic lesion must be considered suspicious for malignancy.

PV: hepatic portal vein

title: Uroflowmetry
description: Various uroflowmetry curve patterns: A normal uroflowmetry curve is bell-shaped with a maximal flow (Qmax) between 15 and 50 mL/s (green curve). Elastic resistance, such as in benign prostatic hypertrophy, also results in a bell-shaped curve, but it more flattened (yellow). Constant resistance, such as in urethral stricture, leads to a flattened curve with a plateau (pink). In detrusor sphincter dyssynergia, the curve is irregular and wavy. A pathological finding is usually accompanied by a longer voiding time.

title: Pancreatic pseudocyst
description:
Ultrasound abdomen of a patient with a history of pancreatitis

Targeted image shows a rounded, predominantly anechoic lesion (green overlay) with a few internal echoes and posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay). Adjacent pancreas (P) tissue is visible.

P: pancreas

title: Asbestosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a sputum sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

A yellow-brown asbestos body is visible (green overlay). It is coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material and has a characteristic dumbbell shape (illustration).

title: Diabetic nephropathy
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mobitz type II second-degree atrioventricular block and bifascicular block
description:
15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.

title: Ocular toxoplasmosis
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

The image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

title: ECG features of hypokalemia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 77/min
– Normal cardiac axis
– Prolonged PR interval (~220 ms)
– ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6 (example indicated by red overlay in V2 zoom box)
– T-wave flattening in the limb leads
– Prominent U waves in the precordial leads, with fusion of the T and U waves (examples indicated by purple and green overlays respectively). The P waves in these leads (example indicated by blue overlay) are also mostly buried in the U waves.

These findings are characteristic of severe hypokalemia.

title: Colorectal adenocarcinoma (pT3)
description:
Photomicrograph of colonic tissue (H&E stain)

Colonic glands, which should only be present in the mucosal layer, are visible in all the layers of the colonic wall, including the outermost serosal layer (pT3). The glands are lined by tall columnar epithelial cells with basally oriented nuclei. The lumen of these glands contains necrotic debris. Goblet cells (which would appear as unstained cells between the lining of epithelial cells) are absent. The fibrous tissue surrounding the tumor cells indicates desmoplasia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mature teratoma of the ovary
description:
Photomicrograph of ovary tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

On the left is an area of dark-pink-stained bone matrix with embedded osteocytes and osteoblasts in the periphery of the aggregation. Various purple-stained hair follicles can be seen from the center to the bottom of the image.

These findings are consistent with a mature teratoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Transesophageal echocardiography of aortic dissection
description:
Echocardiography (transesophageal; transverse view)

The descending thoracic aorta shows a crescentic false lumen and rounded true lumen.

title: Choledocholithiasis
description:
Ultrasound right upper quadrant (common bile duct; transverse oblique plane)

A rounded echogenic calculus (red overlay) in the common bile duct produces posterior acoustic shadowing (green overlay). The duct is dilated (1.1 cm) proximal to the calculus.

L: liver

title: Intracranial toxoplasmosis
description:
A: CT head (with contrast, axial plane); B: MRI head (with contrast, T1-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with AIDS

CT shows a ring-enhancing lesion (arrow) in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The two smaller cerebral lesions seen on MRI (arrows) contain eccentric enhancing nodules.

This appearance has been termed the “eccentric (or asymmetric) target sign” and is considered characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

title: ECG in hypocalcemia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s) of a patient with hypocalcemia (total serum calcium 5.3 mg/dL)

– Sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼ 94/min
– Normal cardiac axis (R > S in I and aVF)
– Normal narrow QRS complexes
– QT prolongation (example indicated by green overlay; QTc ∼ 600 ms) due to a prolonged ST segment. This is the key ECG finding in hypocalcemia.
– Tall, peaked T waves (examples indicated by red overlay). This is not an expected finding in hypocalcemia and should prompt evaluation for a coexisting abnormality, e.g., hyperkalemia.

title: Sigmoid diverticulitis
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with IV contrast; portal venous phase; axial and coronal planes) of an adult female patient with a history of lower abdominal pain and elevated inflammatory laboratory values

Numerous diverticula (examples indicated by red arrowheads) are present throughout the colon. Fatty and fascial inflammatory stranding (red overlay) are seen around one diverticulum (black arrowhead) and the wall of the sigmoid colon is thickened (green overlay) in this region. There is a small amount of adjacent free fluid (blue overlay in axial plane). Inflammatory changes are seen both inferior and superior to the thickened sigmoid segment.

The uterus is surgically absent. A small splenule (yellow overlay) is seen adjacent to the pancreatic tail.

title: Radiation-induced angiosarcoma of the breast
description:
Right breast of a 56-year-old female patient after receiving radiotherapy for ductal carcinoma in situ

A purple macule measuring approximately 7 × 5 cm and resembling a hematoma is visible on the previously irradiated lower right quadrant of the right breast. Parts of the macule appear darker and indurated.

This type of cutaneous lesion combined with the patient's medical history suggest an angiosarcoma of the breast, which can occur secondary to radiation therapy. Since this is a rare condition, the clinical features seen here are easily mistaken for benign angiomas, small hematomas, or atypical telangiectasia. Histopathological investigation is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Target sign in intussusception
description:
Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)

Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

title: Mechanism of action of mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccines
description:
The mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccines contain mRNA coding for the spike protein of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. To increase stability and enhance uptake into cells, the mRNA strands are encapsulated in lipid nanoparticles.

Within the cell, the mRNA causes transient, local expression of the spike protein, which is then either processed and presented via MHC-I molecules or exocytosed. Exocytosed spike proteins are taken up by phagocytes (especially dendritic cells in the muscle) and presented via MHC-II molecules. Presentation of the spike protein fragments via MHC-I and MHC-II leads to the development of a specific immune response against the spike protein.

title: Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a laryngeal tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

Sheet-like arrangement of the tumor cells can be seen (green overlay). The increased number of lymphocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay in zoom box) and desmoplasia in the surrounding stroma suggest inflammation.

title: Fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis with mosaic attenuation
description:
CT chest (inspiratory phase; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP)

An irregular reticular pattern of fibrosis predominates in the subpleural regions of the mid zones of the lungs. A small amount of honeycombing (example indicated by red overlay) is seen. There is a heterogeneous pattern of lung attenuation (mosaic attenuation), with areas of low attenuation (examples indicated by green overlays) in some regions with no fibrosis; expiratory phase imaging could help assess whether or not such areas represent air trapping.

Fibrotic HP has a variable appearance on CT. A pattern typical of fibrotic HP shows a random axial distribution of coarse reticulation and small airway disease with minimal honeycombing and no zonal predominance. Subpleural fibrosis can be compatible with HP, as can upper zonal, lower zonal, or central predominant distributions.

title: Blastomyces dermatitidis (yeast form)
description:
Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

title: Crohn disease
description:
Photomicrograph of a colon biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Infiltrating neutrophils (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the crypts in the upper part of the image. A noncaseating granuloma (green overlay) is visible in the lower part of the image.

These features indicate transmural inflammation, which is a characteristic finding of Crohn disease.

title: Raynaud phenomenon
description: White discoloration of the 4th digit of the left hand distal to the proximal interphalangeal joint (ischemic phase). The other fingers are not affected.

title: Congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spot)
description: An approx. 5 cm, blue-gray macule with irregular borders is visible on the back. The macule has no evidence of hypertrichosis.

title: Liver abscess
description:
Ultrasound liver (oblique plane)

A hypoechoic irregularly shaped lesion (white area) is visible in the right hepatic lobe (white dashed outline). Real-time imaging (not shown) would be able to confirm movement of the small central hyperechoic foci (green areas) to establish that they represent gas. The subtle hyperechoic area around the abscess likely indicates inflammatory infiltration.

title: Intraoral Kaposi sarcoma of the palate
description:
Photographs of the oral cavity

Image 1 shows a single purple nodule on the palate.
Image 2 shows several purple papules on the palate.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma.

title: Psoriatic arthritis of the right hand
description: Erythematous swelling on the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fifth digit and on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. Nail involvement (nail dystrophy with an oil drop sign and pitted nails) is also evident.

title: Polyarteritis nodosa
description:
Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

title: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
description:
Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

title: Nodular melanoma
description:
Upper back

A nodular lesion (diameter approx. 4 cm) with central ulceration is visible. The border appears reddened and markedly raised.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nodular melanoma.

title: Periportal zone and portal triad of liver
description:
Photomicrograph of liver tissue (H&E stain; approx. 300x)

The arrows are located within a hepatic lobule: Arrow 1 points to the central vein (which is not clearly identifiable in this image). Arrow 2 points to the portal triad (comprised of a branch of the portal vein, a branch of the proper hepatic artery, and an interlobular bile duct).

Arrow 1 indicates the direction of blood flow, whereas arrow 2 indicates the direction of bile flow.

title: Audiogram in Meniere disease
description:
Audiograms of a patient with Meniere disease in the left ear

Left audiogram (at first presentation): normal hearing in both ears

Right audiogram (2 years later): sensorineural hearing loss to low and midfrequency signals in the left ear; normal hearing in the right ear

Asymmetric fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is a characteristic feature of Meniere disease.

Circle: hearing threshold of the right ear; Square: hearing threshold of the left ear

title: Heme degradation
description:
Heme degradation occurs in macrophages, which remove erythrocytes from blood circulation. Oxygenated heme (red) is reduced to biliverdin, which is then reduced to bilirubin (yellow) by the biliverdin reductase. Bilirubin is finally excreted through the gall after conjugation with glucuronic acid.

The color changes of hematomas from blue (deoxygenated hemoglobin in the tissue) to green and yellow are also ascribed to these transformational steps.

title: Allergic conjunctivitis
description:
Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

title: Urticaria
description:
Anterior upper body of a man presenting with a pruritic rash after consuming peanuts

Multiple well-defined, raised, erythematous plaques of varying sizes are visible on the upper left abdomen and inner arm. The largest lesion on the trunk shows central clearing.

This is the typical appearance of urticaria (hives).

title: Diffuse nodular pleural thickening
description:
CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Nodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).

The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.

AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

title: Colon cancer
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon

An exophytic, ulcerated mass with raised edges covers more than half of the colon's circumference (green overlay). The surface is amorphous and shows minor spontaneous hemorrhage.

These features are highly suggestive of adenocarcinoma. However, histopathology is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
description:
Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

title: Schistocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Fragmented erythrocytes, which are convex on one side (examples indicated by blue lines) and concave on the other (examples indicated by yellow lines), are visible among the normal erythrocytes. These fragmented erythrocytes are referred to as schistocytes.

Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in patients with microangiopathic hemolytic anemias and those with mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., from artificial heart valves).

title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
description:
CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of trauma

A large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

title: Hyaline arteriolosclerosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a renal tissue biopsy specimen (PAS stain, high magnification)

An abnormally thickened arteriole is seen near the center of the image. Its wall is thickened due to amorphous deposits of hyaline material (mainly leaked plasma proteins; blue overlay), resulting in luminal narrowing and, consequently, impaired perfusion.

These findings are characteristic of hyaline arteriolosclerosis.

title: Air space opacification from Pneumonia
description:
X-ray chest (AP view; semierect) of a patient with clinical presentation of pneumonia

Ill-defined air space opacification is seen in the lower right lung (arrows). Small portions of the right hemidiaphragm are obscured, which suggests that the right lower lobe is involved. Close proximity to the right heart border also raises the question of right middle lobe (medial segment) involvement. PA and lateral views could help distinguish lower and middle lobe involvement.

The radiographic findings favor aspiration as the cause of pneumonia. The lower lobe of the right lung is the most common site of aspiration pneumonia in an erect patient due to the vertical orientation of the right main bronchus and its larger caliber compared to the left main bronchus.

title: Sacral torsion
description: The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).

title: 1st and 2nd Fryette’s Laws
description:
Law I: With the spine starting in a neutral position (i.e., without flexion or extension), sidebending occurs before rotation. Sidebending and rotation then happen to the opposite sides.

Law II: With the spine starting in a nonneutral position (i.e., with flexion or extension) rotation occurs before sidebending. Sidebending and rotation then happen to the same side.

title: Riedel thyroiditis
description:
Photomicrograph of an enlarged thyroid specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Extensive fibrosis (examples indicated by blue overlay) with no intact thyroid follicles can be seen. There is a scattered lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (examples indicated by yellow overlay) within the fibrotic stroma. Additionally, lymphocytic inflammation (examples indicated by arrows) in the walls of trapped veins can be seen.

The replacement of normal thyroid tissue with fibrosis is characteristic of Riedel thyroiditis (invasive fibrous thyroiditis).

title: Metatarsus adductus
description:
Left: feet of a neonate; Right: x-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view) of the same patient

Bilateral forefoot adduction is seen on the photograph. The radiograph shows medial deviation of each of the five metatarsals at the tarsometatarsal joints.

title: Overview of structural formula of proteinogenic amino acids
description: There are 20 proteinogenic amino acids, which can be classified according to the physical properties of their side chains (polarity, charge). The amino acids with aromatic side chains appear in red here, while the branched-chain amino acids are in blue. Polar, uncharged amino acids include the three amino acids with a hydroxyl group on their side chain, serine, threonine, and tyrosine, which often undergo post-translational modification (phosphorylation), as well as the two derivates of positively charged amino acids aspartate and glutamate, asparagine and glutamine, both of which have a carboxamide group on their side chain.

title: Psoriasis
description:
Multiple round, sharply demarcated, scaly, erythematous plaques are visible on the arms and trunk.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis, a subtype of psoriasis.

title: Pautrier microabscesses
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin tissue sample (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

The epidermis contains numerous atypical T-cells. Some of these are scattered around the lower third of the epidermis, a phenomenon called epidermotropism (examples highlighted by green overlay), while others form aggregates, called Pautrier microabscesses (examples highlighted by blue overlay).

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of Mycosis fungoides, a cutaneous T-cell-lymphoma.

title: Neonatal lupus syndrome
description:
Face of a newborn with erythematous rash

Multiple ring-shaped erythematous patches can be seen around the lips, eyelids, and on the forehead. Neither nose or cheeks are affected by the rash.

These findings are typical of neonatal lupus syndrome.

title: Full-thickness rectal prolapse
description: All layers of the rectal wall protrude through the anus (∼ 10 cm in this patient).

title: Thymic sail sign
description:
X-ray chest (AP view) of an infant

A homogeneous soft tissue opacity representing normal thymic tissue extends laterally from the right side of the superior mediastinum into the right upper hemithorax. Its lateral border is convex while its inferior border is straight (green overlay) producing a sail-like appearance (illustration) that has been termed the thymic sail sign.

title: Achalasia
description:
Barium swallow

Smooth funnel-shaped tapering (green overlay) in the region of the lower esophageal sphincter is accompanied by a widening (double-headed arrow) of the prestenotic distal esophagus (red overlay).

The appearance of the esophagus in achalasia is referred to as “bird-beak sign” (illustration). If the contour of the narrowed region is irregular and/or involves more than just the distal esophagus, the alternative diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma must be considered.

title: Peripheral opacity (Hampton hump) from pulmonary embolism
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

title: Cutaneous angiosarcoma
description:
Scalp of a patient with nonhealing ulcer

An ulcerated nodule on erythematous base and surrounding crusts is visible on this patient's scalp.

These findings combined with a skin biopsy revealed cutaneous angiosarcoma, a rare but very aggressive vascular malignancy.

title: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)
description:
Portal hypertension (i.e., elevated portal venous pressure), can lead to the backflow of venous blood into portosystemic anastomoses (gastrointestinal varices) through the branches of the portal vein. Increased blood flow in esophageal varices can cause potentially life-threatening variceal hemorrhages.

In TIPS, a metallic stent is inserted through the jugular vein to connect a hepatic vein radicle with an intrahepatic branch of the portal vein. TIPS diverts the drainage of blood from the portal to the systemic circulation, bypassing the liver, thus lowering portal pressure and reducing the risk of variceal bleeding. TIPS increases the level of ammonia in the systemic circulation because blood bypasses the liver, increasing the risk of hepatic encephalopathy.

title: Tinea corporis
description:
An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.

title: Structure of a sarcomere
description: A sarcomere is composed of the myofilaments myosin (red) and actin (blue). Based on the way in which the filaments intertwine, the sarcomere can be divided into different sections. The anchorage zones of the filaments are termed M lines (for myosin) and Z lines (for actin). The zone containing only actin filaments is termed the I band. The region containing only myosin filaments is termed the H zone. The A band contains the entire length of the myosin filament. A sarcomere is the region between two Z lines, which each sarcomere comprised of ½ I - A - ½ I. The sarcomere is stabilized by several structural proteins. Titin (green) stabilizes the myosin heads between actin filaments. α-Actinin binds the actin filaments of two sarcomeres in the Z lines. The sarcomere is the smallest functional unit of the myofilament in striated muscle. Several aligned sarcomeres are called a myofibril and form the building blocks and functional unit of muscle cells (muscle fiber).

title: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
description: Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.

title: Steroid acne
description: Multiple pustules and erythematous papules are visible on the back of a young woman who had received high-dose methylprednisolone therapy for one week.

title: Larynx (sections)
description: The larynx is divided into three sections: the supraglottic space, laryngeal ventricle, and subglottic space.

title: Circle of Willis
description: The circle of Willis is depicted in light red with the main arteries of the brain in dark red.

title: Chalazion
description:
Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelid

A localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.

This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

title: Internal hordeolum
description:
Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

title: Pathophysiology of hemochromatosis
description:
Left: Iron homeostasis is regulated by the HFE gene. HFE regulates levels of hepcidin, a protein that reduces the transport of iron from the cells to the bloodstream via the ferroportin transport protein.

Right: Hemochromatosis results from the mutation of the HFE gene → reduced hepcidin production → unregulated ferroportin activity → iron accumulation throughout the body → end-organ damage

title: Cardiotocogram (CTG) with normal findings
description:
The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 135 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
There are three FHR accelerations (green arrow overlay), which coincide with periods of increased fetal movement.

title: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate ∼ 160/min
– Irregularly irregular rhythm with wide variation in RR intervals (overlay) and variable PP, PR, and QT intervals
– ≥ P wave morphologies in the same lead (marked in rhythm strip II: normal, inverted, biphasic)
– Isoelectric baseline between P waves
– Narrow QRS complexes with similar morphology throughout

An irregularly irregular tachycardia with an isoelectric baseline and ≥ 3 distinct P wave morphologies in a single lead is consistent with multifocal atrial tachycardia.

title: Mechanism of action: glaucoma medication
description:
PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrix

β-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

α2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine)
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

Cholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor production

Rho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

title: Overview of PSC, PBC, and autoimmune hepatitis
description: Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

title: Neonatal cephalic pustulosis
description:
Papulopustular lesions are distributed across the left cheek, temple, retroauricular area, and parts of the scalp and forehead.

The absence of comedones differentiates this condition from one of infantile acne.

title: Cutaneous leishmaniasis
description:
A well-demarcated, open, ulcerated wound with overlying purulent exudate is visible on the lateral aspect of the right ankle.

This is the characteristic appearance of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

title: Plaque psoriasis
description:
Multiple sharply demarcated confluent plaques covered with hard, coarse, silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

This is the characteristic appearance of plaque psoriasis.

title: Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast
description:
Photomicrograph of a surgical sample of breast tissue (H&E stain, low magnification)

An area of sclerosis (light purple) is visible in the center of the invasive ductal carcinoma (dark purple).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Small cell lung carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
description:
Photomicrograph of pulmonary tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

An abundance of leukocytes is visible in the center of the image. The immune cells appear to form circular patterns enclosing extracellular matrix. Necrotic pulmonary tissue is visible on the right border.

These findings are consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Lymphedema following hysterectomy
description: There is generalized swelling of the right lower leg, foot, and toes. Pitting is visible on the right instep, suggesting early-stage disease (lymphedema is characteristically nonpitting in later stages).

title: Peptide bond formation
description: To form a peptide bond, a carboxyl group (COOH) of an amino acid (AA) reacts with the amino group (NH2) of another AA. An H2O molecule is released in the process.

title: Innominate inflare and outflare dysfunction
description: ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

title: Modified barium swallow
description:
Videofluoroscopy of the neck (lateral view)

The video shows the oral preparatory and propulsive stages followed by the pharyngeal and esophageal stages. No abnormalities are noted.

title: Smudge cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

The smear shows an increase in lymphocytic cells with minimal cytoplasm and dark round nuclei (examples indicated by yellow overlay). Some of those cells are fragmented (smudge cells; also referred to as “Gumprecht shadows;” blue arrowheads).

Smudge cells are artificially ruptured neoplastic lymphocytes and are a characteristic, but nonspecific, feature of CLL.

title: Acute anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R > S in I, S > R in aVF)
– There are both ventricular (green overlay) and supraventricular (purple overlay) extrasystoles.
– ST elevation in all precordial leads (V1–V6; example indicated by blue overlay), as well as I, aVL, and -aVR
– Reciprocal ST depression in III (red overlay), and nonsignificantly also in aVF
– Pathological Q waves in V1–V4 (yellow overlay)

Note that the limb leads of this ECG are arranged differently than usual: in this 'Cabrera' format the limb leads are shown in anatomically contiguous order, as they appear on the Cabrera circle (beginning with aVL and proceeding clockwise). To allow this the format also uses negative aVR (-aVR), which is obtained by simply inverting the polarity of the usual positive aVR. ST elevation in -aVR is therefore equivalent to ST depression in aVR.

title: Large cell carcinoma of the lung
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200× magnification; scale bar: 100 μm; 400× magnification; scale bar: 50 μm)

A tumor composed of multiple, round cell nests (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen. The tumor cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) have abundant pale eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. There is no evidence of keratinization or glandular or neuroendocrine differentiation.

Immunohistochemical stains (negative for TTF-1, p63, and neuroendocrine markers, and positive for cytokeratins) confirm the diagnosis.

title: X-linked recessive inheritance
description:
In X-linked recessive inheritance, two copies of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the female offspring and only one should be passed to the male offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype (since men are hemizygous for X-linked genes). Affected individuals are present not in each generation. Males are affected much more than females who are usually carriers having one copy of the allele. Females can only be affected if they carry two alleles; in such cases, all their sons will be affected, and all their daughters will be carriers. Affected males transmit the allele to all their daughters who thus become carriers, but to none to their sons who receive Y-chromosome.

The overlay indicates the carriers.

title: Basal cell carcinoma
description: A well-defined nodule with telangiectasia and central ulceration are visible on the alar sidewall.

title: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency fact sheet
description:
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

title: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma (2/3)
description:
Photomicrograph of a uterine tissue specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

Irregular glands (examples indicated by yellow overlay) are seen scattered throughout the smooth muscle tissue of the myometrium (blue arrowheads), indicating infiltrative growth. Fusion of glands (blue overlay), cribriform growth patterns (blue outline), and luminal necrotic material (examples indicated by black arrowheads) are also apparent.

These findings indicate uterine carcinoma. Definite diagnosis of endometrioid differentiation should be performed via immunohistochemical stains (estrogen and progesterone receptor expression, vimentin positivity, weak to negative p16).

title: Clostridium perfringens
description:
Photomicrograph of a bacterial culture (Gram stain; very high magnification; cultivated in Schaedler broth)

Multiple gram-positive, rod-shaped Clostridium perfringens bacteria are seen.

title: Caval and azygos venous system
description:
Left: ventral view of the large thoracic and abdominal vessels

Right: ventral view of the superior and inferior vena cava, iliac veins, and the most important tributaries from the internal organs

The veins of the posterior thoracic and abdominal wall are also depicted (transparent blue).

title: Ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch)
description:
Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.

Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.

Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.

title: Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy sample from a pulmonary nodule (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous specialized histiocytes (Langerhans cells; examples indicated by arrowheads) are identifiable as large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and large folded or grooved nuclei (coffee bean nuclei; zoom box). A mixed inflammatory infiltrate of eosinophils (yellow overlay), neutrophils, and lymphocytes is also visible.

The presence of Langerhans cells was confirmed by immunohistochemistry (Langerin, CD1a, and S100 positive).

title: Pancreatic head cancer
description: Tumors of the pancreatic head may obstruct the extrahepatic bile ducts and pancreatic duct. Bile duct obstruction results in Courvoisier sign (painless jaundice plus an enlarged, nontender gallbladder on palpation), pale stools, dark urine, and pruritus. Pancreatic duct obstruction results in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. The obstruction-related dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct demonstrates as the double-duct sign on radiology.

title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
description:
Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

title: Types of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)
description:
GTD is a group of diseases that originate in the placenta and typically result from abnormal fertilization of the ovum. Complete and partial moles may develop malignant traits and become invasive. Choriocarcinoma may be preceded by hydatidiform moles (50% of cases), ectopic pregnancy or miscarriages, or normal pregnancy.

Theca lutein cysts result from exaggerated stimulation of the theca interna cells of the ovarian follicles due to excessive amounts of beta-hCG.

title: Membranous nephropathy
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

title: Uric acid crystals
description:
Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

title: Dermatome map
description:
Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

title: Vaccine types
description:
This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

title: Silicosis
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspnea

There are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.

Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

title: Anterior cruciate ligament injury
description:
MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)

The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.

This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

title: Giardiasis
description:
Photomicrograph of a stool sample (bright-field microscopy; high magnification)

This sample contains multiple cysts of Giardia lamblia (indicated by green overlay), which show an ovoid shape and measure 10–15 μm in diameter.

title: Air trapping in pulmonary emphysema
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperlucent, with diaphragmatic flattening (indicated by dashed lines and arrows) and widening of the costophrenic sulci (indicated by white lines). The findings are consistent with air trapping.

An additional finding is asymmetry of the lung apices with slightly increased opacification in the left apex (red overlay) compared to the right. The chronicity cannot be determined from this single study, and the differential for chronic causes includes both scar and malignancy. A second small indeterminate opacity projects in the lower left lung (green overlay).

title: Air trapping in pulmonary emphysema
description:
X-ray chest (lateral view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperinflated with flattening of the hemidiaphragms, widening of the retrosternal space (green overlay), and increased anteroposterior diameter of the thorax (barrel chest; white bracket).

An area of opacification (red overlay) projecting over the spine above the aortic arch corresponds to an abnormality in the left apex on the PA view.

title: Tinea barbae
description:
Left lateral view of a patient's face and neck

Multiple, partially crusted erythematous plaques with well-defined margins are visible on this patients cheek and neck.

These skin lesions are suggestive of an infection with dermatophytes (most likely T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes) and diagnosis should be confirmed by microscopy and culture in order to definitively determine the type of dermatophytes.

title: Subcapsular hepatic hematomas
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient involved in a motor vehicle crash

Two biconvex hypodense hematomas (1, green overlay) are seen between the hepatic capsule and parenchyma.

2: spleen; 3: liver; 4: IVC (inferior vena cava)

title: Rule of nines
description: The entire body surface of an adult can be divided into 11 regions, each comprising approximately 9% of the total body surface area. The external genitalia accounts for the remaining 1%. The rule of nines is used to quickly estimate the total body surface area affected by burns in adults.

title: Pain localization in secondary headache
description:
Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

title: Scrofuloderma
description:
Axilla and arm of a child with HIV infection and tuberculosis

The region around the axillary lymph nodes shows two ulcerated lesions, which are firm to touch.

These findings are typical clinical features of scrofuloderma, which usually heals leaving a scar.
