title: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)
description:
Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

title: Bilateral complete oculomotor palsy
description:
Eyes and forehead of a 20-year-old female patient with tubercular meningitis

Image A shows bilateral ptosis, due here to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. To open her eyes, the patient must contract the frontalis muscle, resulting in the forehead wrinkles seen in image B. Both eyes deviate outwards (exotropia) and downwards (hypotropia) from the primary gaze position. This occurs due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are the only unaffected extraocular muscles. Mydriasis indicates involvement of the parasympathetic portion of the oculomotor nerve.

Ptosis, mydriasis, exotropia, and hypotropia are the classic signs of complete oculomotor palsy. Complete oculomotor palsy is more commonly unilateral than bilateral.

title: Gastric MALT lymphoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a gastric tissue sample (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

There is a dense infiltrate of atypical small lymphocytes between gastric glands, some of which are in the process of being destroyed.

These lymphoepithelial lesions represent a characteristic histological feature of gastric MALT Lymphoma, often associated with H. pylori infection.

title: Histoplasma capsulatum in liver tissue
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).

title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swelling

The ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.

Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.

LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

title: Aortic dissection (Stanford B)
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis (with IV contrast; venous phase, axial plane)

A Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) aortic dissection extends from the origin of the left subclavian artery into both iliac arteries. The great arteries arise from the true lumen (green). The celiac trunk (CT), superior mesenteric artery (SMA), and right renal artery (ARD) also arise from the true lumen. The left renal artery (ARS) and inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) arise from the false lumen. The malrotated kidneys (K) show perfusion irregularities.

Additional findings include bilateral basal atelectasis (blue overlay), pleural effusions (yellow overlay), right renal cyst, colonic and gallbladder contrast (from a previous CT), foley catheter, and postoperative changes with left periiliac and anterior abdominal wall hematomas. A right internal jugular catheter (red overlay) is well-positioned and terminates in the superior vena cava. The left brachiocephalic vein (BCV) is occluded and a left internal jugular catheter (red overlay) terminates in a small vein anterior to the aortic arch.

title: Blastomycosis
description:
Dorsal surface of a left hand

An ulcerated, slightly raised lesion with a verrucous surface is visible close to the patient's knuckle.

This type of lesion suggests a cutaneous manifestation of Blastomyces dermatitidis infection caused by hematologic dissemination. Such infections are typically asymptomatic, or they manifest as pneumonia from the inhalation of spores. Since Blastomyces dermatitidis infection is rare, it is easily misdiagnosed as squamous cell cancer.

title: Acrochordons (skin tags)
description: Multiple dark-colored pedunculated papules are visible.

title: Cardiotocogram (CTG) showing intermittent variable decelerations
description:
The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 135 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and exhibits moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).

The lower blue tracing shows maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).

The two decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). They moreover vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with < 50 % of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed intermittent variable decelerations.

title: Cardiotocogram (CTG) showing early decelerations
description:
The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 130 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
Contractions and decelerations begin and end together (red dashed line overlay), with the peaks of the contractions coinciding with the nadirs of the decelerations (red arrow overlay). The decelerations are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir. These findings are characteristic of early decelerations.

title: Cardiotocogram (CTG) showing recurrent variable decelerations
description:
The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

title: HIV-associated dementia
description:
MRI brain (a: T2-weighted; b: FLAIR; axial plane) of a 56-year-old patient with a history of HIV infection and longstanding weakness, confusion, and memory loss

The sulci and ventricles are prominent, which is consistent with generalized cerebral atrophy. The white matter is diffusely hyperintense (green overlay). There is no mass effect.

In a patient with HIV or AIDS and no other identifiable cause of neurocognitive decline, these features suggest HIV-associated dementia.

title: Longitudinal section of an incisor
description: Teeth consist of hard tissue (enamel, dentin, cementum) and pulp. Dentin makes up the main body of the tooth and is covered by enamel at the crown and cementum at the root. The periodontium (cementum, periodontal membrane, alveolar bone, gingiva) secures the tooth in the jaw.

title: Skeletal deformities in osteogenesis imperfecta
description:
Left: X-ray whole body (AP view); right: X-ray right arm (AP view) of a 3-year-old boy

Osteoporosis is accompanied by severe deformities of the appendicular (examples indicated by green overlay) and axial skeleton (examples indicated by red overlay on left image). Multiple old fractures (red arrows) are associated with callus formation and sclerosis. There is severe limb bowing and foreshortening.

The findings are consistent with osteogenesis imperfecta.

H: humerus; R: radius; U: ulna

title: Renal artery stenosis
description:
CT angiography (left renal artery; coronal plane)

There is high-grade stenosis (arrow) of the proximal left renal artery. At present, the size of the left kidney is within normal range.

A: aorta; RV: renal vein; K: kidney

title: Salter-Harris type III medial malleolar fracture
description:
X-ray left ankle (mortise view)

A lucent fracture line (green line) through the medial malleolus traverses both the epiphysis and growth plate.

This appearance is characteristic of a Salter-Harris III fracture. Growth plate involvement is often better seen on CT.

E: epiphysis; F: fibula; GP: growth plate; T: tibia

title: Cervical disk herniation
description:
MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathy

A herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.

title: Effects of ionizing radiation on the cell cycle
description:
The radiosensitivity of cells varies with cell cycle phase. The image here shows the phases in which radiation results in chromosome aberration (yellow), apoptosis (blue), or mitotic arrest (green).

Cells in the G2 and M phase demonstrate the highest radiosensitivity, whereas cells in the G1 and S phases generally show radioresistance.

title: Paronychia
description: Massive erythema and swelling of the distal phalanx with pus along the nail margin and fingertip.

title: Ventricular fibrillation
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– No discernible P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves
– Absence of the normal isoelectric baseline
– Chaotic irregular deflections representing disorganized electrical activity in the ventricles with a rate of ∼ 375/min

Diagnosis: ventricular fibrillation. Note that this rhythm results in loss of cardiac output and is fatal unless resuscitation is rapidly commenced.

title: Second-degree atrioventricular block: Mobitz I/Wenckebach
description:
ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

title: Gottron papules in dermatomyositis
description:
Scaly, erythematous papules and periungual erythema are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Both localization and appearance are typical of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

title: Opacified right paranasal sinuses
description:
CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitis

The right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
description:
Grouped papulovesicular eruptions with excoriations and surrounding erythema are visible on the lower arms and elbows (A) and knees (B).

These findings, in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

title: Superior sagittal sinus thrombosis (1/2)
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute lymphoblastic lymphoma presenting with headache and progressive decrease in consciousness

A long segment hypointense area (red hatched overlay) corresponding to a thrombus is visible within the occipital portion of the superior sagittal sinus. The remainder of the sinus shows normal contrast enhancement (green overlay). Retention of contrast within cortical veins in the frontoparietal region is accompanied by hyperintense parenchymal edema (red circle).

The findings are consistent with superior sagittal sinus thrombosis.

title: Conductive hearing loss
description:
Pure tone audiogram

The diagram shows a difference of 30dB between air and bone conduction in the right ear versus the left ear. These findings are indicative of middle or external ear pathologies, such as otitis media or tympanic membrane perforation.

title: Atrial flutter with 4:1 conduction
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate ∼ 240/min, ventricular rate ∼ 60/min (4:1 AV conduction ratio)
– Left axis deviation: R > S in I (green complex); S > R in aVF (red complex)
– P waves with a “sawtooth” appearance (flutter waves)
– Regular, narrow QRS complexes
– Prolonged PR interval (∼ 280 ms)
– Horizontal ST depression (0.1–0.2 mV) with T-wave inversion in leads I and V2–V6, suggestive of myocardial ischemia

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 4:1 conduction, probably secondary to the observed myocardial ischemia.

title: Chancre of penis (primary syphilis)
description:
Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

title: Lichen sclerosus of preputial skin
description: Irregularly shaped, slightly hard white plaque surrounded by an inflammatory halo on the preputial skin. When retracted, the foreskin appears entrapped and constricts the penile shaft; this is most likely pathologic phimosis.

title: Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus)
description:
Colorized scanning electron micrograph

S. aureus is spherical and forms grape-like clusters (the word Staphylococcus name derives from the Greek word "staphyle" = bunch of grapes). This characteristic distribution pattern arises because Staphylococci replicate randomly in all directions; the bacteria themselves are, however, immotile.

title: Influenza virus (subtype H1N1)
description:
Colorized electron micrograph of influenza viruses

The antigens on the outer coat of the influenza virus have a spiky appearance. This occurs as the result of, e.g., the combination of certain hemagglutinins and neuraminidases and can be used to distinguish between the different subtypes of influenza viruses (e.g., H1N1 or swine flu, H5N1 or avian influenza).

title: Influenza virion
description:
Colored electron micrograph of an influenza virion

The central ribonucleoproteins (purple, contains the virus genome and other proteins), matrix (brown), double lipid membrane of the virus envelope (yellow), and membrane proteins (orange) can be seen. The influenza virus strain type is characterized by the constituents of the membrane proteins (especially hemagglutinin [H] and neuraminidase [N]) (e.g., H1N1: swine flu).

title: Mature schizont (Plasmodium malariae)
description: Thin blood smear showing a mature schizont of Plasmodium malariae. A conglomerate of merozoites (red overlay) is organized around the brownish pigment in the center, which is called the rosette. Within the red cell schizont, merozoites replicate asexually every 48–72 hours, depending on the type of Plasmodium. Increased parasite burden causes the infected erythrocytes to burst. A subsequent release of proinflammatory factors results in a fever spike. Merozoites, which have been set free from the erythrocyte, enter other erythrocytes to replicate again.

title: Scabies skin lesions
description: Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

title: Reduviid bug ("kissing bug")
description:
Reduviid bug of the species Triatoma infestans (important vector of Chagas disease)

The reduviid bug usually bites individuals in their sleep and sheds infectious feces next to the bite site. The trypanosomes present in the feces can enter the body when the bitten individual scratches the bite site. Since the reduviid bug tends to bite the face, it is also called the “kissing bug.”

title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix
description:
Photomicrograph of cervical tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Cancer cells with nuclear atypia are growing within the subepithelial stroma (purple area). Tumor necrosis is present throughout the cancerous mass, seen here as an amorphous eosinophilic accumulation of cell debris. The abundance of neutrophils accompanying the invasive component is a sign of active inflammation secondary to malignant neoplasia.

This is the typical appearance of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Pulmonary sarcoidosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung resection specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple noncaseating granulomas are visible individually (example indicated by red overlay) or forming a mass (green overlay), surrounded by normal pulmonary tissue.

Noncaseating granulomas are a typical finding in pulmonary sarcoidosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Pulmonary cavitation in tuberculosis
description:
Photomicrograph of pulmonary tissue (H&E stain)

There is a circular pattern of purple-stained immune cells in the center of the image. These immune cells enclose a large collection of necrotic pulmonary tissue (stained in red). In the periphery, other smaller caseating granulomas can be seen.

The formation of caseating granulomas (also called pulmonary cavitation) is typical of pulmonary tuberculosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Otitis externa
description:
There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.

These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

title: Infantile seborrheic dermatitis (cradle cap)
description:
Photograph of the scalp of a 2-month-old

Yellow, scaling plaques on erythematous skin extend over the scalp.

This appearance in an infant is consistent with infantile seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Uterine leiomyomas
description: Laparoscopic image of an enlarged uterus with multiple, mainly subserosal fibroids on the uterine wall that are sessile or pedunculated.

title: Tinea pedis (athlete's foot)
description:
Plantar view of the left foot

There is skin peeling in the region of the forefoot with a blistered appearance. The erythematous base appears dry and scaly.

These findings are characteristic of tinea pedis.

title: Bacterial conjunctivitis
description:
Left eye

There is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.

This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

title: Howell-Jolly bodies in asplenia
description:
Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; 40x magnification)

There is an increased number of thrombocytes (solitary, small blue cells) and granulocytes (cells with a large purple nucleus). Some of the erythrocytes contain basophilic spots (examples indicated by red arrows), which are consistent with DNA-containing Howell-Jolly bodies.

Erythrocytes with Howell-Jolly bodies are physiologically broken down by the spleen. Thus, they may be seen in asplenic patients, as well as after splenic infarcts, and in hemolytic or megaloblastic anemia.

title: Extrahepatic biliary tree
description: The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 2/3
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

Bilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.

1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

title: Gynecomastia
description: Male patient with bilateral gynecomastia

title: Thymic epithelial neoplasm
description:
CT chest (with contrast; mediastinal window; axial plane)

A heterogeneous anterior mediastinal mass (green overlay) with an irregular border (example indicated by green arrowheads) contains a central rim-enhancing (red overlay) hypodense area of cystic or necrotic change (green hatched overlay).

Anterior mediastinal tumors commonly derive from the thymus gland, fat, or lymph nodes. Noninvasive thymomas are often well-defined masses with homogeneous enhancement. Invasive thymomas are more likely to be irregular or lobulated and to contain hypodense areas and calcification. The imaging characteristics of thymic carcinomas and neuroendocrine tumors can overlap with those of high-grade thymomas. Evidence of pleural or pericardial involvement, pleural effusion, or distant metastases is more suggestive of thymic carcinoma or a neuroendocrine tumor rather than thymoma.

AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 1/3
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

There is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).

Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

title: Terminal ileum in Crohn disease
description:
Endoscopic view of the terminal ileum

Erythema and small aphthous ulcerations are visible on the mucosa. The edematous surface resembles a cobblestone appearance.

These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.

title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 3/3
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

Medial temporal lobe atrophy is accompanied by widening of the subarachnoid space (green overlay) and dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (red overlay).

These morphologic changes have been observed in the setting of Alzheimer disease.

title: Bullous pemphigoid
description:
Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (severe Stevens-Johnson syndrome)
description: Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

title: EEG findings in absence seizures
description: Characteristic 3 Hz spikes and waves. The steep rise is the spike and the flat increase the wave. This complex usually occurs with a frequency of 3 per second (hence its name). This finding most commonly occurs during a seizure in absence epilepsy; it can also be seen in a seizure-free interval (interictal).

title: Preauricular keratoacanthoma
description:
An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

title: Classification of hydronephrosis
description: On the left, there is a normal kidney with no obstruction to urinary outflow. Grade I hydronephrosis involves a dilation of the renal pelvis. In grade II, renal calyces are also dilated. Grade III leads to a flattening of papillae. In grade IV, the kidney is completely atrophied.

title: Hashimoto thyroiditis (Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis)
description:
Ultrasound thyroid (right lobe; longitudinal plane; a: B-mode; b: with power Doppler)

Widely distributed hypoechoic micronodules (examples indicated by arrows) have resulted in a heterogenous echotexture. Power Doppler shows diffusely increased vascularity (red).

Ultrasound features in Hashimoto thyroiditis can vary with the phase and severity of the disease. The thyroid gland may appear enlarged and hypervascular in early-stage disease and small and hypovascular in later stages of disease. Micronodularity and a pseudonodular appearance (also known as “giraffe pattern”) are patterns that result from lymphocytic infiltration and strongly suggest diffuse Hashimoto thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis may also appear as larger focal nodules.

title: Frontotemporal dementia
description:
MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

title: Diagnostic approach to palpable breast mass
description: DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

title: Diagnostic approach to suspected arginine vasopressin disorder (diabetes insipidus)
description:
AVP: arginine vasopressin
BMP: basic metabolic panel
DI: diabetes insipidus
Na+: sodium
POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality

title: Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps
description:
CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthma

Extensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

title: Urticaria
description:
Well-circumscribed, partially confluent erythematous lesions are visible on the torso and limbs.

This is the typical presentation of urticaria (hives).

title: Heterogeneous hepatic mass
description:
Ultrasound abdomen (liver; transverse plane) of a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma

A large heterogeneous mass (green hatched overlay) in the left hepatic lobe proved to be hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC; hepatoma). HCC may be focal, multifocal, or diffuse.

HCC receives the majority of its blood supply from branches of the hepatic artery. As a result, a characteristic pattern of early arterial enhancement and early washout is often seen on CT and MRI. This enhancement pattern may similarly be seen on contrast-enhanced ultrasound examinations.

L: uninvolved liver parenchyma; PV: portal vein

title: Solitary liver lesion with halo
description:
Ultrasound liver of a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma

The surface of the liver is irregular (green line) as a result of cirrhosis. A solitary liver lesion demonstrates an isoechoic center (green hatched overlay) and hypoechoic periphery (green overlay). Such an appearance, which has been termed the “halo sign” (also “target sign” or “bull's eye sign”), may indicate a malignant liver lesion. Hepatocellular carcinoma has variable presentations on ultrasound.

title: Focal nodular hyperplasia
description:
CT abdomen (A. without contrast; B: arterial phase; C: venous phase; D: delayed phase)

A nearly isoattenuating mass (green overlay) on the unenhanced image is hyperattenuating relative to surrounding liver on the artierial phase image. It becomes less conspicuous in the portal venous phase and isoattenuating in the delayed phase. A hypoattenuating central scar (red overlay) visible on the arterial and venous phase images becomes hyperattenuating on the delayed phase image as a result of delayed contrast washout from the scar.

The above CT features are typical of focal nodular hyperplasia.

LK: left kidney; P: pancreas; RK: right kidney

title: Supporting ligaments of the uterus (dorsal view)
description:
The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.

- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

title: Heinz bodies
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (new methylene blue stain; high magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes are visible, some of which contain small, round inclusions (examples indicated by arrowheads) called Heinz bodies. Heinz bodies are composed of denatured hemoglobin and are typically associated with G6PD deficiency but are also seen in other conditions.

title: Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites
description:
Photomicrograph of a fresh stool mount (trichrome stain; very high magnification)

Three trophozoites are visible, two with phagocytosed erythrocytes that appear as dark ovoid inclusions (examples indicated by yellow overlay). The trophozoites have a single nucleus (examples indicated by blue overlay) that contains a small karyosome (examples indicated by arrowheads), surrounded by evenly distributed peripheral chromatin (examples indicated by arrows).

This appearance indicates E. histolytica, which is differentiated from the nonpathogenic E. dispar by its erythrophagocytic capacity.

title: Smooth muscle cell
description: Smooth muscles cells are spindle-shaped, have a single nucleus, and contain numerous invaginations in the sarcolemma (caveolae). Because of the irregular arrangement of myofilaments (actin and myosin) in the cell, smooth muscles cells lack sarcomeres (in contrast to striated muscle). Actin filaments are anchored by dense bodies and dense bands, which are linked together by intermediate filaments. Myosin filaments of smooth muscle have an antiparallel arrangement, with the upper and lower rows of myosin heads facing different directions. This allows strong traction to be exerted on the actin filaments (direction of tension indicated by the arrows).

title: Buerger test (Buerger sign)
description:
The Buerger test is used to evaluate peripheral arterial disease of the lower limbs.

With the patient in the supine position, elevate the lower limbs to ∼45° at the hip and evaluate for foot pallor. If no pallor occurs, ask the patient to plantarflex and dorsiflex or to rotate their feet a few times, looking for exercise-induced pallor.

Next, ask the patient to sit up with their legs hanging off the examination table and evaluate the time taken for the color to return to the feet and for the veins to fill again.

Foot pallor on elevation, or reactive hyperemia or delayed venous refilling on dependency, indicate arterial insufficiency (positive Buerger sign). A venous filling time of > 20 seconds may indicate advanced ischemia.

title: Pap smear showing low-grade dysplasia
description:
Photomicrograph of a cervical pap smear (Papanicolaou stain; high magnification)

Normal superficial squamous cells (pink cytoplasm, examples indicated by dashed outlines) and some intermediate squamous cells (example indicated by outline) are visible. An irregular clump of koilocytes (indicated by arrow) is visible with the characteristic perinuclear halos (indicated by arrowheads). The koilocytes also show slight nuclear enlargement with irregularly distributed chromatin; binucleation (yellow overlay) is also seen.

These are typical features of a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL).

title: Transurethral catheterization of the penis
description:
1. After placement of the sterile drape and retraction of the foreskin, the nondominant hand holds the penis taut and upright. The urethral meatus is cleansed with antiseptic, moving outwards in a circular motion.
2. Viscous lidocaine is injected into the urethra and allowed to take effect before continuing the procedure.
3. The lubricated tip of the catheter is inserted into the urethra and passed into the bladder.
4. After the entire length of the catheter has been inserted, the recommended volume of water or air is injected into the balloon port of the catheter.
5. The catheter is withdrawn slowly until resistance is met and connected to the collection bag.

title: Skin manifestations in scarlet fever
description: The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.

title: Double aortic arch
description:
Ventral view of mediastinal structures

There is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

title: Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

title: Urinary bladder (male)
description:
Left: ventral view of the bladder, urethra, prostate, and penis (coronal section)
Right: dorsal view of the bladder, seminal vesicles, terminal ureters, and prostate
The coronal section of the seminal vesicle and vas deferens is depicted on the right.

title: Owl-eye appearance in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification) from a patient with AIDS and an active CMV infection

The large cell visible near the center of the image is an enlarged pneumocyte, containing a basophilic intranuclear inclusion body (yellow overlay) surrounded by a bright halo (blue overlay). Smaller granular inclusion bodies can be seen in the cytoplasm (arrowheads).

The owl's eye appearance of the intranuclear inclusion body indicates a CMV infection.

title: Ascending sensory tracts of the spinal cord
description:
Left image: the dorsal column (gracile fasciculus and cuneate fasciculus) carries information of fine touch, vibration, pressure, and proprioception (gracile fasciculus: primarily from the lower half of the body; cuneate fasciculus: primarily from the upper half of the body).

Right side: the anterolateral column (anterior spinothalamic tract and lateral spinothalamic tract) carries information of crude touch, pressure, pain, and temperature.
1) Anterior spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Axons from the first neuron split and ascend or descend several segments (a). Having reached another segment, they synapse to the second neuron in the posterior horn of the spinal cord, and the axons decussate to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (b). Further ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract (c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).
2) Lateral spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Synapse to the 2nd neuron in the gray matter on the same segment. The axon of the 2nd neuron decussates to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (a). Ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract (b, c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).

Both pathways end in the somatosensory cortex and transmit sensory information.

title: Metatarsal stress fractures
description: Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

title: Tet spell in tetralogy of Fallot
description:
Tet spells (hypercyanotic spells) are caused by a sudden decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) or increase in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), leading to intermittent worsening of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and increased right-to-left shunting. The resulting decrease in blood flow to the pulmonary circulation results in decreased blood oxygenation.

Knee-to-chest positioning or, in older children, squatting relieve symptoms by increasing SVR, which in turn reduces right-to-left-shunting and improves blood flow to the lungs.

title: Koilonychia (spoon nails)
description:
Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

title: Audiogram in presbycusis
description: Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conduction: In presbycusis, patients struggle to hear the higher frequencies in both air and bone conduction.

title: Audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss
description:
Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conduction

In noise-induced hearing loss, hearing is most impaired at frequencies of 4000 Hz in both bone and air conduction.

title: Hydrostatic pulmonary edema
description:
X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

title: CMV retinitis
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

Multiple retinal hemorrhages (red blotches, white outlines) and areas of retinal necrosis (fluffy white patches, black outlines) are visible in the central retina. In addition, the optic nerve (blue circle) is unsharply demarcated.

This combination of red hemorrhages and white retinal necrosis, referred to as the “pizza pie” (illustration) or “cottage cheese with ketchup” appearance, is characteristic of CMV retinitis, which most commonly affects immunocompromised individuals.

title: Iliopsoas abscess
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane)

A large, hypodense rim-enhancing lesion (green overlay) involving the right iliopsoas muscle contains a small amount of gas (example indicated by arrowhead). The appearance is characteristic of an abscess.

F: fluid-filled bowel loops; G: gas-filled bowel loops; P: psoas muscle; I: iliacus muscle

title: Hygienic hand rub (antiseptic hand rub)
description:
Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm

title: Pericardial thickening and calcification
description:
X-ray chest (lateral view) of a patient with pericardial constriction

Pericardial thickening (green overlay) with calcification (indicated by arrow) is seen. Pleural effusions (yellow overlay) obscure the costophrenic angles.

An additional finding in this patient is opacification of the lower lungs by pulmonary edema (blue overlay). Fissural thickening (indicated by red lines) is visible.

title: Lacerated spleen
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crash

The spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.

Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).

Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

title: Posture-dependent pain in lumbar spinal stenosis (neuropathic claudication)
description: Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

title: Erythrocyte morphologies in sickle-cell disease
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Numerous crescent-shaped erythrocytes, known as “sickle cells,” can be seen (examples indicated by blue overlay; two normal erythrocytes are indicated by arrowheads for comparison). Erythrocytes with a red center and a white contouring ring, known as “target cells” (yellow overlay; cf. illustration) are visible at the bottom of the image.

Sickle cells are pathognomonic of sickle-cell disease. Target cells can be found in sickle-cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

title: Ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis
description:
Echocardiography transthoracic (apical view; A: without needle; B and C: with needle)

Anechoic pericardial effusion (PE) was identified. Needle position (arrows) was continuously monitored while the pericardial space was entered to drain the effusion.

Arrowheads: myocardium

title: Reed-Sternberg cell
description:
Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

title: Osteosarcoma
description:
X-ray of the right femorotibial joint (AP view) of a 17-year-old male patient

A sclerotic outgrowth of the bone (green overlay) surrounded by osteolytic destruction of medullary and cortical bone (red overlay) is visible on the medial metaphysis of the femur.

The periosteum over the lesion is noncontinuous (dashed line), indicating rapid growth of the bone lesion.

This appearance of a mixed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesion in the metaphyses of long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma.

title: Watershed areas in colon ischemia
description:
The watershed areas of the colon are the splenic flexure (Griffiths point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck point).

The splenic flexure is supplied by the ascending branch of the left colic artery (from the inferior mesenteric artery) and the marginal artery of Drummond (an anastomosis between terminal branches of the superior and the inferior mesenteric arteries).

The rectosigmoid junction is supplied by an anastomosis between the last sigmoid branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and the terminal branches of the superior rectal artery (also from the inferior mesenteric artery).

title: Chronic hepatitis B
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Most of the hepatocytes have a pale, homogeneous cytoplasm (ground glass hepatocytes; examples marked by blue overlay).

Ground glass hepatocytes are often found in chronic hepatitis B infection.

title: Toxic megacolon (Toxic colitis with megacolon)
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a patient with ulcerative colitis

The transverse and the descending colon (green outline) are featureless, with a loss of haustral markings (cf. illustration). The transverse colon is dilated to a diameter > 6 cm and some pseudopolyps (examples indicated by red overlay) are visible.

The radiographic findings are characteristic of toxic megacolon.

title: Widened mediastinum secondary to traumatic thoracic aortic injury
description:
X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with a recent history of a motor vehicle crash

A lobulated convexity projects along the left superior mediastinum (green overlay and arrows) in the region of the aortic knob.

The differential for the mediastinal widening includes a range of mediastinal soft tissue masses; however, traumatic mediastinal injury (particularly involving the thoracic aorta) is the primary concern in view of the trauma setting. CT angiography is the appropriate next imaging study in a hemodynamically stable patient.

Green dashed line: normal margin of the aorta

title: SARS-CoV-2 entry mechanism: membrane fusion
description:
Detailed illustration of SARS-CoV-2 cell entry via membrane fusion.

1. The viral spike protein is a homotrimer. Each trimer consists of two different subunits (S1 and S2). As shown in the left zoom box, S1 is located at the top and S2 at the base.

2. The S1 subunit undergoes a hinge-like conformational change to expose the receptor-binding domain (RBD) and binds to the membrane protein ACE2 on host cells.

3. Activation of spike protein (S protein priming): The membrane protein TMPRSS2 acts as a protease. S protein cleavage at the S1/S2 cleavage site leads to cleavage of S1 (including the RBD). The fusion peptide of the S2 subunit is exposed in the cleavage of the S2 site.

4. The fusion peptide of the S2 subunit is inserted in the host cell membrane.

5. Membrane fusion: Conformation change of the S2 subunit (folds together to the side; not depicted here) causes fusion of the viral membrane and host cell membrane. Uncoating of the viral RNA takes place.

title: Oral mucositis
description:
Oral cavity of a patient with acute myeloid leukemia receiving chemotherapy

Whitish patches on an erythematous base are visible on the tongue and the buccal surfaces.

These inflammatory changes are characteristic of generalized oral mucositis, a possible complication of chemotherapy. These findings must be differentiated from leukoplakia or candidiasis: unlike oral mucositis, leukoplakia manifests without erythema and candidiasis with white patches that can be scraped off.

title: HIV retinopathy
description:
Fundus photography of the right eye of a HIV-positive patient

Opaque white patches are present along the retinal blood vessels in the upper third of the image (a prominent example is indicated by the arrow).

These small perivascular opacities are called “cotton-wool spots” and are consistent with noninfectious retinopathy in HIV patients.

title: Dix-Hallpike maneuver
description:
A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

title: Jugular venous pressure waveforms in common cardiac conditions
description:
A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

title: Trypanosoma cruzi
description:
Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

title: Hemothorax following rib fracture
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopnea

The margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.

Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

title: Hypertrophic gastropathy (Ménétrier disease)
description:
CT scan of the abdomen (coronal section, oral and IV contrast)

There is significant hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa that is visible as thick, convoluted rugae projecting into the gastric lumen (green overlay).
A large simple hepatic cyst is also visible in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay).

The appearance of the stomach is typical of hypertrophic gastropathy (Ménétrier disease).

title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

Narrow retinal arteries with box-carring of the retinal vessels (black dashed outline) and a pale retina indicating nerve fiber layer edema are visible. The fovea centralis appears red (cherry-red spot; purple overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. Additionally, at the temporal superior arcade an embolus is present (arrow-head).

This is the classical finding of acute central retinal artery occlusion.

Purple circle: Optic disc

title: Myocardial infarction (extensive coagulative necrosis)
description:
Photomicrograph of myocardial tissue (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The cardiomyocytes show hypereosinophilia (intense red staining), and there are interstitial red blood cells and intact neutrophils. Moreover, edema is visible, seen as clear spaces between cardiomyocytes.

These are early signs are of myocardial infarction (1–3 days old).

title: Visual mnemonic for omphalocele and gastroschisis
description:
Omphalocele: congenital herniation of abdominal viscera through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus. The hernia sac is covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum.
To remember this, think: the herniating abdominal contents stay within the “O” (i.e., they are covered by peritoneum).

Gastroschisis: congenital paraumbilical herniation of the intestine through the abdominal wall without formation of a hernia sac.
To remember this, think: the herniating abdominal contents come out of the “G” (i.e., they are not covered by peritoneum).

title: Junctional tachycardia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular rhythm

- Heart rate: ∼ 130/min

- P waves immediately follow the QRS complexes (examples indicated with green arrowheads) and are inverted in I, II, aVF, and V4–V6 (retrograde P waves; examples indicated with red arrowheads).

- Cardiac axis borderline normal/right axis deviation (isoelectric in I, R > S in aVF)

- Narrow QRS complexes (∼80 ms)

- Persistent S wave

A regular, narrow complex tachycardia with retrograde P waves is suggestive of junctional tachycardia.

title: Uterine adenomyosis
description:
MRI pelvis (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Uterine enlargement accompanied by diffuse, predominantly hypointense widening of the junctional zone is seen. Multiple punctate high-intensity myometrial foci are visible within the uterine wall, demonstrating scattered foci of ectopic endometrium (examples indicated by arrowheads).

The findings are characteristic of uterine adenomyosis.

title: Diffuse airspace opacification
description:
X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Confluent and multifocal airspace opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) predominate in the lower zones of the lungs. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red lines) are visible in some locations. There are no Kerley lines or pleural effusions. The cardiac silhouette size is normal. An endotracheal tube (arrow) is present.

ARDS and other causes of noncardiogenic edema can produce extensive airspace opacification, as can cardiogenic edema, diffuse pneumonia, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, pneumonic-type adenocarcinoma, and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Radiography alone cannot establish a diagnosis of ARDS.

title: Pediatric lichen sclerosus
description:
Photographs of two pediatric vulvas

Porcelain-white, polygonal, well-demarcated plaques in a figure-eight appearance involve the vulvar and perianal area. In the left picture, the atrophic patches are surrounded by an inflammatory erythematous halo.

These findings are typical of lichen sclerosus.

title: Infant botulism
description: This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

title: Intertrochanteric femoral fracture
description:
X-ray right hip (AP view)

A comminuted intertrochanteric fracture (fragments indicated by green, white, and yellow overlay) of the right femur is accompanied by superior displacement of the femoral shaft and distraction (indicated by red dashed lines and arrows) of the main fracture fragments.

title: Olecranon stress fracture
description:
X-ray right elbow (A: AP view, B: lateral view) and CT right elbow (C: frontal plane; D: sagittal plane) of a 16-year-old baseball pitcher with progressive posterior elbow pain

No fracture is visible on the AP radiograph; however, a subtle irregular line (green arrows) projecting over trabecular bone on the lateral view raises the possibility of a fracture. CT images reveal a nondisplaced oblique fracture through the mid-third of the olecranon (white arrows).

Stress fractures may be very subtle or not visible at all on radiographs. Additional imaging is warranted when clinical findings suggest injury, but radiographs are equivocal or negative. CT, MRI, and bone scintigraphy have been used to further evaluate stress fractures.

title: Ureterolithiasis
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial, coronal, and sagittal planes) of a 54-year-old patient with a history of renal calculi

An obstructive calculus (green arrowhead) is present in the proximal left ureter. Pelvicaliectasis and ureteral dilatation (green overlay) are seen to the level of the calculus. There is a small amount of asymmetric fat and fascial stranding around the left kidney and proximal ureter as a result of edema.

Additional findings include a small hypodense right adrenal mass (yellow overlay), small hepatic hypodensities (example indicated by white arrowhead), a lumbosacral perineural (Tarlov) cyst (red overlay), and atherosclerotic calcifications.

title: Hypopigmented macules in leprosy
description: Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.

title: Lung abscess
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with pneumonia and lung abscesses

Two thick-walled cavitary lesions (green overlay) are seen in the right middle lobe. A sharp air-fluid level is visible within the anterior cavity. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red overlays) are present within the surrounding consolidation.

title: Nuclear grooves and Orphan-Annie eyes in papillary thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a thyroid tumor tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Cells arranged in a papillary architecture are visible (examples indicated by green overlay). Some cell nuclei appear invaginated (nuclear grooves), giving them a coffee-bean appearance (examples indicated by white lines). The nuclei in general show pale staining centrally and powdery chromatin in the periphery (Orphan Annie-eye nuclei; example highlighted by red overlay).

These nuclear changes in a thyroid tumor with papillary architecture confirm the diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
Well-defined erythema with peripheral scaling is visible on this child's neck. Fine, whitish scaling is also visible behind the ear.

The location of these lesions is typical of infantile seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
description:
Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms

title: Common warts (verrucae vulgares)
description:
Multiple whitish plaques and papules are visible on the distal end of the fingers. A larger hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous and scaly surface can be seen on the distal end of the right thumb.

Common warts are typically associated with HPV infection.

title: Aneurysm of the ascending aorta
description:
CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; mediastinal window) of a patient with Marfan syndrome

A large aneurysm of the ascending thoracic aorta (AA) is seen. The diameter of the descending aorta (DA) is normal.

title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
description:
The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.

These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

title: Sellar mass with suprasellar extension
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; left: sagittal plane; right: coronal plane) of a 21-year-old, male patient with a pituitary macroadenoma

A large, lobulated mass (green overlay) with heterogeneous contrast enhancement extends from the sella turcica into the suprasellar space.

Blue overlay: compressed third ventricle

title: Vaginal discharge in bacterial vaginosis
description: Speculum view of the cervix with thin gray and milky discharge

title: Hyperdense middle cerebral artery (MCA) sign
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right middle cerebral artery (MCA; green overlay) is hyperdense compared to the regions of the left MCA (arrow) and tip of the basilar artery (red overlay).

The hyperdense MCA sign is a marker of middle cerebral artery thrombosis. This sign is visible before parenchymal changes of ischemia.

title: Great vessel stenoses
description:
Angiography thoracic aorta (left anterior oblique view) of a patient with Takayasu arteritis

Stenoses (examples indicated by white arrows) are seen in the innominate (I), left common carotid (C), and left subclavian (S) arteries. An injection catheter is seen in the dilated ascending aorta (green overlay).

title: Spinal epidural abscess, osteomyelitis, and discitis
description:
MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

High signal intensity collections are seen in the posterior epidural space. The largest collection (blue overlay) causes anterior displacement and high-grade compression of the spinal cord from C7-T2. The appearance is consistent with epidural abscess. The differential would also include epidural hematoma.

High signal intensity consistent with osteomyelitis and discitis involves the C6 and C7 vertebral bodies (green overlay), prevertebral soft tissues (red overlay), and intervening disc space (yellow overlay).

title: Ring-enhancing lesions in the brain
description:
MRI head (A and B: T1-weighted, with contrast; C: FLAIR; axial plane) of a patient with HIV-associated primary CNS lymphoma

Ring-enhancing lesions in the right thalamus (A) and left frontal lobe (B) have central, low-signal intensity (hatched green overlay), suggesting necrosis. Hyperintense edema (green overlay) surrounds both lesions on the FLAIR sequence. Prominent sulci and ventricles reflect mild, generalized cerebral volume loss.

Toxoplasmosis and primary CNS lymphoma in patients with HIV/AIDS can have similar appearances, and further workup is needed if MRI cannot distinguish between them.

title: Craniopharyngioma
description:
MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute visual loss in the right eye

There is an intrasellar and suprasellar mass (green overlay) with both cystic and solid portions. The solid portions show strong contrast enhancement.

title: Symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction
description: Acute disruption of the blood supply to myocardial muscle triggers ischemia-related chest pain, often described as nonfocal retrosternal chest discomfort or pressure. Accompanying symptoms, including nausea, diaphoresis, lightheadedness, palpitations, and/or dyspnea, may result from increased sympathetic tone and/or reduced cardiac output.

title: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
description:
Ultrasound abdomen (pylorus; longitudinal plane) of an 8-week-old male infant

The single wall thickness of the muscular layer measures 6.5 mm (normal cutoff: 3 mm). The pyloric channel measures 17 mm (normal cutoff: 14 mm). No fluid was seen to pass through the pylorus into the duodenum during real-time evaluation when the infant was fed.

The imaging findings confirmed the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.

title: Classification of shock
description: Overview of types of shock and aspects of their etiology and pathophysiology. Common to all types of shock is the development of tissue hypoperfusion and, consequently, tissue hypoxia and end-organ dysfunction.

title: Acute-on-chronic pancreatitis
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane)

An enlarged heterogeneous pancreatic head (green overlay) contains multiple calcifications, which is characteristic of chronic pancreatitis. Peripancreatic inflammatory fatty stranding (red overlay) is also seen.

Incidental findings include a small hypodense cyst (yellow overlay) in the dorsal parenchyma of the left kidney and atherosclerotic vascular calcifications (blue overlay). Intravenous contrast is seen in the liver (L), and oral contrast is seen in the bowel loops (indicated by arrows).

title: Pathophysiology of heart failure
description:
Reduced cardiac output results in the activation of compensatory mechanisms (i.e., ADH and BNP production, activation of the renin-angiotensin system and sympathetic nervous system) in an attempt to restore cardiac output.

Cardiac remodeling and increases in afterload both have a negative effect on cardiac output. Increases in heart rate and preload have a positive effect on cardiac output. The net effect of these compensatory mechanisms may be sufficient to restore cardiac output. If not, the cycle repeats.

title: Brugada pattern
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

title: Osteoblastoma cervical spine
description:
X-ray cervical spine (lateral view) and CT cervical spine (bone window; axial plane)

An expansile mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion involves the right C7 posterior elements (green overlay). The epicenter is in the region of the right lateral mass.

title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
description:
MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndrome

A confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.

The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.

title: Pityriasis versicolor (tinea versicolor)
description:
Numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions.

This is the typical appearance of pityriasis versicolor.

title: Natural course of HIV infection
description:
Graph showing typical cell counts, antibody levels, and viral loads during different stages of untreated HIV infection/AIDS

The dashed line at the level of 500 cells/mm3 represents a state of moderate immunocompromise.

CD4+ or CD8+ thresholds at which select common opportunistic infections most frequently occur:
I (< 200 cells/mm3): pneumocystis pneumonia, histoplasma capsulatum
II (< 100 cells/mm3): cryptococcal meningitis, candida esophagitis, cerebral toxoplasmosis
III (< 50 cells/mm3): CMV infection, atypical mycobacterial infections

title: Aplastic anemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

title: Nit of a pubic louse
description: Pubic lice attach their nits (louse eggs) to human pubic hair using a sticky secretion.

title: Erythema multiforme
description:
Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

title: Viral conjunctivitis
description:
Left eye

The conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.

This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

title: Abdominal organs
description:
Ventral view (left)
Dorsal view (right)

title: Transverse sections of the spinal cord
description:
The transverse width of the spinal cord varies significantly depending on the level. It is largest at the cervical (C4/5) and lumbar (L4/5) enlargements, where neurons of the brachial and lumbosacral plexus are located. The white matter is a collection of nerve fibers and decreases in size as it descends, as descending fibers decrease from cranial to caudal, and ascending fibers increase from caudal to cranial.

Important structures of the gray and white matter are marked in the image.

title: Alveolar structure
description: The alveolar walls contain three cell types: type 1 pneumocytes, type 2 pneumocytes, and alveolar macrophages. Type 1 pneumocytes are thin, flat cells that form the alveolar structure and make up 95% of its surface. Type 2 pneumocytes are far smaller in size but more numerous (thus accounting for about 60% of alveolar cells but taking up only 5% of the surface space) and produce the surfactant, which covers the entire alveolar lumen to reduce surface tension. The alveoli are separated from each other by the interalveolar septum with elastic fibres and capillaries; interalveolar pores connect adjacent alveoli.

title: Infantile superficial hemangioma
description:
The scalp has a solitary, ovoid, bright red nodule with irregular texture.

This finding is suggestive of superficial hemangioma.

title: Rash in secondary syphilis
description:
A nodular, partially pustular, copper-colored rash with some superficial scaling is visible over the back, arms, and shoulders. The palms and soles of the feet are typically also affected.

These findings are consistent with a rash seen in secondary syphilis.

title: Warfarin-induced skin necrosis
description: Six large, partially crusted, partially moist ulcerations, approx. 1–2 cm in size extend from the distal upper arm to the forearm. A large area of purpura is seen between the lesions.

title: Granuloma inguinale
description: Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

title: Blood supply of the female reproductive organs (dorsal view)
description:
The arterial supply of the female reproductive organs mainly comes from branches of the uterine artery. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery and crosses the ureter anteriorly in the broad ligament at the level of the cervix. The ovary and fallopian tubes are supplied by branches of the ovarian artery that arise from the abdominal aorta and anastomose with the ovarian branches of the uterine artery.

Note that the vessels adjacent to the uterus are tortuous to accommodate the massive growth of the uterus during pregnancy.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Photograph of the right temporal region in a male patient

A large (approx. 6–8 cm), eroded, and inflamed lesion is visible with a slightly crusted and irregular border. There also appear to be small areas of bleeding around the left border of the lesion.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

title: Osteofascial compartments of the leg
description:
Transverse section of the right leg (caudal view)

The interosseous membrane and deep fascial septa divide the leg into three compartments:
1. Anterior (extensor) compartment: bound by the tibia and the anterior intermuscular septum (junction of blue and purple compartments)
2. Lateral (fibular) compartment: bound by the anterior and posterior intermuscular septum (junction of purple and green compartments)
3. Posterior (flexor) compartment, which is further divided into:
- Deep posterior compartment: bound by the interosseous membrane anteriorly (junction of blue and orange compartments) and the transverse intermuscular septum posteriorly (junction of orange and green)
- Superficial posterior compartment: posterior to the transverse intermuscular septum

title: Condylomata acuminata
description:
Confluent nodular, verrucous “cauliflower-like” lesions are visible on the entire labia and the anogenital region.

These findings are characteristic of Condylomata acuminata, which are mostly caused by infection with HPV types 6 and 11.

title: Compound melanocytic nevus
description: A round, well-demarcated, sessile papule with evenly distributed, brown pigmentation and a slightly warty surface is visible.

title: ST-elevation myocardial infarction
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R wave > S wave in lead I, R < S in aVF and II)
– ST elevation in V2–V4 (example indicated by ST)
– Pathological Q waves in V1–V4 (example indicated by Q)
– T-wave inversion in V1–V4 (example indicated by T)
– Reduced R wave amplitude in V4–V6 (example indicated by R)

These findings are consistent with the intermediate stage of an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

title: Hepatitis B virus
description:
Electron micrograph of hepatitis B virus

Different forms of virus particles are present. In the center, large, circular virus particles can be seen, which are surrounded by filamentous particles and smaller spherical particles.

The circular particles are infectious virus particles, also called Dane particles, which consist of a nucleocapsid and core proteins. The filamentous and spherical particles only consist of the lipid envelope and are therefore noninfectious.

D: Dane particle or virion; F: filamentous viral particle; S: spherical viral particle

title: Anopheles mosquito sucking blood
description: A female Anopheles mosquito (Anopheles gambiae) sucking blood from the photographer's hand using its proboscis. The mosquito's abdomen is already filled and expanded to the extent that one drop of blood is directly excreted. At the start of the blood meal, the mosquito injects saliva that contains anticoagulation agents and, in some cases, sporozoites (infectious form of the malaria parasite).

title: Head of a pork tapeworm (Taenia solium)
description: The distinct head (scolex) of a pork tapeworm. Characteristic of Taenia solium are two rows of hooks, which permit attachment to the host's intestinal wall. In contrast to pork tapeworms, beef tapeworms do not have hooks.

title: Ulcerative colitis
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Ulcerative colitis
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Colorectal adenocarcinoma (pT1)
description:
Photomicrograph of colonic tissue (H&E stain)

The hyperchromatic area on the right two-thirds of this image shows a moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma. The cells lining the colonic glands appear hyperchromatic, with basally oriented nuclei with atypical features. The lumen of these glands contains necrotic debris. The colonic glands, which are typically only present in the mucosal layer, are visible in the submucosa, but not beyond (pT1). Goblet cells are absent. (They would appear as unstained cells between the lining epithelial cells.) Desmoplasia is identifiable as fibrous tissue surrounding the tumor cells.

Normal colonic mucosa is identifiable on the left third of the image as paler staining tissue. Note the abundance of goblet cells.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Tetralogy of Fallot
description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

title: Elephantiasis from lymphatic filariasis
description:
Photograph of the legs of an adult male

Severe edema of the lower legs.

This is likely due to an infection with tropical roundworms (lymphatic filariasis).

title: Adenoma sebaceum in patient with tuberous sclerosis
description:
Multiple papules, resembling acne, can be seen on this patient's face.

These findings are suggestive of adenoma sebaceum, a cutaneous condition in patients with tuberous sclerosis characterized by the presence of angiofibromas.

title: Actin and vimentin filaments
description:
Multiphoton fluorescence micrograph of HeLa cells
