Certain cellular structures were stained immunohistochemically with various fluorescent-labeled antibodies. Actin filaments (green) form a fine network in the cell. They are involved in transport processes as well as cell membrane specialization (e.g., cell junctions, microvilli). The intermediate filament vimentin (red) provides the cell with structural stability. The DNA in the nucleus is fluorescently labeled in blue.

title: Larynx (ventral view)
description:
Larynx (ventral view):

The thyroid cartilage (top) and the cricoid cartilage (bottom) are cleary visible. Above the larynx is the hyoid bone, which is connected to the thyroid cartilage through the thyrohyoid membrane.

title: Onychomycosis
description:
The fingernail shows yellow discoloration starting at the distal edge, longitudinal striations, and separation from the nail bed.

This is a typical finding in the most common subtype of onychomycosis, distal subungual onychomycosis, which is usually caused by dermatophytes.

title: Fungal hyphae
description: Wet mount of scraped skin stained with 20% KOH solution, which dissolves keratinocytes. While this method makes fungal elements easily visible, it does not allow for differentiation between different types of fungi (dermatophytes, yeast, etc).

title: Nummular eczema
description:
Upper ankle region with a round, red-brown, scaly plaque.

Nummular eczema is usually associated with severe pruritus. Tinea corporis should be considered as a differential diagnosis.

title: Nummular eczema (hands)
description: Several red-brown, round, crusted, and slightly scaly plaques can be seen on the back of the hands, fingers, and lower arm.

title: Tinea capitis
description:
Scalp of a child

There is a round, almost hairless plaque with coarse scaling.

The patient was diagnosed with superficial tinea capitis caused by dermatophytes.

title: Tinea cruris
description: There is well-demarcated erythema with a raised border visible around the scrotum and upper thighs of the patient.

title: Tinea capitis
description:
There are multiple confluent, scaly lesions with central redness and hair loss visible on the scalp.

This is the typical appearance of tinea capitis due to infection with microsporum canis

title: Cervical discharge in gonorrhea (speculum view)
description:
The surface of the cervix is covered with yellowish-white, purulent discharge. The external os of the uterus is inflamed and red.

These findings are consistent with gonorrhea.

title: Vulvar lichen sclerosus
description: An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.

title: Sialadenitis in mumps
description: There is pronounced neck swelling due to enlargement of the salivary glands (including the parotid glands) bilaterally as well as the thyroid gland.

title: Neck swelling in mumps
description: There is significant symmetrical neck swelling due to swelling of the salivary glands and lymph nodes.

title: Fracture of the fifth metacarpal 2/2
description:
X-ray right hand (oblique view)

An acute oblique fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck is accompanied by volar and radial angulation of the distal fragment. Sometimes termed a “boxer's fracture,” this injury is frequently the result of a closed fist colliding with a solid surface at high speeds.

title: Blowout fracture of the orbital floor
description:
CT of the midface (frontal view, bone window)

Orbital (O) floor fracture (white line shows the original course of the bone), resulting in herniation of the infraorbital adipose tissue (green overlay) into the maxillary sinus (MS). This is also known as the teardrop sign. The inferior rectus muscle (green hatched overlay on the right) is no longer clearly defined on the left and likely entrapped in the area of the orbital floor fracture.

title: Acute tonsillitis
description:
Oropharynx of a child presenting with fever and sore throat

The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and yellow-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.

Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

title: Central retinal vein occlusion
description:
Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

title: Acoustic neuroma in a 43-year-old patient
description:
Photomicrograph of a tumor arising from the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII (H&E stain; medium magnification)

A characteristic finding of neuromas is the simultaneous occurrence of areas with densely packed nuclei (palisade pattern; A) and scattered or anuclear areas (B). There is also a large number of vacuolated cells (C).

title: Superficial spreading melanoma
description:
A roughly symmetrical lesion with an irregular border and heterogeneous pigmentation can be seen. The lesion is approx. 12 mm in diameter and slightly raised.

These findings suggest superficial spreading melanoma.

title: Aneurysmal bone cyst
description:
X-ray of the right knee joint (PA)

A sharply demarcated, osteolytic lesion (green area) with a thin sclerotic edge (white lines) can be seen in the lateral part of the distal femur. It is most likely an aneurysmal bone cyst, although the finding could also be unicameral bone cyst.

title: Brain lesion
description:
Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)

An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

title: Herpes zoster
description: A patient with painful lesions (erythema with vesicles and papules) in a dermatomal distribution (T4 and T5) on the back and chest.

title: Streptococcus
description:
Photomicrograph of Streptococcus (Gram stain)

The chains of bluish-purple (gram positive) cocci seen on this Gram stain are characteristic of the genus Streptococcus.

title: Histopathology of Candida pneumonia
description:
Grocott's methenamine silver staining (~ 120x magnification) of lung tissue contaminated with Candida albicans (black).

Candida albicans is dimorphic: It can appear either as oval/round or filamentous. The filamentous, elongated form of Candida albicans (pseudohyphal form) is more pathogenic than the oval/round form (blastospore). Transition from blastospore to filament can occur. Candida albicans can also form true hyphae, which may sometimes be found in invasive candidiasis but are not shown here.

title: Overview of bacteria
description: Depicted here is the classification of bacteria according to their Gram staining properties. Bacteria are further classified according to morphology, genus, and hemolytic and enzymatic properties.

title: Types of volvulus
description:
The types of volvulus are classified by anatomical location as illustrated here.

- Midgut volvulus: A malrotated midgut causing mechanical bowel obstruction, mostly in neonates and infants. Fibrous peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) attaching the cecum to the retroperitoneum are a common pathological finding in midgut volvulus.

- Cecal volvulus: The cecum rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

- Sigmoid volvulus: The sigmoid colon rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

title: Renal mass
description:
Ultrasound kidney (longitudinal plane)

An irregular heterogeneous hypoechoic mass involves the lower pole renal cortex and the adjacent region of the collecting system. There is no posterior acoustic enhancement to indicate a cystic component.

The differential for a hypoechoic solid renal mass includes both benign and malignant tumors as well as several non-tumorous lesions. The most common tumor is renal cell carcinoma. Further imaging would be necessary for a definitive diagnosis and would typically include CT and possibly MRI and/or biopsy.

Outline: kidney

title: Posterior myocardial infarction
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V2 and V3 and horizontal ST depression in V4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V1 and QRS duration of 0.12 s

These findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

title: Pigmented basal cell carcinoma
description: A red-brown plaque with nodules is visible on an area of skin from the patient's upper thigh. The lesion exhibits both irregular (left) and well-defined borders (right). The surface of the lesion is shiny. Brown melanin pigmentation can also be seen.

title: Actinic keratosis
description:
The entire hairless portion of the scalp is covered with telangiectasia, light brown papules, and yellow-brownish, hyperkeratotic plaques.

This appearance is typical of actinic keratoses.

title: Rubella rash
description: A nonconfluent, pink, maculopapular rash is visible across this infant's trunk and extremities.

title: Superficial spreading melanoma
description:
Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

title: Gallbladder calculi and wall thickening
description:
Ultrasound gallbladder (longitudinal plane)

Acoustic enhancement (green overlay) is seen distal to the gallbladder except where multiple small dependent hyperechoic calculi (yellow overlay) reflect the ultrasound beam and cast an acoustic shadow (green hatched overlay). Biliary sludge (yellow hatched overlay) is slightly hyperechoic compared to anechoic bile. The gallbladder wall is thickened (normal size: 1–2 mm) and has a layered appearance (red overlay), with central hypoechoic edema.

These findings in a patient with typical clinical features of RUQ pain strongly indicate acute calculous cholecystitis. Additional findings that would support a diagnosis of cholecystitis include an obstructing calculus, positive Murphy sign, pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder dilatation, and hyperemia of the gallbladder wall on color Doppler.

G: gallbladder; L: liver

title: HIV patient with oral hairy leukoplakia
description:
A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

title: Pericardial tamponade: opened pericardium (2/2)
description:
Photograph of a heart at autopsy (close-up of the left ventricle in longitudinal section)

There is coagulated, brown blood in the opened pericardium.

Coagulation indicates previous hemorrhage from the heart chambers into the pericardium. The coagulated blood compresses the heart (pericardial tamponade), leading to cardiac arrest.

title: Pityriasis rosea
description: A secondary rash after primary plaque formation (not shown) can be seen on the back of this patient. The secondary eruption of pityriasis rosea is usually episodic and distributed along Langer lines.

title: Tumor at the base of the skull
description:
MRI of the brain (T1-weighted; sagittal view; with contrast)

A hyperintense, ovoid, sharply demarcated lesion (green overlay) is visible within the sella turcica and partially extends into the sphenoidal sinus.

The location and appearance of the lesion suggest a craniopharyngioma or a pituitary adenoma.

title: Layers of the skin
description:
The skin is composed of the cutis (epidermis and dermis) and the subcutis.

- The epidermis has five layers: stratum corneum, lucidum, granulosum, spinosum, and basale.
- The dermis has two layers: papillary and reticular dermis.
- The subcutis contains fat and neurovascular structures.

title: Types of hiatal hernias
description:
Type I (sliding): The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) and the gastric cardia slide up into the mediastinum while the gastric fundus remains below the diaphragm.
Type II (paraesophageal): Part of the gastric fundus herniates into the thorax while the GEJ remains in its anatomical position below the diaphragm.
Type III (mixed): The GEJ and a portion of the gastric fundus prolapse through the hiatus.
Type IV (complex): herniation of any abdominal structure in addition to the stomach (e.g., colon, spleen)

title: Leukocyte extravasation
description:
Marginalization: The liver releases fibrinogen, an acute phase protein, in response to cytokines produced by macrophages, monocytes, and other cells (not shown). The increased levels of fibrinogen cause rouleaux formation (not shown), which pushes neutrophils towards the venule endothelium.

Rolling: Adhesion molecules on neutrophils (e.g., Sialyl-LewisX) and other leukocytes interact with adhesion molecules on endothelial cells (e.g., E-selectin, P-selectin), causing leukocytes to roll along the endothelial surface. Chemokines pass through the endothelium and then bind to proteoglycans in the intravascular lumen.

Adhesion: In response to cytokines, cellular adhesion molecules (e.g., ICAM) are upregulated on endothelial cells and integrins (e.g., β2-integrin) are upregulated on leukocytes, which bind firmly to endothelial cells via these cell adhesion molecules and integrins.

Diapedesis: Leukocytes cross the endothelial wall. Neutrophils release type IV collagenase to dissolve the basement membrane. Neutrophils and endothelial cells express platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1), which regulates diapedesis.

Migration: Leukocytes, mediated by chemoattractants, move to the site of infection through a process called chemotaxis. Chemoattractants that draw neutrophils to the site of infection include leukotrienes (e.g., LTB4), platelet-activating factor (PAF), chemokines (e.g., IL-8), kallikrein, complement fragments (e.g., C5a), and bacterial products.

title: Management of meningitis
description:
BMP: basic metabolic panel
CBC: complete blood count
CRP: C-reactive protein
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid
DDx: differential diagnoses
HSV: herpes simplex virus
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
LP: lumbar puncture
PCR: polymerase chain reaction
VZV: varicella zoster virus

title: Atrial flutter with 2:1 atrioventricular (AV) block
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular rhythm
– Atrial rate of ∼ 300/min and ventricular rate of ∼ 150/min
– Normal axis (R > S in I and aVF)
– Regular, narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms)
– Atrial flutter waves (F waves) with characteristic saw-tooth morphology (negative in inferior leads, examples indicated by blue overlay in II)

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 2:1 AV block.

title: Vitamin B12 absorption
description:
Vitamin B12 (cobalamin, Cbl) is required as a cofactor for methylation reactions and cannot be produced by the body. The process of vitamin B12 absorption from food is complex.

Vitamin B12 is usually absorbed by binding to another food protein (Cbl-Prot). These complexes are cleaved by HCl and pepsin in the stomach. Cobalamin then binds to haptocorrin (HC), which protects it from gastric acid. Once this complex reaches the duodenum, which has a significantly higher pH value, this protective mechanism is no longer required and the cobalamin and haptocorrin complex (Cbl-HC) is cleaved by trypsin. A complex of cobalamin and intrinsic factor (Cbl-IF) forms to prepare cobalamin for absorption. There are cubilin receptors present in the terminal ileum that recognize intrinsic factor and initiate endocytosis of the Cbl-IF complex in enterocytes (intestinal absorptive cells).

Cobalamin is cleaved from intrinsic factor in the enterocytes (see box) and transferred to the transport protein transcobalamin II (Tc). Cobalamin is then bound to Tc and enters the bloodstream, at which point it is distributed throughout the body.

One of the most important storage sites for cobalamin is the liver, the site of inactive precursor activation.

title: Structure and function of the Golgi apparatus
description: The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

title: Anatomical locations and auscultatory sites for heart valves
description:
I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

title: Mechanism of action: oral diabetes medications
description:
- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

title: Common intervertebral disc pathologies
description:
Left: normal anatomy of the intervertebral disc and spinal canal

Right: common disc pathologies

– Disc protrusion: protrusion of the nucleus pulposus through the annulus fibrosus
– Disc herniation/extrusion/prolapse: complete herniation of the nucleus pulposus through a tear in the annulus fibrosus
– Disc sequestration: extrusion of the nucleus pulposus and separation of fragments

title: Freiberg disease
description:
X-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view)

Sclerosis (green overlay) and flattening (indicated by white line) of the articular surface of the 3rd metatarsal head are consistent with prior avascular necrosis. Osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay) have formed on both sides of the widened joint space.

Freiberg disease (previously known as Freiberg infarction) is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of a metatarsal bone. It typically develops in the second metatarsal head, but may involve any metatarsal bone.

title: Rib motions
description: Each rib exhibits different degrees of motion based on its position within the rib cage, e.g., ribs 1–5 predominantly engage in a pump-handle motion.

title: Targets of antimalarial drugs
description:
Illustration depicting the stages of a malaria parasite within a human host
- Right: legend of antimalarial drugs and their targets
- Bottom left: erythrocytic cycle (within blood)
- Top left: exoerythrocytic cycle (within the liver)

The four main targets of antimalarial drugs are the tissue schizont, hypnozoite, blood schizont, and gametocyte, which are the asexual developmental stages of malaria parasites that occur within the liver and blood of an infected human host. Most antimalarial drugs act on the erythrocytic stages of the malaria parasite, especially the blood schizonts. Primaquine is the only antimalarial that attacks the hypnozoites, which are the dormant stages of P. vivax and P. ovale, responsible for relapses of malaria.

title: Intussusception
description: A proximal part of the bowel invaginates into a distal part → congestion of mesenteric vessels → edema, ischemia → necrosis, perforation

title: Innominate shear dysfunction
description:
ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

title: Initial management of acute asthma exacerbation
description:
BP: blood pressure
HR: heart rate
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
ICU: intensive care unit
IV: intravenous
O2: oxygen
PEF: peak expiratory flow
PO: per os
RR: respiratory rate
SABA: short-acting beta agonist
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist
SpO2: oxygen saturation

title: Syphilis serological testing algorithm
description:
FTA-ABS: fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption
NTT: nontreponemal test
RPR: rapid plasma reagin
TPPA: treponema pallidum particle agglutination
TT: treponemal test
VDRL: venereal disease research laboratory

title: Lupus nephritis
description:
Photomicrograph of a renal cortex biopsy specimen (PAS stain; 250x magnification)

Sections of numerous tubules and vessels and three centrally located renal glomeruli (blue outlines) are visible. The latter show a partially increased mesangial cell density (examples indicated by black outlines), thickened capillary loops (due to subepithelial immune complex deposits; examples indicated by blue overlay), extracapillary epithelial proliferation (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (examples indicated by arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, the most common form of lupus nephritis, in which more than half of the glomeruli are affected.

title: Smudge cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads), a neutrophil (black arrowhead), several small lymphocytes (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), and smudge cells (blue overlay) can be seen.

Smudge cells, also known as Gumprecht shadows, are ruptured small neoplastic lymphocytes and are a characteristic but nonspecific feature of CLL.

title: Complete vs. incomplete fractures
description:
In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

title: Barrett esophagus with adenocarcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of an esophageal tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

The upper right edge of the image shows physiological multilayered squamous epithelium of the esophageal mucosa (white overlay), which changes into metaplastic prismatic epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett metaplasia; yellow overlay) toward the center of the image. Barrett metaplasia can eventually develop into epithelial dysplasia and, further, to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus (blue overlay). The carcinoma is characterized by loss of tissue architecture (atypical to absent gland formation) and invasive growth.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Bigeminy
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: ∼ 70/min
– Rhythm: bigeminy - alternating sinus complexes (examples indicated by green circles) and premature ventricular complexes (PVCs; examples indicated by red lines)
– Axis: normal or slight left axis deviation
– Nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay in the sinus complexes (QRS duration > 0.12 s but no clear right or left bundle branch block morphology)
– The PVCs are unifocal (all PVCs in a given lead look the same, indicating they come from the same focus) and most likely arise in the left ventricle (positive in V1, negative in V5/V6).

title: Acute pericarditis
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Rate ∼60/min
- Regular sinus rhythm
- Normal cardiac axis (R >S in I and aVF)
- Normal PR interval (∼140ms) and QTc (∼400ms)
- Narrow QRS complexes
- Diffuse concave ST elevation (in I, II, aVF, V3–V6) with reciprocal ST depression in aVR and V1 (red overlay).

These findings are consistent with acute pericarditis.

title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

title: Congenital muscular torticollis
description: Congenital muscular torticollis (CMT) is caused by fibrosis and/or contraction of a sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, resulting in neck flexion toward the affected SCM and chin rotation toward the opposite side. Physical examination typically shows limited passive range of motion (limited rotation and flexion of the neck). If untreated, CMT can result in craniofacial asymmetry.

title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E staining; high magnification)

There are several nests (example indicated by yellow overlay) composed of large, polygonal, atypical squamous cells with polymorphic nuclei, intercellular bridges (examples indicated by arrowheads) and evidence of keratinization (examples indicated by blue circles).

These are the classic features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with keratinization. In lung tissue, the presence of SCC can represent primary SCC of the lung or metastasis of an extrapulmonary SCC (more common). Therefore, initial diagnosis in biopsy material requires clinical exclusion of a primary extrapulmonary SCC (e.g., pharyngolaryngeal or anogenital).

title: Flow-volume loop in acute asthma
description: Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally high (∼ 2 L), as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.

title: Overview of flow-volume loops
description:
A flow-volume loop is most commonly used as a graphical representation of spirometry testing. It plots inspiratory and expiratory flow (y-axis) against lung volume (x-axis) during a maximal forced expiration and a maximal inspiration.

A (normal): At the beginning of the test, the patient has inhaled to total lung capacity of approx. 6.25 L (normal adult range: 6–6.5 L), and there is no flow. As the patient forcefully exhales, the flow quickly reaches a peak at approx. 10 L/s (normal adult range: 6–12.5 L/s) and then declines almost linearly until flow is zero at the residual volume of just over 1 L (normal adult range: 1–1.5 L). The patient then takes a full inspiration to return to total lung capacity.

B (acute asthma): Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally elevated, as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.

C (emphysema): Expiratory flow is obstructed by the collapse of small airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume and total lung capacity are abnormally elevated due to the lung's increased compliance, decreased recoil, and air trapping.

D (fixed upper airway obstruction): Expiratory and inspiratory flows are flattened and reduced, as they are impeded by the fixed obstruction.

E (unilateral mainstem obstruction): The shape of the loop is normal, but peak expiratory and inspiratory flow rates are reduced, as air can only enter the open portion of the lung. The residual volume is greater than normal because air in the obstructed airway cannot be fully exhaled.

F (obesity): Expiratory and inspiratory flows and total lung capacity are slightly reduced (compared to diagram A) because of the mechanical limitation of the obese chest wall to expand to full capacity.

G (neuromuscular weakness): Respiratory muscle weakness results in reduced expiratory and inspiratory flows, reduced total lung capacity, and increased residual volume.

H (fibrosis): Total lung capacity and peak expiratory and inspiratory flows are substantially decreased due to the lung's decreased compliance. Note that due to the enhanced elastic recoil of fibrotic lung parenchyma, expiratory flow is not decreased as greatly as lung volume.

title: Flow-volume loop in fibrosis
description: Total lung capacity (∼ 3.25 L) and peak expiratory and inspiratory flows are substantially decreased because of the lung's decreased compliance. Note that due to the enhanced elastic recoil of fibrosed lung parenchyma, expiratory flow is not decreased as greatly as lung volume.

title: Hydronephrosis
description:
Ultrasound left kidney (longitudinal plane)

There is hypoechoic dilation (green overlay) of the renal pelvis (RP) and visible calyces. The thickness of the renal parenchyma is normal.

This appearance is characteristic of hydronephrosis grade II (illustration).

title: Lesser trochanter avulsion fracture
description:
X-ray (AP view) of an adolescent athlete

An avulsion fracture of the lesser trochanter of the left femur is displaced superiorly (green overlay). The donor site of the left lesser trochanter shows an irregular contour (arrowheads) in contrast to the smooth contour of the right lesser trochanter.

The lesser trochanter is the insertion site for the iliopsoas muscle.

title: Acute inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 83/min
- Normal cardiac axis: R > S in leads I and aVF
- Normal QRS complex
- ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF; blue overlay) with reciprocal ST depression in aVL (red overlay) and pathological Q waves in III (example indicated by green circle overlay)

title: Chlamydia trachomatis in McCoy cell culture (magnified view)
description:
Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (200x magnification)

The cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (example circled in blue) are identifiable by inclusion bodies (brown; example marked by hatched overlay), surrounded by a thin rim of host cytoplasm. Over the course of the pathogen's life cycle, elementary bodies (examples circled in white) are formed within the inclusion bodies. These are released from the cell and serve to transmit the pathogen to other cells or hosts.

title: Lymph nodes of the breast
description:
Lymphatics of the breast drain into three groups:

1. Axillary group, further divided into three levels
– Level I: lateral to the lateral border of the pectoralis minor
– Level II: behind the pectoralis minor
– Level III: medial to the medial border of the pectoralis minor
2. Parasternal (internal thoracic) group
3. Posterior intercostal group (not shown here)

Efferent lymphatics travel to the supraclavicular nodes and terminate in the thoracic duct (on the left; not shown here) or the right lymphatic duct.

title: Signal transduction of G protein-coupled receptors
description:
G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are membrane receptors with seven transmembrane helices (shown in blue), a binding site for extracellular ligands, and a binding site for an intracellular G protein.

Binding of an extracellular ligand (shown in green) causes the receptor to undergo a conformational change and bind the G protein. This activates the G protein, causing it to bind a GTP molecule (in place of the GDP molecule bound in its inactive state) and dissociate into an α subunit and a complex of β- and γ-subunits (both the γ subunit and the α subunit remain anchored to the cell membrane, as indicated for the α-subunit by the membrane sections shown with each stage).

Both the α-subunit and the β-γ complex can now act on various effector molecules, including both membrane and cytosolic proteins. This signaling cascade is stopped when the α-subunit (which has inherent GTPase activity) hydrolyzes the attached GTP molecule to GDP and recombines with the β-γ complex to form the inactive state of the G protein.

title: Molluscum contagiosum
description:
Photograph of the abdomen and groin of a young child

Single and grouped skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.

These features are consistent with the diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 2/2
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 1/2
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

title: Horner syndrome triad
description:
Orbital region of a female patient

The left eyelid is drooping (ptosis), the left pupil is smaller (miosis) than the right, and the left bulbus appears sunken into the orbit (enophthalmos).

Ptosis, miosis and anhydrosis (not shown) represent the classical triad of Horner syndrome.

title: Drug-induced phototoxic reaction
description:
Upper back and chest of a 70-year-old patient with pruritus after sun exposure one month after first administration of dronedarone due to new-onset atrial fibrillation

An erythematous maculopapular rash can be seen on sun-exposed areas such as the neck and chest. After discontinuation of dronedarone, the symptoms disappeared.

title: Anterior mediastinal mass in Hodgkin lymphoma
description:
X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma

The PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).

Li: liver; LV: left ventricle

title: Acute subdural hematoma
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane; brain window)

A hyperdense, crescent-shaped extra-axial collection (green overlay) on the right side is accompanied by a contralateral shift of the midline structures.

The appearance is characteristic of an acute subdural hematoma.

White dashed line and arrow: midline; arrowhead: right lateral ventricle

title: Gastroparesis
description:
Gastric emptying study (Tc-99m scintigraphy; 0, 30, and 120 min after ingestion of radioactive solid meal; A. healthy control subject; B. Parkinson patient)

Compared to the healthy control (A) with a normal gastric emptying time, images of the patient with Parkinson disease (B) show delayed gastric emptying confirming a diagnosis of gastroparesis.

Nuclear medicine scintigraphy is frequently performed during the workup for gastroparesis. Gastroparesis is associated with multiple disorders, among them Parkinson disease, as in this case.

St: stomach; Sb: small bowel

title: Hemochromatosis of the liver
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy (H&E stain, high magnification)

Deposits of coarse granular brown pigment are visible within the hepatocytes (examples indicated by blue circles). Further deposits also appear in portal tract macrophages (examples indicated by yellow circles).

These deposits stained positive with the iron stain (prussian blue stain; not shown here), which leads to the diagnosis of hemochromatosis.

title: Staghorn calculus
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view)

A large branching structure is seen within the renal pelvis and several enlarged calyces (green overlay). The appearance is typical of a struvite staghorn calculus. The term “staghorn calculus” is used when at least two calyces are involved, giving rise to the appearance of a stag's antlers.

Struvite calculi are caused by urease-producing bacteria. Calcium carbonate precipitates with struvite to form large calculi that are radiographically visible and conform to the renal collecting system.

Severe lumbar rotatory scoliosis is also seen on the radiograph.

P: renal pelvis; VB: vertebrae

title: Acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼78/min
- Normal heart axis (R > S in I and aVF)
- Normal PR interval (∼200 ms), narrow QRS complex (∼100 ms), normal QT interval (∼400 ms)
- ST elevation in II, III, and aVF (examples indicated in green) with reciprocal ST-depressions in lateral leads (I and aVL; examples indicated in red)

title: Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy
description:
Fundus photography of the right eye

There are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.

These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

M: Macula

title: Bilateral optic disc edema
description:
Fundus photography of the right (R) and left (L) optic disc of the same patient

The optic discs have severely blurred margins (dashed circle indicates approximate margin). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). There are multiple peripapillary, flame-shaped hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue overlay). Cotton wool spots appear as bright spots (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. Possible causes of bilateral optic disc edema include hypertensive emergency and intracranial hypertension; in intracranial hypertension, optic disc edema is called papilledema.

title: Elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from phrenic nerve paralysis 2/2
description:
X-ray chest (lateral view)

There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).

Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm

title: Ovarian torsion
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (ovary; with color Doppler)

The ovary is enlarged, rounded, and heterogeneous. No blood flow is visible within the color Doppler box (green outline).

Arrowhead: example of follicle

title: Left upper lobe pneumonia 1/2
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A large area of opacification (green overlay) in the left lung obscures pulmonary vessels, the left heart border, and the left hilum. Air bronchograms are visible (indicated by red lines), consistent with the presence of air space disease. Non-visualization of the hilum limits the ability to assess for a central mass.

title: Posterior cervical tender points (osteopathy)
description:
PC1 inion (midline): inferior nuchal line, lateral to the inion

PC1 occiput (lateral): just below the nuchal line, midway between the inion and mastoid process

PC2 occiput (lateral): inferior nuchal line at the attachment of the semispinalis capitis

PC2 (midline): superior aspect of the C2 spinous process

PC3–PC7 (midline): inferior aspect of the spinous process of the vertebra above the named point

PC3–PC7 (lateral): posterior-lateral surface of articular processes of each named point

PC8 (midline): inferior aspect of C7 spinous process

title: Diverticulitis
description:
CT abdomen and pelvis (oral and IV contrast; coronal plane)

Mural thickening (green overlay) and luminal narrowing (red overlay) of the sigmoid colon are accompanied by fatty and fascial stranding, indicating a localized inflammatory process. When viewed on serial sections, multiple small, well-defined gas collections (arrowheads) represent inflamed sigmoid diverticula.

The features are characteristic of acute sigmoid diverticulitis.

title: Pulmonary nodule
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.

title: Histopathological changes in celiac disease
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of duodenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Intraepithelial lymphocytosis (examples indicated by arrowheads), villous atrophy (dashed outline showing the approximate height of a normal villus), and crypt hyperplasia (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Fascias of the neck
description:
Transverse section of the neck at the level of C7

The investing layer is located below the platysma and covers the sternocleidomastoid muscle as well as the trapezius muscle.
The pretracheal layer covers the infrahyoid muscles and attaches to the carotid sheath.
The prevertebral fascia surrounds the deep muscles of the neck, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, the subclavian artery and the phrenic nerve (not all depicted in this illustration).
The visceral fascia covers the organs of the neck.

title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
description:
CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)

The ascending aorta is dilated. A dissection flap (green overlay) involves both the ascending and descending thoracic aorta. Additional axial and sagittal images (not shown) revealed extension of the flap from the aortic root across the arch into the descending aorta, consistent with a Stanford type A dissection.

AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; SVC: superior vena cava

title: Exudative age-related macular degeneration
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.

title: Fluorescein angiography in ischemic branch retinal vein occlusion
description:
Fluorescein angiography of the right eye

There is hypoperfusion of the temporal inferior vascular arcade, with capillary nonperfusion visible as areas of hypofluorescence (blue overlay). Vessels are tortuous. There is no neovascularization.

This is the typical appearance of ischemic RVO on fluorescein angiography.

Blue circle: Optic disc
M: Macula

title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
description:
Fundus photography of the right eye

There is detachment of the temporal (left side of the image) and central neurosensory retina (blue overlay) from the retinal pigment epithelium, involving the fovea centralis, creating an opaque, corrugated appearance of the retina compared to the intact medial side.

A retinal tear was identified superotemporally at the 11-o'clock position (not shown here), classifying this as a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Blue circle: optic disc; M: macula

title: Otomycosis
description:
Otoscopy of the left ear

The external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane show multiple small white to yellowish appearance of fungal debris and fruiting bodies. They are partly confluent and involve the entire visible area of the auditory canal. Hyphae and fungal spores are visible at the top and bottom of the meatus.

These findings are usually caused by Aspergillus spp. or Candida spp. and are typical for otitis externa mycotica.

title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

title: Ruptured aortic aneurysm
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)

An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

title: Central retinal vein occlusion
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

Multiple punctual hemorrhages in every quadrant of the retina and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the peripapillary and perivascular region are present (examples marked by blue overlay), as are markedly dilated tortuous veins (example framed by white lines) and mild disk edema (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line).

This is the classic appearance of central retinal vein occlusion.

M: Macula

title: Paget disease of lower leg
description:
X-ray right lower leg (left: AP view; right: lateral view)

The tibia is heterogeneous in appearance, with multiple lytic (examples indicated by green overlay) and sclerotic areas (example shown with S and black arrows), coarsened trabeculae, and cortical thickening characteristic of Paget disease. There is lesser involvement of the fibula. Anterior bowing of the tibia, as seen in this patient, is sometimes termed “saber shin deformity” or “saber tibia.”

title: Chondrosarcoma
description:
X-ray of the pelvis (AP view)

Osteolytic zone in the left acetabulum (green overlay).

title: Scabies mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)
description:
Photomicrograph of a human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)

Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, the mite that causes scabies, has a round body and four pairs of legs (green overlay): The front legs end in suckers, while the hind legs end in long bristles. Between the medial front legs, the scabies mite has a mouthpart (red overlay) that it uses for burrowing into the host's skin. Between the medial posterior pairs of legs, the anus of the mite is visible (yellow overlay), from which the female mites lay eggs in the skin's stratum corneum.

title: Right upper lobar consolidation
description:
X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a patient with pneumonia

There is heterogeneous right upper lobe consolidation (green overlay) with air bronchograms (examples of bronchial walls indicated by white lines). The major (white dashed line) and minor fissures (red dashed lines) are elevated from normal position as a result of accompanying atelectasis. No hilar enlargement or pleural effusion is seen.

The differential diagnosis for airspace consolidation considers the radiographic appearance, associated findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion), and patient history and symptoms. Pneumonia, hemorrhage, edema, tumor, and protein can all present as consolidation on a chest radiograph.

Green line: aortic arch margin; LL: lower lobe; ML: middle lobe; UL: upper lobe

title: ECG rhythm strip with frequent premature ventricular complexes (PVCs)
description:
ECG rhythm strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm (blue overlay: heart rate approx. 95 bpm; narrow QRS complexes) with frequent PVCs (monomorphic QRS complexes approx. 440 ms wide)
– Top strip: trigeminy (a repeating pattern of one PVC after every two sinus beats)
– Middle strip: two short runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT; yellow overlay: heart rate approx.150 bpm) and one PVC couplet (green overlay)
– Bottom strip: one short run of NSVT, two PVC couplets, and a fusion complex (red overlay)

title: Steeple sign
description:
X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)

The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).

The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

title: Rickets of the lower extremities
description:
X-ray legs (AP view) of a 2-year-old child with rickets

Deficiency in mineralization has resulted in bowing of the legs (genu varum; indicated by dashed lines). Excess nonmineralized osteoid at the metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification has produced widening of the epiphyseal growth plate (examples indicated by green overlay) along with metaphyseal splaying (examples indicated by red lines), cupping (yellow line), and fraying (examples indicated by blue overlay).

title: Classification of perineal lacerations
description:
First degree: cutaneous to subcutaneous tissue tear (skin, fourchette, posterior vaginal wall) with no involvement of the perineal muscles

Second degree: first-degree lacerations plus laceration of the perineal muscles without involvement of the anal sphincter

Third degree: second-degree lacerations plus involvement of the external anal sphincter

Fourth degree: third-degree lacerations plus lacerations of the anterior wall of the anal canal or rectum

title: Eosinophilic esophagitis
description:
Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential lesions (examples indicated by green lines) and longitudinal furrows (examples indicated by blue lines) are visible along the esophageal mucosa. The pattern created by the repeated circumferential lesions is referred to as “trachealization” because it has a similar appearance to a trachea.

These are characteristic endoscopic features of eosinophilic esophagitis.

title: Medullary thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

There is a very dense conglomeration of parafollicular cells arranged in nests and clusters (examples indicated by dashed circles). Amyloid is visible in the stroma as amorphous, pink, hyaline material (examples indicated by green overlays).

These are typical histological findings in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

title: Multiple sclerosis; baseline images (1/2)
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

title: Coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus
description:
X-ray abdomen (left lateral decubitus view)

Gaseous distention of a closed loop of sigmoid colon (red overlay) has caused apposition of the medial walls (green lines). The resultant cleft-like configuration, in conjunction with the lateral walls of the loop, produces an appearance reminiscent of a coffee bean (illustration).

The coffee bean sign (also called “kidney-bean sign” or “bent-inner-tube sign”) is a classic conventional radiographic finding of sigmoid volvulus.

Dashed line: air-fluid level

title: Aspergilloma (fungus ball) within right upper lobe cavity
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

An elongated homogeneous mass in right right upper lobe represents an aspergilloma (green overlay) within a cavitary lung lesion. Air is present between the aspergilloma and the thin wall (dashed outline) of the cavity. A thin crescent of air is seen along the sides of the aspergilloma, whereas a larger collection of air is seen above it.

Other findings on this radiograph include large lung volumes, small dense pulmonary nodules that are likely calcified (examples indicated by arrowheads), and a possible mass (circle) projecting over right lower lobe pulmonary vessels.

The term “air crescent sign” is sometimes applied to air that may accompany an aspergilloma, cavitary malignancy, lung abscess, or other entity. However, the term is most commonly used to describe air between devitalized lung tissue and surrounding parenchyma in the setting of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.

title: Posttraumatic diaphragmatic hernia simulating diaphragm elevation
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient following thoracic trauma

A gas bubble on the left (green overlay) is positioned higher than normal and contains an air-fluid level (line). Additionally, the left hemidiaphragm is elevated, lobulated, and not sharply delineated in its entirety (dashed line).

Elevation of a hemidiaphragm can result from abnormalities above, below, or involving the diaphragm. Diaphragmatic rupture can simulate elevation and must be considered in the differential diagnosis of elevation in a trauma setting. A CT scan of this patient confirmed diaphragmatic rupture with the stomach located in the left hemithorax.

title: Medulloblastoma
description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Numerous small, blue, round cells with scant cytoplasm can be seen throughout the specimen (examples indicated by green overlay). Their nuclei vary in size and structure (nuclear pleomorphism) and many cells feature distinctly hyperchromatic nuclei.
The majority of the cells are arranged in concentric clusters around lighter central areas consisting of neuropil (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These clusters are referred to as Homer Wright rosettes.

These histopathological features, particularly the Homer Wright rosettes, are characteristic of a medulloblastoma.

title: Geographic distribution of yellow fever (risk of transmission)
description: The green areas indicate regions where yellow fever is endemic. The WHO recommends vaccination for travelers to high-risk areas. When traveling to low-risk areas, there is no general recommendation; however, vaccination may be considered for longer stays or if there is a high risk of exposure. Proof of vaccination may be required when traveling to or from certain countries. Consult information from the WHO or CDC before traveling.

title: Pleural effusion and passive atelectasis
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.

The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).

In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).

title: Hummingbird sign
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

The hummingbird sign (illustration; also known as “penguin sign”) refers to the appearance of the brainstem on MRI in the sagittal plane in patients with progressive supranuclear palsy. The atrophic mesencephalon (red overlay) represents the bird's head, with the beak extending towards the optic chiasm. The preserved pons (green overlay) represents the body of the bird.

Yellow overlay: medulla oblongata

title: Distal radius fracture (2/2)
description:
X-ray distal forearm (lateral view)

A comminuted fracture (red lines) of the distal radius shows intraarticular extension. Dorsal angulation of the main distal fragment has altered the bony alignment (indicated by green lines and arrows).

title: Distal radius fracture 1/2
description:
X-ray distal forearm (PA view)

A comminuted fracture (red lines) of the distal radius shows intraarticular extension and radial displacement (indicated by green lines and arrows) of the main distal fragment (F). The ulnar styloid process (USP; normal position indicated by yellow dashed outline) is also fractured and displaced medially (indicated by yellow overlay and arrow).

title: Bowenoid papulosis
description:
Labia majora of an immunocompetent patient with an infiltrative and eroded tumor (arrow)

Multiple flat and hyperpigmented patches are disseminated over the patient's upper labia majora.

These patches suggest Bowenoid papulosis, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

title: Cavernous hemangioma of the liver
description:
Photomicrograph of a hepatic nodule biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

Numerous cystic spaces lined by a single layer of endothelial cells are visible throughout this microscopic field (examples indicated by green overlay). The cyst walls are thin and composed of smooth muscle, elastic tissue, and fibrous tissue. Multiple thrombi (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within the cysts.

This histopathological appearance is characteristic of cavernous liver hemangioma.

title: Bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma)
description: T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

title: Renal cyst
description:
Ultrasound right kidney (transhepatic longitudinal view)

There is a thin-walled, round, sharply demarcated, anechoic lesion (green overlay) within the renal parenchyma. There is also posterior acoustic enhancement (white overlay). The renal capsule is demarcated by a white line (blue overlay) and the liver is seen adjacent to the kidney (red overlay).

These findings are consistent with a renal cyst.

title: Erythema multiforme
description:
Trunk and right arm of an infant

Multiple erythematous macules are visible, arranged in concentric rings with a pale center and an outer erythematous margin. The macules are partly confluent and of different sizes.

These lesions are suggestive of erythema multiforme, a hypersensitivity reaction that can be caused by various infections (most commonly herpes simplex virus infections), certain drugs, or immune dysregulation.

title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

The fovea centralis looks dark red (cherry-red spot; green overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. The surrounding retina is pale and opacified, indicating ischemic edema. Narrow retinal arterioles with box-carring (examples indicated by arrowheads) are also visible.

These findings are typical of acute central retinal artery occlusion.

title: Sunken fontanelle
description:
Head of a 1-month-old infant

The skin overlying the anterior fontanelle is notably indented. This finding typically indicates dehydration, especially if other signs of dehydration, such as decreased wet diapers and poor feeding, are present.

title: Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
description:
MRI of the head (FLAIR sequence, axial section); 40-year-old female patient with sudden loss of visual acuity, 2 weeks before acute pancreatitis due to alcohol consumption:

Symmetrical signal enhancements in the occipital lobes on both sides can be seen (green overlay). The findings are consistent with vasogenic edema in the setting of PRES.

title: Discoid systemic lupus erythematosus
description:
Back of a patient with Takayasu arteritis

Several annular (discoid), sharply-demarcated, erythematous lesions can be seen. The center of the lesions appears atrophic.

These are characteristic features of discoid systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: Small bowel obstruction
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; venous phase; axial and coronal planes) of a patient with sharp right lower quadrant pain

Multiple fluid-filled and dilated segments of small bowel (examples marked by red overlay) are seen. A site of transition (indicated by red outline) from dilated (green overlay) to decompressed small bowel is visible in the right lower quadrant. Affected bowel shows wall-thickening and intramural air (examples indicated by white outlines), which is concerning for necrosis. Interloop fluid and edema (green hatched overlay) are also seen, and free fluid is present in the pelvis (blue hatched overlay).

Surgical clips in the right upper quadrant (white arrowheads) indicate a previous cholecystectomy, and there is mild postoperative intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation (blue overlay). A small peripheral splenic defect (yellow overlay) is the site of a previous infarction.

title: Two-person bag-valve-mask-ventilation technique
description:
The left image shows the EC-clamp technique, in which the 3rd, 4th, and 5th fingers of both hands are used to lift the jaw anteriorly towards the mask (forming an “E” shape), while the thumb and index fingers press the mask onto the face (forming a “C” shape).

The right image shows the thenar eminence technique, in which the thumbs and thenar eminences of both hands are placed on top of the mask, while the other fingers pull the jaw into the mask.

Both techniques require a second person to perform ventilation.

Two-person bag-valve-mask ventilation provides greater tidal volumes with less air leak than the one-handed EC-clamp technique.

title: Lateral compartment osteoarthritis of the knee
description:
X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

title: Tension pneumothorax
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).

These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

title: Deep neck infection
description:
X-ray neck (lateral view) of a patient with a retropharyngeal abscess

Retropharyngeal soft tissue swelling has produced widening (indicated by left-right arrows) of the prevertebral soft tissues.

title: Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux
description:
Voiding cystourethrogram (AP view)

Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) has resulted in dilatation of the ureters and pelvicalyceal systems. The right ureter is tortuous and moderately dilated, with blunting of calyceal fornices (example indicated by arrow) but preserved papillary impressions (green line; Grade 4 VUR). The left ureter is markedly dilated with loss of the fornices and papillary impressions (Grade 5 VUR).

B: bladder

title: Vertebral compression fractures
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

There is marked compression of the L3 vertebral body (green overlay). Additional radiographic findings include diffuse osteopenia, multiple endplate compression deformities (examples indicated by dashed lines), and extensive atherosclerotic calcification of the abdominal aorta (A) and iliac arteries.

title: Choledocholithiasis with biliary obstruction
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; coronal plane)

Calculi are visible as hyperdense structures (green overlay) in the distal common bile duct (CBD). The CBD is dilated as a result of obstruction, and the distal duct shows inflammatory thickening (arrowheads).

GB: gallbladder; red overlay: gallbladder calculi

title: Pemphigus foliaceus
description:
The erythematous skin of the face is covered with yellowish scales and crusts; the lips appear unaffected.

The diagnosis of pemphigus foliaceus was confirmed via skin biopsy and positive direct immunofluorescence. Unlike pemphigus vulgaris, which affects only the lower epidermal layers, including of the mucous membranes, but causes neither scaling nor crusting, pemphigus foliaceus is a blistering disease of the upper epidermal layers, resulting in the features seen here but not affecting the mucous membranes.

title: Torsades de pointes
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Bursts of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT; rate ∼ 220/min) alternating with sinus beats
– During the VT phases, the QRS complexes are wide (∼ 200 ms) and appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern (best seen in V1 rhythm strip; indicated by green ellipse).

These findings are characteristic of torsades de pointes (TdP), a subtype of polymorphic VT.

Note how the sinus rhythm converts to VT/TdP as a result of the R-on-T phenomenon (best seen in rhythm strip V6): a premature ventricular complex (PVC; red line) occurs in the downslope of the preceding T wave, initiating VT/TdP.

title: Splenic infarction
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane)

Well-demarcated, nonenhancing, low attenuation areas in the splenic parenchyma extend to the periphery. The larger lesion (green overlay) has the typical wedged shape of a splenic infarction. A small enhancing vessel (arrowhead) is seen within the area of infarction.

L: liver

title: Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)
description:
CT chest (lung window; a: axial plane; b: coronal plane) of a patient with progressive dyspnea on exertion

Extensive reticular interstitial thickening with honeycombing (examples indicated by green outlines) is accompanied by traction bronchiectasis (examples indicated by red arrows). The distribution is subpleural and basal predominant. The appearance is diagnostic of a usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. There are no CT features to suggest an alternative diagnosis.

DA: descending aorta; H: heart

title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis 1/2
description:
X-ray chest (posteroanterior view) of a patient with chronic progressive shortness of breath

Coarse reticular opacities (examples indicated by blue circles) in both lungs show a basal predominant distribution. The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and midline sternotomy wires (example of sternal wire indicated by black outline) and surgical clips (red lines) are evidence of prior coronary artery bypass grafting; however, there are no supportive findings for cardiogenic pulmonary edema, such as Kerley lines or pleural effusions.

CT was subsequently performed and showed peripheral honeycombing diagnostic of a usual-interstitial-pneumonia pattern. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (green overlay).

title: Foreign body aspiration
description:
X-ray chest (lateral decubitus view; A: right lateral decubitus, B: left lateral decubitus) of a child who aspirated an almond

No radiopacity demonstrating the foreign body is seen. However, the right lung (red outlines) remains hyperinflated when the patient is positioned with the right side down on the radiographic table. The hyperinflation reflects air trapping from foreign body aspiration into the right main bronchus.

Decubitus radiographs are sometimes used to evaluate for the presence of an inhaled foreign body. The expectation is that a dependent lung will partially collapse in a normal patient, but will remain hyperinflated in the setting of an obstructive foreign body.

Green outlines: left lung

title: Paralytic Ileus
description:
X-ray abdomen (top: AP view; bottom: left lateral decubitus view) of a patient with mesenteric ischemia

Multiple dilated loops of small bowel (examples indicated by green outlines) are present in the mid-abdomen on the AP radiograph, some of which are recognizable by their valvulae conniventes (Kerckring folds; hatched green overlay). Gas is present in the left colon (red outlines). Multiple air-fluid levels (examples indicated by blue overlay) are seen on the decubitus view.

title: Diabetic neuropathic arthropathy
description:
X-ray forefoot (dorsoplantar view) of a patient with diabetes mellitus

There is marked deformity of the second metatarsal head and malalignment at the second and third metatarsal-phalangeal (MTP; green circle) and interphalangeal (IP) joints. The proximal phalanges show lateral subluxation. Additional findings include metatarsus varus and hallux valgus with bunion formation (arrow).

title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
description: X-ray chest of a premature infant

title: Anterior temporal spikes and sharp waves
description:
EEG (10-20 system; longitudinal bipolar montage) of a patient with temporal lobe epilepsy

Tracings of the left cerebral hemisphere show anterior temporal spikes and sharp waves (examples in red boxes).

These findings indicate a possible epileptogenic source in the left anterior temporal lobe.

title: Chancre of African trypanosomiasis
description: An ulcerating swelling with an erythematous base is visible on this patient's neck.

title: Arterial blood supply of the colon
description:
The mesenteric arteries and their branches supply parts of the pancreas, the jejunum, the ileum, the cecum, the vermiform appendix, the colon, and the rectum. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the intestine up to the transverse colon, while the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the descending colon, the sigmoid colon, and the upper rectum.

Proximal to the Cannon point, parasympathetic innervation is provided by the vagus nerve. Distal to that point, the pelvic splanchnic nerves provide innervation.

title: Unhappy triad
description: A triad of medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial collateral ligament tears. This injury typically occurs due to excessive valgus and external rotational stress with a fixed foot position.

title: Carcinoid syndrome
description:
Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

title: Right middle lobe atelectasis
description:
X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: lateral view)

A poorly marginated opacity (arrow) obscures part of the right heart border on the PA view. On the lateral view, it is seen as a wedge-shaped opacity coursing anteroinferiorily from the hilum, sharply demarcated superiorly by the depressed minor fissure (m) and inferiorly by the elevated right major fissure (M).

The appearance is typical of right middle lobe atelectasis.

title: Genital herpes
description:
The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.

These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

title: Hidradenitis suppurativa (acne inversa)
description: Multiple suppurative lumps and erythema in the axilla. Intertriginous skin is a classic site of predilection.

title: Trachoma
description:
Clinical features of trachoma in a child

A: Conjunctival follicles, consisting of whitish hyperplastic lymphatic tissue, on the ectropionized
upper eyelid

B: Conjunctival scarring of the ectropionized upper eyelid

C: The upper eyelid is folded inwards (entropion) and the eyelashes are growing inwards towards the cornea (trichiasis)

D: Corneal opacification due to scarring (manifests as loss of vision)

These findings are consistent with the active and cicatricial phase of C. trachomatis infection.

title: Erysipelas
description:
A sharply demarcated erythematous rash with discrete narrowing extensions is visible on the lower leg of this patient.

Location and appearance of the lesion are typical of a bacterial infection with Group A Streptococcus affecting the upper dermis and lymphatic vessels.

title: Rectus sheath hematoma
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with acute left anterior abdominal pain

There is marked asymmetry in size of the right and left rectus muscles. The enlarged left rectus muscle (green overlay) is heterogeneous, with low and high attenuation components. High attenuation (hatched green overlay) represents a site of contrast-enhanced blood from acute hemorrhage.

RRM: right rectus muscle

title: Intracerebral hematoma
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).

ROH: right occipital horn

title: Mass in region of duodenum
description:
CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a duodenal hematoma

A heterogeneous mass with high attenuation areas representing hemorrhage (green overlay) is present in the right upper quadrant in the region of the proximal duodenum.

G = gall bladder, P = pancreas

title: Third-degree atrioventricular block
description:
Rhythm strip ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate ∼100/min
– Ventricular rate ~40/min (escape rhythm)
– RR intervals and PP intervals are regular.
– Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation: P waves (red overlay) and QRS complexes (green overlay) have regular but unrelated rhythms because there is no conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in some P waves being completely or partially buried in QRS complexes (6th P wave) or T waves (4th and 9th P waves).

AV dissociation with bradycardia is characteristic of third-degree AV block (complete heart block).

title: Xeroderma pigmentosum
description:
Hyperpigmented, freckle-like lentigines cover the entire face and neck. The skin of the nose is atrophic and hypopigmented.

These features are typical of xeroderma pigmentosum.

title: Aphthous stomatitis
description: Two shallow ulcers with erythematous and well-defined borders are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip.

title: Retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the left common iliac artery
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with abdominal pain after lumbar discectomy

The large collection with irregular margins in the left retroperitoneum represents hemorrhage (H; green overlay). The site of active bleeding is indicated by contrast-enhanced blood (bright green overlay) arising from the proximal left common iliac artery (CIA).

PV: portal vein; K: kidney; GB: gallbladder; A: aorta

title: Spectrum of cervical dysplasia
description:
