Photomicrograph of a cervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

1. Normal squamous epithelium (N; green overlay): normal nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, intact cell polarity (epithelial cells have distinct lateral, apical, and basal membrane domains)

2. Mild dysplasia (1; yellow overlay): mild pleomorphism (loss of uniformity in cell size and shape), mild chromatin abnormalities (hyperchromatic), koilocytes (cells with perinuclear halos), dysplasia confined to the basal third of the epithelium

3. Moderate dysplasia (2; blue overlay): loss of cell polarity, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, moderate nuclear chromatin abnormalities, increased normal and abnormal mitosis, dysplasia confined to the basal two-thirds of the epithelium

4. Severe dysplasia (3; red overlay): irreversible high-grade dysplasia, irregular epithelial stratification, involves the entire thickness of the epithelium, clear demarcated basement membrane (no invasion)

Koilocytes in dysplastic cervical epithelium indicate an underlying persistent HPV infection as the cause of dysplasia.

title: Mechanical small bowel obstruction
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view; erect position)

Multiple air-fluid levels (green overlay) are visible in the mid-abdomen. The opaque appearance of the pelvis (red overlay) is due to fluid-filled loops of small bowel. There is a paucity of gas in the colon, and an air-fluid level is present in the dilated stomach (S).

Erect and decubitus radiographs can reveal air-fluid levels that are not identifiable on supine radiographs. Air-fluid levels can indicate ileus or mechanical obstruction. A lack of distal gas and air-fluid levels at different heights in the same bowel loop (differential air-fluid levels) suggest obstruction.

title: Vibrio cholerae
description:
Scanning electron micrograph

Numerous curved (comma-shaped) vibrio cholerae bacteria can be seen.

title: Mitochondrial inheritance
description: Mitochondrial inheritance implies transmission of the disease only through the mother. All the offsprings of affected females may express the phenotype. Variable expression is observed due to heteroplasmy.

title: Bilateral hip osteoarthritis
description:
X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Marked narrowing of the weight-bearing regions of the acetabulofemoral joint spaces (yellow lines) is accompanied by femoral head and acetabular sclerosis (green overlay), subchondral cyst formation (examples indicated by white dashed outlines), and osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay). The femoral heads show superolateral migration and loss of normal sphericity.

title: Facial features in DiGeorge syndrome
description: Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.

title: Oral leukoplakia
description:
Oral cavity

Well-defined white plaques with irregular borders can be seen bilaterally on the mucosa of the soft palate.
These patches cannot be scraped off with gauze.

title: Subclavian artery and its branches
description:
Ventral view

The left subclavian artery arises directly from the arch of aorta. The right subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic artery. At the outer border of the first rib, the subclavian arteries continue as the axillary arteries. The main branches of the subclavian artery (from proximal to distal) are:
- Internal thoracic artery (internal mammary artery)
- Vertebral artery
- Thyrocervical trunk
- Costocervical trunk

title: Calcinosis cutis
description:
Photograph of the elbow of a patient with CREST syndrome

A multinodular yellowish-white lesion with superficial ulceration can be seen.
Small satellite nodules are visible adjacent to the main lesion.

These features are characteristic of calcinosis cutis, which most commonly occurs over the pressure points of the extremities.

title: Candida albicans
description:
Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

title: Candida albicans
description:
Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

title: Cryptococcus neoformans
description:
Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

title: Giardia lamblia cyst
description:
Photomicrograph of a stool sample (wet mount; iodine stain)

An oval-shaped cyst with a prominent, double-layered wall is visible in the center of the image. The cytoplasm contains four nuclei, which are identifiable as spherical structures. It also contains an axostyle, a fibrillary structure from which the flagella of the trophozoite arises.

This is the typical appearance of a Giardia lamblia cyst, which is excreted in feces and responsible for the transmission of giardiasis through the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

title: Lineweaver-Burk-Diagram
description: Regarding the Michaelis-Menten kinetics, the most important parameters of an enzyme reaction are shown in the Lineweaver-Burk diagram: the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction speed, whereas the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration. The reciprocal of vmax can be taken directly from the intersection point of the straight and the y-axis, whereas the reciprocal of KM (with negative sign) can be taken from the intersection point of the straight and the x-axis. Both values can as well be identified by the slope of the line, as the slope is calculated by the quotient of KM and vmax.

title: Cutaneous sensory receptors (mechanoreceptors)
description:
Papillary dermis of mainly glabrous (hairless) skin (i.e., palms, soles, tongue, lips)
– Merkel nerve endings: sensitive to crude, static touch (e.g., discrimination of shapes and edges)
– Meissner corpuscles: sensitive to low-frequency vibration (e.g., texture) and light touch

Reticular dermis
– Ruffini corpuscles: mainly located in joint capsules and hair-bearing skin; sensitive to pressure and changes in joint angles
– Free nerve endings: thermoception and nociception

Subcutaneous tissue
– Pacinian corpuscles: sensitive to vibration and pressure

title: Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum)
description:
Photograph of a 1-year-old child with recent febrile illness

A patchy, nonpruritic, blanching, erythematous rash with macules and papules can be seen on the trunk and arms. Symptoms manifested one day after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

title: Celiac disease
description:
Endoscopic view of the duodenum

The surface of the duodenum is smooth, with small notches forming a mosaic pattern. Villous atrophy and hyperplastic crypts (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of celiac disease.

title: Dry gangrene in peripheral arterial disease
description:
There are sharply demarcated areas of black, dry, scaly skin on the right medial foot and 1st–3rd toes. Blue discoloration of the 4th toe indicates it is affected by the ischemia as well.

This is the typical appearance of dry gangrene. Dry gangrene is consistent with advanced peripheral arterial disease (Fontaine classification stage IV).

title: Ecthyma gangrenosum
description:
Two purpuric erythematous patches are visible. The large lesion has a necrotic center with an erythematous halo. The smaller lesion at the bottom right may represent an earlier stage.

These lesions are suggestive of ecthyma gangrenosum, which is typically caused by an infection by pseudomonas aeruginosa.

title: Dacrocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Erythrocytes with a teardrop shape can be seen throughout the image (red overlay). The majority of the erythrocytes appear round and normal.

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, known as dacrocytes, are found in conditions that involve extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly).

title: Flow cytometry scatter plot of B and T cells in infectious mononucleosis
description:
Flow cytometry with fluorescent-tagged antibodies was used to differentiate lymphocyte populations. Each point in the image represents a labeled B or T lymphocyte.

The T cell scatter plot shows a high concentration of CD8+ T cells (upper left quadrant), which is consistent with the immune-mediated reaction of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells against EBV infected B lymphocytes seen in infectious mononucleosis.

T cell plot:
Upper left quadrant: cells that are CD4- and CD8+
Upper right quadrant: cells that CD4+ and CD8+
Lower left quadrant: cells that are CD4- and CD8-
Lower right quadrant: cells that are CD4+ and CD8-

title: Atypical lymphocytosis in infectious mononucleosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Multiple atypical lymphocytes (1) are visible. Atypical lymphocytes are activated T cells with a polymorphic nucleus and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. Inactive lymphocytes (2) are comparatively smaller with a round nucleus and thin cytoplasm rim. Despite being activated T cells, atypical lymphocytes strongly resemble monocytes (3), hence the name infectious mononucleosis.

title: Hair tourniquet
description:
Infant's left foot

The second digit is constricted, presumably by a hair. The entire digit is markedly swollen and the distal part is also reddened (due to blood being trapped). This condition requires swift removal of the hair to prevent irreversible damage.

title: Varicocele
description: Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.

title: Reactive fetal nonstress test (NST)
description:
Recording of a fetal nonstress test

There is a baseline heart rate of ∼ 130/min (white dotted line) with four accelerations (1–4) within the recorded window (recording shows 13.5 minutes).

This is a reactive, normal fetal nonstress test.

title: Rotator cuff tear
description:
X-ray of the right shoulder (AP view)

The acromiohumeral interval (red overlay; white arrowheads), which is normally ∼10 mm wide, has been obliterated.

As some of the rotator cuff tendons lie within the acromiohumeral interval, its obliteration indicates either a tear or degeneration of the rotator cuff tendon(s). MRI is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Int-Rot: internal rotation

title: Acute uterine inversion
description: 37 year old women, gravida 4 para 4 who presented in ER right after the birth of her child. She was in pain but did not have active bleeding. The uterus is inverted and prolapsed completely through the vagina and vulva. The insertion site of the placenta (which is not attached anymore) can still be seen as a round, darker part compared to the lighter myometrium.

title: Anterior shoulder dislocation with Hill-Sachs lesion
description:
X-ray right shoulder (AP view (left); lateral (scapular) Y-view (right))

There is anterior and inferior displacement of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa. Hill-Sachs lesion can be seen in AP view.

title: Bartholin cyst
description:
Vaginal introitus of a woman presenting with painless swelling of her right labia

There is a small fluid-filled cyst visible as a translucent gray mass at the posterolateral aspect (8 o'clock position) of the vaginal introitus, distending the right labia minora. There are no signs of inflammation.

title: Brainstem and ventricular system
description: Sagittal section of the brainstem reveals the three major components (from cranial to caudal: midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata) and their associated structures. The parts of the CSF space that traverse the brainstem are shown in blue.

title: Meckel diverticulum
description: The Meckel diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct. The omphalomesenteric duct connects the yolk sac to the alimentary tract in the embryo (left image). The duct is normally obliterated by the 6th week of intrauterine life. However, incomplete obliteration leads to the development of a diverticulum located approx. 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve (right image). The Meckel diverticulum is often connected to the navel via a fibrous cord, which is the obliterated part of the omphalomesenteric duct (middle image).

title: Epidermolysis bullosa
description:
Right foot, ankle, and lower leg of an infant.

There are three large ruptured blisters over the big toe and posterior aspect of the ankle and medial malleolus. There are also two, unruptured blisters (approx. 1–2 cm) on the medial aspect of the lower leg and another in the popliteal fossa.

These findings are typical of epidermolysis bullosa.

title: Congenital umbilical hernia
description:
Anterior abdominal wall of a newborn

There is a mass ∼2 cm in diameter protruding through the umbilical orifice.

This is the typical appearance of a congenital umbilical hernia, which characteristically increases in size on crying or coughing.

title: Bullous pemphigoid
description:
Erythematous skin with a solitary tense blister (unknown localization) is visible in the center of the image.

This appearance is typical of bullous pemphigoid.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Scalp of an older adult

An ulcerated lesion (approx. 1–2 cm) with significant crusting around the irregular border is visible. The center of the lesion is eroded and shows a shiny surface with mild hemorrhage.

These findings are consistent with skin lesions in pemphigus vulgaris.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Multiple ruptured blisters with surrounding erythema are visible. A single intact blister can be seen in the center of the image.

This finding is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, but histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Herpangina
description:
Oral cavity of a child with fever and odynophagia

Multiple white vesicles 1–2 mm in diameter and an erythematous rim can be seen on the uvula, soft palate, and tonsillar pillars.

These herpes-like vesicles on the posterior oropharynx are characteristic of herpangina, a Coxsackie virus infection mostly seen in young children.

title: Facial features of Down syndrome
description: Upward slanting of the eyelids, prominent epicanthal folds (resulting in almond-shaped eyes), broad and flat nasal bridge, prominent tongue due to macroglossia and muscular hypotonia, low-set ears, and a short neck.

title: Infantile hemangioma
description:
Dome-shaped, crusted, red nodule on the lower left eyelid of a child. Two smaller nodules can be seen above the left eye and on the forehead.

These lesions are also referred to as strawberry hemangiomas and are usually located on the head and neck region.

title: Respirographic patterns
description:
Normal resting respiration: regular, automatic sequences of inspiration and expiration

Kussmaul respiration: regular but deepened breathing (occurs in acidosis)

Biot respiration (cluster respiration): groups (clusters) of irregular breaths followed by periods of apnea (occurs if the respiratory center in the medulla oblongata is damaged)

Cheyne-Stokes respiration: spindle-like, periodic increase and decrease in the depth of respiration; interrupted by short phases of apnea (occurs if the respiratory center in the medulla oblongata is damaged)

Agonal respiration: single, deep breaths with long pauses in between (occurs in cardiac arrest)

title: Cellulitis in superinfected scabies
description:
Diffuse, poorly demarcated erythema and edema associated with small, crusted red patches are visible over the left leg.

These findings are consistent with cellulitis due to scabies infection.

title: First-degree burn (superficial burn)
description:
Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.

title: Second-degree burn (2a; superficial partial-thickness burn)
description:
A singular blister on an erythematous base is visible on the back of the hand.

The presence of a blister within the area of erythema differentiates this from a first-degree burn. No deeper tissue injury suggestive of a higher-degree burn is evident, confirming a second-degree burn.

title: Fourth-degree burn (deeper injury burn)
description:
Photograph of the left hand

There are deep burn injuries visible across all digits, with charred black tissue and exposed bone and tendon. Second-degree burns are present on the palmar skin, indicated by erythema, vesicles, and blistering.

title: Third-degree burn (full-thickness burn)
description:
Photograph of the chest and right shoulder

The skin appears dry, leathery, and black, indicating tissue necrosis (eschar). There is no visible blistering.

These features are characteristic of a third-degree burn, which affects all the layers of the skin (i.e., the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue).

title: Second-degree burn (2b; deep partial-thickness burn)
description:
Back and gluteal region

A large burned area with many vesicles and multiple large, fragile bullae (partially ruptured or deroofed) is visible.

The presence of blistering differentiates this from a first-degree burn. Wound bases appear to extend into deeper layers of the dermis than would be expected with a superficial partial-thickness burn (especially where blisters have been deroofed). There is no obvious tissue necrosis or eschar formation, differentiating this from higher-degree burns.

title: Pyoderma gangrenosum
description:
A purulent ulcerative lesion with central necrosis and erythematous borders is visible on this patient's shin. The surrounding tissue appears to be swollen.

These findings are consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum, which most commonly affects the lower extremities.

title: Pilonidal abscess
description: An infected pilonidal cyst (i.e, pilonidal abscess) with localized swelling and reddening is visible on the upper part of the natal cleft.

title: Hypertropia
description: While the right eye fixates straight, the left eye deviates upwards (hypertropia). This may be due to congenital superior oblique palsy or trochlear nerve palsy.

title: Spherocytosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Multiple spherocytes can be seen (red circles), which have a typical round (rather than biconcave) shape and no central pallor. The erythrocytes vary significantly in size, which is consistent with anisocytosis (red arrows). On electron microscopy (overlay box with drawings based on EM appearance), the spherical shape of spherocytes (1) and normal biconcave erythrocytes (2) can be seen.

title: B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia
description:
Photomicrographs of a peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

The large basophilic cell in the center of each photomicrograph is a lymphoblast, identifiable by its large spherical nucleus surrounded by a thin rim of cytoplasm (high nucleocytoplasmic ratio). The nucleus of the lymphoblasts is often indented (green arrows) and shows fine loose (noncondensed) chromatin. Lymphoblasts differ from lymphocytes, which are smaller in size with smaller nuclei, condensed chromatin, and more cytoplasm.

The presence of numerous lymphoblasts in a peripheral blood smear is indicative of lymphoblastic leukemia. The diagnosis of B-cell ALL was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

Note: Basophilic remnants (Howell-Jolly bodies) are visible within the erythrocytes in the last photomicrograph, indicating (in this case) increased hematopoiesis.

title: Acute promyelocytic leukemia
description:
Photomicrographs of a peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

The large basophilic cells are promyelocytes, identifiable by their eccentric nuclei and abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing numerous Auer rods (rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies). This type of hypergranular leukemic promyelocyte is often still referred to as a “faggot cell” for the resemblance of accumulation of Auer rods to a “bundle of sticks,” although the term is typically avoided today due to its derogatory associations.

The presence of promyelocytes containing Auer rods in a peripheral blood smear is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Note: Basophilic remnants (Howell-Jolly bodies) are visible within most of the erythrocytes, indicating (in this case) increased hematopoiesis.

title: Granular cast in urine sediment
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy; high magnification)

The granular cast in the center of the image is comprised of a hyaline matrix (green overlay) with large droplets of plasma proteins embedded within.

Granular casts can be an indication of proteinuria (e.g., in glomerulonephritis or pyelonephritis). However, they may also be present in healthy individuals (e.g., after severe physical stress).

title: Basophilic stippling of erythrocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

title: Plasma cells
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow specimen (H&E stain)

Plasma cells are large cells that typically have an eccentric nucleus (hatched overlay) with dense, clumped chromatin. The cytoplasm is deeply basophilic due to the abundance of rough endoplasmic reticulum required for the synthesis of antibodies.

title: Renal amyloidosis
description:
Microscopic image of kidney tissue (Congo red stain, approx. 300x)

Two glomeruli containing abnormal hyaline depositions (arrow) are seen in the center of the image.
The interstitial tissue exhibits identical depositions (arrowheads).

Hyaline depositions that stain with Congo red are suggestive of amyloidosis. A definitive diagnosis can only be made by subjecting the sample to polarizing light microscopy.

title: Kidney involvement in amyloidosis (2 of 2)
description:
Polarized light photomicrograph of the kidney (Congo red stain; 300x magnification)

The sediments in the area of the glomeruli and renal interstitium (white arrow; white arrowheads) appear birefringent in the polarized light and bright green in color (characteristic of amyloids).

These are both key diagnostic features of amyloid sediments.

title: Actinic keratosis (solar keratosis)
description: Left temporal and cheek region of a 75-year-old female patient with long-term exposure to UV radiation: All three skin lesions are erythematous. There is an atropic crater in the upper lesion. Yellow-brown, squamous changes can be seen in the lower two lesions. This dermatological findings, in association with the patient's history of long-term UV radiation exposure, most likely indicates actinic keratosis.

title: Right adrenal lesion
description:
MRI Abdomen (T2-weighted fat-saturated sequence, coronal plane) in a 54-year-old patient with anxiety, tachycardia, and vertigo.

A circular, well-defined, and hyperintense structure is demonstrated superior to the right kidney. It demonstrates slightly heterogenous signal and does not invade any surrounding structures. The fluid in the urinary bladder (arrow tips) demonstrates hyperintense signal, as this is a T2 weighted sequence. The image is also fat-saturated, as the adipose tissue in the mid-region of the image is hypointense (white dashed lines). There are areas of failed fat saturation in the upper and lower border of the image, where the fat appears hyperdense, as it would in a sequence without fat saturation(white solid line). Depending on technical and patient factors, fat saturation is not always optimal.

This is an example of a pheochromocytoma. They are usually hyperintense on T2-weighted sequences due to their water content.

title: Orbital cellulitis
description:
Orbital region of a 45-year-old patient with headache, yellowish rhinorrhea, and diplopia

Swelling and erythema of the left eyelid are present.

In light of the patient's other symptoms, especially diplopia, orbital cellulitis is the most probable diagnosis.

title: Gottron papules in dermatomyositis
description:
Erythematous papules are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. This is the typical localization of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

Periungual erythema is also visible.

title: Venous ulcer in chronic venous insufficiency
description:
Posterior aspect of the left lower leg

Several ulcerations with surrounding erythema and xerosis are visible. The ankle appears edematous.

These findings are consistent with chronic venous insufficiency.

title: Chronic venous insufficiency
description:
Yellow-brown skin discoloration (hemosiderin deposition) and edema is present. A varicose vein can be seen on the anterior aspect of the right leg below the knee.

These changes are consistent with CEAP class 4 venous insufficiency.

title: Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
description:
MRI brain (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year-old patient with personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis.

In the white matter of the right hemisphere, there is a large, poorly circumscribed space-occupying lesion, which is hypointense centrally (green overlay) with strong peripheral contrast enhancement (red overlay). The lesion is surrounded by edema (white overlay), suggesting rapid growth and displacement of surrounding structures. The mass effect has also caused a slight midline shift to the contralateral side (white dashed line), and compression of the right lateral ventricle (white arrowheads indicate anterior horn compression).

These radiographic features are typical of a glioblastoma.

title: Finkelstein test
description: The examiner holds the patient's thumb in flexion and applies ulnar deviation to the wrist. The test is positive if the patient feels a sharp pain over the first extensor tendon compartment (along the distal radius). This finding is pathognomonic for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

title: Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA)
description:
Indirect immunofluorescence of p-ANCA on ethanol-fixed neutrophils

Fluorescently labeled antibodies bind to the p-ANCA, forming a thin, band-shaped pattern of fluorescence around the nuclei (hence perinuclear, or “p”-ANCA).

This pattern is characteristic for Churg-Strauss syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis. In contrast, c-ANCA show a cytoplasmic fluorescence pattern.

title: Crusted scabies (Norwegian scabies)
description:
Thick crusts, scaling, and fissures on are visible on both hands and the left arm of this patient with AIDS.

This is a severe case of crusted scabies, a highly contagious form of scabies that typically occurs in immunosuppressed or debilitated patients.

title: Normal transverse colon
description:
Endoscopic view of the transverse colon

The semilunar folds and haustra of the colon are visible. In the transverse colon, the folds typically form an almost triangular shape. The mucosa is glossy and shows a normal vascular pattern.

title: Geographic distribution of schistosomiasis (risk of transmission)
description: Areas in which schistosomiasis (bilharzia) are endemic are highlighted. Clinical features depend on the type of Schistosoma. May manifest in urogenital, intestinal, or hepatosplenic form. On this map, hepatosplenic schistosomiasis is counted as intestinal schistosomiasis.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum
description:
The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) forms a broad, branching system of channels in the cell. It is surrounded by a membrane and is in contact with the nuclear envelope. There are two types of ER, which differ both histologically and functionally.

Rough ER (RER) is tightly packed with ribosomes and forms elongated lamellae. Noncytosolic proteins are synthesized in the RER, whereas cytosolic proteins are directly synthesized in the cytosol on free ribosomes, which partially assemble into polysomes.

Smooth ER (SER) extends across the cytosol with a lattice of sacs or tube-like structures. It also stores carbohydrates and calcium and synthesizes lipids and steroids.

title: Branches of the abdominal aorta
description:
There are:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Note that the superior suprarenal artery originates from the inferior phrenic artery, while the inferior suprarenal artery originates from the renal artery.

title: Germinal center
description:
Microscopic image of a lymph node (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

The pale germinal center contains centroblasts and centrocytes. The darker mantle zone is composed of mature, naive B cells.

title: Parathyroid chief cells
description:
Microscopic image of the parathyroid gland (H&E stain, 100x magnification)

The parathyroid gland is composed primarily of parathyroid hormone-producing chief cells, whose cytoplasm stains white as a result of their glycogen and lipid stores.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Chronic suppurative otitis media
description:
Otoscopic image of the middle ear

The tympanic membrane is completely perforated and the tympanic cavity can be seen. The mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity is edematous and covered by clear secretions.

These findings are diagnostic of chronic suppurative otitis media, which can develop from acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation.

title: Brunner glands
description:
Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (Alcian blue-PAS stain; 200x magnification)

Tissues (from top left to bottom right and from inside out):
– Brunner glands (dark red) surrounded by submucosal connective tissue (light blue)
– Lamina muscularis mucosa (light purple)
– Villous and cryptic mucosa (purple) with the lamina propria (pale purple with dark purple nuclei) on the inside and the lamina epithelialis (purple) with goblet cells (dark blue, large) and enterocytes (dark purple, small) on the outside

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Cholesteatoma
description:
Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane.

Encrustation and darkening of the epithelium can be seen in the posterior upper quadrant marginal to the pars flaccida (arrow). The localization and findings indicate a cholesteatoma.

title: Paneth cells
description:
Photomicrograph of duodenal mucosa (H&E stain; 300x magnification)

Numerous cells with eosinophilic granules in their cytoplasm are visible within the mucosal crypts (examples indicated by green overlay). These cells, known as Paneth cells, store antipathogenic defensins and lysozyme in their granules.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Fallopian tube
description:
Microscopic image of cross section of fallopian tube (H&E stain, 25x magnification)

Tissue layers (from the inside out):

Lumen (white) and highly folded mucosa (dark purple)
Muscularis (purple)
Serosa (light purple)
Branches of the ovarian and uterine artery (purple epithelium with red and white lumen; right)

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mucosal lesions in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)
description:
There is desquamation of the tongue and pustules are visible on the lips.

Mucosal involvement occurs in > 90% of SJS cases. This can help differentiate it from staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), where mucusal membranes are typically not involved.

title: Hashimoto thyroiditis
description:
Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.

title: Intestinal necrosis in mesenteric ischemia
description:
Intraoperative finding

The loops of small intestine appear distended and hyperemic, most likely due to paralytic ileus. The wall of several intestinal loops in the lower section of the image have pronounced gray discoloration, indicating necrosis.

title: Thyroid cancer
description:
Photograph of the anterolateral aspect of the neck

The thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged in the region of the isthmus. A prominent nodule is visible in the right lateral aspect of the neck, which could be a nodule within the right lobe or a right lateral cervical lymphadenopathy.

Thyroid cancer typically manifests as a solitary, painless, firm to hard thyroid nodule with cervical lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis should be confirmed on cytological (i.e., fine-needle aspiration biopsy) or histopathological examination.

title: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)
description:
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) can be used for chromosome analysis. The example shown here involves chromosomes during metaphase.

(1) Chromosomes are prepared and DNA is denatured into single strands. DNA probes are added that are complementary to the DNA segment and bind specifically to it (hybridization). (2) The DNA probe can be directly labeled (direct staining, 2) or chemically modified (3a), which requires the addition of a fluorescent-labeled antibody for detection (indirect staining, 3b). The fluorescent-labeled chromosome (segments) can be examined using a microscope (4).

title: Burkitt lymphoma
description:
Seven-year-old boy from Nigeria

A massive swelling with central ulceration and peripheral scaling is visible above the right mandible.

The age and origin of the boy as well as the localization of the lymphoma most likely indicate the endemic form of Burkitt lymphoma (mainly found in Africa), which is associated with the Epstein Barr virus (EBV).

title: Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct carcinoma)
description:
Histological section of a tumor in the pancreatic head (H&E stain)

Abnormal glands with round and white lumina are visible. Generally, the architecture of the glands is irregular. In some areas, they are densely assembled, whereas in other areas the distance between individual glands is comparably large. On close examination, the glandular epithelial lining differs from normal tissue. Several cells are columnar, whereas others appear flattened. The epithelium is stratified in several areas.

These tissue irregularities are a typical characteristic of adenocarcinoma, which arises from the glandular epithelium. Here, the carcinoma has originated from the glandular epithelium of the bile ducts.

title: Lid hematoma and subconjunctival bleeding
description:
A lower eyelid hematoma on the right side is visible. Subconjunctival bleeding is present temporally as well.

A traumatic cause was reported (fist to the eye), further investigation regarding orbital floor fracture is needed, especially as the patient reports binocular diplopia while looking upwards (not shown), suggesting an infringement of the inferior rectus muscle.

title: Acne vulgaris
description: Several comedones, papules, and partially inflamed pustules are localized to the right cheek.

title: Anterior uveitis
description:
Slit-lamp examination of the anterior part of the eye

Iris details are blurred. This indicates inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. Keratic precipitates, originating from inflammatory material, are present on the endothelium of the cornea.

These are typical signs of anterior uveitis.

title: Radical surgical staging of progressive serous ovarian cancer
description:
Intraoperative specimen from an en bloc pelvic resection of the uterus and uterine adnexa

The uterus and the lateral fallopian tubes (both within green dashed outline) are visible. The ovary located beneath the right fallopian tube (green arrowhead) is the normal yellow color and has a characteristic elongated shape and ridged surface. The left ovary contains a large, serous cyst (white overlay) with a gray wall, which has been opened up and, therefore, collapsed. There are nodular, solid carcinoma lesions on the inner membrane of the cyst (white arrows). Similar nodules (black arrowheads) can be identified on the peritoneum (green overlay) above the uterus, which may correspond to peritoneal carcinomatosis.

title: Graves ophthalmopathy
description:
Orbital area of a 32-year-old patient with Graves disease and symptoms of binocular diplopia

The globe protrudes out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos); the upper eyelids are retracted, resulting in the superior sclera becoming visible (Dalrymple sign). There is, furthermore, conjunctival injection and edema of the eyelids. The combination of findings indicates Graves orbitopathy.

title: Laryngeal papillomatosis
description:
Laryngoscopy of the vocal cords.

At the upper edge of the picture, at the front commissure, there are several pale pink "raspberry shaped" tumors on the mucous membrane. Below these there are other similar nodules.

This appearance is characteristic of laryngeal papilomatosis.

title: Skin hemorrhages in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome
description:
There are multiple small, nonblanching purple macules on the upper thigh, medial aspect of the knee, and anterior lower leg.

This appearance is consistent with purpura due to Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

title: Target lesion in erythema with scaling
description:
Left torso of a patient

A round, erythematous skin lesion with discrete central scaling and typical target-shape appearance is seen.

These findings are highly suggestive of erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease.

title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

title: Graves ophthalmopathy
description:
The eyelids are edematous and there is conjunctival injection. The superior sclerae are visible (Dalrymple sign) due to retraction of the upper eyelids.

The combination of these signs is typical for Graves ophthalmopathy.

title: Erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease
description:
Localization: left chest (supramammillary) and axilla
Lesion: erythema
Description: prominent rim of sharply marginated erythema; annular reddening within the right border; no pain or itching.
Diagnosis: erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease

title: Diabetic foot infection (cellulitis)
description:
Left foot of a patient with diabetes and a history of having stepped on a nail

The big toe appears severely swollen and erythematous with a large ulcer on the medial side of the first metatarsophalangeal joint and a second ulcer more distally. Cellulitis extends to the black line. HbA1c of > 10% confirmed the diagnosis of diabetic foot infection.

title: Mastoiditis
description:
Left retroauricular region of a child

There is pronounced erythema and swelling, with ventral protrusion of the pinna as a result of swelling. The features are typical of mastoiditis, which can occur as a complication of otitis media.

title: Bronchiole with an arterial vessel
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (Ladewig trichrome stain; 200x)

A bronchiole (with a prominent air-filled lumen) is visible at the center of the image. Its wall features ciliated simple columnar epithelium and circular bundles of smooth muscle. Note that, unlike in a bronchus, there is no cartilage and glands. An arterial vessel is visible left of the bronchiole. Its entire lumen is filled with erythrocytes. The bronchiole and arterial vessel are surrounded by numerous air-filled alveoli.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Cross-section of the trachea
description:
Photomicrograph of a tracheal biopsy sample (Ladewig trichrome stain; 50x magnification)

Tissue layers (from top to bottom and the outside in):

- Mediastinal connective tissue (white)
- Plate of hyaline cartilage (purple; hatched green overlay)
- Perichondrium (dark purple; black overlay)
- Smooth muscle (red; yellow overlay)
- Lamina propria with elastic fibers (red; red overlay)
- Respiratory epithelium (pink; green overlay)
- Tracheal lumen (white; hatched red overlay)

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Acute otitis media
description:
Otoscopic image of the tympanic membrane

There is bulging and erythema of the tympanic membrane, which appears dull and thickened. The light reflex is visible in the posterior upper quadrant (should normally appear in the anterior lower quadrant) and appears widened and heterogeneous due to bulging of the membrane.

title: Endometrium, early follicular phase
description:
Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E stain; 100x magnification)

Tissue layers (from bottom left to top right and from inside out):
– Myometrium (light purple)
– Endometrium (dark purple) with endometrial glands (white)

During the beginning of the proliferative phase, the endometrial glands are still relatively straight, unlike the cork-screw shape they adopt during the late proliferative and the luteal phase.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Cervix with external os of uterus
description:
Photomicrograph of cervical tissue (H&E stain; 25x magnification)

The image shows the junction between the cervical canal (top) and the vagina (bottom), where the simple columnar squamous mucosal epithelium of the endometrium transitions to the nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the vaginal mucosa.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Oral candidiasis
description:
Oral mucosa of an HIV-positive patient

There are several distinct white plaques on the soft palate and uvula.

title: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ due to chronic arsenic exposure
description:
A single, asymmetric cutaneous lesion with an irregular border and varied pigmentation can be seen.

Histologic examination revealed squamous cell carcinoma in situ.

title: Chancre of the glans penis in primary syphilis
description:
A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

title: Aphthous stomatitis
description:
Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.

title: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
description:
Area below the popliteal fossa of the right knee (image mirrored and rotated left by 90°) of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

title: Orbital cellulitis
description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

title: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci)
description:
Scanning electron photomicrograph

A joined pair of spherical cocci (diplococci) is visible.

title: Herpetic gingivostomatitis
description:
Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

title: Herpes labialis
description:
Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

title: Giardia lamblia during replication
description:
Colorized scanning electron micrograph

The protozoal parasite Giardia lamblia (brown) appears here during a late stage of replication, which explains the heart shape. Giardia lamblia uses flagella (purple) for motility. Therefore, it classified as a flagellate. It is the causative agent of giardiasis.

title: Trypanosoma brucei
description:
Blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Extracellular trypanosomes (Trypanosoma brucei) are visible with a typical streamlined and tapered shape and a flagellum that arises from the basal body.

title: Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts
description:
Fecal sample of a patient with cryptosporidiosis

Several round oocysts (red) that contain a large number of sporozoites. Oocysts are highly resistant to environmental factors and disinfectants (also to chlorine, e.g., in drinking water). They are the infective form of the parasite Cryptosporidium parvum.

title: High-grade serous carcinoma of ovary
description:
Photomicrograph of specimen from an ovarian cystic mass (H&E stain, medium magnification):

The carcinoma has a complex papillary architecture, with stromal cores lined by atypical, intensely staining (serous) epithelial cells. At higher magnification, these cells show hyperchromatic (dark blue staining), pleomorphic nuclei that often contain mitotic or apoptotic figures.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Hodgkin lymphoma (immunohistochemistry for CD30)
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Spinal disk herniation with migration (1/3)
description:
MRI lumbar spine (T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

The L4–5 disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

title: Pterygium
description:
Slit-lamp photography of the left eye

A fibrovascular proliferation (marked by overlay) originating from the nasal conjunctiva is seen growing onto the cornea.

This is the typical appearance and localization of a pterygium.

title: Chocolate cyst in endometriosis
description:
A large bisected ovarian cyst

The cyst is filled with coagulated blood from endometriosis, giving it a chocolate-like appearance.

title: Spinal disk herniation with migration (3/3)
description:
MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The desiccated disk at L4–5 is hypointense and the disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

Hatched green overlay: normal intervertebral disks

title: Total hip replacement
description:
(1) Removal of the damaged femoral head from the acetabulum and resection of the femoral head and neck along the line between the greater and the lesser trochanter (red line)
(2) Enlargement of the acetabulum and the medullary cavity of the femur
(3) Insertion of the prosthesis stem into the femoral canal and insertion of the artificial socket and inlay into the widened acetabulum
4) Reduction of the prosthetic head into the prosthetic socket

title: Congenital melanocytic nevi
description: Extensive congenital melanocytic nevi in an infant, showing the characteristic variable coloration.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Flaccid bullae and gray-white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

title: Oral candidiasis
description:
There is a distinct area of white plaque on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

This finding is characteristic oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush).

title: Cholelithiasis
description:
Ultrasound gallbladder (longitudinal plane)

Several dependent hyperechoic structures (green overlay) in the gallbladder lumen (G) absorb a portion of the ultrasound beam (dashed white line), resulting in posterior acoustic shadowing (hatched green overlay).

Gallbladder calculi are characteristically seen as mobile dependent hyperechoic intraluminal structures that produce acoustic shadowing. Shadowing is dependent on stone size, but independent of stone composition, calcium content, and shape.

L: liver; green outline: gallbladder wall

title: Emphysematous cholecystitis
description:
Transabdominal ultrasound (right upper quadrant; longitudinal view)

The gallbladder wall is thickened (green outline). Its inner and outer walls appear hyperechoic and the intervening tissue (between the white lines) appears hypoechoic, indicating acute inflammation of the gallbladder wall. Hyperechoic areas within the gallbladder wall (blue and yellow boxes) indicate intramural gas (green overlay in magnified boxes).

Intramural air is a characteristic feature of acute emphysematous cholecystitis, which is a variant of acute cholecystitis caused by infection with gas-producing organisms.

G: gallbladder; L: liver; In: intestines

title: Tinea corporis
description:
Localization: typically the upper body and arms
Lesion: local, multiple, eczematous, pruritic, red lesions with marginal pustules and scaling
Diagnosis: tinea corporis

title: Vitiligo
description:
Localization: dorsal aspect of the forearm

Lesion: characteristic, well demarcated, irregularly shaped, white macules

title: Nail pitting in psoriasis
description:
Multiple, small round depressions are seen in the nails.

This appearance is caused by the presence of parakeratotic cells (cells with impaired keratinization) in the nail matrix. Over time, these cells grow into the nail plate from the nail matrix, where they erupt from the horny layer, leaving small visible depressions.

title: Colosigmoidal intussusception in a 4-year-old girl
description:
Contrast enema; lateral view
Rectum and lower sigmoid are filled with contrast (dark); sudden interruption of contrast in the upper sigmoid (green area).
S = spine
LE = lower extremity

title: Heberden and Bouchard nodes
description:
Nodular thickening of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ) can be seen.

This appearance is characteristic of bony swellings caused by osteophyte formation in osteoarthritis. At the DIPJ these are called “Heberden nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger and both index fingers), and at the PIPJ they are called “Bouchard nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger).

title: Echinococcosis
description:
Transverse CT abdomen

A single hypodense septated cyst in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay) can be seen. The cyst is most likely due to Echinococcus granulosus.

L: liver; S: stomach; V: vertebra; A: aorta; K: kidney; Sp: spleen

title: Hemorrhagic stroke in MCA territory
description:
Frontal brain section (ventral view)

There is a sharply demarcated region of liquefactive necrosis (green overlay) in the right hemisphere. The necrotic area corresponds to the vascular territory of the right middle cerebral artery.

title: Auricular hematoma following trauma
description: There is swelling and ecchymosis of the auricle. Swelling is most pronounced in the anterosuperior aspect, where it obscures the normal anatomical landmarks.

title: Disseminated plaque psoriasis
description: Multiple erythematous, partially confluent plaques with silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor and flexor sides of the legs.

title: Lichen sclerosus (et atrophicus)
description:
Upper back of a female patient

Multiple white plaques with a dry, wrinkled appearance are visible.

These findings are suggestive of extragenital lichen sclerosus. However, the diagnosis requires histological confirmation.

title: Actinic keratosis of the scalp
description:
Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adult

Multiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.

These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

title: Froment sign
description: The patient is asked to tightly pinch a piece of paper between the tips of the thumb and index finger or, as shown here, between the thumb and the second metacarpal. Inability to keep the thumb's interphalangeal joint extended while performing this maneuver is referred to as the “Froment sign,” which occurs with ulnar nerve palsy because the flexor pollicis longus (innervated by the median nerve) compensates for the action of the weak adductor pollicis (innervated by the ulnar nerve).

title: Petechial bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
description: The lower leg displays numerous red spots, each about the size of a pinhead, that do not blanch or disappear when pressed. These are indicative of petechial hemorrhages related to thrombocytopenia.

title: Medulloblastoma in a child
description:
Head MRI (T2 weighted image)

Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

title: Noncaseating granuloma in sarcoidosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy specimen (high magnification)

Purple-stained epithelioid cells forming circular patterns (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.

This pattern is characteristic of noncaseating granulomas, which are a typical finding in sarcoidosis.

title: Porphyria cutanea tarda
description:
A single blister can be seen on the left ring finger. Erosions, crusts, scars, and areas of hyperpigmentation are visible on the back of the left hand.

These features are characteristic of porphyria cutanea tarda.

title: Porphyria cutanea tarda
description:
Numerous erosions, excoriations, and scars are visible on the back of the left hand.

These features are characteristic of porphyria cutanea tarda

title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
description:
X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a child

The left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.

This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.

title: Amyloid plaques in Alzheimer disease
description:
Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

title: Myositis ossificans
description: X-ray of the left knee; AP view. Overlay shows calcification of soft tissue in the area of the distal part of the vastus medialis muscle (heterotopic ossification) as a result of myositis ossificans. (Fe = femur, T = tibia, F = fibula)

title: Mycosis fungoides
description: Left upper arm, shoulder, and back with sharply demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous scaling lesions that are severely pruritic.

title: Acute and chronic vertebral fractures
description:
MRI lumbar spine (left: STIR image; right: T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

Compression deformities of the T8, T10, and L4 vertebrae (green overlays) are visible. The T8 and T10 fractures are hyperintense on the STIR image, indicating that they are recent. The compressed superior endplate of L4 is iso- to hypointense, indicating an old or chronic deformity. The hypointense appearance of the L2–3 intervertebral disc (green circle) on the STIR image indicates disc degeneration.

title: Diverticulosis
description:
Double-contrast barium enema of the colon

Multiple diverticula in the colon can be seen (examples circled in green).

title: Omphalitis in a newborn
description:
Ventral view on the umbilical region of a newborn (5 days old)

The umbilicus and surrounding tissue appear erythematous. The umbilicus is edematous and still connected to a necrotic, reddish-black umbilical stump.

These features likely indicate omphalitis, which may progress to sepsis and should therefore be treated with systemic antibiotics. The blue clamp remains in place for 48–72h after birth for the umbilical cord to dry out.

title: Fournier gangrene
description: Necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal region

title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
description:
A pink multinodular lesion with central indentation is visible adjacent to the medial canthus of the left eye and the lower eyelid. Dried crusts can be seen on the surface of the lesion, suggesting ulceration.

This is the typical appearance of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

title: Bullous pemphigoid
description:
Multiforme lesions and serous fluid-filled blisters of various sizes are visible over the entire anterior aspect of the patient's body. Marked erythema is also present.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

title: Malar rash in systemic lupus erythematosus
description:
An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."

title: Hippocratic nails and finger clubbing
description:
The nails are enlarged and rounded with increased convexity (Hippocratic nails). There is club-shaped swelling of the distal phalanges in all fingers.

These findings indicate an underlying pathology causing chronic hypoxemia.

title: Erysipelas of the breast
description: Extensive, sharply demarcated erythema can be seen on the left breast. Cracked skin at the lower edge of the areola is also visible.

title: Uterine leiomyoma
description: Limited assessment possible as only one image is accessible: This image is of a transvaginal ultrasound, whereby the transducer is positioned near the cervix and the sound waves are sent cranially, resulting in a sagittal section of the uterine corpus (D) and cervix (C). The endometrium (A) lies central in the uterus and is termed endometrial stripe in ultrasound. There are three suspected myomas (B) in the myometrium, with both cranially located myomas heterogeneous and hypoechoic and the myoma at the bottom of the image demonstrating calcifications.

title: Osteochondroma
description: Bony exostosis on the lateral right distal tibial metaphysis and deformation of the right fibula

title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
description:
Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

title: Giant cell arteritis
description: The superficial temporal artery is prominent, which is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

title: Necrobiosis lipoidica
description:
Several well-demarcated, irregularly shaped, yellow-erythematous plaques are visible on both lower legs.

This appearance is characteristic of necrobiosis lipoidica.

title: Maculopapular rash in secondary syphilis
description:
Partially confluent and partially scaling red papules and macules of ∼2–5 mm diameter are visible on the palms and wrists.

This appearance is typical of secondary syphilis.

title: Malum perforans
description:
Well-demarcated ulcerations are visible on the plantar aspect of this patient's left foot

This appearance together with a consistent medical history is suggestive of diabetic foot ulcers, which are likely caused by diabetic polyneuropathy.

title: Klinefelter syndrome
description: Testicular hypoplasia and bilateral gynecomastia are characteristic features of Klinefelter syndrome.

title: Psoriasis capitis
description:
Silver-white scaling and plaques are visible on the scalp and forehead parallel to the hairline.

This is the characteristic appearance of psoriasis capitis.

title: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis 1/2
description:
Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boy

Cobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.

This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.

title: Acute anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 85/min
- Normal cardiac axis (leads I, II, and III positive, but difficult to interpret because of the ST changes)
- ST elevation in V2–V6, aVL, and slightly in I
- Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF

title: Skin lesion in scabies
description:
Localization: periumbilical region

Lesion: papules, erythema, excoriations

Description: elongated, erythematous papules, inflamed nodules, and excoriations

title: Lichen planus
description:
Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

title: Red blood cell cast
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

A cast consisting of multiple red blood cells is visible.

RBC casts are typically seen in patients with glomerular damage (e.g., glomerulonephritis).

title: Dermatomyositis
description:
Histological section of muscle from the upper thigh (H&E stain)

In addition to the normal musculature, the following pathological findings are visible: pronounced interstitial (green overlay) and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration (V = vessel), muscle fiber necrosis and resorption (green arrow), and perifascicular atrophy (green hatched area), which is characteristic of dermatomyositis.

title: Acute leukemia in myelodysplastic syndrome
description: Bone marrow smear in iron stain (Prussian blue): Excess of immature blasts (B) and presence of ringed sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are erythrocytes with iron-loaded (hence blue) mitochondria (arrows). The presence of ringed sideroblasts indicates ineffective erythropoiesis.

title: Fungal endophthalmitis
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

White and fluffy vitreous or retinal infiltrates are visible. Retinal details are blurred through the vitreous cellular infiltrate.

Candida is a common cause of fungal endophthalmitis. In patients with a systemic candida infection, endogenous endophthalmitis is a possible complication, as in the case here.

title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, erythematous lesions are visible in the perianal region.

title: Sickle cell disease with drepanocytes and target cells
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

There are crescent to sickle-shaped erythrocytes (green overlay, black circles), which are referred to as drepanocytes or sickle cells. Erythrocytes with a red center and a white contouring ring (T), known as target cells, are visible on the left.

Drepanocytes are pathognomonic of sickle cell disease. Target cells can be found in sickle cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

title: Fibrinous pericarditis
description:
Macroscopic specimen of the heart showing the pericardium

The pericardium is covered by a fibrinous exudate, which is assembled in long, gray-white, villus-like strands. Fibrinous pericarditis occurs as a concomitant disease in 10% of patients with uremia.

title: Intertrigo
description:
Left submammary region of an older female adult

An extensive, well-defined erythema is seen. The lesion features multiple macules in its periphery (plus some macules surrounding the lesion).

This is the typical appearance of intertrigo.

title: Swan neck deformity
description: Proximal interphalangeal joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal joint flexion

title: Lateral patellar dislocation
description: The localized swelling in the distal upper thigh is the patella, which is laterally dislocated. Lateral patellar dislocation is much more common than medial dislocation.

title: Thenar atrophy secondary to median nerve injury
description: Atrophy of the left and right thenars (abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis muscles) secondary to bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome

title: Eosinophilia in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
description:
Photomicrograph of bone marrow (very high magnification)

The bone marrow is hypercellular, with an increased number of neutrophils and precursor cells (red arrows), and numerous eosinophils with red cytoplasmic granules (E).

Eosinophilia is typical of, but not specific for CML.

title: Squamous cell carcinoma
description:
A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

title: Esophageal barium swallow with barium sulfate in two phases in Zenker diverticulum
description: The predominantely left-sided, dorsal contrast-filled structure in the upper esophagus most likely indicates Zenker diverticulum.

title: Herpangina
description:
Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

title: Squamous cell carcinoma
description:
A solitary, partially pigmented nodule is visible on this patient's lower lip.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

title: Atopic dermatitis
description: Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.

title: Porphyria cutanea tarda
description:
A fluid-filled blister is visible on the index finger. Deep ulcers and superficial erosions can be seen on the back of the left hand.

These features are consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda.

title: Osteosarcoma
description:
Microscopic image of the bone marrow of the lateral epicondyle of the femur (van Gieson's stain)

The atypical, polymorphic, mesenchymal cells (green overlay), which synthesize the reticular osteoid (blue overlay), are characteristic for osteosarcoma.

title: Condylomata lata in secondary syphilis
description:
Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

title: Suspicious breast mass
description:
Mammography (right breast; craniocaudal view)

A mass (circled) with suspicious features, including high density and indistinct margins, is visible in the posterior third of the breast.

title: Graves ophthalmopathy
description:
The patient's sclerae are visible at the upper margin of the cornea (Dalrymple sign) due a widening of the palpebral fissure caused by upper eye lid retraction. In addition, chemosis and conjunctival injection are evident.

This combination of these signs is classical for Graves ophthalmopathy.

title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
description:
X-ray of the abdomen

Dilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

title: Common warts
description: Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

title: Pulmonary tuberculosis in the left upper lobe
description:
X-ray chest (PA view; lateral view)

A heterogeneous partially circumscribed consolidation is present in the left upper lobe (green overlay).

The consolidation represented pulmonary parenchymal tuberculosis.

title: Left shift to promyelocyte stage in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.

Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

title: Congenital CMV infection
description: Ultrasound of the CNS, coronal section: dilated lateral ventricles with hyperechoic deposits that are compatible with intraventricular hemorrhage (green areas). (Arrow = periventricular calcification)

title: Cricothyroidotomy
description: Diagram showing an emergency cricothyroidotomy, which is typically performed if attempts to intubate have been unsuccessful. An incision is made through the cricothyroid membrane, and a cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted through the incision site. Cricothyroidotomy allows ventilation of the patient until a more definitive airway is placed.

title: Zenker diverticulum
description:
Barium swallow

The contrast-enhanced mass in the upper esophagus is most likely a Zenker diverticulum.

title: Intraepithelial precancerous skin lesion: lentigo maligna
description:
A 3-cm large, irregularly pigmented macule with irregular borders and surrounding mottling is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of lentigo maligna. However, dermoscopy should be performed to further assess and classify the lesion.

title: Chronic rhinosinusitis
description:
CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)

The ethmoid sinuses are opacified (hatched green overlay) and there is lobulated thickening of the walls of the maxillary sinuses (green overlay). The findings indicate nasal polyps and retention cysts.

title: Vocal cord nodules
description:
Laryngoscopic image of the vocal folds of an adult with increasing hoarseness of voice.

Right picture: vocal folds in the respiratory position. Pinhead sized tumors lie on both sides, between the middle and anterior thirds of the vocal folds (place of the highest oscillation amplitude).
Left picture: same finding in phonation position.

Diagnosis: vocal cord nodules (phonation nodules).

title: Dermoid cyst
description:
Ultrasound of the right ovary

A partially cystic (white overlay), partially solid tumor (green overlay) of the ovary with an approximate diameter of 35 mm can be seen.

This finding is consistent with a dermoid cyst (mature teratoma).

title: Tinea capitis
description:
Multiple patches with fine white scaling are visible on the back of this patient's head.

This appearance is typical of tinea capitis (commonly caused by Microsporum canis)

title: Popliteal (Baker) cyst
description: Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).

title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
description:
Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boy

A large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

title: Karyogram in balanced Robertsonian translocation (14/21)
description: The karyogram for karyotype 45,XX,t(14;21) shows the translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to the long arm of chromosome 14 with the elimination of the respective short arms and fusion of the chromosomes.

title: Shingles in a 10-year-old child
description:
Multiple, partly confluent vesicles with a strict dermatomal distribution are visible.

This appearance is suggestive of shingles.

title: Erythema nodosum in sarcoidosis
description:
Erythema localized to the extensor surface of both legs.

There are red, nodular skin lesions due to inflammation of the subcutaneous tissue.

title: Scaphoid fracture
description:
Radiograph of the right hand: scaphoid fracture (arrow) following a fall on the outstretched hand.
(1 = scaphoid; 2 = lunate; 3 = triquetrum; 4 = pisiform; 5 = trapezium; 6 = trapezoid, 7 = capitate; 8 = hamate; I–V = metacarpals; R = radius; U = ulna)

title: Tinea corporis (ringworm)
description: Four round, erythematous plaques with central clearing and raised, scaly borders are visible on this patient's arm.

title: Atopic dermatitis
description: There are erythematous papules and vesicles coalescing into plaques with hemorrhagic and honey-colored crusts on the face and neck of this infant.

title: Bilateral ischemic stroke in the calcarine sulcus
description:
Coronal brain section

There is bilateral brown discoloration of the tissue below the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle and blurring of the cortex-medulla margin in the calcarine sulcus (red lines).

These findings are the result of thromboembolic infarcts of the posterior cerebral arteries (outlined in green).

A1: vascular territory of the anterior cerebral artery (green overlay); A2: middle cerebral artery (yellow overlay); A3: posterior cerebral artery (red overlay); 1: hippocampus; 3: corpus callosum; 4: lateral ventricle; 5: cingulate sulcus

title: Oral leukoplakia
description:
Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

title: Tinea capitis
description: Multiple, round lesions with hair loss caused by Microsporum canis.

title: Right anterior pneumothorax
description:
CT thorax (axial view; lung window)

There is a loss of bronchovascular markings over the anterior aspect of the right lung.

These findings are pathognomonic of right anterior pneumothorax.

title: Gouty tophi due to urate crystal deposition in bones and soft tissues
description: White chalky, nodules in the first and second toes (left)

title: Erythematous lesions in erythema multiforme
description:
Lower thigh and knee of a patient after antibiotic intake

Multiple erythematous, well-demarcated lesions can be seen. The lesions vary in size and shape, and some have merged to form larger lesions. The lesions show central erythema surrounded by a pale pink ring, characteristic of target lesions.

title: Endometriosis of the appendix
description:
Photomicrograph of appendix specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The appendix mucosa shows crypts (arrows), and the adjoining lamina propria contains lymph follicles (L). There is an internal circular muscular layer (Mc) and an external longitudinal muscular layer (Ml), which is typical for the GI tract.

The subserous connective and fat tissue of the mesoappendix and the external longitudinal muscular layer contain ectopic endometrial glands (green overlay) that are surrounded by a dark (basophilic) stroma, which is consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis.

title: Neurofibromas
description:
Multiple papules and nodules of varying sizes located on the upper back.

Numerous neurofibromas are pathognomonic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease).

title: Septic arthritis of the shoulder
description:
Scintigraphy: increased radionuclide activity in the left shoulder joint
Diagnosis: septic arthritis of the shoulder

title: Schistocytes in hemolytic uremic syndrome
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes) with a normal convex border on one side and concave or straight border on the other side (examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible. The majority of erythrocytes appear normal.

Schistocytes are a typical diagnostic finding in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

title: Polymorphous light eruption
description: Erythematous papules and lesions with irregular borders are visible on the cheeks and forehead.

title: Invasive breast carcinoma of no special type (invasive ductal carcinoma) 1/3
description:
Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white).
