The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

title: Progressive muscular dystrophy (Duchenne and Becker subtypes)
description:
Photomicrograph of muscle tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is considerable variability in the size of each muscle fiber due to progressive destruction and fibrosis of the myofibres. Many fibroblasts are visible interspersed between the muscle cells and a large necrotic muscle fiber is seen at the left of the image. Much of the normal contractile muscle fibres have been replaced by hypertrophic connective and adipose tissue.

These are characteristic histological features of muscular dystrophy.

title: Intertrochanteric femoral fracture
description: AP radiograph of the right hip: Because of the low quality, the structure of the greater trochanter (T) is poorly defined; the dotted line shows a possible contour. A radiolucent fracture gap is located in between the greater and lesser trochanter and at the base of the lesser trochanter (t), possibly indicating an intertrochanteric femoral fracture.

title: Stretch marks (striae)
description:
Multiple vertical, approx. 2-cm wide, violaceous striae are visible along the lateral and ventral thorax of this 32-year-old, overweight man.

This constellation of features suggests Cushing syndrome.

title: Hemochromatosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample (Prussian blue stain)

Prussian blue stains the iron deposits dark blue (green arrows) and the nuclei bright red. A portal triad (P; green overlay) is visible in the lower left corner.

title: Venous leg ulcer in chronic venous insufficiency
description:
Medial aspect of the right foot

An ulcer with surrounding erythema is visible on the medial malleolus of the right foot.

These findings are characteristic of venous ulcer secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.

title: Allergic contact dermatitis
description:
Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

title: Eczema herpeticum
description:
Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

title: Basal cell carcinoma
description:
A well-defined nodule with central ulceration, telangiectasia, and pearly-pink rolled-out borders is visible beneath the medial canthus of the left eye.

The location and appearance of this lesion are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma.

title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
description:
An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
description:
Fundus photography of the eye

In the upper part of the image, the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (green overlay). This part of the retina is detached due to a retinal tear (red overlay).

title: Lichen planus
description:
Lacelike papular lines are visible on the penis, extending from the glans to the shaft.

This feature is suggestive of Wickham striae, a typical finding in Lichen planus.

title: Aminopenicillin-related exanthem in infectious mononucleosis
description:
Upper body of a patient with a pruritic rash associated with the administration of an aminopenicillin for suspected bacterial tonsillitis.

There is an erythematous, patchy, partly confluent, maculopapular rash.

This appearance is typical of an aminopenicillin-related rash, seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis.

title: Erythrasma
description:
There is a ∼ 15-cm red-brown, sharply demarcated, distally extending patch in the right groin area, which shows partial scaling.

This is the typical appearance of erythrasma.

title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
description: H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

title: Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm
description:
Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen (transverse section at L3; arterial phase)

Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (5 x 5.5 cm) with peripheral, hypodense thrombotic material (red overlay) and central, hyperdense contrast-enhanced blood (green overlay). A light calcification of the aortic wall is visible (red outline).

title: Basal cell carcinoma
description:
A solitary lesion (~4 cm in diameter) with a central crater, and pearly, rolled out borders is visible on the forehead.

These features are typical of basal cell carcinoma, a type of slow-growing lesion that most commonly presents on sun-exposed areas of the body.

title: Shingles
description:
A widespread erythematous papular rash is visible over the left inguinal region. Several individual and confluent vesicles can be seen in a T12-L1 dermatomal distribution. Additional lesions are visible beyond this distribution.

This is the characteristic appearance of shingles (herpes zoster infection).

title: Dactylitis
description:
The entire left index finger of this patient with psoriatic arthritis is swollen.

This appearance is typical of dactylitis, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including spondyloarthropathies, infections, and sickle cell disease.

title: Erysipelas
description: Extensive, sharply demarcated erythema with swelling, bullae, and necrosis is visible on the right anterior distal forearm and wrist.

title: Seborrheic keratosis
description:
A sharply demarcated, pigmented macule with a stuck on appearance

This appearance is consistent with seborrheic keratosis. Dermatoscopic examination should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Cerebral metastasis in lung carcinoma 2/2
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with lung carcinoma

A solitary, well-circumscribed, predominantly hyperintense mass (hatched overlay) in the left occipital lobe is accompanied by perifocal edema (green overlay).

The lesion is consistent with a cerebral metastasis.

title: Acne
description:
The skin of the patient shows multiple papules and pustules on an erythematous base. In addition, several open comedones with the characteristic darkening (blackheads) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acne vulgaris.

title: Free intraperitoneal air
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view in left lateral decubitus position)

The left lateral decubitus, or left side down decubitus, radiograph was obtained with the patient's left (L) side dependent on the x-ray table. The image is centered on the nondependent right (R) hemidiaphragm. Free intraperitoneal air (pneumoperitoneum; green overlay) is interposed between the right hemidiaphragm and liver.

title: Achondroplasia
description:
Short stature and prominent lumbar lordosis can be seen in this 11-year-old patient.

This is the characteristic appearance of achondroplasia.

title: Maculopapular rash in secondary syphilis
description:
An erythematous maculopapular rash with scaling is visible on the left palm.

A rash with this appearance typical for secondary syphilis.

title: Melanosis coli
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon in a patient with a history of laxative abuse

The colonic mucosa is lined with a pattern of sharply demarcated, dark brown hyperpigmentations, caused by the deposition of anthraquinone pigments from a plant-based laxative (e.g., senna gylcosides or aloe emodin) in the mucosa. The mucosa's surface texture and the colon's haustral folds are unchanged.

title: Synovial fluid analysis in septic arthritis
description: Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

title: Hodgkin lymphoma
description:
Histopathologic image of Hodgkin lymphoma (CD30 immunostain)

Reed-Sternberg cells (middle of the image). CD30 is a surface marker expressed on Reed-Sternberg cells and stains red.

title: Seborrheic keratosis
description:
Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

title: Purpura in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome
description:
Purple nonblanching macules of various sizes, consistent with purpura (larger macules) and petechiae (smaller macules), are visible.

These findings are consistent with purpura in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

title: Invasive breast carcinoma of no special type (invasive ductal carcinoma) 3/3
description:
Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At high magnification, the tubular formations of the carcinoma can be seen in detail, showing hyperchromatic nuclei and an increased nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio (i.e., shifted in favor of the nuclei). These changes cause the marked dark blue/basophilic appearance of the tumor tissue in the overview magnification.

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

title: Osteopetrosis
description: Anteroposterior x-ray of the hand of an 8-year-old girl: pronounced metaphyseal densities in line with increased sclerotization of the bones of the fingers.

title: Cataract
description:
Slit-lamp photograph of a left eye

The pupil is dilated. The lens (solid green overlay) appears cloudy and yellow.

This is the typical appearance of cataracts.

Dashed lines: optical path from the slit-lamp to the eye
Hatched green overlay: optical cross-section of the cornea, produced by the light of the slit-lamp

title: Glandular cystic, simple endometrial hyperplasia
description:
Microscopic image of the endometrium (H&E stain)

Endometrial tissue obtained via fractional curettage. The glandular cystic endometrial hyperplasia is characterized by an increase in both stromal and glandular cells. Enlarged, dilated mucosal glands (swiss cheese pattern) are located between the abundant stromal tissue.

title: Low-grade glioma
description:
MRI head (top left: T1-weighted, axial plane; top right: T2-weighted, axial plane; bottom left: T1-weighted, with contrast, axial plane; bottom right: T1-weighted, with contrast, coronal plane)

There is a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe (green overlay), which demonstrates hypointense signal on the T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighting with no significant surrounding edema. No significant enhancement is demonstrated on the post-contrast sequences.

title: Hematoma of the nasal septum
description: Bilateral, firm, balloon-like swelling of the nasal mucosa.

title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

title: Hiatal hernia
description: Barium swallow, AP radiograph showing the contrast-enhanced esophagus (1), the herniated esophageal sphincter (arrow), the sliding hiatal hernia (2), and the stomach (3) with typical contour.

title: Atelectasis
description:
Chest x-ray (AP view, supine position)

Mediastinal shift (big arrow) to the left.
Left lung reduced in volume (outline with small arrows). Basal opacities are seen. The left hemidiaphragm is not demarcated.

title: Pineal region meningioma
description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, transverse and sagittal views, with contrast)

Round lesion in the pineal region (green overlay) showing pronounced and homogeneous enhancement (snowball appearance). There is no perifocal edema, which indicates slow tumor growth. The discretely dilated third ventricle (3) is located in front of the lesion, the dilated lateral ventricle (1) is located laterally (upper image) and cranially (lower image) to the lesion, and the cistern of the great cerebral vein (2, white hatched outline) can be seen caudal to it.

title: Diaphragmatic rupture
description: AP chest X-ray of a 29-year-old patient with chest trauma after a motor-vehicle crash: the tip of the central venous catheter on the right side (black arrows) projects onto the right atrium. The left hemidiaphragm (black dotted line) is much higher than the right one. The stomach is located within the thorax, as can be seen by the circled gastric bubble. The lung tissue shows streaky densities, which hints towards intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The combination of these findings most likely indicates a ruptured diaphragm with a stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity.

title: Anal cancer
description:
A friable, exophytic mass is visible at the anal orifice.

These features suggest an anal cancer.

title: ECG in (peri)myocarditis
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm
- Heart rate approx. 65/min
- Normal heart axis (R > S in I and aVF)
- PR-interval duration approx. 120–160 ms
- Narrow QRS complex (approx. 100 ms)
- Concave ST elevations from a descending R wave in leads II, aVF, and V5–V6
- ST elevation (I and V4)

Unlike myocardial infarction, perimyocarditis does not manifest with ST elevations that correspond with the anatomy of coronary arteries.

title: Tzanck cell
description:
Photomicrograph of a smear from the base of a herpetic (HSV-1) gingivostomatitis lesion (Pappenheim stain; very high magnification)

A multinucleated giant cell (Tzanck cell) can be seen, indicating a positive Tzanck test.

title: Atopic dermatitis
description: Papulovesicular erythema and hyperpigmentation are visible on the popliteal fossae of both legs

title: Nonbullous impetigo
description: Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

title: Lichen planus
description: Linear, lymphocyte infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction

title: Monteggia fracture-dislocation
description:
X-ray of the elbow (lateral view, positive mode)

Fracture of the proximal ulna with anterior dislocation of the head of the radius.
The radiodensity of soft tissue anterior to the elbow joint is also increased.

title: Superficial spreading melanoma
description:
Upper back

An asymmetrical lesion approx. 16 mm in diameter is visible.

This lesion fulfills the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria for melanoma. The diagnosis should be confirmed by performing a full-thickness excisional biopsy.

title: Ascaris lumbricoides (giant roundworm)
description: A type of soil-transmitted helminth; 15-cm long specimen.

title: Stage 3 decubitus (pressure) ulcer
description: A decubitus ulcer with loss of all skin layers and subcutaneous involvement is visible to the right of the intergluteal cleft.

title: Cardiomegaly and prominent thoracic aorta in aortic regurgitation
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of aortic regurgitation

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left ventricle, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are prominent as a result of dilatation.

title: Erythroderma
description: Back of a 68-year-old patient showing generalized erythematosquamous skin.

title: Bowen disease
description:
Photograph of an area of skin on a patient's trunk

A well-defined erythematous plaque with scaling is visible.

This is the typical appearance of Bowen disease, i.e., squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin

title: Nephroblastoma
description:
MRI abdomen (T2-weighted with fat saturation; coronal plane) of a 3-year-old child

A large heterogeneous but relatively well-circumscribed solid mass is centered within the lower pole of the left kidney. Normal renal tissue is seen cranial to the mass. The hypointense areas of the mass suggest soft tissue, whereas the areas of hyperintensity suggest hemorrhage or necrosis.

Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), the most common type of pediatric renal cancer, with a peak incidence at 3–4 years of age.

title: Hirschsprung disease in a 5-day-old male newborn
description: Distended, bulging abdomen that is tender on palpation. Diagnosis performed by rectal suction biopsy: Hirschsprung's disease

title: Angioedema
description: The severely swollen lower lip is most likely angioedema.

title: Lytic calvarial lesions in multiple myeloma
description:
X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

title: Crohn disease
description:
Photomicrograph of colonic mucosal tissue (H&E stain; 450x magnification)

Colonic crypts (example indicated by green dashed outline) with goblet cells (examples indicated by yellow overlays) and an epithelioid cell granuloma without necrosis (red overlay) are visible. In the area immediately surrounding the granuloma and its multinucleated giant cell (purple overlay), a lymphocytic infiltrate (white arrowhead) and numerous neutrophil granulocytes can be found.

These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.

title: Dermoid cyst (mature teratoma)
description:
Resection specimen of a mature teratoma of the ovary

This sebaceous and solid ovarian tumor contains skin, fat, hair, and cartilage.

Mature teratomas can derive from all three embryological germ layers.

title: Arteriovenous malformation (angioma)
description: Angiography of the internal carotid artery and its branches. The parietal-occipital region shows a conglomerate of very small vessels (arteriovenous angioma, green overlay). Both the afferent artery (A) and the efferent vein (V), which drains the blood into the dural venous sinus, can be seen.

title: Dermatological tuberculosis - lupus vulgaris
description:
Localization: skin covering the right mandible
Lesion: flat to slightly raised, irregularly demarcated, squamous skin lesion, which may ulcerate in the future

title: Molluscum contagiosum
description:
Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

title: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)
description:
Microscopic image of the kidney (van Gieson's stain)

Microthrombi from cell residues (yellow) and fibrin (bright red) in the glomerular capillaries.

title: Enchondroma of the fifth metacarpal of the left hand
description:
Anteroposterior x-ray of the left hand: oval area of reduced bone density in the distal third of the fifth metacarpal bone (circled area);
Diagnosis: enchondroma of the fifth metacarpal bone

title: Osteosarcoma of the distal femur
description:
X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

title: Skin hyperextensibility in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
description:
The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.

This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

title: Xanthelasma
description:
There are well demarcated, yellow plaques on the medial aspect of the bilateral eyelids, which is consistent with xanthelasma.

Xanthelasma consists of cutaneous lipid deposits and is a common finding in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

title: Congenital clubfoot in a newborn
description:
Right lower leg and foot of a newborn, ventral view of the back of the foot

The achilles tendon is shortened, resulting in plantar flexion and the foot pointing downwards (hindfoot equinus). The calcaneus is supinated (hindfoot varus). The forefoot is adducted and supinated and rotates medially (forefoot varus). The midfoot cavus cannot be seen from this perspective.

title: Corneal microdeposits
description:
Slit-lamp examination in a 75-year-old patient

Whorl-shaped opacification in the cornea (black arrow). The patient is on amiodarone therapy.

title: Karyogram in full trisomy 21
description: The karyogram for karyotype 47,XY,+21 shows three complete copies of chromosome 21 and a total of 47 chromosomes.

title: Galeazzi fracture and fracture of the first metacarpal bone
description:
X-ray of the distal lower arm (left, lateral view; right, PA view)

A distal third radius fracture (green outline, bottom left) and distal ulnar head dislocation (green dashed line) can be seen; this fracture pattern is referred to as a Galeazzi fracture. Fracture of the first metacarpal bone (green outline, top right) is also visible.

title: ERCP in primary sclerosing cholangitis
description:
ERCP (positive mode; ventral view)

Multifocal strictures with dilation and beading of the intrahepatic bile ducts are visible (examples indicated by green outlines).

These findings are characteristic of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

title: Chronic subdural hematoma
description:
CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window)

There is a large, crescent-shaped, hypodense lesion (green overlay) over the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere that crosses cranial sutures. Mass effect of the lesion is visible as compression of the left lateral ventricle.

These findings are characteristic of a large chronic subdural hematoma.

title: Molluscum contagiosum with concomitant conjunctivitis
description:
Right eye

Several papules (green overlay) with central umbilication are visible on the eyelid and in the periocular region. Conjunctival injection is also present.

These findings are consistent with molluscum contagiosum with concurrent conjunctivitis.

title: Papillary urothelial carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of urothelial tissue (H&E stain; 750x magnification)

Papillary urothelial carcinoma with lamina propria infiltration, moderately differentiated.

A) Mitotic figure
B) Urothelial cell with severe nuclear atypia; no mitotic figure
C) Small, round lymphocytes; no mitotic figure
D) Structure with a nucleus
E) Atypical urothelial cell; no mitotic figure

title: Membranous tonsillitis
description: Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

title: Tertian malaria: immature trophozoite in Plasmodium vivax infection
description:
Red blood cell inclusions in a patient with malaria

A large ring-like inclusion within erythrocyte in the center of the slide is an immature trophozoite. Thick, dark purple, ring‑shaped inclusions and fine dotting within erythrocytes (i.e., "Schüffner granules") are characteristic of infection with Plasmodium vivax or P. ovale.

title: Hereditary angioedema
description: Facial edema, primarily affecting the eyelids, is visible on the patient's face.

title: Porcelain gallbladder
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view)

A well-defined oval lesion is visible in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, encapsulated in a thin rim of radiodense material, indicating intramural calcification of the gallbladder.

This is the typical appearance of porcelain gallbladder, which is a consequence of chronic gallbladder inflammation that is usually secondary to cholelithiasis.

title: Rosacea
description: Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

title: Senile purpura and skin atrophy
description:
Forearm of an elderly patient

There are multiple irregular dark purple macules with well-defined margins. The surrounding skin appears thin and inelastic.

title: Carotid artery stenosis
description:
MR angiography (right carotid artery)

There is severe stenosis (hatched green overlay) of the proximal internal carotid artery.

1: superior thyroid artery; 2: lingual artery; 3: facial artery

title: Gouty tophi
description: Tophi (monosodium urate crystal deposition in bones and soft tissues) are visible distributed irregularly in the fingers and metacarpus of this patient's left hand.

title: Diabetes medications: Pros and Cons
description:
Schematic illustration of situations in which different antidiabetic substance classes should be preferred or avoided

Eligible substance classes for the treatment of type 2 diabetes are insulin, metformin, sulfonylureas (SU), SGLT-2 inhibitors (SGLT-2-I), dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP-4-I), glucagon-like-peptide-1 agonists (GLP-1-RA), alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (AGI), and thiazolidinedione (TZD). TZDs are greyed out as some substances are currently not available in the EU and should be used less commonly due to safety concerns.

title: Management of hyponatremia
description:
BMP: basic metabolic panel
FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
NaCl: saline solution

title: Neonatal resuscitation algorithm
description:
CPAP: continuous positive airway pressure
CPR: cardiopulmonary resuscitation
ECG: electrocardiogram
FiO2: fraction of inspired oxygen
HR: heart rate
PPV: positive pressure ventilation
SpO2: oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry

title: Pulmonary hypertension (1/2)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The central right and left pulmonary arteries are also enlarged, with rapid tapering of peripheral branches (vascular pruning; indicated by arrowhead). The left pulmonary artery is seen through a prominent convexity along the left mediastinum, which corresponds to an enlarged main pulmonary artery.

Black arrow: margin of right atrium; LDPA: left descending pulmonary artery; RDPA: right descending pulmonary artery

title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
description:
X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.

title: CMV retinitis
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

There are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).

These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

title: Mesencephalon (midbrain)
description:
Left: Transverse section at the level of the superior colliculi
The mesencephalon contains the tectum (yellow), the tegmentum (green), and the crus cerebri (blue).

Right: Transverse section
Important functional structures are depicted.

title: Thyroid gland and surrounding structures
description:
The thyroid gland is located in front of the trachea in the lower neck and consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus. A third pyramidal lobe extending from the isthmus is present in 50% of patients. This third lobe is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.

The parathyroid glands are located posterior to the thyroid gland; they may vary in number and location. The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) branch off from the vagus nerve; the left RLN loops under the aortic arch, and the right RLN passes beneath the subclavian artery. Both RLNs are vulnerable to injury during thyroid surgery as they ascend to the larynx behind the thyroid gland. Unilateral RLN injury may result in hoarseness, and bilateral RLN injury may cause dyspnea and stridor.

title: Schistocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Normal erythrocytes (example indicated by arrow; bottom left) and several fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes; examples indicated by black dashed circles) with a normal convex side (example marked with red line) and a fragmented side that is concave or straight (example marked with blue line) can be seen. Additionally, multiple erythrocytes with dark staining Howell-Jolly bodies (examples indicated by arrowheads) are present.

Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. These cellular fragments can also result from mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., due to prosthetic heart valves). Howell-Jolly bodies can occur in functional asplenia or after splenectomy, severe anemia, and bone marrow disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic syndrome).

title: Heart murmur in patent ductus arteriosus
description: Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

title: Phonocardiogram of diastolic murmurs
description:
Diastolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:

(A) Mitral stenosis (decrescendo murmur with OS)
(B) Tricuspid stenosis (mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur)
(C) Patent ductus arteriosus (continuous crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(D) Aortic and pulmonary regurgitation (decrescendo murmur)

Note that patent ductus arteriosus produces a continuous murmur heard in both systole and diastole.

OS: opening snap

title: Distribution of joint involvement in rheumatoid arthritis of the hand
description: Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.

title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
description:
An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
description:
A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

title: Types of cerebral palsy
description:
Based on the localization of the brain damage, a distinction can be made between pyramidal and extrapyramidal cerebral palsy.

Pyramidal cerebral palsy is characterized by spastic paralysis of one or more extremities. Depending on the pattern of damage, it can manifest as spastic diplegia, spastic hemiplegia, or spastic tetraplegia.

Extrapyramidal cerebral palsy results in variable movement disorders of the extremities, e.g., dyskinesia (athetosis, dystonia) or ataxia.

title: Idiopathic scoliosis
description: Idiopathic scoliosis is a deformity of the spine characterized by lateral deflection and rotation of the vertebral bodies. Adam forward bend test usually shows a thoracic rotation (rib hump). Other findings include asymmetry of the waist space and/or shoulder girdle and protrusion of the scapulae.

title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

title: Ebstein anomaly
description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

title: Bubbly bone lesion
description:
X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the lung
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Adjacent to normal lung tissue at the bottom of the image (dashed line) several nests of abnormal, pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen. Some of the nests form central lumina that contain necrotic debris (examples indicated by blue overlay).

These findings suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung. However, a metastasis of adenocarcinoma of another origin (e.g. colon) must be ruled out by immunohistochemistry.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Gustatory pathway
description:
The first neuron of the taste pathway is located in the ganglia of the facial, vagus, and glossopharyngeal nerves. The afferent gustatory nerve fibers join to form the nerve tract that projects to the nucleus of the solitary tract.

Second-order neurons project from the medulla oblongata in three distinct branches. Projections to the hypothalamus and amygdala transmit the emotional component of taste perception. Projections to the ventral posterior nucleus (VPM) of the thalamus transmit to the gustatory cortex at the foot of the postcentral gyrus for conscious taste perception.

title: Overview of visual field defects
description:
(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

title: Neonatal phototherapy
description:
Neonate under a phototherapy lamp

Except for the diaper and socks, the neonate is undressed to expose the greatest skin surface area. The phototherapy goggles protect from potential retinal damage.

title: Renal cell carcinoma (2/3)
description:
CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane) of patient with a history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney.

A: abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney; P: pancreas

title: Renal cell carcinoma (3/3)
description:
CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; coronal plane) of patient with a history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney. Soft tissue density (red overlay) visible in the perinephric space raises concern for extracapsular extension. A large pleural effusion (outline) accompanied by passive atelectasis (green overlay) depresses the right hemidiaphragm.

A : calcified abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney; L: liver

title: Pulmonary hyperinflation with pulmonary hypertension
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with history of panlobular emphysema

There is evidence of hyperinflation, with large lung volumes accompanied by hyperlucency, reduced peripheral vascularity, diaphragmatic depression (indicated by arrows), and intercostal space widening (examples indicated by brackets). Additionally, the presence of central pulmonary artery enlargement (dashed outlines) suggests accompanying pulmonary hypertension. No thickened bronchial walls or discrete bullae are visible on this radiograph.

Bullae may be visible in advanced panlobular emphysema, although are not commonly seen in the early stages. Bilateral hyperinflation can also be seen in asthma; however, the bronchial thickening that sometimes accompanies severe or chronic asthma is not a typical feature of panlobular emphysema.

title: Arterial blood gas analysis
description:
This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

title: Anatomy of the heart and adjacent large vessels
description:
Blue: structures that carry deoxygenated blood
Red: structures that carry oxygenated blood

title: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
description: In newborns with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, an enlarged, thickened, olive-shaped, nontender pylorus may be palpable in the epigastrium. The primary symptom of the condition is projectile, nonbilious vomiting immediately after feeding.

title: Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis)
description:
Ultrasound thyroid (longitudinal plane)

A geographic hypoechoic area (blue overlay) is seen within the thyroid gland.

This appearance can be seen with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis). The lesions may be unilateral or bilateral, and gland size may be small, normal, or enlarged. The hypoechoic areas may show reduced or absent blood flow on color Doppler.

T: normal thyroid parenchyma

title: Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Diffuse, bilateral, interstitial opacification (blue overlay) can be seen extending from the hila to the periphery of the lungs.

This appearance is characteristic of PCP infection.

title: Anatomy of the inner ear
description: The inner ear consists of a bony labyrinth with a membranous labyrinth inside it, separated by a space containing perilymph fluid. It contains the cochlea and vestibular system. The cochlea (on the right) is responsible for the conversion of sound waves into neuronal signals, which are transmitted via the cochlear nerve (depicted by a cartoon DJ). The vestibular system (on the left) consists of three semicircular canals, the saccule, and the utricle. Semicircular canals detect angular acceleration in three planes: the superior or anterior semicircular canal in the sagittal plane, the posterior semicircular canal in the coronal plane, and the lateral or horizontal semicircular canal in the transverse plane. The saccule and utricle contain cells that detect linear motion in the vertical and horizontal planes, respectively. The neuronal signals from the semicircular canals are transmitted via the vestibular nerve (depicted by a dancing cartoon).

title: Barrett esophagus
description: Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.

title: Selection of statistical tests depending on data type
description: For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.

title: Management of acute lower gastrointestinal bleeding
description:
CT: computed tomography
IV: intravenous
LGIB: lower gastrointestinal bleeding
NPO: nil per os
RBC: red blood cell

title: Autosomal recessive inheritance
description:
In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

title: Pupillary light reflex
description:
The afferent pathway (blue tract) is initiated when light hits the retina:
- Retinal photoreceptors → ipsilateral optic nerve → nuclei of bilateral pretectal areas (nasal fibers of the optic nerve cross to the contralateral side at the optic chiasma)

The efferent pathway (green tract) transmits neural impulses to the iris sphincter muscle:
- Nuclei of pretectal area → bilateral Edinger Westphal nuclei (parasympathetic preganglionic nucleus of the oculomotor nerve) → bilateral oculomotor nerves (synapse at the ciliary ganglion) → bilateral iris sphincter muscle (and ciliary muscle) → bilateral pupillary constriction (and accomodation).

Shining a light into one eye causes constriction of the ipsilateral pupil (direct pupillary reflex) as well as that of the contralateral pupil (indirect or consensual pupillary reflex).

title: Renal cholesterol emboli
description:
Photomicrograph of renal tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Spindle-shaped, white spaces (yellow overlay) can be seen in an arterial vessel (dashed outline). These spaces (cholesterol clefts) are formed when the fat molecules in cholesterol emboli dissolve during sample processing.

title: Right convex thoracic scoliosis
description:
X-ray spine (left: frontal view, right: lateral view)

A severe scoliotic curvature is seen, with the Cobb angle (green overlay) of the major curve (MC) measuring 80° and the Cobb angle (red overlay) of the compensatory curve (CC) measuring 50°.

A scoliosis radiograph is generally performed PA (posteroanterior) rather than AP in order to reduce breast dose. A lateral radiograph is sometimes additionally obtained.

The Cobb angle measures the maximal angle between tangents placed along the upper endplate of the superior-end vertebra and the lower endplate of the inferior-end vertebra of the scoliotic curvature. Particularly if the tangents do not intersect, the Cobb angle is measured at the point of intersection between perpendicular lines drawn at each of the tangents. A Cobb angle in the range of 10-20° is considered to denote mild scoliosis, between 20-40° moderate scoliosis, and >40° severe scoliosis.

title: Methanol and ethylene glycol metabolism
description: Metabolic pathways for methanol and ethylene glycol are shown. Both methanol and ethylene glycol are converted to toxic metabolites (purple boxes) by alcohol dehydrogenase. Alcohol dehydrogenase is inhibited (red boxes) by fomepizole and ethanol. The toxic metabolites are converted to nontoxic metabolites with the help of specific adjunctives (blue boxes).

title: Titration curve of the amino acid lysine
description:
Titration curve of the amino acid lysine, with changes in pH levels following the addition of a base. Also depicted here is the corresponding protonation state (as a structural formula).

Lysine is a basic amino acid and has three pKs values.

title: Tibial stress fracture
description:
X-ray right knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of atraumatic leg pain following intense exercise

An irregular linear lucency (green overlay) accompanied by sclerosis (arrowheads) is seen in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis. The appearance is compatible with a stress fracture.

The sensitivity of x-ray for the detection of early-stage stress fractures is low, although increases as the fracture heals. Examples of positive findings include a visible fracture line, sclerosis or cortical thickening, and periosteal reaction. MRI is the most sensitive modality for the detection of a stress fracture.

title: Patella alta from patellar tendon rupture
description:
X-ray knee (lateral view)

The patella is abnormally high-riding (patella alta; normal position illustrated by outline). Although no fracture fragment is visible, a small defect at the patellar apex (green overlay) raises question of a prior avulsion fracture.

Patellar tendon rupture can result from trauma or systemic illness. A traumatic rupture usually occurs at either the patellar or tibial insertion site and may be accompanied by an avulsion fracture. A systemic illness usually results in a midtendon tear.

F: femur; T: tibia

title: Prolonged QT-interval (long QT syndrome)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular ectopic atrial rhythm: negative P-waves in II and aVF (normally positive), positive P-waves in aVR (normally negative) and V1 (normally biphasic) (examples indicated by blue overlay)
- Heart rate of approx. 75/min
- Normal cardiac axis
- Normal PR interval (approx. 120 ms), normal QRS duration (approx. 80 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 580 ms, example indicated by red overlay)
- Ventricular extrasystoles seen in leads I to III

title: Esophageal web
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A thin, semilunar membrane (esophageal web; blue overlay) projects into the esophageal lumen. Esophageal webs usually occur in the upper esophagus and do not involve the muscle layer.

Cervical esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia form the classic triad of findings in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

title: Lysosomes
description: Substances taken up during endocytosis are initially delivered to the endosomes. These fuse with primary lysosomes (enzyme-rich vesicles, which are formed by detachment of the Golgi apparatus) to secondary lysosomes, where lysosomal enzymes start to degrade the ingested material. If complete degradation is possible, the products generated, e.g., glucose, proteins, and lipids, are transported to the cytosol for further use. The lysosome can also fuse again with endosomes or secondary lysosomes. If lysosomal enzymes are unable to degrade the material that has been taken up, these remain in the lysosome and accumulate to form telolysosomes. Telolysosomes are exocytosed by the cell or accumulate in the cytosol of older cells.

title: MALT lymphoma
description:
Endoscopic view of the stomach

In the antrum, a tumorous process involves almost the entire circumference. The tumor's surface is ulcerated and amorphous (blue overlay). A small area of normal mucosa is visible (dashed line).

These findings are highly concerning for malignancy. Histopathology is necessary to determine the exact diagnosis.

title: Erythema marginatum
description:
Left upper arm of a child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF)

Erythematous plaques with areas of central clearing are visible on the ventral aspect of the forearm.

This is characteristic of erythema marginatum, the characteristic annular erythema occuring in 10% of attacks of acute rheumatic fever in children, caused by group A streptococcus.

title: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
description: A congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins merge to form a connecting vein that drains into the systemic venous circulation (e.g., the vena cava) rather than the left atrium. Without return of blood to the left heart, there is no systemic circulation. Survival after birth depends on the presence of a right-to-left shunt (usually an atrial septal defect) to allow for blood to enter the left heart, then systemic circulation.

title: Heteroplasmy
description: Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

title: Epidural anesthesia (2/2): procedure
description:
The injection site may be at any vertebral level (cervical, thoracic, and lumbar). This illustration shows a midline approach, but a paramedian approach is also possible.

(1) Local anesthetic is infiltrated into the subcutaneous tissue (1a) and interspinous ligament (1b).
(2) The epidural needle is inserted, angled slightly cephalad with the bevel orientated cephalad. Once the needle has been advanced by about 2–3 cm into the interspinous ligament, the stylet is removed and a loss-of-resistance syringe filled with saline is attached.
(3) The needle is advanced while applying constant, gentle pressure on the syringe plunger. After passing through the ligamentum flavum and entering the epidural space, a sudden loss of resistance is felt and the saline is more easily injected (3a); at this point, advancement is stopped.
(4) The syringe is removed and the epidural catheter is inserted through the needle to its correct depth (puncture depth + 4–6 cm). The tip of the catheter must always be advanced cephalad (4a); therefore, the bevel of the needle must remain facing cephalad.
(5) The epidural needle is removed, taking care to maintain the epidural catheter at the correct depth. At this time, aspiration is attempted from the catheter (5a: this should return neither blood nor CSF), and an epidural filter is attached (5b).
(6) The puncture site is covered with a transparent dressing and the catheter is secured to the patient's back with adherent dressings. A test dose is then administered.

title: Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis
description:
Face of a 54-year-old man after a fall on the back of his head 2 days earlier

Bilateral, symmetrical, dark purplish discoloration around the eye sockets is visible.

This appearance, also referred to as "raccoon eyes," is a typical sign of basilar skull fractures involving the anterior fossa and typically develops 1–3 days after injury. Nontraumatic causes include neuroblastoma, plasma cell proliferative disorders (e.g., amyloidosis), and hematological malignancies. Periorbital ecchymosis may occur unilaterally or bilaterally.

title: String-of-beads (chain-of-lakes) sign in chronic pancreatitis
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with autoimmune pancreatitis

The pancreas is partially visualized; the head is not included. Within the body, the main pancreatic duct shows alternating segments of dilatation and stenosis, giving it its string-of-beads or chain-of-lakes appearance (red arrowheads; cf. illustration). There is atrophy of the pancreatic parenchyma, and a few punctate calcifications are seen (white arrowheads).

The CT features are compatible with a diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. Pseudocysts and pseudoaneurysms may also be seen with chronic pancreatitis.

BD: bile duct; K: kidneys; L: liver; Sp: spleen: St: stomach; PV: portal vein

title: Persistent truncus arteriosus
description:
Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) is a congenital cyanotic heart defect in which the truncus arteriosus fails to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta and instead remains as a single trunk that receives blood from both ventricles. The pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation are not separated from one another, therefore, deoxygenated and oxygenated blood mix.

After birth, the pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) drops, resulting in blood being shunted to the pulmonary circulation, leading to pulmonary congestion and subsequent heart failure.

title: Tricuspid valve atresia
description:
AA: ascending aorta
PT: pulmonary trunk
PV: pulmonary valve
RA: right atrium
SVC: superior vena cava
TV: tricuspid valve

title: Flow-volume loop in obstructive lung diseases
description:
Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

title: Alveolar collapse in surfactant deficiency
description: Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension. In surfactant deficiency, increased surface tension results in increased alveolar collapse during expiration and decreased alveolar expansion during inspiration.

title: Leonine facies in lepromatous leprosy
description:
45-year-old woman with a five-year history of facial appearance changes and paresthesia of both hands and feet

The skin of the face is thickened and furrowed, with multiple areas of nodular lesions coalescing into plaques. The hair of the eyebrows has been lost (madarosis), and there is a saddle nose deformity.

Leonine facies (so termed after the ostensible resemblance to a lion's face) is characteristic of lepromatous leprosy, as seen here, and Paget disease of bone, but can also occur various other conditions, e.g., mycosis fungoides, leishmaniasis, or sarcoidosis.

title: Sinonasal changes in granulomatosis with polyangiitis
description:
CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)

The right maxillary sinus is completely opacified (yellow overlay). An erosion (red arrowhead) through the nasal septum (red overlay) is seen, and a second erosion involves the right orbital floor (white arrowhead).

LMS: left maxillary sinus

title: Chronic pancreatitis
description: In chronic pancreatitis, inflammation and fibrosis of pancreatic tissue can manifest with abdominal pain (main symptom), which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Symptoms of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency (pancreatic diabetes) typically occur late when more than 90% of pancreatic tissue is destroyed.

title: Deep sulcus sign
description:
X-ray chest (AP view; supine)

A pneumothorax is visible in the left pleural space. The air has displaced the visceral pleura medially (arrowheads), portions of which are seen as a thin white curvilinear opacity. Pleural air has reduced the density of the lower left hemithorax compared to the right and has widened the left lateral costophrenic angle (deep sulcus sign, red overlay).

Pneumothorax collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent pleural space when a patient is positioned supine. Air located laterally can abnormally deepen the lateral costophrenic angle. The deep sulcus sign is sometimes the only finding of pneumothorax in a supine patient.

Blue overlay: endotracheal tube; green overlay: atelectasis; yellow overlay: left internal jugular line

title: Trigeminal neuralgia
description: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

title: Bilateral papilledema
description:
Fundus photography of right (R) and left (L) optic disc of the same patient

The optic discs show severely blurred margins (dashed circle indicates supposed margin). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples marked by white lines). There are multiple peripapillary hemorrhages, which appear as flame-shaped hemorrhages (examples marked by blue overlay). Cotton wool spots are also present and appear as bright spots (examples marked by arrowheads).

These features are characteristic of papilledema. If present bilaterally, possible causes include cranial hypertension or hypertensive emergency.

title: Cerumen impaction
description:
Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

title: Thoracostomy sites
description:
The 2nd intercostal space, located at the midclavicular line (1; orange marker), can be used in both adults and children for emergency needle thoracostomy to decompress a tension pneumothorax.

The 4th or 5th intercostal space, between the anterior and midaxillary lines (2; blue marker), is the standard site for tube thoracostomy in both adults and children and in adults may also be used for needle thoracostomy.

title: Anatomical structures in lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, and epidural anesthesia
description: For lumbar puncture (including spinal anesthesia) the spinal needle is typically inserted in the L3-4 or L4-5 interspace and directed toward the umbilicus.

title: Mechanism of action: antibiotics
description:
A. Bacterial cell envelope
- Polymyxins disrupt the outer membrane that is present in gram-negative bacteria.
- Beta-lactams, glycopeptides, and epoxides inhibit cell wall synthesis.
- Daptomycin forms ion channels on the cell membrane that lead to membrane depolarization and disruption.

B. Nucleic acids and related enzymes
- Nitroimidazoles disrupt DNA strands by creating free radicals.
- Fluoroquinolones interrupt DNA replication by inhibiting prokaryotic DNA gyrase.
- Rifamycin prevents transcription by inhibiting RNA polymerase.

C. Bacterial ribosomes
- Macrolides, amphenicols, lincosamides, and oxazolidinones inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
- Aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, and glycylcyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

D. Folic acid metabolism (required for DNA synthesis)
- Sulfamethoxazole inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydropteroate synthetase, which converts para-aminobenzoate (PABA) into dihydrofolate (DHF).
- Trimethoprim, a diaminopyrimidine, inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, which converts DHF into tetrahydrofolate (THF).

title: Brain metastases in lung cancer
description:
CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gait

Cerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.

P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum

title: Aortic dissection
description:
CT scan of the thorax (axial view)

An intimal flap (dashed line) resulting in a double lumen is seen in the descending aorta. The smaller lumen (true lumen; red overlay) shows high contrast density. The larger lumen (false lumen; green overlay) shows low-contrast density due to delayed enhancement.

This appearance is typical of an aortic dissection.

Arrows: atelectasis; AA: ascending aorta; PA: pulmonary artery

title: Tuberculous granuloma with Langhans cells
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A large epithelioid granuloma containing several multinucleated giant cells (Langhans cells; black arrowhead) is visible. Dense collections of leukocytes (examples indicated by black arrows) can be seen in the surrounding area. Necrotic areas (yellow overlay) are also visible.

These findings are characteristic of a caseating tuberculous granuloma.

title: Types of plaques in coronary artery disease
description: In stable plaques, the lipid pool is surrounded by a thick fibrous cap and leads to extensive narrowing of the arterial lumen. In vulnerable plaques, the lipid pool is surrounded by a thin fibrous cap and minimally narrows the arterial lumen.

title: Auer rods
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Two red rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusions (blue overlay) are visible within the myeloblast, which is the large basophilic cell in the center of the image with an eccentric, indented nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

These rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions are known as Auer rods, and they are typically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., acute promyelocytic leukemia) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

title: Coccidioidomycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, medium power magnification)

A thick-walled spherule (yellow overlay) is visible near the center of an inflammatory granuloma (blue overlay). The spherule contains multiple endospores.

This histological appearance suggests pulmonary coccidioidomycosis. The diagnosis should be confirmed by culture and serological tests (IgM and IgG antibodies).

title: Phyllodes tumor
description:
Photomicrograph of a breast tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

A hypercellular stroma (example indicated by blue overlay) is visible in the right half of the image. Several clefts or slit-like spaces (examples indicated by black dashed line) lined by darker stained epithelial cells are visible within the stroma, giving it a leaf-like appearance. These are characteristic features of a phyllodes tumor.

Normal breast tissue is visible in the left half of the image.

title: Low-flow vs. high-flow priapism
description:
In a normal erection, an increase of arterial inflow into the corpora cavernosa's sinusoids makes the penis become rigid. As the pressure builds up, the blood-filled cavernous sinusoids compress venous outflow, maintaining the erection. During detumescence, venous drainage is restored and the erection ends.

In low-flow (ischemic) priapism, blood is trapped within the cavernous sinusoids because of impaired venous outflow (e.g., due to medication, autonomic dysfunction, sickle cell disease), leading to a prolonged, painful erection with completely rigid corpora cavernosa. Increasing pressure within the corpora cavernosa then blocks arterial inflow, resulting in penile ischemia and tissue damage.

In high-flow (nonischemic) priapism, a fistula between the cavernosal artery and cavernous sinusoids (e.g., due to blunt perineal trauma) leads to unregulated, excessive arterial inflow bypassing the protective, high-resistance helicine arterioles. Typically, the corpora cavernosa are not fully rigid or painful, as the venous outflow is intact and there is no tissue ischemia.

title: Diabetic nephropathy
description:
Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain; high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus can be seen (dashed outline), featuring a thickened glomerular basement membrane and containing abundant pink, hyaline depositions of PAS-positive material (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules or nodular glomerulosclerosis; examples indicated by yellow overlay). Various tubules and vessels surround the glomerulus. An arteriole with distinct hyaline deposits is located above the glomerulus (hyaline arteriolosclerosis; blue overlay).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis combined with hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a typical feature seen in diabetic glomerulopathy.

title: Porcelain gallbladder
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; left: soft tissue window; right: bone window)

The calcified wall of the gallbladder is seen as a hyperdense oval outline (green overlay) in the gallbladder fossa. The greater density of the gallbladder calcification compared to the intravenous contrast in several other organs is more conspicuous on the bone window than the soft tissue window.

The calcification is diagnostic of a porcelain gallbladder, a rare complication of chronic gallbladder inflammation.

L: Liver; IVC: Inferior vena cava; LK: Left kidney; RK: Right kidney; S: Spleen; Arrow: Kidney cyst

title: Enterococcus faecalis
description:
Bright-field photomicrograph (Gram stain; 1000x magnification)

Large numbers of gram-positive bacteria are visible. The bacteria form pairs (examples indicated by arrowheads) and short chains (examples indicated by circles).

title: Iron deficiency anemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Most of the red blood cells are small (microcytic) and contain a central zone of pallor (hypochromasia; examples indicated by blue overlay). There are also cells with abnormal morphology (poikilocytosis; examples indicated by arrow-heads).

In the center of the image, a distinctly basophilic lymphocyte (example indicated by yellow overlay) is visible, which can be used to compare cell sizes.

These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

title: Trichomonas vaginalis
description:
Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

title: Ovarian torsion
description: In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).

title: Targets and mechanisms of antidepressants
description:
Antidepressants work by increasing levels of serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT; green circles), norepinephrine (NE; purple circles), or dopamine within the synaptic cleft, which can be achieved by:

1. Increasing neurotransmitter release
– Mirtazapine increases the release of NE and 5-HT into the synaptic cleft by blocking the presynaptic alpha-2 adrenergic receptors. It also inhibits postsynaptic 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors, reducing some of the side effects of increased serotonergic activity (e.g., nausea, sleep disturbances).

2. Decreasing neurotransmitter breakdown
– Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors decrease the breakdown of NE and 5-HT.

3. Inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters and thereby increasing their concentration within the synaptic cleft
– Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) block serotonin transporters (SERTs), inhibiting the reuptake of 5-HT.
– Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) and selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SSNRIs) block SERTs and norepinephrine transporters (NETs), inhibiting the reuptake of 5-HT and NE respectively.
– Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of NE by blocking NETs.
– Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitors (SARIs) block postsynaptic 5-HT2 receptors and weakly inhibit the reuptake of 5-HT (by blocking SERTs at higher doses).

title: Crescent formation in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
description:
Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy (H&E stain, medium-power magnification)

Poorly formed noncaseating (nonnecrotizing) granulomas are visible. The largest granuloma (arrow) has a core of large, pale epithelioid macrophages surrounded by lymphocytes and an outer layer of fibrous tissue. Smaller granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (blue overlay), and foamy histiocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads) are also visible. There is a dense chronic inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the pulmonary interstitium.

These histological findings, in combination with a patient history of antigen-related symptoms, are suggestive of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

title: Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney tissue sample (PAS stain, medium magnification)

Various elements of the renal tubular and vascular system are seen in different sections. An arteriole is visible on the left (arrow), showing a thick, laminated wall (onion-skin appearance) due to hyperplasia of the smooth muscle tissue (examples of nuclei indicated by yellow overlay) and reduplicated basement membrane material, which stains PAS-positive (magenta-colored laminae; examples indicated by arrowheads). The lumen is severely narrowed as a consequence of these vessel wall changes.

These are typical features of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis.

title: Paralytic ileus
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a patient with COVID-19, acute renal failure, and paralytic ileus

Gaseous distention of both small and large bowel is the result of paralytic ileus.

C: cecum; SB: small bowel; SF: splenic flexure; TC: transverse colon

title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
description:
X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)

The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).

The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

title: Area of tenderness on palpation in plantar fasciitis
description: In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).

title: Entamoeba histolytica trophozoite
description:
Photomicrograph of a stool mount (trichrome stain; very high magnification)

A trophozoite with phagocytosed erythrocytes can be seen (dark circular inclusions, examples indicated by arrowheads).

title: Rouleaux formation
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Red blood cells are aggregated in chains and appear like stacked coins (rouleaux formation (illustration); examples indicated by blue overlay).

This phenomenon occurs in disorders with increased serum proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia).

title: Dry age-related macular degeneration
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

There are drusen (yellow deposits, area marked by dashed blue circle) and retinal pigment epithelium atrophy (blue overlay).

Blue circle: optic disc
M: macula

title: Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
description:
Microscopic image of a kidney biopsy (PAS stain, high magnification)

A renal corpuscle surrounded by numerous tubules can be seen in the center of the image. Because the renal corpuscle is markedly enlarged, the space between the glomerular capillaries and the parietal layer of the Bowman capsule (black dashed outline) is narrowed. Within the glomerulus, there is hypercellularity due to proliferation of endothelial cells (yellow arrowheads) and mesangial cells (black arrowheads). Inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly neutrophils (blue arrowheads) and monocytes (white arrowheads), is also present. As a result, the lumina of the capillaries are not clearly identifiable.

This is the histopathologic appearance of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

title: Splenic abscess
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a splenic abscess

A solitary low attenuation lesion (green overlay) in the region of the spleen contains small collections of gas (arrowheads) and a gas-fluid level.

The presence of gas in a splenic lesion is an uncommon but characteristic finding of abscess.

A: aorta; Arrow: transverse diameter; G: gas; GB: gallbladder; IVC: inferior vena cava; K: kidney; L: liver; P: pancreas; S: spleen

title: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia
description:
Single-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: 192/min
– Regular rhythm
– No P or T waves are discernible because of the high ventricular rate.
– QRS complexes are broad (> 120 ms) and monomorphic (there is a similar QRS morphology in all beats).

These features are characteristic of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT persisting for ≥ 30 seconds is considered sustained VT (this strip does not show the full 30-second interval).

title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

title: Ruptured middle cerebral artery aneurysm
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A rounded area of high attenuation (1) in the left frontoparietal region indicates intracerebral hemorrhage from a ruptured left middle cerebral artery aneurysm. Extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage is present in the basal cisterns (2), interhemispheric fissure (3), right Sylvian fissure (4), left frontal lobe fissures (5), and posterior fossa (6). Ventricular dilatation (green overlay) is the result of obstruction of CSF drainage.

title: Paget disease of the skull
description:
X-ray skull (lateral view)

The calvarium is markedly thickened (left right arrow), with widening of the diploic space. Numerous ill-defined lytic (examples indicated by green overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by red overlay) lesions are present.

The presence of multiple poorly marginated sclerotic lesions in Paget disease has been termed “cotton wool appearance.”

title: Cavitary lung lesion (1/2)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung carcinoma

A cavitary lesion containing an air-fluid level (red line) is seen in the right middle lobe, which is also opacified (green overlay) from air space consolidation. The consolidation abuts the minor fissure (black dashed line) and obscures the right heart border (silhouette sign).

The major diagnostic considerations for the cavitary lesion would include abscess or cavitary carcinoma.

White dashed line: approximate location of the right heart border

title: Tension pneumothorax
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Much of the left hemithorax is hyperlucent, with a lack of vascular markings when compared to the right hemithorax. Lobulated opacities that project through the cardiac silhouette and along the left heart border represent collapsed lobes of the left lung (green overlay).

Accompanying depression of the left hemidiaphragm (arrowheads), mass effect on the mediastinum, and widening of some intercostal spaces (double-headed arrows) are signs of tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

title: Unstable pelvic ring fracture
description:
X-ray pelvis (AP view)

The right hemipelvis is displaced superiorly, compatible with disruption of the sacroiliac joint (indicated by dashed lines and double-headed arrow). Bilateral pubic ramus fractures are also present (indicated by arrowheads).

title: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
description:
Photomicrograph (methylene blue stain)

Numerous gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria can be seen (examples marked by blue overlay). The pathogens exhibit pleomorphism and do not show a particular arrangement.
The bacterial poles appear nodular (exampled indicated by arrow-heads). The nodules usually contain granules, which can be made visible with special metachromatic stains (not shown here).

title: Aspergillus fumigatus
description:
Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

title: Red blood cell (RBC) casts in urine sediment
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy)

A tubular cast (blue overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The cast is composed of numerous RBCs, identifiable by their characteristic biconvex shape (examples outlined in yellow), in a matrix of fibrin and plasma proteins. Several epithelial cells surrounding the RBC cast are also visible.

RBC casts in urinary sediment are typically seen in glomerulonephritis.

title: White blood cell casts
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy; high magnification)
