White blood cell (WBC) casts (blue overlay) contain leukocytes (examples outlined in yellow) that are compressed in a matrix. Sharp margins are characteristic of WBC casts, differentiating them from randomly assembled leukocyte conglomerates.

title: Subdural hematoma
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The hyperdense, crescent-shaped, extra-axial collection (green overlay) visible along the left frontal convexity is compatible with an acute subdural hematoma.

Additional findings of dilated ventricles and sulci indicate generalized cerebral atrophy. The periventricular hyperlucencies are consistent with cerebral small vessel disease.

title: Obstructive sleep apnea
description: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

title: Retinal detachment in Marfan syndrome
description:
Fundus photography

A giant tear (blue overlay) with rolled margins (hatched overlay; the arrows show the path along which the retina has rolled up) is visible. The giant tear has caused retinal detachment (yellow overlay); the detached portion of the retina appears brighter than the attached portion of the retina.

The risk for retinal detachment is elevated in individuals with Marfan syndrome.

title: Papilledema in non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION)
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

The optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).

This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.

Hatched overlay: artifacts

title: Atrial flutter with 2:1 atrioventricular (AV) block
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regularly irregular rhythm
- Atrial rate of ∼ 300/min and ventricular rate of ∼ 150/min
- Normal axis (R > S in I and aVF)
- Sawtooth P-wave morphology (flutter/F waves) best seen in II, III, aVF (indicated by green lines)

These findings are indicative of atrial flutter with 2:1 AV block.

title: Premature ventricular complex
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: ∼ 60/min
– Normal axis
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Single premature ventricular complex (at far right of each strip) with typical morphology (broad QRS, polarity of ST segment, and T wave discordant with QRS complex)

title: Tractional retinal detachment in proliferative diabetic retinopathy
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

Fibrovascular proliferation (green overlay) obscures the optic disc (dashed circle) and can be seen extending along the retinal vasculature in fibrovascular strands. This has resulted in tractional retinal detachment (blue overlay). Multiple retinal hemorrhages can also be seen (arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

M: macula; N: nasal; T: temporal

title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

title: Duodenal stenosis from annular pancreas
description:
Upper GI series (single contrast; lateral view)

Narrowing of the second (descending) portion of the duodenum (white arrow) remained fixed during fluoroscopy. A CT scan (not shown) revealed an annular pancreas as the cause.

DB: duodenal bulb; S: stomach

title: Pneumothorax without tension
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).

The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a premature neonate

Multiple loops of gas-filled bowel are seen, some of which are accompanied by linear (example indicated by red arrowhead) and bubbly (examples indicated by green arrowheads) lucencies that indicate intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis; areas in green circles). Subtle linear lucencies (examples indicated by black arrowheads) projecting over the right upper quadrant might indicate portal venous gas. There is no pneumoperitoneum.

An NG tube (yellow overlay) terminates in the stomach.

title: Entamoeba histolytica cyst
description:
Photomicrograph of a stool mount (chlorazol black stain; very high magnification)

A circular Entamoeba histolytica cyst with a darkly stained chromatoid body (green overlay) can be seen. Mature cysts usually contain four nuclei, but only three are visible (red overlay) in this focal plane.

title: Double bubble sign on ultrasound
description:
Ultrasound of a fetus in the second trimester with duodenal atresia

The stomach (S) and proximal duodenum (D) show severe dilatation and fluid collection (resembling two bubbles). Both structures are separated by the pyloric sphincter (green overlay).

title: Thalamic hemorrhage
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of an older adult

Hyperdense hemorrhage (blue overlay) involving the right thalamus extends to the posterior limb of the right internal capsule. Intraventricular hemorrhage (yellow overlay) is also present. Mass-effect has caused a slight midline shift.

Prominent sulci and ventricles are consistent with cerebral atrophy.

Green overlay: internal capsule; red line: midline; T: thalamus

title: Pneumatosis intestinalis and free air in necrotizing enterocolitis
description:
X-ray abdomen (cross-table lateral view) of an infant with necrotizing enterocolitis

Small collections of gas (pneumatosis intestinalis; examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within the intestinal wall. Free intraperitoneal air has ascended to a nondependent position within the anterior abdomen and has extended into the anterior abdominal wall (green overlay).

Red line: nasogastric tube

title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonate

Multiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).

Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
description:
X-ray left knee (lateral view) of patient with history of recurrent minor trauma and chronic proximal anterior tibial pain

An ossified fragment (green overlay) is separate from the remainder of the tibial tuberosity, which shows an irregular margin (yellow overlay). There is thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) and pretibial soft tissues (blue overlay).

In conjunction with the clinical presentation, the radiographic features are consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

title: Klebsiella pneumoniae
description:
Photomicrograph of a sputum specimen (Gram stain and safranin counterstain; 100x)

Short, gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria (pink appearance due to the safranin counterstain; examples indicated by green overlay) can be seen. Some of them have formed short chains.

Several neutrophil granulocytes are also visible (examples indicated by arrowheads).

title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
description:
CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)

A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.

Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.

AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

title: Atelectasis
description:
X-ray chest (AP view)

Suboptimal aeration has resulted in areas of ill-defined opacification in both lungs (example indicated by red overlay). Additionally, there is marked opacification of the retrocardiac lower left lung (green circle), with non-visualization of left lower lobe pulmonary vessels and obscuration of the margin of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by dashed line). The overall volume of the left lung is reduced; the distance between ribs (indicated by black and white double-arrows) is smaller on the left than right, and the cardiac silhouette is positioned slightly to the left of normal (indicated by dashed and continuous lines and arrows) despite good positioning of the patient (similar distance between spinous processes and medial clavicles bilaterally; yellow overlay).

The above findings indicate the presence of atelectasis, which is marked in the lower left lung. Clinical parameters would help exclude concomitant pneumonia or aspiration.

Blue overlay: ECG pads

title: Small bowel obstruction
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view; erect)

Multiple distended bowel loops (examples indicated by white dashed outlines) are seen, many of which contain air-fluid levels (examples indicated by green overlay). A distended colon (with haustra) is not visible. The pattern of the distended loops suggests small bowel obstruction.

S: stomach

title: Red cell schizont (P. vivax)
description: Giemsa-stained blood smear showing erythrocytes of a patient infected with Plasmodium vivax. In the middle, there is a red cell schizont (green overlay), which is an erythrocyte containing many merozoites (yellow overlay). Within the red cell schizont, merozoites replicate asexually every of 48–72 hours, depending on the type of Plasmodium. The increased parasite burden causes the infected erythrocytes to burst. A subsequent release of proinflammatory factors results in a fever spike. Merozoites, which have been set free from the erythrocyte, enter other erythrocytes in order to replicate again.

title: Renal cell carcinoma
description:
Photograph of a nephrectomy specimen

A large, yellow mass (green overlay) is visible infiltrating the top half of the kidney (K).

title: Pancreatic pseudocyst
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial view)

A large circumscribed fluid collection (green overlay) with an enhancing wall (red overlay) surrounds the pancreas (P).

title: Choanal atresia
description:
Retropalatal endoscopic view

Unilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

title: Paracoccidioidomycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.

title: Lewy body and Lewy neurite
description:
Photomicrographs of a substantia nigra tissue sample (A: H&E stain, 500x magnification; B: immunochemical α-synuclein stain, 400x magnification)

Image A: An eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion (Lewy body; blue overlay) is visible inside a neuron. There is a large accumulation of neuromelanin (brown granules; green overlay).

Image B: A neurite staining positive for α-synuclein is visible in the center of the image (Lewy neurite; yellow overlay).

Lewy bodies and neurites are seen in various neurodegenerative disorders, e.g., Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies.

title: Osteosarcoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

Osteoid (appearing as a homogeneous, partially strand-like, eosinophilic substance) interspersed with tightly packed spindle cells and some osteoclast-like, multinucleated giant cells (examples indicated by green overlay). The tissue shows typical hallmarks of malignancy, e.g., high mitotic index, irregular sizes and shapes of cells and nuclear membranes (examples indicated by arrowheads), and the presence of osteoclast-like giant cells.

This is the typical histological appearance of osteosarcoma.

title: Reticulocytes in peripheral blood
description:
Photomicrograph of a blood smear (supravital staining)

A mixture of cells can be seen, some of which (reticulocytes) contain deep blue granular or meshwork-like cytoplasmic RNA inclusions (red overlay). Reticulocytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are slightly larger and rounder than mature erythrocytes and usually lack their characteristic central pallor.

Multiple mature erythrocytes can also be seen. They feature no cytoplasmic RNA inclusions, usually show distinct central pallor, and are less spherical than reticulocytes.

title: Splinter hemorrhages in endocarditis
description: The vertical hemorrhages (arrowheads) underneath this patient's fingernails are most commonly caused by trauma but can also occur as a result of immune complex deposition or microthrombosis in subacute, infective endocarditis, SLE, or rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Concentric hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
description:
Four transverse slices of the heart

There is concentric hypertrophy (indicated by arrows) of the left ventricular myocardium (green overlay), which has narrowed the lumen (red overlay) and caused a reduction in the intraventricular volume.

title: Lytic calvarial lesions in multiple myeloma
description:
X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Numerous very small, well-circumscribed (punched-out) lytic lesions without sclerotic margins are seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).

title: Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma
description:
MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a child

A large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).

Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

title: Epidural hematoma
description:
CT head (axial section; noncontrast)

An epidural hematoma is visible as a solitary biconvex hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region (green overlay), causing a midline shift to the contralateral side (indicated by lines and arrows). The soft tissue of the scalp overlying the lesion also appears hyperdense, indicating a scalp hematoma (red overlay).

title: Flail chest
description:
X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs

title: Facial edema in drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
description:
Facial erythema and edema are visible, sparing only the periorbital region. The erythema, especially around the mouth, has an eczematous appearance.

Facial edema is a common clinical feature in DRESS, but also occurs in many other conditions. The triad of high fever, extensive skin rash, and organ involvement should raise concern for DRESS.

title: Sarcoidosis
description:
CT of the thorax (axial view)

Bilateral hyperdensities in the areas of the mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes can be seen (green overlay).
There is also evidence of right-sided pleural effusion (red overlay).

This is the typical appearance of bilateral lymphadenopathy, a common finding in sarcoidosis.

title: CTG showing sinusoidal variability
description:
20 minute cardiotocogram (CTG) section

Upper blue trace: fetal heart rate in beats per minute (bpm)
Middle trace (black bars; light blue overlay): fetal movement recording
Lower blue trace: maternal contractions in mmHg

The baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm (dashed green line overlay) is within the normal range (110-160 bpm; light green overlay). However, the oscillation is smooth and regular, resembling a sinus wave (rather than the spiky and slightly irregular appearance of a normal trace).

Fetal movements are sparse. There are two contractions visible ∼ 10 minutes apart.

This is a highly concerning CTG suggestive of severe fetal anemia or hypoxia.

title: Struvite crystals
description:
Photomicrograph of a canine urine sample

Sample shows clear, euhedral, rectangular prism crystals (struvite crystals with their characteristic coffin-lid appearance (cf. illustration); examples indicated by green overlay) composed of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. In humans, struvite crystals are only seen in upper urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing organisms (e.g., Proteus or Klebsiella species).

title: Dawson fingers
description:
MRI Brain (FLAIR; axial view)

There are periventricular areas of linear and ovoid hyperintense signal orientated perpendicular to the body of the right lateral ventricle (green overlay).

This feature is known as Dawson fingers and is strongly associated with multiple sclerosis. It represents perivascular inflammation around the subependymal veins.

title: Widened mediastinum
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a Stanford type A dissection

Widening of the mediastinum is accompanied by a prominent aortic knob on the left side (green dashed line) and convexity in the region of the ascending aorta on the right side (red dashed line). Cardiac silhouette enlargement is also visible (black arrow line), which could indicate aortic regurgitation or pericardial effusion.

Orange dashed line: proximal descending aorta

title: Orthodromic and antidromic AVRT
description: Atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia (AVRT) can occur when an accessory pathway allows the formation of a reentrant circuit. AVRT is classified as orthodromic (90–95%; conduction through AV node is atrium → ventricle) or antidromic (rare; conduction through AV node is ventricle → atrium), which can be differentiated by their ECG features. Note that the ECG of antidromic AVRT is very difficult to distinguish from that of ventricular tachycardia (VT).

title: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)
description:
Left: ultrasound abdomen (transverse plane); right: CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of AAA and increasing mid abdominal pain over 24 hours

Luminal thrombus is heterogeneous on point-of-care ultrasound performed in the emergency room. An elongated hypoechoic area projecting from the right side of the aorta (red overlay) is suspicious for para-aortic hemorrhage from rupture of the aneurysm.

Intermittent calcification helps define the aortic wall on CT. The extent of a large right retroperitoneal hematoma (green overlay) is well demonstrated. The attenuation of the collection is compatible with subacute hemorrhage.

A: aneurysmal abdominal aorta

title: Semilobar holoprosencephaly
description:
MRI head (FLAIR weighted; axial plane) of a 12-month-old boy with global developmental delay, irregular sleep patterns, and poor weight gain.

There is incomplete forebrain division, with the cerebral lobes differentiated posteriorly but remaining fused anteriorly. The lateral ventricles are also fused.

title: Hirschsprung disease
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newborn

A massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.

Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

title: Gout of the knee
description:
X-ray knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of gout

An eccentric lesion involves the lateral femoral condyle (green overlay) and adjacent soft tissues (red overlay). A sclerotic margin is seen along part of the lesion (arrowheads).

title: Right lower lobe consolidation
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of aspiration pneumonia

Heterogeneous consolidation is present in the lower lobe of the right lung (green circle). There is also fullness overlying the inferior aspect of the right hilum, which is suspicious for lymphadenopathy (red circle).

In an erect patient, aspiration is likely to involve basal lung segments as well as the middle lobe and lingula. The upper lobe posterior segments and lower lobe superior segments are more likely to be involved in a recumbent patient.

title: Generalized exfoliative dermatitis
description:
57-year-old man with a long-standing history of psoriatic arthritis, two weeks after stopping all medications

The upper body and feet show severe erythroderma, generalized diffuse yellow scaling, and nail involvement.

These features represent a generalized exfoliative dermatitis, caused by an outbreak of erythrodermic psoriasis, which was precipitated here by medication cessation.

title: Takayasu arteritis
description:
MRI angiography aorta (A: with contrast; sagittal plane. B: inversion recovery dark blood sequence; axial plane)

The descending aorta shows luminal dilatation and irregularity (A: green overlay), with multiple areas of wall thickening (B: examples indicated by red dimension lines).

These features are characteristic of Takayasu arteritis.

title: Genital herpes
description:
Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

title: Bacillary angiomatosis
description:
Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.

This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.

title: Single-chamber cardiac pacemaker
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A single-chamber pacemaker is visible, with the pulse generator (G) on the upper right chest wall and a single lead wire (green dashed line) in the right ventricle.

Additional radiographic findings include mild cardiac silhouette enlargement, aortic tortuosity, and thoracic spine curvature with degenerative changes.

title: Chiari II malformation
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a neonate

The brainstem (red overlay) is elongated. The medulla (M), fourth ventricle (yellow overlay), and cerebellum (green overlay) are displaced caudally through the foramen magnum (white dashed line).

title: Spiculated lung mass
description:
X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinoma

A spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).

RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

title: Enlarged cardiac silhouette
description:
Chest X-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of pericarditis and clinical findings of tamponade

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (globular water bottle-shape; enlargement highlighted by green-hatched overlay) due to pericardial effusion.

title: Acute ulcerative colitis
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Mucosal granularity and ulcerations (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

title: Hepatocellular carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

The cancerous tissue (border indicated by green line) features tumor cells with granular eosinophil cytoplasm and nuclear pleomorphism (examples indicated by green arrow and green overlay). Adjacent to the neoplasm is a portal field (border indicated by red dashed line) with fibrosis, minimal inflammation, and an inconspicuous bile duct (red overlay). Normal liver tissue is not depicted here.

This is the appearance of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.

title: Ichthyosis vulgaris
description:
The skin of the shins appears dry and scaly (fish-scale pattern).

These findings are characteristic of ichthyosis vulgaris and usually affect extensor aspects of the limbs. Skin folds are usually spared.

title: Disseminated varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection
description:
Disseminated VZV infection in an immunocompromised patient with HIV

A vesicular, pustular rash, with lesions in different stages of healing, is visible on the throat and back.

title: Citric acid cycle
description:
The citric acid cycle (CAC) or Krebs cycle occurs in the mitochondria. It is the common metabolic pathway at the end of the degradation of carbohydrates, lipids, and numerous amino acids. The CAC also produces precursors for the biosynthesis of other biologically important molecules.

The breakdown of glucose in glycolysis yields pyruvate, which enters the CAC in the form of acetyl-CoA. Fatty and amino acids also enter as acetyl-CoA. The condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate results in the formation of citrate or citric acid, which gives the cycle its name.

Each C2 molecule that enters the cycle leads to the production of 10 ATP, three molecules of NADH+H+, and one FADH2. In this way, each C2 molecule is completely oxidized to CO2 and water. The resulting oxaloacetate is recycled.

title: Pituitary mass 2/2
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

title: Abdominal aorta and inferior vena cava
description:
Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.

title: Hepatic venous obstruction in Budd-Chiari syndrome
description:
Ultrasound liver (hepatic veins; longitudinal plane)

Echogenic thrombus (green overlay) obstructs the region of the confluence of the hepatic veins with the inferior vena cava.

The term Budd-Chiari syndrome refers to the clinical manifestations of hepatic venous outflow obstruction. Other imaging findings can include narrowing or a lack of visualization of the hepatic veins, enlargement of the caudate lobe of the liver, splenomegaly, and ascites. Color Doppler may show absence or reversal of hepatic venous flow or reduced phasicity of the hepatic venous waveform.

title: Thoracic outlet syndrome secondary to hyperabduction
description: Hyperabduction of the arm can lead to compression of the neurovascular structures under the coracoid process through the pectoralis minor muscle.

title: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo
description:
Cranial MRI (T2-weighted, axial view)

The butterfly-shaped lateral ventricles are symmetrically dilated and filled with CSF (green overlay). The cerebral gyri appear atrophic (example indicated by white asterisk) and the sulci are deep and prominent (example indicated by black arrow).

These features are characteristic of hydrocephalus ex vacuo, a condition in which the ventricles dilate due to brain parenchymal atrophy and CSF fills the void.

title: Polycythemia vera
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

There is normal maturation of the three bone marrow cell lineages (erythropoiesis; examples indicated by yellow overlay, granulopoiesis; examples indicated by green overlay, and thrombopoiesis). The megakaryocytes are pleomorphic, with atypical and sometimes hyperlobated nuclei (example indicated by red overlay).

These features are typical of polycythemia vera.

title: Podocyte foot processes fusion in minimal change disease
description:
Electron micrograph of kidney tissue

The effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).

This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

title: Torsades de pointes
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT; rate ∼ 200/min)
– QRS complexes are wide (∼ 280 ms) and appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern (best seen in V2; indicated by green ellipse).

These findings are characteristic of torsades de pointes (TdP), a subtype of polymorphic VT.

Note how the initial sinus rhythm converts to VT/TdP as a result of the R-on-T phenomenon (best seen in rhythm strip II): After the initial normal sinus complex (green overlay), a premature ventricular complex (PVC; red overlay) occurs in the downslope of the T wave, initiating a brief period of VT. After one further sinus complex, the phenomenon repeats itself and initiates a more prolonged period of VT/TdP.

title: Chronic lacunar infarcts
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Multiple, very small, sharply-demarcated hypodense lesions are present in the basal ganglia (green overlay), left internal capsule (blue overlay), and right thalamus (red overlay). Additionally, there is diffuse cerebral atrophy with prominence of the sulci and ventricles.

title: Serratia marcescens colonies
description:
Agar gel plate

Several isolated, partially confluent, round colonies of Serratia marcescens can be seen on the agar medium. The colonies appear red due to the production of a color pigment (prodigiosin).

title: Bamboo spine and dagger sign in ankylosing spondylitis
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (AP view)

Marginal syndesmophytes formed by ossification of outer fibers of the annulus fibrosis have caused the spine to resemble a bamboo stem (so-called “bamboo spine”; red outlines).

Additional ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments has produced a dense line (dagger sign; green overlay) projecting through the vertebrae. Fusion (ankylosis) across the sacroiliac joints (indicated by arrowheads) can also be seen.

title: Mandibular advancement device
description: The device is worn during sleep to treat mild to moderate obstructive sleep apnea or primary snoring. It pushes the lower jaw forward, leading to a wider opening of the upper airway and preventing airway collapse.

title: Waxy casts
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

Degenerating granular casts are described as waxy casts, which typically have a homogeneous, smooth, yellowish appearance and show clearly defined, dark borders with blunt and broken-off ends. They are more brittle and fragile in comparison with other casts. The lower figure shows a segmented example, where sharp indentations are easily recognizable.

Waxy casts are found in the urine sediment of patients with chronic kidney failure.

title: Anterior Chapman points (osteopathy)
description: Anterior Chapman point locations

title: Facial features of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
description: Photographs of two patients with the genetic disorder Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are shown. Both patients have prominent eyes, a thin face with sunken cheeks, and small lips (due to reduced subcutaneous fat tissue). The patient on the right has lobeless ears, which are a common sign of this condition.

title: Wallenberg syndrome
description:
Wallenberg syndrome results from occlusion of either the vertebral artery or its branch, the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Occlusion leads to lateral medullary infarction, which can affect multiple brainstem areas in the following ways:

– Lateral spinothalamic tract (purple): contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs
– Trigeminal nucleus (purple): ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face
– Vestibular nucleus (red): vertigo with falling to the affected side and nystagmus to the opposite side
– Inferior cerebellar peduncle (dark blue): ataxia and dysmetria
– Nucleus ambiguus (green): dysphagia, hoarseness, and a decreased gag reflex
– Sympathetic fibers (light blue): Horner syndrome

Nucleus ambiguus injury and damage to sympathetic fibers can both cause persistent hiccups.

title: Metaphyseal torus fractures of the radius and ulna
description:
X-ray right forearm and wrist (PA view) of a young child

Fall on the outstretched hand caused axial loading of the radius and ulna along their long axes. The resultant trabecular compression (yellow overlay) produced torus (buckle; green overlay) fractures of each metaphysis.

Ossification centers in the wrist and hand have not yet fully developed in this child. The normal cartilaginous growth plate (physis; red overlay) of the radius is visible as a lucent region.

title: Hair-on-end appearance of the skull
description:
X-ray skull (lateral view) of a child with beta thalassemia

Expansion of the diploic space with thickening of the trabeculae (example indicated by green overlay) is the result of extramedullary hematopoiesis. The hair-on-end appearance (examples indicated by red lines) produced can also be seen in other chronic hemolytic anemias.

title: Atrial fibrillation
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
description:
MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

title: Accordion sign in pseudomembranous colitis
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with pseudomembranous colitis

Enhanced hyperemic colonic mucosa is stretched over thickened submucosal folds (examples indicated by green lines), simulating the appearance of an accordion. The accordion, or concertina, sign can also be seen when oral contrast is trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes.

The accordion sign is considered highly suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis, although other forms of colitis have been reported to produce the same appearance.

arrow: intramural air; K: kidney

title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
description:
1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

title: Hypothalamic-pituitary-somatotropic axis
description:
Hypothalamic hormone GHRH (growth hormone-releasing hormone) stimulates the release of growth hormone (GH) from the acidophilic cells of the pituitary gland. GH-release is inhibited by somatostatin (growth hormone-inhibiting hormone, GHIH), which is produced in the hypothalamus and D cells (pancreas, duodenum). Ghrelin (produced in stomach) acts as another stimulator of GH-release.

As a nontropic hormone, GH either directly stimulates target cells or acts indirectly via synthesis of insulin-like growth factors (IGFs). GH-release is inhibited by GH itself and IGFs, GHRH-release only by IGFs.

title: Felon (pulp space infection)
description: The distal thumb is erythematous and swollen. At the tip, a likely pus-filled compartment is visible.

title: Ingrown toenail
description: The hallux toenail has grown into the subcutaneous tissue. The skin around the nail matrix is erythematous and swollen, and the surface is shiny. There are signs of pus discharge and bleeding.

title: Anatomical structures at risk in humerus fractures
description:
Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

title: Neonatal herpes simplex
description:
Scalp of a 9-day-old newborn

Multiple partially confluent vesicles on an erythematous base are visible on the right frontotemporal aspect of the scalp. Further erythematous patches can be seen over the right temple and forehead.

title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
description:
Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

title: Galactocele
description:
Ultrasound breast (targeted; palpable lesion) of galactoceles in two lactating women

The palpable masses in A and B are circumscribed and wider-than-tall (oriented parallel to the skin). They have thick hyperechoic walls and both hypoechoic (green overlay) and hyperechoic (yellow overlay) internal components. The palpable mass in B additionally has a hypoechoic rim (black arrows). Both lesions show posterior acoustic enhancement.

The appearances of galactoceles vary with the amounts of fluid and solid milk components contained in the lesions. They can appear cystic, mixed cystic and solid, or solid. When present, the demonstration of a fat-fluid level (dashed line) can help confirm the diagnosis.

title: Alport syndrome
description:
Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).

These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

title: Ring-enhancing lesion left temporal lobe
description:
MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with a history of left advanced otitis media

In the left temporal lobe, there is an oval lesion with ring-like contrast enhancement (green outline), central low signal intensity necrosis (green hatching), and perifocal edema (white area). The walls of the left ear canal and middle ear are thickened and show contrast enhancement consistent with otitis media and otitis externa.

The appearance of the temporal lobe lesion is compatible with an abscess. Examples of other brain lesions that may show ring enhancement include cerebral toxoplasmosis, primary CNS lymphoma, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

title: Metabolism of methionine, isoleucine, valine, and threonine
description: The amino acids methionine, isoleucine, valine, and threonine are metabolized to succinyl-CoA via propionyl-CoA and methylmalonyl-CoA. Succinyl-CoA is introduced into the citric acid cycle and can, when required, enter into gluconeogenesis via oxaloacetate.

title: Burton line
description:
The gums and teeth of a 7-year-old boy

A purplish-blue line (Burton line; green overlay) is visible at the margin of the gums.

A Burton line is typically seen in patients with chronic lead poisoning.

title: Herpes simplex keratitis
description:
Slit lamp photography with fluorescein application under cobalt blue light filter

Fluorescein staining of the cornea under blue light shows green fluorescence of geographic epithelial defects. These defects are characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis, though less common than dendritic epithelial defects, which represent the hallmark of herpes simplex keratitis.

title: Osteoid osteoma
description:
X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boy

A small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).

The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.

title: Spinal epidural hematoma
description:
MRI spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

A hyperintense collection (green overlay) in the posterior spinal epidural space at level T11–L1 causes a narrowing of the spinal canal and compression of the spinal cord. There is an increased T2 signal (red overlay) within the cord, likely reflecting cord edema.

These findings are consistent with spinal epidural hematoma.

title: Ground glass opacification in Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

There is widespread increased attenuation of the lung parenchyma with preservation of bronchial and vascular markings (ground-glass opacification; green overlay). In the posterior lungs, markings are obscured by consolidation (red overlay). Scattered small gas-filled cystic spaces (pneumatoceles; examples indicated by white arrows) are present bilaterally.

Extensive ground-glass opacification is a frequent feature of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and may be accompanied by pneumatoceles.

S: sternum; AA: ascending Aorta; PT: pulmonary trunk; DA: descending aorta; V: vertebra; RMB: right mainstem bronchus; LMB: left mainstem bronchus

title: Signal transduction at the motor end plate
description:
The axon of an α-motor neuron supplying a certain muscle fiber splits up into several synaptic terminal buttons. This is where neuromuscular transmission occurs.

(1) An action potential triggers depolarization of the presynaptic membrane.
(2) The influx of calcium ions is mediated by voltage-gated calcium channels.
(3) The synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane and subsequently release the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh).
(4) ACh diffuses through the synaptic cleft and binds to postsynaptic nicotinic receptors.
(5) The attachment to nicotinic receptors triggers a conformational change allowing sodium ions to enter the muscle cell. The influx of sodium ions leads to depolarization with subsequent formation of an end-plate potential (EPP).
(6) Signal transduction is terminated by cleavage of ACh into acetate and choline. The process is catalyzed by the enzyme cholinesterase.
(7) Acetate and choline undergo reuptake into the presynaptic membrane to function as a substrate for the production of new ACh.

title: Overt umbilical cord prolapse
description: The umbilical cord lies between the presenting part of the fetus and the maternal pelvic wall. The membranes are ruptured, and the cord prolapses into the cervical canal or further. There is a high risk of cord compression and life-threatening hypoxia for the fetus. Management includes intrauterine resuscitation measures and emergency cesarean delivery.

title: Triphalangeal thumb
description:
X-ray right and left thumb (PA view)

A small triangular bone (delta phalanx, or longitudinal epiphyseal bracket; red overlay) is present between the proximal and distal phalanx of each thumb. There is ulnar deviation of the distal thumbs.

A delta phalanx can appear as an isolated finding or as part of a wide variety of congenital syndromes and dysplasias.

title: Monoamniotic twins
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (15 weeks' gestation)

Twin pregnancy shows a single placenta. There is no intertwin membrane. The left twin is imaged in the coronal plane. The right twin is imaged in the sagittal plane.

A: amniotic fluid; H: head; P: placenta

title: Subungual squamous cell carcinoma
description:
Crusts and erosions can be seen on the right side of the right thumb. The nail appears completely destroyed. On the left side, a punch biopsy was taken for diagnostic purposes.

These findings suggest malignant transformation. However, histologic examination is crucial for diagnosis. In this case histology revealed subungual squamous cell carcinoma.

title: Thoracic aortic aneurysm
description:
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm: the most common type; can arise from the aortic valve to the brachiocephalic trunk
Aortic arch aneurysm: involves the brachiocephalic vessels
Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm: arises distal to the left subclavian artery

title: Laryngeal papillomatosis
description: Laryngoscopy showing laryngeal papillomas, appearing as multiple raspberry-like swellings on vocal cords.

title: Virchow node
description:
A swelling is visible at the left supraclavicular fossa.

This finding is due to enlarged lymph nodes and is typical for lymph node metastasis from gastric cancer. It can also be found in other abdominopelvic malignancies.

title: Subdural hematoma: Etiology
description: Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.

title: Multiloculated hepatic mass
description:
Ultrasound abdomen (liver; left: color Doppler, right: contrast-enhanced ultrasound)

A multiseptated hepatic lesion with an anechoic fluid center (left image) shows no vascular enhancement on color Doppler. The necrotic center also does not enhance on contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS; right image), although enhancement of the septae and surrounding parenchyma on CEUS increases the conspicuity of the lesion.

title: Pulmonary fibrosis
description:
CT chest (high resolution; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with usual interstitial pneumonia

A diffuse reticular interstitial pattern is accompanied by traction bronchiectasis (examples indicated by green outline) and clustered small cystic air spaces (honeycombing). Multilayered honeycombing (example indicated by red outline) is conspicuous in the periphery of the lungs.

title: Tubal ring sign (blob sign) of ectopic pregnancy
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal; oblique plane)

In the right adnexa, an ectopic pregnancy is visible as a rounded mass (blob sign) adjacent to the right ovary (blue overlay). Echoes are seen within fluid in the peritoneal space, indicating hemoperitoneum with coagulated blood. A small hyperechoic linear structure located centrally within the endometrial cavity represents the visible portion of an IUD (red overlay).

Green overlay: uterus

title: Ectopic pregnancy
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal; sagittal plane)

A gestational sac (indicated by cursors) containing an embryo (green overlay) is seen during adnexal imaging. There is no adjacent free fluid. The uterus is not visible on this image.

title: Venous stasis
description:
Diffuse erythema with livid discoloration and irregular white scarring (atrophie blanche) of both lower legs is visible.

This is the typical appearance of venous eczema, as a result of long-term venous stasis.

title: Costophrenic sulcus blunting from pleural effusion
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with tamoxifen-induced acute eosinophilic pneumonia

Peribronchial thickening (examples circled in yellow) and linear parenchymal opacities (examples indicated by white lines) are evidence of interstitial lung disease. A small pleural effusion (red line) projects through the right hemidiaphragm and blunts the right lateral costophrenic sulcus. A normal costophrenic sulcus is typically seen as an acutely angled junction between the costal and diaphragmatic pleural reflections (white dashed line).

Right chest wall staples (examples indicated by black overlays) and breast asymmetry (green outline) are the result of a recent mastectomy and reconstruction.

title: Necrolytic migratory erythema
description:
Feet of a patient with pancreatic glucagonoma

An annular erythema consisting of ring-shaped, linear, bronze-colored areas as well as red patches is visible. The surface of the erythema crusts and has formed macules and erosions.

These lesions are suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema associated with pancreatic glucagonoma. They can be differentiated from acrodermatitis enteropathica by the measurement of plasma zinc levels.

title: Resolution of subconjunctival hemorrhage
description:
Photograph of a patient's left eye showing subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Top (one week after hemorrhage): large, sharply demarcated areas of the sclera are red, indicating recent subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Bottom (four weeks after hemorrhage): while the lateral sclera is still red, the medial sclera has become yellow, indicating reabsorption of the blood and resolution of the hemorrhage.

Usually, subconjunctival hemorrhage resolves spontaneously within 2–3 weeks, with the color changing from red to shades of orange and yellow before clearing completely. Persistent or recurrent hemorrhage requires further investigation.

title: Rheumatoid arthritis of the wrist and hand
description:
X-ray hands (PA view)

There is generalized periarticular osteopenia (example indicated by green overlay) and narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint spaces (example indicated by green line). The marked deformity of the wrists is the result of numerous carpal, base of metacarpal, and radiocarpal erosions (red lines). Erosive scalloping (example indicated by yellow line) also involves the radioulnar joint.

The radiographic findings are typical of rheumatoid arthritis with advanced wrist involvement.

title: Paget disease of pelvis
description:
X-ray pelvis

Enlargement of the right hemipelvis is accompanied by coarsened trabeculation and areas of sclerosis compatible with abnormal remodeling in Paget disease (green overlay).

title: Colles fracture
description:
X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view) after a fall onto an outstretched hand

A metaphyseal fracture of the distal radius (green line) shows dorsal angulation of the distal fragment and impaction. (The vertical white line represents the axis of the radius. The horizontal white line represents the right angle that the radial articular surface physiologically stands at. The dotted white line illustrates the dorsal angulation of the distal fragment.) This type of fracture has been termed a Colles fracture. The pronator quadratus fat pad is displaced and seen as a convex lucency (red curved line). A fracture of the ulnar styloid is also present (white arrow).

title: Omega-shaped epiglottis
description:
Laryngoscopy

During inspiration, the lateral folds of the epiglottis curl inward, creating an omega shape. This finding may be a normal variation but is more frequently seen in laryngomalacia. Clinical correlation is required to establish a diagnosis of laryngomalacia.

title: Small cell lung cancer
description:
Photomicrograph of small cell lung cancer (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Sheets of small round cells with scanty cytoplasm and deep blue nuclei are visible throughout the image. The stroma (pink hypocellular tissue) is scanty.

This is the typical appearance of small cell lung cancer at high magnification.

title: Osler-Weber-Rendu disease
description:
Telangiectasia of the tongue and lips are visible in this patient.

This is a typical finding in Osler-Weber-Rendu disease, a rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder.

title: Normal bronchial histology
description:
Photomicrograph of bronchial tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Layers of the bronchial wall are visible. The innermost layer is formed by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked with green outline) containing goblet cells (yellow overlay) and intercalated between epitheliocytes. Beneath the epithelium is a fibromuscular layer (smooth muscle tissue marked by green overlay) with hyaline cartilage (black dashed outline) and seromucous glands (black dotted outline).

title: Solar lentigo
description:
Multiple hyperpigmented brown macules are visible on this older patient's hand.

This is the characteristic appearance and location of solar lentigo, which results from exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

title: Dyshidrotic eczema
description:
Multiple vesicles with an erythematous base are visible on the finger.

These findings are suggestive of dyshidrotic eczema.

title: Auer rods in acute myeloblastic leukemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain; high magnification)

Multiple red rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusions (Auer rods, highlighted by gray overlay) are visible within a myeloblast, the large basophilic cell (marked by arrow) with an eccentric, indented nucleus (marked by black outline) and a prominent nucleolus (green overlay).

Auer rods are typically seen in acute myeloblastic leukemia and acute promyelocytic leukemia.

title: Lumbar spinal stenosis
description:
MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Advanced degenerative changes (red overlay) involve the intervertebral disks and posterior elements at multiple levels. The spinal canal (green overlay) is narrowed at L2–3 and L3–4 (indicated by arrows).

White dashed outline: spinal cord

title: Coagulative necrosis of the spleen
description:
Gross specimen of a spleen post infarction

Multiple infarcts can be seen as lighter-colored areas of coagulative necrosis against the normal dark red splenic tissue. Splenic infarcts are classically subcapsular and wedge-shaped, following the spleen's segmental arterial supply (e.g., infarct in top left).

title: Bilateral femoral head avascular necrosis
description:
X-ray pelvis (anteroposterior view)

Increased density of the femoral heads (green overlay) is accompanied by articular surface irregularity and subchondral lucency (crescent sign; red line overlay).

title: Atopic dermatitis
description:
A scaly, erythematous plaque surrounded by multiple, partly confluent, follicular papules is visible on the skin of the antecubital fossa.

This finding is characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

title: Trochlear nerve palsy
description:
Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.

Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).

title: Abducens nerve palsy
description: Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

title: Trochlear nerve palsy
description: Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) and excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye (middle image). Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia may increase with ipsilateral head-tilt (right image) and decrease with contralateral head-tilt (left image; patients may adopt this posture as a compensatory posture).

title: Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma
description:
The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.

These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

title: Toe gangrene
description:
There are areas of black, necrotic tissue visible on the first toe of the right foot and the third toe of the left foot surrounded by white areas of maceration. Furthermore, the fifth toe of the left foot shows early signs of autoamputation. Massive trophic nail changes can be seen especially on the left foot. Generally, the toes of the left foot look swollen and have a livid discoloration (left more than right).

These findings are typical of gangrene, in this patient caused by thromboangiitis obliterans.

title: Kaposi sarcoma on skin
description:
A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

title: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
description:
Photomicrograph of cortical brain tissue (H&E stain)

The tissue shows spongiform degeneration, which is the result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles of varying size (green overlay).

This is the characteristic histopathological appearance of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (detection of prions is only possible via immunohistochemistry).

title: Caseous necrosis in lung tissue
description:
Close-up photograph of a lung

Ivory-white, cottage cheese-like lesion within a cavity in the lung tissue (green overlay).

This is the typical macroscopic appearance of caseous necrosis, which is commonly associated with tuberculosis.

title: Arteriole with fibrinoid necrosis
description:
Microscopic image of arteriole in the lung tissues (H&E stain)

The wall of the arteriole exhibits annular deposition of amorphous and proteinaceous material, and inflammatory infiltrates.

These are the typical features of fibrinoid necrosis.

title: Anthracotic pigment in lung in coal worker's pneumoconiosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain, low magnification)

Accumulations of carbon particles (anthracotic pigment) can be seen in the lung tissue. Some of the pigment can be found in pigment-laden macrophages. Also, collagenous fibrosis is predominant throughout the lung tissue.

This appearance is diagnostic of pneumoconiosis (e.g., coal workers' pneumoconiosis).

title: Intracerebral, intraventricular, and subarachnoid hemorrhage
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Left temporal lobe hemorrhage (red hatched overlay) has extended into the subarachnoid space (red overlay) and ventricular system (green hatched overlay). Impairment of cerebrospinal fluid circulation has resulted in ventricular dilatation and periventricular edema (green overlay).

1 = internal capsule; 2 = lentiform nucleus

title: Papillary muscle rupture
description:
Autopsy specimen of a heart (close-up of the longitudinally opened ventricle)

A papillary muscle of an atrioventricular valve is ruptured (white arrow) and almost completely detached from its valve-sided end (green arrow).

Papillary muscle rupture is a complication of myocardial infarction and, in this case, most likely due to occlusion of a branch of the right coronary artery (e.g., posterior descending artery).

title: Glomus tumor
description: A solitary vascularized subcutaneous nodule is visible on the pulp of the little finger of the left hand.

title: Oculocutaneous albinism
description:
Four Chinese children with oculocutaneous albinism (OCA).

In individuals with OCA, reduction or complete absence of melanin pigment results in abnormal eye development as well as light-colored hair, skin, and eyes. However, the severity of visual impairment and the degree of hypopigmentation (as seen here in the variations of hair and iris color) may vary.

title: Ectopic thyroid tissue
description:
Nuclear medicine thyroid scan (technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope; anterior and lateral views)

Increased uptake of radiotracer is visible in the hyoid region and lingual or sublingual regions. There is no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid gland in the anterior neck.

The findings indicate two sites of ectopic thyroid tissue. The possibility of ectopic tissue in a thyroglossal duct cyst would also be a consideration for the hyoid region uptake.

title: ECG abnormalities in tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus tachycardia (heart rate: ∼143/min)
– Left-axis deviation (R > S in lead I; S > R in aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼160 ms in lead II)
– QT prolongation (QTc ∼556 ms)
– Prominent R wave in aVR

In a patient with suspected drug overdose, wide complex sinus tachycardia with QT prolongation and a prominent R wave in aVR suggest sodium channel blocker toxicity, which may indicate TCA overdose.

title: Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

title: ECG in left ventricular hypertrophy
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼55/min
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal cardiac axis: positive (+) QRS complex polarity in leads I, II, and III
– Broad and bifid P waves (P): referred to as “P mitrale” and suggestive of left atrial enlargement
– SV2 (S) + RV5 (R) >3.5 mV: meets Sokolow-Lyon criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy
– Left ventricular strain pattern: ST depression (ST) with T-wave inversion (T) in left-sided leads I and V4–V6

Positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria and left ventricular strain pattern are characteristic of left ventricular hypertrophy.

title: Cystic hygroma
description:
Right lateral region of the neck

(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.

(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

title: Effects of glucagon on glycogen metabolism
description:
Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-determining step of glycogenolysis and is activated by glucagon or adrenalin (not illustrated here).

Glucagon activates a G protein that stimulates adenylate cyclase, which increases the concentration of cyclic AMP (cAMP). This, in turn, activates the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA). PKA then acts to phosphorylate (P) multiple enzymes, leading to an increase in glycogenolysis:
- PKA activates phosphorylase kinase → activation of glycogen phosphorylase → increased glycogenolysis.
- PKA deactivates glycogen synthase, → decreased glycogen synthesis.
- PKA activates protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) inhibitor → inhibition of protein phosphatase 1 → increased glycogen phosphorylase and phosphorylase kinase (the latter steps are not shown here).

title: Coronary arteries
description:
Coronary artery anatomy in the majority of the population:

Branches of the right coronary artery supply the sinoatrial node, the majority of the right atrium and ventricle, the atrioventricular node, approx. ⅓ of the interventricular septum, and a small part of the inferior surface of the left ventricle.

Branches of the left coronary artery supply the majority of the left atrium and ventricle, the anterior aspects of both ventricles, the cardiac apex, and ⅔ of the interventricular septum.

title: Pap smear showing severe dysplasia
description:
Photomicrograph of squamous cells of the cervix (Papanicolaou stain; very high magnification;)

There is a loosely connected group of abnormal squamous epithelial cells (blue-green cytoplasm). The nuclei are variable in size with a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio and there are course clumps of chromatin. The large cell with pink cytoplasm is a normal superficial squamous cell.

These findings are characteristic of severe dysplasia as seen in high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).

title: Translation initiation
description: Translation in eukaryotes begins with initiation. First, the small ribosomal subunit (40S) combines with specific initiation factors. This prevents premature joining of small and large subunits. The ternary complex of methionine-loaded initiator tRNA, initiation factor eIF-2, and GTP binds to the small ribosomal subunit and forms the 43S preinitiation complex. The mRNA recognized by eIF-4 binds to the 43S preinitiation complex, resulting in the 48S preinitiation complex. Initiator tRNA recognizes the start codon (usually the first AUG triplet after the 5' cap of mRNA). GTP hydrolysis leads to the release of eIF-2-GDP. The large and small ribosomal subunits merge to form the 80S ribosome, the final initiation complex (eukaryotic ribosome).

title: Seborrheic keratosis
description:
Photograph of the face of an adult patient

Two large, brown, fissured papules with a characteristic stuck-on appearance can be seen.

title: Ranula
description: Floor of the mouth of a 55-year-old patient with an asymmetrical, partially white, partially translucent swelling, which extends above the lower teeth. This finding is a ranula, which is a retention cyst arising in the sublingual gland. It is most commonly seen in patients 10–30 years of age. First-line treatment is the excision of the ranula, including the sublingual gland.

title: Keratoderma blenorrhagicum
description:
Soles of an adult patient with reactive arthritis

Multiple hyperpigmented papules and plaques are visible on the soles of the forefoot.
The glabrous skin of the forefoot appears thickened and scaly (hyperkeratosis).

This is the typical manifestation of keratoderma blenorrhagicum, a cutaneous eruption seen in a third of patients with reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome).

title: Stage 3 pelvic organ prolapse
description: The cervix can be seen visibly protruding out of the vaginal introitus of this older postmenopausal patient. Note that the labia are thin and atrophic, a normal postmenopausal change.

title: Nocardia in blood culture
description:
Photomicrograph of bacteria in blood culture (Kinyoun stain)

Clusters of branching, filamentous rods are concentrated in the center.

title: Pulmonary aspergillosis with air crescent sign
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

There are diffuse reticulonodular opacities in both lungs with numerous larger nodules interspersed throughout (examples indicated by red rectangle). In the upper zone of the right lung, an ovoid lesion can be seen that is surrounded by a thin rim with normal radiolucency (arrowheads).

This finding is known as the air crescent sign and is characteristic of aspergilloma.

title: Mycobacteria
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin tissue specimen (H&E stain)

Purple-colored and rod-shaped bacilli (arrowheads) can be seen dispersed throughout the specimen.

This appearance is characteristic of mycobacterial species, such as M. tuberculosis.

title: Pseudomonas aeruginosa on cetrimide agar
description:
Photomicrograph of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on cetrimide agar (high magnification)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes a variety of pigments, including pyocyanin (blue-green), pyoverdine (yellow-green and fluorescent), and pyorubin (red-brown).

title: Negri bodies in a neuron
description:
Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A pyramidal cell (green overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The distinct eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions within the pyramidal cells are Negri bodies (examples indicated by black arrowheads and white dashed outlines).

Negri bodies are most commonly found within the pyramidal cells of hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of patients infected by the rabies virus. Although the presence of Negri bodies is pathognomonic of rabies, their absence does not rule out infection.

title: Multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions
description:
Microscopic image of lung tissue (H&E stain)

Several multinucleated giant cells (syncytial macrophages) can be seen in the center of the image (examples indicated by green overlay), surrounded by inflammatory infiltrate. The giant cells feature characteristic eosinophilic nuclear inclusions (Cowdry type A, blue overlay).

Giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions are a characteristic histopathological finding in infections with varicella zoster virus, herpes simplex virus, and cytomegalovirus.

title: Synovial fluid crystals in gout
description:
Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

title: Torus palatinus
description: A bony protrusion covered with normal mucosa is visible as a bump in the midline of the hard palate.

title: Folliculitis
description: A solitary pustule with surrounding erythema is visible in the center of the image. In many cases of folliculitis, a single hair can be seen in the middle of the lesion.

title: Acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma
description:
CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window)

A crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses cranial sutures is visible on the anterolateral aspect of the right hemisphere. The anterior aspect of the lesion is hypodense (green overlay) indicating a chronic hematoma (serum extrusion and degradation of the clot decreases its radiodensity). The posterior aspect of the lesion is isodense to hyperdense (red overlay), indicating a recent hemorrhage into the existing hematoma (recent blood clots contain concentrated hemoglobin, which is hyperdense). Mass effect is visualized as a shift in the midline (white line) to the left (dashed white line), compression of the left lateral ventricle, and compression of the adjacent cerebral parenchyma, which appears edematous (hyperdense with loss of the sulci and gyri).

These features are characteristic of an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma.

title: Subacute posterior cerebral artery infarct
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A hypodense occipital infarct (green) in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery is accompanied by a loss of normal gray-white matter differentiation. The density of the lesion is greater than that of CSF. There is no mass effect or hemorrhage. Choroid plexus calcifications in the lateral ventricles are physiologic.

title: Coup-contrecoup injury
description:
CT head (axial section; without IV contrast)

Brain window (left): A contusion is visible within the left frontal lobe as a well-defined heterogeneous lesion (green overlay) surrounded by edema (hypodense rim; white overlay).

Bone window (right): A fracture of the skull in the occipital region (red overlay) can be seen.

These features are characteristic of a coup-contrecoup injury wherein the impact of the external force to the back of the head resulted in a cerebral contusion in the frontal lobe.

title: Mallet finger
description:
Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP joints

This condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

title: Boutonniere deformity
description:
Characteristic appearance of the ring finger with flexed PIP and hyperextended DIP joints

This condition is the result of injury to or slippage of the central band of the extensor digitorum, usually caused by trauma (e.g., sports injury) or chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Arcus senilis
description:
Slit-lamp photography of the left eye

A white opacity, caused by lipid deposition, lines the lower and slightly also the upper periphery of the cornea while being clearly separated from the limbus by clear cornea.

This is the typical appearance of an arcus senilis. In the early stages, it is usually seen in the inferior cornea. It may extend to a full circle in more advanced stages. If present in young individuals blood lipid levels should be examined.

title: The cell cycle
description:
The cell cycle can be divided into two phases: interphase and mitosis.

Interphase is further divided into the G1 (gap 1), S (synthesis), and G2 (gap 2) phases, which prepare the cell for division. In the G1 phase, proteins and cell organelles are synthesized. DNA is replicated in the S phase. In the G2 phase, DNA replication errors are repaired. Interphase is followed by mitosis (M) or cell division. There are various checkpoints within the cell cycle that ensure the cell is ready to enter the next phase (G1, G2, and M checkpoints). Only proliferating cells pass through the cell cycle. Most mature tissue cells are in a resting phase, the G0 phase. These cells are differentiated, with each performing a specific function. Mature differentiated cells do not divide.

title: Necrotizing fasciitis
description:
Posterolateral aspect of the left thigh, gluteal region, and popliteal fossa

There is significant diffuse edema and erythema across the entire visible region, with well-defined areas of necrosis, desquamation, and hemorrhagic bullae.

These features are strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, a rapidly progressive infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and superficial and deep fascia that requires urgent debridement.

title: Cancer of the anal margin
description:
Patient in the lithotomy position

An exophytic tumor of the anal margin is visible, located from approximately 12 to 7 o'clock in the lithotomy position. There are also multiple round skin lesions that are approx. 15 mm in diameter, with most on the right buttock bordering the lower back.

title: Paronychia
description: Characteristic finding of paronychia: Periungual erythema and pus lateral to the nail.

title: Paronychia
description: Periungual erythema, swelling, and pus proximal to the nail are characteristic findings of paronychia, in this case caused by Candida.

title: Peroxisome
description: Peroxisomes are small, round organelles that are surrounded by a lipid bilayer and frequently have crystalline inclusions. They contain enzymes that oxidize amino acids and fatty acids. As a result, peroxide is formed, which is converted into water and oxygen by the enzyme catalase.

title: Xanthelasma
description:
Well-defined yellow plaques (xanthelasma) are visible on the medial aspect of the upper and lower eyelids bilaterally.

These cutaneous lipid deposits are a common finding in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

title: Sickle cell disease
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

title: Acne vulgaris
description: Cysts, nodules, papules and comedones (including multiple healed lesions with visible scarring) are visible on this patient's upper back.

title: Diabetic foot ulcer
description:
Right big toe of a patient with diabetes mellitus

A well-demarcated ulceration is visible on the medial aspect of the foot.

This appearance together with a consistent medical history is suggestive of a diabetic foot ulcer, which is likely caused by diabetic polyneuropathy.

title: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus
description:
Three erythematous, maculopapular lesions with crusting can be seen on the left side of the face, at the hairline and supraorbitally. Left periorbital swelling and erythema are also visible.

The distribution and appearance of these lesions suggest herpes zoster ophthalmicus affecting the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

title: Spongy bone with red marrow
description:
Microscopic image of spongy bone (H&E stain, 350x magnification)

A trabecula (dark pink) extends through the spongy bone from the left edge across the lower portion of the image. The trabecula is surrounded by several hematopoietic elements (purple) that make up the red marrow. Dispersed throughout the red marrow are adipocytes (white) that comprise the yellow marrow.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Ataxia telangiectasia
description:
Medial angle of the left eye showing severely dilated blood vessels on the conjunctiva (conjunctival telangiectasia).

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a clinical finding of ataxia telangiectasia (Louis-Bar syndrome), a rare neurocutaneous syndrome

title: Thymine dimer formation
