description: UV light (abbreviated as h×ν) causes damage to the DNA, most commonly by dimerisation of adjoining thymine bases: the C=C double bonds are coupled to form a cyclobutane ring (red). A thymine dimer immediately interrupts DNA replication.

title: Codon wheel
description: The codon wheel is a representation of the genetic code. It shows which mRNA codon translates into which amino acid. The wheel is read from the inside (5' end) to the outside (3' end). For example, the triplet UAC codes for the amino acid tyrosine (Tyr). Start codons are shown as triangles, while stop codons are shown as squares.

title: Chickenpox
description:
A diffuse rash is seen in various stages of lesion evolution (starry-sky appearance), with mainly ruptured vesicles and crusted erosions seen here.

These findings are typical for chickenpox.

title: Lateral view of important areas of the brain
description:
The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

title: Structure of the nucleus
description: The nucleus is surrounded by a nuclear envelope, which consists of an inner and outer nuclear membrane. The inner nuclear membrane is covered by the nuclear lamina, a network of intermediate filaments (lamina) that acts as a support and separates the nuclear membrane from chromatin. The outer nuclear membrane gradually extends into the endoplasmic reticulum. The inner and outer nuclear membranes fuse at some points and form nuclear pores with the aid of large protein complexes. Chromatin is located in the nucleus (karyoplasm). It is present as two forms: euchromatin, which is loosely packaged and active, and heterochromatin, which is densely packaged and inactive. The nucleolus is also located in the karyoplasm and is not surrounded by a membrane. It synthesizes ribosomes and consists of proteins and ribosomal RNA.

title: Spider angioma
description: A telangiectasia characterized by a vascular arcade branching out from a central arteriolar point. Spider angiomas can arise during childhood or pregnancy as well as in patients with liver disease or thyrotoxicosis.

title: Inguinal lymphadenopathy in chancroid
description: There is massive bilateral swelling of inguinal lymph nodes. The skin above the lymph nodes is livid. The causative agent is Haemophilus ducreyi.

title: Vitiligo
description: Frontal photo of a male patient: multiple, partially confluent, irregularly configured, sharply demarcated, hypo-/depigmented macules (white) on the trunk.

title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

title: Vaginal ulcer in chancroid
description: A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

title: Facial rash in chickenpox
description: The face of the girl shows macules, vesicles, and papules on an erythematous base, as well as erupted vesicles and crusted papules. The simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash is sometimes described as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.

title: Chlamydia trachomatis in McCoy cell culture
description:
Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (unknown magnification)

Cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (black arrows) show inclusion bodies (reticulate bodies, here in brown) under the microscope.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular bacteria that require cell culture, rather than growth medium, to grow. This characteristic is especially important for determining the best antibiotic for treatment.

title: Campylobacter jejuni
description:
Scanning electron micrograph

C. jejuni is a spirillum bacteria. Contamination with even very small quantities of C. jejuni causes inflammatory gastroenteritis.

title: Giardia lamblia (trophozoite)
description:
Scanning electron micrograph

The trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia can be seen. Trophozoites are capable of reproduction and have two nuclei (N) in the ventral part as well as flagella (marked with arrows).

title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
description:
Hemorrhage in the region of the left basal ganglia causing a midline shift to the right

The basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the middle cerebral artery. Hemorrhage from a lenticulostriate artery (e.g., due to poorly controlled hypertension or rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm) leads to a basal ganglia hemorrhage.

title: Babesia microti (blood smear)
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

The erythrocyte in the center of this blood smear is infected by the protozoan parasite Babesia microti (green overlay). This obligate intracellular pathogen causes babesiosis.

title: Vitiligo
description:
Localization: dorsal and palmar side of both hands and fingers

Lesion: multiple, partially confluent, irregularly shaped, well demarcated, depigmented macules

title: Lupus pernio
description:
Extensive purple nodular lesions on the nose and cheeks

Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of extrapulmonary sarcoidosis.

title: Grade III urinary tract obstruction
description:
Ultrasound right kidney (longitudinal transhepatic view)

There is dilation of the renal pelvis and the calyces with blunting of the fornices. The renal parenchyma is hypoechoic and the renal capsule (green border) is irregular in shape, indicating a chronic problem.

These findings are consistent with a grade III urinary tract obstruction with evidence of chronicity.

C: calyces; RP: renal pelvis

title: Infraspinatus test
description: The patient's arm is abducted to 90° and the humerus is medially rotated to 30° (green arrow around the arm). The examiner applies resistance (red arrow) to the back of the patient's hand (green arrow), while the patient is asked to maintain his/her position. The examiner should ensure that the patient's elbow is not be positioned against the chest, which would prevent abutment in external rotation (line outlined in red).

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

title: Belly press test
description: The patient is asked to press the anterior abdominal wall with the flat of his/her palm while keeping the hand in a straight line with the forearm, and the elbow flexed to 90°. The test is positive if the patient is unable to press the abdomen without flexing the wrist. A positive test indicates a difficulty in internal rotation of the shoulder due to a lesion in the subscapularis muscle.

title: Jobe test
description: In Jobe test, the examiner applies downward pressure (red arrow) onto the abducted, horizontally flexed, and internally rotated arm of the patient. The patient is asked to resist the downward pressure (green arrow). The supraspinatus muscle, in particular, is required to maintain the arm's position. If there is pain or if the patient is unable to maintain this position against resistance exerted by the examiner, this indicates a functional disorder of the supraspinatus muscle (e.g., rupture, tendinopathy, or subacromial bursitis). If an impairment is present, Jobe's test is considered positive.

title: Displacement of femoral head and hinge abduction in Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
description:
A. Normal anatomy: The femoral head is located in the center of the acetabulum.
B. Femoral head necrosis leads to lateral subluxation and displacement of the femoral head in the acetabulum.
C. Fractures and subsequent bone resorption result in an unstable femoral head. Lateral displacement puts a pathological strain on the femoral head when weight-bearing, which leads to deformities.
D. Hinge abduction: On hip abduction, the deformed lateral pillar of the femoral head impinges on the acetabular rim, preventing the femoral head from entering the acetabulum. This results in a hinge joint articulation instead of a ball-and-socket joint articulation at the hip.

title: Congenital nevus in the intergluteal region
description: Large congenital nevus: Additional malignancy criteria are the diverse coloration and the slightly irregular margin of the nevus.

title: Atypical nevus
description:
An asymmetric, pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variegation is visible over the left little finger.

These are characteristic features of an atypical nevus.

title: Appendicitis with target sign
description:
Ultrasound of the appendix (axial view)

The diameter of the appendix is increased to 12.1 mm (normal ≤ 6 mm). The wall has hyperechoic and hypoechoic layers due to inflammation and resulting edema; because of this appearance, this sign is termed target sign.

These are characteristic features of acute appendicitis.

title: Diverticulitis
description:
Ultrasound left lower quadrant (longitudinal plane)

Diverticula are visible as outpouchings (arrows) on the antimesenteric border of the sigmoid colon (dotted outline). The sigmoid is edematous, with a thickened wall, loss of distinction of mural layers, and narrowing of the lumen (wavy white line). Abnormally hyperechoic inflamed fat (yellow overlay) is also seen. A thin hypoechoic region along the mesenteric border (green overlay) may demonstrate free fluid.

The imaging features are suggestive of diverticulitis.

title: Pityriasis versicolor (tinea versicolor)
description:
There are multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, light-brown macules visible on this patient's back.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, caused by Malassezia species.

title: Pityriasis rosea
description:
Initial eruption (herald patch) and secondary eruption on the trunk

The herald patch (black arrow) is ovoid with a raised dark border and central clearing. The secondary eruption consists of scattered papules and plaques on an erythematous base.

title: Interdigital skin lesions in scabies
description:
Multiple erythematous papules can be seen in the interdigital folds between the index and middle finger.

Interdigital folds are a common site for scabies, as the scabies mite prefers warmer skin regions with a thin keratinous layer.

title: Plaque psoriasis
description: Multiple sharply demarcated erythematosquamous plaques with coarse, silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor sides of the lower arms and elbows.

title: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
description:
Multiple, partially confluent, round circular maculae (purpura) can be seen on both lower legs and thighs.

This is a common cutaneous symptom of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.

title: Lentigo maligna melanoma
description:
An asymmetrical lesion with an irregular border and variable pigmentation is visible on the right cheek. The lesion developed over a 10-year period from a lentigo maligna (in situ carcinoma).

These findings are suggestive of lentigo maligna melanoma.

title: Urticaria
description:
Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

title: Walled-off necrosis (pancreatic abscess)
description:
CT abdomen (IV and oral contrast; axial section) of a patient with a history of pancreatic necrosis

A well-defined, complicated collection (solid outline) containing gas (examples indicated by arrows) is seen in the region of the pancreatic body and tail. Abdominal ascites (hatched overlay) and inflammatory fatty and fascial stranding are present in the right upper quadrant.

L: liver; G: gallbladder; CBD: common bile duct; A: abdominal aorta; K: kidney; V: vertebra

title: Dural based lesion
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a 58-year-old patient with parosmia.

There is a large, well-defined mass with homogeneous contrast enhancement in the olfactory groove (green overlay.

This is an example of an olfactory groove meningioma.

title: Oral lichen planus
description:
Lacelike, white lesions on the oral mucous membrane that cannot be scraped off (Wickham striae) are visible.

This appearance is typical for oral lichen planus.

title: Small cell lung carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

title: Bilateral pleural effusion
description:
Chest CT with contrast (axial view; approx. at the level of T5)

Bilateral crescent-shaped attenuated areas (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pleural effusion.

AA = ascending aorta; DA = descending aorta; PT = pulmonary trunk, Vc = superior vena cava; PA = right pulmonary artery, V = vertebra

title: Adenocarcinoma of the lung
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

title: Ganglion cell with Negri bodies
description:
Photomicrograph of autopsy specimen of brain tissue (H&E stain)

Negri bodies (examples indicated by green arrows) are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies present within the cell bodies and axons of neurons infected by the rabies virus. Although the presence of Negri bodies is pathognomonic of rabies, their absence does not rule out infection.

title: Gastric adenocarcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of gastric tissue from a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are atypical cells forming glandular structures (green circles) of various sizes with intraluminal debris.

These findings are consistent with gastric adenocarcinoma.

title: Multiple sclerosis
description:
MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

At the level of the fourth cervical vertebral body, there is an area of poorly defined hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay). The first cervical vertebra is not well visualized in this image due to its shape, whereas the second cervical vertebra is well recognized due to the superior projected bony element known as the dens or odontoid process.

This is an example of a demyelinating plaque in a patient with multiple sclerosis. Spinal cord demyelinating plaques from multiple sclerosis are most often found in the cervical segment of the cord. They are usually shorter than two vertebral bodies in length.

title: Ichthyosis vulgaris
description:
Dry skin with fine, white scaling sparing the popliteal fossa is visible on this patient's legs.

This appearance is suggestive of ichthyosis vulgaris.

title: Pleomorphic adenoma
description: Oral cavity of a patient, ventral view: A protrusion of the left lateral wall of the pharynx can be seen. Further diagnostics performed on the patient confirmed a pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland, which expanded into the parapharyngeal space.

title: Serous papillary cystadenoma of the ovary with Psammoma bodies
description:
Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

title: Parasagittal meningioma
description:
MRI Head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing rounded mass (green overlay) continuous with the falx cerebri and dura of the right parietal bone. It does not invade the surrounding brain tissue or bone.

This is a case of meningioma. This is the most common diagnosis for a dural-based mass with smooth margins and homogeneous contrast enhancement. Other important differentials include lymphoma and metastasis, both of which would more likely (but not always) be less uniform in shape and enhanceheterogeneously.

title: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
description:
X-ray ankle (left: AP view; right: lateral view)

Smooth periosteal reaction (green overlay) has developed primarily along the distal metaphyses of the tibia and fibula.

This appearance is characteristic of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

title: Osteochondroma of the humerus
description:
X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

title: Thymoma in myasthenia gravis
description:
Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

title: Meningioma with psammoma bodies
description:
Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (H&E stain)

Several eosinophilic cells arranged in whorls are visible. The whorls have a layered or lamellated appearance, resembling the layers of an onion. These are known as meningocytic whorls. Two of these whorls have a deeply basophilic acellular core, known as a psammoma body, which indicates dystrophic calcification.

Meningocytic (onion skin) whorls and psammoma bodies are typically seen in meningiomas.

title: Psoriasis
description:
Well-demarcated erythematosquamous plaques and silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor side of both lower legs.

These findings are characteristic of psoriasis.

title: Seborrheic keratosis
description:
Trunk of a patient

Multiple, slightly raised plaques, with varying degrees of pigmentation are visible.

title: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
description:
Multiple partially confluent, sharply demarcated, erythematous, scaling plaques are visible on this patient's flank.

This appearance is suggestive of cutaneous lymphoma.

title: Osteopetrosis
description:
X-ray of the thoracic and lumbar spine (AP and lateral view)

Broad, linear sclerotic lesions of the inferior and superior endplates (box 1, highlighted with green overlay in box 3). Normal findings are shown in boxes 2 and 4. This finding is sometimes referred to as “sandwich vertebral body.”

Diagnosis: autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis

title: Alcohol-related cirrhosis (1/2)
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

Typical features of liver cirrhosis can be seen in form of septal, connective tissue reconstruction with lymphocyte infiltration (green overlay), a regenerative nodule (R) with macrovesicular steatosis in hepatocytes (H), and proliferation of bile duct-like structures (B).

title: Biological prosthetic heart valve
description: A stented bioprosthetic valve, consisting of xenograft material (most commonly porcine aortic valve leaflets or bovine pericardium) mounted on a manufactured supporting stent.

title: Smudge cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a blood smear (H&E stain; high magnification) of a patient after splenectomy

Smudge cells (Gumprecht shadows) are present (red overlay). These artifacts are caused by ruptured mature lymphocytes. There is also a lack of Howell-Jolly bodies in the erythrocytes, which may indicate the presence of an accessory spleen.

The presence of smudge cells is characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, however, it is a nonspecific finding.

title: Fracture dislocation of the femoral head with a medial fracture of the femoral neck
description: Anteroposterior x-ray of the pelvis: A femoral head fracture (green area and green line) in combination with a medial fracture of the femoral neck (angle 75°, Pauwels' classification) can be seen in this x-ray image. This fracture combination (femoral head fracture and medial fracture of the femoral neck) is categorized as Pipkin III according to the Pipkin classification.

title: Erythema nodosum
description:
Poorly demarcated red nodules are seen on the extensor sides of both lower legs with peripheral edema of the lower left leg and foot.

These findings are characteristic of erythema nodosum.

title: Tonsillar cancer
description: Exophytic lesion of the left tonsil

title: Acute tonsillitis
description:
The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and gray-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts as well as on the posterior aspect of the tongue. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.

Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
description: A solitary lesion with an irregular, raised, pearly pink border and a multinodular surface with telangiectasia is visible. The center of the lesion appears atrophic and the uppermost nodule shows central ulceration.

title: Open spina bifida
description:
Lumbar region of a neonate

The protruding cystic lesion with concurrent hypertrichosis is consistent with open spina bifida. Subtyping requires further diagnostics.

title: Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon
description:
Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a colonic polyp (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The hyperchromatic purple (highly basophilic) cells in the center of this image are colonic epithelial cells. They have hyperchromatic cytoplasm and large, mitotic nuclei (red overlay), which are signs of malignancy. The cells surround pools of extracellular mucin (green overlay). Inflammatory cells are visible in the stroma surrounding the glands.

Mucinous pools that make up at least 50% of the tumor mass are characteristic of mucinous adenocarcinoma.

title: Psoriasis of the knee
description: Erythematosquamous plaques with silver-white scaling and surrounding erythema are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

title: Pityriasis versicolor alba
description:
Pea-sized, partly confluent, macular lesions with complete depigmentation can be seen on the upper back of this patient following UV-light exposure.

Irregular borders and satellite lesions are suggestive of pityriasis versicolor alba, caused by Malassezia globosa infection.

title: Pancreatic regional anatomy
description:
The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.

Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary

title: Transscaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation (1/2)
description:
X-ray right wrist (PA view)

The scaphoid (yellow overlay) is seen as two overlapping fragments as a result of a waist fracture, and the lunate (blue overlay) has a triangular shape (termed the piece of pie sign). A triangular lunate can be seen in both lunate and perilunate dislocations, which can be better differentiated with the addition of a lateral view.

C: capitate; R: radius; U: ulna

title: Cardiac conduction pathway
description: The subepicardial sinus node generates electrical impulses, which then travel through the walls of the atria to the subendocardial atrioventricular node. After a short delay in the atrioventricular node, the impulses pass through the bundle of His (situated in the membranous part of interventricular septum) to the Tawara branches. These then terminate in numerous small fibers (Purkinje fibers), which activate the heart muscle cells of the chambers and thus initiate cardiac contraction.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS; Stein-Leventhal syndrome)
description: Macroscopic specimen of an ovary, transverse section: There are multiple, circularly arranged, brown subcapsular cysts (examples indicated by green overlay) on the subcapsular region, which are relatively small and of approx. the same size. This is the typical appearance of a polycystic ovary (see illustration for a schematic representation). In addition to the abnormal changes observed here, the ovary is frequently enlarged and as a result there is an increase in stromal tissue.

title: Central retinal artery occlusion
description:
Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

title: Tension pneumothorax
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient without a history of trauma

A large left pneumothorax (blue overlay) is seen, with an absence of lung markings peripheral to the collapsed lung (yellow overlay). Contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by arrows) has resulted in a prominent right heart border (white line), and there is slight widening of the left lateral costophrenic angle (angle marker). These findings are consistent with tension pneumothorax. Incidentally noted is a mild rotatory curvature of the upper thoracic spine.

The absence of thoracic trauma suggests a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Dashed white line: visceral pleural line; green overlay: spinous process; red overlay: vertebral pedicles

title: Lambda sign in dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

A thick inter-twin membrane containing both amnion and chorion separates adjacent twin embryos, with a triangular projection of chorion visible at the base of the membrane. The appearance produced by this projection of tissue has been termed the lambda sign (also the twin peak sign) because of its resemblance to the Greek symbol λ (blue overlay).

Although its absence is not sufficient to exclude dichorionicity, the lambda sign is a strong indicator of a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. In a monochorionic diamniotic pregancy, the inter-twin membrane may either terminate in a T configuration (T sign) or create a black triangular space with the uterine wall, sometimes termed the black lambda sign.

E: embryo; yellow overlay: uterine wall

title: Lambda sign (twin peak sign) in twin pregnancy
description:
Transabdominal ultrasound of a pregnant patient

A dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy in the first trimester is seen. The triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between layers of the intertwin membrane resembles the Greek letter lambda (λ; blue overlay). The lambda sign (also known as the “twin peak sign”) strongly suggests a dichorionic twin pregnancy.

Green overlay: placenta; red overlay: uterus; yellow overlay: fetus

title: Modified WHO Analgesic Ladder
description: This illustration shows a stepwise, bidirectional algorithmic approach to the management of acute and chronic pain. Acute pain is initially treated with the strongest analgesic for that intensity of pain and then stepped down. Chronic pain is treated from the bottom up. The original WHO analgesic ladder was unidirectional (escalating) and included only the first 3 steps; other authors have since modified the ladder, by adding the fourth step including interventional procedures (e.g., nerve blocks) for unrelenting pain.

title: Pathophysiology of preeclampsia
description:
In normal pregnancy, uterine spiral arteries develop into high-capacity, low-resistance blood vessels, leading to increased blood flow to the placenta.

In preeclampsia, abnormal vascular remodeling and cytotrophoblast invasion result in narrow, high-resistance vessels with pulsatile flow. The resulting placental hypoperfusion induces the release of vasoactive substances, which, in turn, cause endothelial dysfunction, vasoconstriction, and, ultimately, maternal hypertension to ensure sufficient blood supply of the fetus.

title: 5-Alpha-reductase deficiency
description: Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

title: Incidence of cancers in the US (2025 estimates)
description: Estimated incidence of the most common cancers in the US in total figures and as a percentage of total cancer incidence (excluding non-melanoma skin cancers and in-situ carcinoma, except urinary bladder). Figures are prospective estimates of the American Cancer Society for 2025.

title: Management of hypertensive crisis
description:
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
BP: blood pressure
BMP: basic metabolic panel
BNP: brain natriuretic peptide
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
CTA: computed tomography angiography
DBP: diastolic blood pressure
ECG: electrocardiogram
FoCUS: focused cardiac ultrasound
HTN: hypertension
MAP: mean arterial pressure
POCUS: point-of-care-ultrasound
SBP: systolic blood pressure
UA: urinalysis

title: Cancer mortality in the US (2025 estimates)
description: Estimated mortality from the most common cancers in the US in total figures and as a percentage of total cancer mortality. Figures are prospective estimates of the American Cancer Society for 2025.

title: Differential diagnosis of metabolic alkalosis
description:
ABG: arterial blood gas
BMP: basic metabolic panel

title: Evaluation of thyroid nodule
description: TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

title: Mechanism of primary angle-closure
description:
Cross-section of the anterior portion of the eye

Pressure rises in the posterior chamber if the flow of aqueous humor from the posterior to the anterior chamber is obstructed due to a functional block (pupillary block) between the lens and the pupillary portion of the iris. This increase in pressure causes the peripheral portion of the iris to move anteriorly and to cover parts or all of the chamber angle (particularly in mydriasis or mid-dilation), potentially leading to acute angle-closure with massively increased intraocular pressure. In certain anatomical variants (e.g., shallow anterior chamber), the chamber angle is already narrow and therefore increases the probability of acute and/or chronic angle-closure, which can lead to damage of the optic nerve (glaucoma).

title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

title: POCUS protocol for detection of lower extremity DVT
description:
Various POCUS (point of care ultrasound) protocols exist for the detection of lower extremity DVT (deep vein thrombosis). In contrast to the whole-leg scans performed by radiology departments, POCUS protocols typically use only 2 or 3 points of compression along the femoral and popliteal veins.

– Preferred probe: linear

– Patient positioning: supine; leg rotated laterally at the hip and knee bent ∼ 30º

– Compression technique: Holding the probe perpendicular to the skin, apply enough downward pressure to slightly compress the pulsatile artery.

– Interpretation: The pressure needed to slightly compress the artery should completely collapse a non-thrombosed vein. A non-collapsible vein is highly suggestive of a DVT. Direct visualization of an intraluminal hyperechoic mass (asterisk) confirms the diagnosis.

Three-point protocol steps:

1. Locate the CFV and CFA at the branch point of the GSV from the CFV. Compress.

2. Move the transducer distally along the CFV, just past the branch point of the FV and DFV, where the FA is superficial to the FV. Compress.

3. Reposition the probe behind the knee and locate the PV superficial to the PA. Compress.

CFA: common femoral artery; CFV: common femoral vein; DFV: deep femoral vein; GSV: great saphenous vein; FA: femoral artery; FV: femoral vein; PA: popliteal artery; PV: popliteal vein

title: Superior vena cava syndrome
description:
Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is caused by obstruction of the SVC (e.g., due to malignancy or intraluminal thrombosis), resulting in impaired blood flow from the SVC into the right atrium. As a consequence, drainage occurs increasingly into the inferior vena cava via collateral veins, resulting in a prominent venous patterning on the upper body. Venous congestion proximally to the obstruction results in edema of the upper extremities, neck, and face.

SVC syndrome can become life-threatening if cerebral edema (leading to increased intracranial pressure) or laryngeal edema develop.

title: Types of pelvic organ prolapse
description:
Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

title: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome and pattern
description:
Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

title: Pathophysiology of typical atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT)
description:
AVNRT is a tachyarrhythmia caused by a dysfunctional AV node with two electrical pathways, one fast with a long refractory period and one slow with a short refractory period (dual AV nodal physiology). During normal sinus rhythm, the conduction occurs via the fast pathway, and the incoming current from the slow pathway is extinguished (top right image).

Typical AVNRT is triggered by an atrial premature beat (APB).

(1) An APB arrives at the AV node during the fast pathway's refractory period. The impulse is, therefore, conducted through the slow pathway, which is out of its refractory period.
(2) When the impulse reaches the distal junction of the two pathways, the fast pathway has recovered its excitability and the impulse can travel up retrograde.
(3) The impulse reaches the atria, leading to an almost simultaneous depolarization of the atria and ventricles. The current reenters the slow pathway.
(4) A reentry circuit is created with anterograde conduction across the slow-conducting pathway and retrograde conduction in the fast pathway resulting in sustained tachycardia.

title: Subtotal gastrectomy (with Roux-en-Y anastomosis)
description:
Subtotal gastrectomy:
- Subtotal gastrectomy involves the resection of the body and pyloric channel of the stomach (transparent portion of the stomach in this image).
- The cardia and fundus of the stomach and their blood supply is preserved (opaque portion of the stomach here).
- The duodenal stump (dashed red line) is closed.

Roux-en-Y anastomosis:
- A segment of the proximal jejunum is divided.
- Gastrojejunostomy creation: The distal cut end of the jejunal loop (black I) is anastomosed side-to-side to the gastric stump (purple dashed line; I–I).
- Jejunojejunostomy creation: The proximal jejunal stump (green II) is anastomosed end-to-side to a distal jejunal loop (green dashed line, II–II).

title: Breast mass
description:
Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

title: Intraductal breast mass
description:
Ultrasound breast

A well-defined solitary mass (blue overlay) is seen within a dilated mammary duct.

The main differential diagnoses are intraductal papilloma, ductal carcinoma (especially papillary carcinoma), and inspissated secretions. Secretions do not show vascularity on color Doppler. Intraductal papilloma may show a vascular stalk. Ductal carcinoma cannot always be reliably distinguished from intraductal papilloma by ultrasound.

title: Cat scratch disease
description:
A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

title: Macrocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Throughout the specimen, there are cells with an irregular, oval form and marked hyperchromasia (intense staining) that are known as macrocytes (examples indicated by arrows). These are surrounded by normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Macrocytes may be found in megaloblastic forms of anemia.

title: Pityriasis rosea
description: Trunk of a patient showing a plaque and maculae with scaling. There is a plaque with collarettes (primary plaque; dashed outline) beneath the right costal arch that is approx. 3 cm in diameter and small, confluent, homogeneous, oval lesions scattered on the trunk that are partially scaly.

title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
description:
In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

title: Management of acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding
description:
EGD: esophagogastroduodenoscopy
IV: intravenous
NPO: nil per os
UGIB: upper gastrointestinal bleeding

title: Koplik spots
description:
Numerous tiny white spots on an erythematous background (Koplik spots; examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible on the buccal mucosa.

Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles infection.

title: Hypothalamic-pituitary hormone axis
description:
The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

title: Ovotestis
description:
Photomicrograph of a gonadal biopsy specimen (H&E stain; intermediate power magnification)

The image shows an area on the border between ovarian and testicular parenchyma. Primordial follicles (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen in the ovarian parenchyma on the left, while primitive seminiferous tubules (examples indicated by blue overlay) can be seen in the testicular parenchyma on the right.

The combination of ovarian and testicular tissue in the same biopsy specimen is diagnostic for ovotestis.

title: Pericarditis
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Heart rate approx. 70/min

- Regular sinus rhythm

- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in I and aVF)

- Normal narrow QRS complexes

- Concave ST elevation in multiple leads (I, II, V2–6; blue arrows), with reciprocal ST depression in aVR (red arrow).

- PR segment depression in multiple leads (II, V2, V4–V6; purple arrows)

Upward concave ST elevation and PR segment depression in multiple leads (with reciprocal ST depression usually confined to aVR/V1) are characteristic of acute pericarditis.

title: Heart failure cells in decompensated heart failure
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.

Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.

title: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure)
description:
(1) Preoperative situation: The grey mass represents a tumor in the pancreatic head. The structures depicted as transparent are resected.
- Distal stomach (antrum and pylorus)
- Entire duodenum
- ∼ 15 cm of the proximal jejunum
- The pancreatic head with the distal pancreatic duct
- The gall bladder and the CBD

(2) Post-operative situation: Four anastomoses are created.
- Pancreaticojejunostomy (I)
- Hepaticojejunostomy (II; common hepatic duct is sutured to the jejunum)
- Gastrojejunostomy (III)
- Enteroenterostomy (IV; between the afferent and efferent jejunal loop)
The blind proximal end of the jejunum is closed (red line).

title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

title: Gingival leukoplakia
description:
White patches that cannot be scraped off are visible on the gingiva of the lower labial sulcus (green overlay).

This finding is typical of leukoplakia, which is most commonly found in the oral cavity.

title: Initial pharmacotherapy for stable COPD
description:
CAT: COPD Assessment Test
COPD: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
GOLD: Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
LABA: long-acting beta agonist (e.g., salmeterol or formoterol)
LABA/LAMA: combination of a LABA and a LAMA (e.g., umeclidinium/vilanterol)
LAMA/LABA/ICS: combination of a LAMA, LABA, and an ICS (e.g., fluticasone furoate/umeclidinium/vilanterol)
LAMA: long-acting muscarinic antagonist (e.g., tiotropium bromide)
mMRC: modified Medical Research Council
SABA: short-acting beta agonist (e.g., albuterol)
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist (e.g., ipratropium bromide)

title: Mallory bodies in steatohepatitis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification)

An enlarged hepatocyte with cobweb-like cytoplasm, known as ballooning degeneration (example indicated by yellow overlay), can be seen. An intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion with a twisted rope appearance, known as a Mallory body (example indicated by blue overlay), is visible. Additionally, macrovesicular steatosis (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the surrounding hepatocytes.

Macrovesicular steatosis and mallory bodies are findings that indicate steatohepatitis.

title: Evaluation and management of ischemic stroke
description:
BMP: basic metabolic panel
BP: blood pressure
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
DW-MRI: diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging
ECG: electrocardiogram
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
MRI: magnetic resonance imaging
NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale
POC: point-of-care

title: Mallet finger with avulsion fracture
description:
X-ray finger (lateral view) of a patient with inability to extend finger after trauma

An avulsion fracture of the dorsal aspect of the base of the distal phalanx (green overlay) shows intraarticular extension into the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The injury to the extensor mechanism has resulted in a flexion deformity (indicated by arrow and lines) at the DIP joint (mallet finger).

Mallet finger may be an isolated tendinous injury or may occur in combination with an avulsion fracture of the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of a finger.

title: Hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system in Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome
description:
MRI images (contrast-enhanced; T1-weighted) of a patient with Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

Image A (brain; axial view) shows a tumor within the lateral aspect of the right cerebellum. It consists of an enhancing solid component (red overlay) and a larger, hypointense part representing a cystic component (blue overlay).

Image B (brain; sagittal view) shows a contrast-enhancing tumor (green overlay) between medulla oblongata and cerebellum, within the region of the foramen of Magendie/median aperture.

Image C (spine MRI; sagittal view) shows a hyperintense tumor (yellow overlay) within the dorsal/posterior spinal canal at the level of vertebra C5-C6.

Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary disorder characterised by the development of tumors in multiple parts of the body. This includes hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, such as in this example. Hemangioblastomas are highly vascular tumours, resulting in the intense enhancement demonstrated on these post contrast images. Peritumoural cysts are common in these tumors, and result from plasma ultrainfiltrate passing through the permeable tumor blood vessels.

title: Left hip joint effusion
description:
MRI Hips (axial view; T1 weighted; with contrast) of an 11-year-old boy with a painful left hip and a fever.

The synovium of the left hip is thickened and there is a joint effusion. As this is a T1-weighted image, fluid appears hypointense and therefore the effusion demonstrates hypointense signal (blue overlay). The synovium of the hip demonstrates hyperintense signal due to enhancement (green overlay). A large area of soft tissue around the left hip enhances, demonstrated as hyperintense signal around the hip joint (red overlay). This is due to inflammation of these soft tissues.

The main differentials for these imaging findings are septic arthritis and transient synovitis. It is often very difficult to differentiate these two conditions on imaging alone during the early stages. Bone marrow edema in the femur or acetabulum, or extensive soft tissue edema around the joint is more suggestive of septic arthritis but is not always demonstrated early, and aspiration of joint fluid may be required to aid diagnosis. This is an example of septic arthritis.

Outlines: Sartorius m., Rectus femoris m., Tensor fasciae latae m.

title: Erosive esophagitis
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Several linear and round erosions (purple overlay) can be seen proximal to the Z-line (dashed outline).

These features are pathognomonic of erosive esophagitis.

title: Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
description:
X-ray right hip (AP view)

The articular surface of the femoral head is irregular (black dotted line) and the underlying bone is heterogeneous (green overlay) as a result of osteonecrosis. A zone of sclerosis (red overlay) is present along the interface with normal bone.

title: Ependymoma
description:
MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

title: Nephrolithiasis
description:
Ultrasound kidney (longitudinal plane; imaged from flank)

A left lower pole renal calculus is seen as a hyperechoic structure (red overlay) with posterior acoustic shadowing (green overlay).

Posterior acoustic shadowing is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when beam penetration is severely impeded by a structure with a high attenuation coefficient (e.g., calculus, bone, dense fibrous tissue).

title: Single steps of heme synthesis
description:
Heme is synthesized in the mitochondria and cytoplasm through a series of enzymatic reactions. An overview of the most important reaction is shown here.

- The first and rate-limiting step of heme synthesis is the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine within the mitochondria to form δ-Aminolevulinic acid (δ-ALA), which is catalyzed by the δ-ALA synthase.
- δ-ALA then enters the cytoplasm and condenses with another δ-ALA molecule to form one molecule of porphobilinogen. Eight δ-ALA molecules are required for the synthesis of one heme molecule. Four molecules of porphobilinogen condense to form a linear tetrapyrrole that closes to form a porphyrin ring (uroporphyrinogen III). The porphyrin ring is converted to coproporphyrinogen III and then transported back into the mitochondria.
- Decarboxylation of the porphyrin ring results in the formation of a protoporphyrin molecule. Ferrochelatase catalyzes the final step, in which a a ferrous molecule is added to protoporphyrin, which results in the formation of a heme molecule.

title: Mechanism of action: respiratory chain inhibitors
description:
Uncoupling agents (e.g., salicylic acid, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and thermogenin) act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial inner membrane, resulting in the dissociation of the electron transport chain and the ATP synthase complex.

Respiratory chain inhibitors target specific protein complexes of the electron transport chain. Electron transport chain inhibitors (e.g., rotenone, malonate, antimycin A, and certain toxic substances such as cyanide and aspirin in toxic doses) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting the proton gradient. ATP synthase inhibitors (e.g., oligomycin) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting ATP synthase, the protein complex that catalyzes the synthesis of ATP from ADP and phosphate (Pi).

title: Surgical management of carpal tunnel syndrome
description:
Intraoperative palmar view of the wrist

The incision is held open by a self-retaining retractor (distal; top of image) and a hook-shaped retractor (proximal; bottom of image). The transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum of the hand) has been surgically divided to decompress the median nerve. The thenar part of the split transverse carpal ligament (blue overlay) and the median nerve (green overlay) are visible in the wound.
Next to the median nerve, the median artery (red overlay) can be seen (this usually regresses before birth but may persist). Sources differ widely regarding the frequency of a persisting palmar median artery (1.5% to 50%), and it has been suggested that its presence may be associated with an increased risk of carpal tunnel syndrome.

title: Pulmonary trauma
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window) following trauma to the chest

Areas of ground glass and consolidation in both lungs are the result of pulmonary contusion (green overlay). Ovoid traumatic lacerations in the left lung contain opaque blood (red overlay). Two of the lacerations also contain air, producing air-fluid levels (dashed line). A pneumothorax is present anteriorly in the right hemithorax (blue overlay).

title: Hairy cell leukemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Multiple atypical lymphocytes (examples indicated by blue circles) can be seen among numerous normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads) in the center of the image. The cell membrane of these lymphocytes feature fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections (examples indicated by black arrowheads) and enlarged nuclei with slightly irregular borders (examples indicated by dashed line). A binuclear cell is also present (arrow).

The presence of atypical lymphocytes with hair-like cytoplasmic projections in a peripheral blood smear indicates hairy cell leukemia. The diagnosis was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

title: Extensive anterolateral STEMI with septal involvement and reciprocal inferior changes
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼ 110/min
– Normal sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Narrow QRS complexes
– Normal PR interval
– Prolonged QT interval (QTc ∼ 650 ms), likely secondary to ischemia
– ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4
– Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, avF, and V6

These findings are consistent with an extensive anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) with septal and lateral extension, likely due to proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) occlusion.

title: Malignant esophageal stricture
description:
Barium esophagram (lateral view) of a patient with esophageal carcinoma

A long segment irregular stricture is seen in the mid third of the thoracic esophagus (green overlay). The superior aspect of the stricture has an apple-core appearance (indicated by dashed line).

title: Eosinophilic esophagitis
description:
Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential mucosal lesions (rings/corrugations; examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible.

Yellow lines: longitudinal furrows; Dashed encirclement: Z-line

title: Leishmaniosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow tissue specimen (Giemsa stain, very high magnification)

Dark purple, intracellular Leishmania parasites (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within a histiocyte (blue overlay).

This finding suggests visceral leishmaniosis. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed by PCR or serology.

N: neutrophil; M: myeloid precursor cell; Eb: erythroblast

title: Giant-cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma)
description:
Photomicrograph of a section from a bone tumor biopsy (H&E stain)

Numerous giant cells containing multiple nuclei are visible throughout the image (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These cells are surrounded by a hypercellular stroma composed of mononuclear cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

These features are typical of giant-cell tumors of the bone.

title: Multifocal choroiditis in sarcoidosis
description:
Fundus photography of a left eye

Several choroidal granulomas are visible, appearing as yellow spots (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This finding is consistent with the diagnosis of multifocal choroiditis, associated here with sarcoidosis.

Circle: optic disc; M: macula

title: Pathophysiology of paradoxical embolism
description: In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

title: Villous adenoma of the colon
description:
Photomicrograph of a colon biopsy sample (H&E stain, medium power magnification)

In colorectal adenoma, the surface epithelium appears darker stained (examples indicated by blue overlay) than the normal colonic epithelium (examples indicated by hatched blue overlay) due to atypical elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei and loss of goblet cells (examples of normal goblet cells indicated by arrowheads). Villous adenoma, furthermore, show finger-like projections of the mucosa (examples indicated by yellow overlay).

Colorectal adenomas are divided into low-grade or high-grade, depending on the extent of epithelial atypia.

title: Essential thrombocythemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow aspirate smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

The bone marrow appears hypercellular. Giant mature megakaryocytes, identifiable by their large size and multilobulated nucleus (example indicated by arrowhead), can be seen forming multiple clusters (example indicated by yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of essential thrombocythemia (also known as “essential thrombocytosis”), a myeloproliferative neoplasm.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Infectious cervicitis
description:
Colposcopy view of the ectocervix

The ectocervix is erythematous and there is purulent discharge from the external os.

title: Dural based mass
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

title: Management of ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
description:
ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme
ADP: adenosine diphosphate
ECG: electrocardiogram
GP: glycoprotein IIb/IIIa
LBBB: left bundle branch block
PCI: percutaneous coronary intervention
RBBB: right bundle branch block
SpO2: oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry
STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
UFH: unfractionated heparin

title: Hemangioblastoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a cerebellar mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous thin-walled small blood vessels (examples indicated by yellow overlay) containing red stained erythrocytes are visible throughout the tumor.
Surrounding the blood vessels large stromal cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with pale intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (so-called "foamy" cytoplasm) can be seen.

This appearance is indicative of hemangioblastoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

title: Pediatric fourth ventricular tumor
description:
MRI Head (T2-weighted; axial view) of a 7-year-old boy

There is a lobulated heterogeneous posterior fossa mass (green overlay) present in the midline of the cerebellum at the level of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle is obscured by the mass and is, therefore, not well seen in this image.

This is a medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric tumor of the central nervous system. Medulloblastomas most commonly involve the cerebellar vermis, the structure that connects the two cerebellar hemispheres. In the pediatric population, other tumors that commonly occur in similar locations include brainstem glioma, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor, and astrocytoma. All of these should be considered in this case, although a brainstem glioma would rather be located predominantly within the brainstem rather than the vermis and is, therefore, less likely.

Arrowhead: basilar artery; C: cerebellum

title: Management of bradycardia
description:
ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

title: Papanicolaou test showing HSIL
description:
Photomicrograph of a Papanicolaou test sample of squamous cells of the cervix (Papanicolaou stain; very high magnification)

Multiple normal intermediate squamous cells (light blue cytoplasm, examples indicated by yellow overlay) and a neutrophil (arrowhead) can be seen. A sheet of smaller, abnormal, epithelial cells (dashed outline) is also present at the bottom of the image. These cells have irregular nuclear contours with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and irregular clumped chromatin. There is a dyskeratotic cell (red cytoplasm, arrow) within the clump of abnormal cells.

These findings are characteristic of severe dysplasia, i.e., a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).

title: Lobar pneumonia with parapneumonic effusion
description:
X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of a patient with history of pneumonia

Extensive heterogeneous air space consolidation (green overlay) in the left upper lobe abuts part of the major fissure (dashed line). A small pleural effusion is present.

Examples of causes of pulmonary consolidation that can mimic the appearance of infectious pneumonia include organizing pneumonia, malignancy (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma), and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Red: meniscus of pleural effusion

title: Skin alterations in congenital syphilis
description:
Plantar surfaces of the feet in a newborn with congenital syphilis

The right foot shows a fluid-filled blister. The left foot shows a blister that has already peeled.

These features suggest pemphigus syphiliticus, which is pathognomonic for congenital syphilis.

title: Diagnostic approach to pulmonary embolism
description:
CTPA: computer tomography pulmonary angiogram
PE: pulmonary embolism
PERC: Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria
PTP: pretest probability
RV: right ventricle
V/Q scan: ventilation/perfusion scan

title: Characterization of nystagmus by direction
description: In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).

title: Comparison between myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton syndromes
description: AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

title: Left ventricular pseudoaneurysm
description:
Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical 4-chamber view) of a 61-year-old patient with ST elevations and a 10-day history of chest pain and progressive dyspnea

The myocardium is disrupted at the apex and a large saccular outpouching extends into the pericardial space. Turbulent blood flow is seen between the ventricle and the pericardial outpouching.

These findings are consistent with a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm.

title: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
description:
X-ray chest (AP view) of an intubated newborn with bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Ill-defined reticular markings (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and small rounded lucent areas (examples indicated by green arrowheads) are diffusely present throughout both lungs.

An endotracheal tube (green overlay), nasogastric tube (red overlay), and central venous catheter (yellow overlay) are properly positioned. Rotation of the patient to the left has resulted in an appearance of elongation of the left ribs compared to the right ribs and leftward positioning of the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

title: Hydronephrosis
description:
Ultrasound left kidney (longitudinal plane)

The calyces (green overlay) are dilated and have lost their normal cup-shaped appearance. Flattening of papillae and blunting of fornices can be seen. Where visible, the renal cortical parenchyma is not thinned.

RP: renal parenchyma; Arrowheads: hyperechoic renal sinus

title: Anatomical vs. alveolar dead space (minute ventilation)
description: The physiologic dead space (VD) consists of the volume of air in the conducting airways (i.e., anatomic dead space) and the sum of alveolar volumes that do not participate in gas exchange (i.e., alveolar dead space). In a healthy lung, anatomical dead space is almost equal to VD because alveolar dead space is negligible. In diseases that result in a mismatch in lung ventilation/perfusion ratio (e.g., pulmonary embolism), alveolar dead space is increased, resulting in reduced alveolar ventilation (the volume of gas that reaches the alveoli each minute).

title: Rosenthal fibers
description:
Photomicrograph of a tissue section of a brain mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is an abundance of eosinophilic, fusiform inclusions (Rosenthal fibers; examples indicated by blue overlay).

Rosenthal fibers are intracellular inclusions within astrocyte cytoplasmic processes. They represent a nonspecific degenerative changes that are often found in CNS tumors (in this case in pilocytic astrocytoma).

title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
description:
TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.

TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

title: Pulmonary fat embolism
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient after physical trauma

Parenchymal opacities (green overlay) are seen in both lungs, predominantly in the lower zones. No pleural effusions are visible (indicated by red overlay). The cardiac silhouette is not enlarged. A right central line is present (yellow outline). The radiopaque line on a nasogastric tube (blue overlay) can be traced into the mid-thorax, beyond which it is not well seen.

Nonspecific homogeneous or heterogeneous opacities may become visible on chest radiographs in various locations about 24–48 hours after an insult that results in pulmonary fat embolism. A normal cardiac silhouette size and absence of Kerley lines, pleural effusions, and pulmonary venous hypertension can help exclude a diagnosis of cardiogenic edema.

title: Illustration of the coronary arteries
description: This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

title: Tram-track appearance in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; high magnification)

The glomerulus shows slightly increased mesangial cellularity (examples indicated by circles) and duplication of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). The latter displays in the form of a double contour of the GBM (tram-track appearance; examples indicated by yellow lines).
As a secondary finding, there is an Angiostrongylus larva within the glomerulus (blue overlay).

Duplication of the GBM is a typical finding in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

title: Posterior cruciate ligament tear
description:
MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).

A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

title: Mass effect from glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastoma

The right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.

Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification

title: Cholecystoenteric fistula and gallstone ileus
description:
Cholecystoenteric fistula is an abnormal connection between the gallbladder lumen and the adjacent bowel (usually duodenum or stomach). The fistula creates a conduit for the passage of gallstones from the gallbladder into the bowel and for air from the bowel into the biliary system (i.e., pneumobilia), which can be seen on imaging.

Large gallstones can become lodged in the distal ileum (most commonly the ileocecal valve), causing gallstone ileus. Radiographic imaging typically shows signs of mechanical obstruction (distended bowel loops proximal to the obstruction) and the gallstone.

title: Greenstick fracture of the distal radius
description:
X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescent

A greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).

Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.

Red overlay: growth plate

title: Mechanism of action: osteoporosis medication
description:
– Calcitonin: inhibits osteoclast activity and reduces renal and gastrointestinal resorption of calcium
– Romosozumab: a monoclonal antibody that binds sclerostin, promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption
– Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs; e.g., raloxifene) and estrogens: suppress chemical mediators (e.g., cytokines, TGFb), resulting in inhibition of osteoclast bone resorption and promotion of osteoclast apoptosis
– Bisphosphonates (alendronate, risedronate): inhibit osteoclast activity and, therefore, bone resorption
– RANKL inhibitors (denosumab): bind to RANKL, preventing it from activating osteoclasts via the RANK receptor
– Strontium: activates osteoblasts and stimulates them to produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), which inhibits RANK-RANKL binding
– PTH/parathyroid analogs (teriparatide): promote both osteoblast and osteoclast activity but with the net result of increased bone mass
– Vitamin D: increases absorption of calcium and phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract

title: Ottawa ankle and foot rules
description:
The Ottawa ankle and foot rules apply to patients presenting to the emergency department (ED) with traumatic ankle and/or foot injuries.

Ankle x-rays are indicated in the presence of pain in the malleolar zone AND one or both of the following:
- Tenderness along the posterior distal 6 cm of the lateral OR medial malleolus
- Inability to weight-bear both immediately post-injury AND for at least 4 steps in the ED

Foot x-rays are indicated in the presence of pain in the midfoot zone AND one or both of the following:
- Tenderness at the base of the 5th metatarsal OR the navicular bone
- Inability to weight-bear both immediately post-injury AND for at least 4 steps in the ED

title: Bimanual uterine massage
description:
1. One hand is carefully inserted into the anterior vaginal fornix.
2. The inside hand is clenched into a fist while the other hand is placed on the patient's lower abdomen over the uterine fundus.
3. The uterus is compressed and massaged between the two hands until it contracts.

title: Urogenital fistulas
description: Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.

title: Neonatal clavicle fracture
description:
X-ray upper chest (AP view) of a newborn

A complete fracture of the mid-third of the left clavicle shows overriding of the fragments (green overlay).

Fractures of the clavicle are the most common birth trauma and may be complete or incomplete. Major causes include extended arms in breech presentation deliveries and shoulder dystocia in vertex presentation deliveries.

1: left first rib; white outlines: clavicle

title: Foramen magnum meningioma
description:
MRI of the neck and base of the skull (left: T1-weighted, with contrast, sagittal plane; right: T2-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is a well-defined mass in the anterior aspect of the foramen magnum, which enhances on the T1-weighted post-contrast image (red overlay) and appears hyperintense to gray matter on the T2-weighted image (green overlay). The mass is continuous with the adjacent thickened and enhancing dura (arrowhead). This is known as the “dural tail sign.”

The dural tail sign suggests lesion originates from the dura mater. The sign is most commonly seen in meningiomas but may also be seen in other malignancies originating in the dura mater, such as lymphoma and metastasis.

title: Adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma
description:
Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)

Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .

This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

title: Steatohepatitis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Signs of hepatocellular injury due to steatohepatitis are seen in form of macrovesicular steatosis (large droplet of fat inside hepatocytes; examples indicated by yellow overlay), ballooning degeneration (cellular swelling of hepatocytes; example indicated by dashed outline), and Mallory bodies (hyaline intracytoplasmatic inclusions; examples indicated by arrowheads), combined with a scattered lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (examples indicated by blue overlay).

title: Multi-infarct dementia
description: Frontal section of the brain at the level of the optical chiasma (dashed blue overlay) showing hemorrhage and infarction (examples indicated by green circles) in the region of the basal ganglia. As a result, there is reduced demarcation of the internal capsule (dashed white outline) between the caudate (yellow overlay) and lentiform nuclei (blue overlay).

title: Enlarged hypoechoic pancreatic head
description:
