Ultrasound pancreas (transverse plane) of a patient with clinical signs of acute pancreatitis

The pancreatic head (green overlay) is enlarged and hypoechoic, with an ill-defined border.

The findings are consistent with acute pancreatitis. However, a wide spectrum of benign and malignant conditions can have a similar appearance on ultrasound.

A: aorta; dashed outline: pancreas; SMA: superior mesenteric artery; SMV: superior mesenteric vein; SV: splenic vein; V: inferior vena cava

title: Permeative bone lesion
description:
X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

title: Pathophysiology of polycystic ovary syndrome
description: In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

title: Chronic rhinosinusitis with polyposis
description:
CT facial bones (bone window; coronal plane)

Extensive polyp formation has caused circumferential thickening of both maxillary sinuses (green overlay) and widening of the ostia. Mucosal thickening and opacification also involve the nasal cavity (blue overlay), ethmoid sinuses (yellow overlay), and frontal sinuses (red overlay).

title: Imperforate anus
description:
X-ray abdomen (invertogram view) of a newborn

A coin has been placed over the anus and the patient has been turned upside down. Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of bowel (examples indicated by green line) are seen proximal to a point of abrupt termination of the distal colon. Beyond this (double arrow), no gas continues to the anus.

The appearance is consistent with imperforate anus (anal atresia). The distance between the gas column and the coin can be measured to determine the length of the atretic segment. Imperforate anus can be associated with other congenital abnormalities, among them esophageal atresia, VACTERL association, caudal regression syndrome, trisomy 21, and Currarino triad.

title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

title: Ectopic pregnancy
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transabdominal; transverse plane) of a 31-year-old woman with history of abdominal pain, presyncope, and a positive pregnancy test

A thick-walled echogenic ring lesion (blue overlay) is seen in the right adnexa, adjacent to which there is trace free fluid (yellow overlay). No uterine masses were identified and an intrauterine gestation was not detected. The adnexal lesion proved to represent a gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

An adnexal mass separate from the ovary is a common presentation of ectopic pregnancy. The diagnosis becomes more specific if a yolk sac or living embryo is detected within the mass. Color Doppler of an ectopic pregnancy may show prominent peripheral vascularity (ring of fire sign), which can similarly occur with a corpus luteum cyst.

Green overlay: uterine wall
Red overlay: endometrial stripe
IIA: internal iliac artery
IIV: internal illiac vein
O: ovary

title: Multifocal pneumonia with pleural effusions
description:
X-ray chest (left; PA view) and CT chest (right; lung window; top: coronal plane; bottom: sagittal plane) of a patient with Legionella pneumonia

Scattered ill-defined opacities are seen in both lungs, and extensive air space consolidation is present in the left upper lobe (green overlay). The latter is accompanied by slight elevation of the major fissure (arrowheads), indicating volume loss. Bilateral pleural effusions (red overlay), left greater than right, are present .

The imaging features of Legionella pneumonia are variable. Consolidation can manifest in a single lobe or as bilateral and multifocal opacities. Pleural effusions are common. Radiographic findings may lag behind clinical improvement.

title: Air in the right ventricle
description:
CT chest (with contrast; mediastinal window; coronal plane) of a patient with polytrauma from a motor vehicle crash

A large amount of air is seen within the right ventricle (green overlay). The air was inadvertently injected during the transfusion of blood products.

L: liver; LV: left ventricle; S: sternum; white arrow: contrast

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
Photograph of a patient’s upper back and neck

Erythematous, partly confluent plaques with silver scaling and greasy crusts are visible.

These findings suggest seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Glycolysis
description:
Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and is the metabolic pathway in which glucose is broken down into two pyruvate molecules, generating two molecules of ATP in the process (four ATP generated minus two ATP consumed). In the first phase of glycolysis, ATP (energy) is consumed. In the second and third phases, ATP and reducing equivalents (NADH) are generated.

Black boxes: reactants/products
Blue text: enzymes
Green text: electron carriers (NAD+, NADH+H+) or nucleotides (ATP, ADP) involved in energy consumption and production
Red text: energy (ATP) that is consumed (-) or produced (+) and reducing equivalents (NADH+H+) of each phase

title: Breast calcifications
description:
Mammography (right breast; A. mediolateral oblique (MLO) view; B. magnification view) of a patient with biopsy-proven fibrocystic disease

Multiple coarse heterogeneous (examples indicated by green arrowheads) and fine pleomorphic calcifications (examples indicated by red arrowheads) are segmentally distributed in the breast.

The main descriptors of breast calcifications (examples indicated by green circle) on mammography are morphology and distribution. Both descriptors are considered in the evaluation of cancer risk and in the determination of need for further imaging or biopsy. Mammographic findings are categorized according to the American College of Radiology (ACR) Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS).

title: Papillary thyroid carcinoma
description:
Micrograph image of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Arrowheads: examples of pathological nuclei
Blue overlay: connective tissue core of papillae
Yellow dashed overlay: epithelial cancer cells covering the papillae
Yellow overlay: psammoma bodies

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Lung opacities in acute chest syndrome
description:
X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with Hb S/β+ thalassemia and symptoms of acute chest syndrome

Lung volumes are low, and bilateral ill-defined opacities (examples indicated by green circles) are seen.

Acute chest syndrome is precipitated by a variety of infectious and noninfectious conditions. Opacities from atelectasis or consolidation are frequently more pronounced at the lung bases. Pleural effusion is sometimes present and skeletal abnormalities may be visible.

Red lines: endotracheal tube

title: Ureterolithiasis with obstructive uropathy
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; coronal plane)

The left renal collecting system (green overlay) is dilated to the level of a hyperdense calculus (yellow overlay) within the proximal third of the ureter. The left renal parenchyma shows less enhancement than the right renal parenchyma as a result of impaired excretion from ureteral obstruction.

Blue overlay: inferior vena cava; red overlay: abdominal aorta

title: Psoriatic arthritis
description:
X-ray hands (PA view)

Asymmetric advanced arthritis involves the left hand, with ankylosis of several proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints (examples indicated by green overlay) along with multiple flexion deformities. Marginal erosions are present at the bases of the small finger proximal phalanx and thumb distal phalanx (red overlay). Central subchondral erosions and proliferative changes with a gull-wing deformity are seen at the right ring finger DIP joint.

Also shown is an illustration of a pencil-in-cup deformity (not present here), which can occur in psoriatic arthritis and several other inflammatory arthritides.

Advanced degenerative changes additionally involve multiple left carpal and metacarpal joints.

title: Intraconal orbital mass
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.

The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

title: Split-pleura sign
description:
CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; mediastinal window)

CT scan shows right-sided pleural fluid collection (PC). The collection has a lenticular (biconvex) shape and is accompanied by thickening of the adjacent parietal (red line) and visceral pleurae (green line).

The split-pleura sign refers to thickening and contrast enhancement of the parietal and visceral pleurae separated by empyema or exudative effusion. The sign is the result of a fibrin pleural coat with capillary ingrowth and is considered reliable in distinguishing empyema from lung abscess. Lung abscesses, furthermore, tend to be round in contrast to the lenticular shape typical of empyemas.

T: trachea

title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

title: Lateral patellar dislocation
description:
X-ray left knee (AP view)

The patella (green overlay) is displaced laterally. It is normally located anterior to a groove between the femoral condyles (the patellofemoral groove; indicated by red overlay).

title: Pneumoperitoneum and Pneumoretroperitoneum
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP erect view) and chest (PA and lateral views)

Multiple air-fluid levels are seen in the colon and small bowel (examples indicated by black lines). Some dilated segments of left colon are seen and gas is present in the peritoneal space as a result of bowel perforation. Gas is primarily located beneath the diaphragms (green overlay) because of the erect positioning of the patient. Additional gas has dissected into the retroperitoneum (examples indicated by red overlay) and is visible as linear collections parallel to the spine.

title: Abnormal contour of thoracic aorta
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of aneurysmal dilatation of the thoracic aorta

The mediastinum is widened, with the descending thoracic aorta (white line) extending further to the left than is normal (normal course estimated by white dashed line). The margin of the ascending aorta also extends to the right to a greater degree than normal (white line). Widening of the mediastinum on a chest radiograph as a result of an abnormal aortic contour can be seen in several settings, among them age-related aortic ectasia, aneurysmal dilatation, and dissection. Further imaging (e.g., computed tomography) may be required.

A fine curvilinear structure (azygos fissure) courses inferiorly in the medial right apex, terminating at an opaque, tear-shaped structure, which represents the azygos vein (green overlay). The finding is a normal anatomical variant formed by displacement of the azygos vein during fetal development. An azygos fissure is comprised of two layers of parietal pleura and two layers of visceral pleura. Lung medial to the fissure is called an azygos lobe.

AK: aortic knob

title: Coarctation of the aorta
description:
(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

title: Manual reduction of uterine inversion (Johnson method)
description:
1. Grasp the protruding portion of the uterus.
2. Direct fingers towards the posterior fornix.
3. Lift the uterus into the abdominal cavity.

title: Pneumomediastinum
description:
CT thorax (axial plane)

Extensive radiolucent gas (pneumomediastinum; green overlay) is seen throughout the prevascular tissues and adjacent to the trachea and esophagus. Some gas has tracked from the mediastinum into the subcutaneous tissues (subcutaneous emphysema) and is visible within the left breast (examples indicated by red arrowheads).

E: esophagus; T: trachea

title: Pneumoperitoneum
description:
CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with abdominal distention

A large amount of free air is seen in the peritoneal cavity (indicated by arrows) anterior to the liver (L) and stomach (St). A perforation site was not identified by CT.

Pneumobilia (example indicated by green overlay) is due to a biliary stent (not shown). Cysts in the right kidney are partially visible on this image (red overlay).

Sp: spleen

title: Coarctation of the aorta
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.

The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

title: Varicocele
description: A varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum.

title: Overview of diuretics
description:
A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

title: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus is visible at the center of the image. The perihilar region is hypercellular and contains hyaline deposits (examples indicated by blue overlay). Loss of the capillary lumens and diffuse sclerosis is also present.

These are the typical features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (perihilar type).

title: Mismatched perfusion defects from pulmonary emboli
description:
Nuclear medicine ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan of a patient with a recent history of bilateral pleuritic chest pain; A: ventilation image (20.1 mCi of Xenon-133 gas), posterior projection; B: perfusion image (4.1 mCi of Technetium-99m-labeled macroaggregated albumin), posterior projection

The ventilation image shows uniform distribution of gas throughout the lungs, indicating normal ventilation. The perfusion image shows bilateral wedge-shaped defects (examples indicated by red overlay) from pulmonary emboli. Mismatched perfusion defects may also be seen in a variety of other settings, including venoocclusive disease, pulmonary artery obstruction from tumor, and radiation therapy.

H: heart

title: Clusters of plasma cells in multiple myeloma
description:
Bone marrow aspirate smear (May-Gruenwald stain; high magnification)

An increased density of plasma cells is visible. Plasma cells possess a round eccentric nucleus (example indicated by yellow hatched overlay) with clock-face chromatin (example indicated by white circle) and a perinuclear halo (perinuclear hof; example indicated by white overlay). Other cell types present include neutrophils (example indicated by blue overlay), lymphocytes (examples indicated by black arrowheads), and erythrocytes (example indicated by blue hatched overlay).
Additionally, the plasma cells in this specimen show features of atypia, e.g., multinucleated cells (example indicated by yellow outline), prominent nucleoli (example indicated by yellow arrowhead), and enlarged as well as irregularly shaped cytoplasm (example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of multiple myeloma requires the lesion to consist of monoclonal plasma cells, which is confirmed by kappa or lambda light chain restriction.

title: Comparison of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis
description: Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway through which glucose is broken down into pyruvate (yielding energy in the form of ATP), while gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway through which glucose is synthesized from noncarbohydrate precursors, including pyruvate. Most of the enzyme-catalyzed reactions of these pathways are reversible. However, there are three glycolytic reactions that are irreversible (enzymes shown in brown) and that are circumvented in gluconeogenesis by other enzymes (shown in blue).

title: Pulmonary embolism
description:
X-ray chest (left; lateral view) and CT angiography (right; sagittal plane) of a patient with right thoracic and flank pain, intermittent cough, and blood-tinged sputum

A peripheral opacity (green overlay) seen on the chest radiograph in the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe correlates with a heterogeneous area of opacification on the sagittal image of the CT angiogram. A wedge-shaped region of consolidation on the CT image indicates ischemic pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. An embolus (hypodense filling defect; white arrow) is visible within the contrast-enhanced posterior basal segmental pulmonary artery.

title: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; coronal plane)

Both kidneys are markedly enlarged and feature multiple round-to-ovoid, hypodense lesions of various sizes (examples indicated by green overlay) compatible with cysts. Some smaller cysts are present in the liver (examples indicated by red overlay). Contrast-enhanced renal parenchyma is seen between the cysts (yellow overlay).

The CT features are consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

B: bladder; L: liver; SB: small bowel

title: Osteoarthritis of the left knee
description:
X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

title: Metatarsal stress fracture
description:
X-ray foot (AP view)

A fracture (green line) of the distal third of the second metatarsal is accompanied by mature callus formation (red overlay). The location and appearance are suggestive of an old stress fracture with nonunion.

Radiographs performed at the onset of symptoms of a stress fracture may be normal or may show subtle findings (e.g., inconspicuous fracture line, loss of cortical density, cortical sclerosis or thickening, periosteal elevation). Mature callus is a later finding.

title: Tension pneumothorax
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A large right tension pneumothorax is accompanied by lung collapse. When compared to the left hemithorax, no lung markings are seen in the right hemithorax beyond the margin of the collapsed right lung (green overlay). Signs of tension seen here include contralateral shift of mediastinal structures and depression of the right hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and arrow). Another sign that may be seen in tension pneumothorax is ipsilateral intercostal space widening.

An unrelated finding on this radiograph is slight curvature of the upper to midthoracic spine, convex to the left.

Black line and arrows: shift of mediastinal pleura; white line and arrows: shift of cardiomediastinal silhouette

title: Vesicoureteral reflux
description:
Fluoroscopy (voiding cystourethrogram; supine; frontal view)

Reflux of contrast (vesicoureteral reflux; green overlay) from the bladder (B) into the right ureter is seen, without dilation of the ureter. The proximal collecting system and kidney are not visible on this image.

U: urethra

title: Electrical alternans
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Narrow-complex tachycardia with a ventricular rate of approx. 150/min
- Likely atrial fibrillation (irregular RR intervals, no definitive P waves)
- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in both I and aVF)
- QRS voltage is low, and consecutive R waves alternate in height (electrical alternans, red lines)

The combination of tachycardia, low QRS voltage, and electrical alternans is highly suggestive of a large pericardial effusion.

title: Epiglottitis (supraglottitis)
description:
CT neck (sagittal view; with contrast) and laryngoscopy of a patient with throat pain, hoarse voice, left-sided neck swelling, and a positive rapid strep test

The CT scan reveals edematous mucosal thickening of the oropharynx and supraglottic larynx, including the epiglottis (indicated by red arrowhead). The supraglottic laryngeal lumen appears severely narrowed (indicated by green arrowhead). Bedside flexible laryngoscopy shows edema of the epiglottis (E), vocal cords (V), and arytenoids (A).

Clinical findings and imaging suggest acute pharyngitis and supraglottic laryngitis with severe narrowing of the supraglottic laryngeal lumen.

Black arrowhead: subglottic larynx

title: Viral bronchiolitis
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a child with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

Extensive peribronchial thickening (examples indicated by green circles) has caused the hilar and perihilar regions to appear prominent. Additionally, the lung volumes are large as a result of air trapping.

One of the radiographic features suggestive of hyperinflation is the visualization of more than 6 anterior or 10 posterior ribs above the hemidiaphragm (indicated by numbers).

title: Chronic hepatitis B
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A chronic inflammatory infiltrate (blue overlay) consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophilic granulocytes can be seen in the center of the image. The infiltrate is located at the interface of the portal tract and hepatic lobules (yellow overlay), which is referred to as “interface hepatitis.”

These features are typical of chronic hepatitis, in this case, hepatitis B. Chronic inflammation of any tissue typically shows mononuclear cell infiltration (e.g., lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) and fibrosis may be present simultaneously as well (not present here).

title: Otitis media with effusion (OME)
description:
Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane (TM)

There is no noticeable bulging of the TM and the light reflex is visible in its normal position in the anterior inferior quadrant, indicating the TM is in a neutral position. The TMs yellow color and slight opacity suggest a serous effusion. There is no erythema.

title: Situs inversus with dextrocardia (situs inversus totalis)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

The aortic arch (dotted line), cardiac apex (arrow), and gastric bubble (red overlay) are seen on the right side of the body. Opacification in the left upper abdominal quadrant (green overlay) is the result of a left-sided liver.

title: Chondrosarcoma
description:
Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

Blue overlays: examples of calcifications; yellow outlines: examples of lobulations; arrowheads: examples of enlarged nuclei

title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

title: Preseptal cellulitis
description:
The left eyelid appears swollen and erythematous.

These clinical features are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis, an inflammation of tissue anterior to the orbital septum.

title: Polymorphous light eruption
description:
Left hand of a patient with pruritus after exposure to sunlight

Numerous small papules are visible on the dorsum of the hand.

In a patient with a history of direct exposure to sunlight, these features are consistent with polymorphous light eruption.

title: Meckel diverticulum
description:
Nuclear medicine technetium-99m pertechnetate (99m Tc) scan (anterior view of trunk over 60 min interval following injection)

Radiotracer activity in both the stomach (indicated by yellow circle) and right lower quadrant (indicated by blue circle) shows increased intensity over time (top left to bottom right).

The appearance is diagnostic of a Meckel diverticulum with gastric mucosa.

title: Foreign body (coin) ingestion
description:
X-ray chest (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a 10-month-old child

A well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body (arrows) projects partially over the trachea on the AP view and posterior to the trachea on the lateral view. Close inspection of the foreign body indicates that it is of uniform density. There is no double rim on the AP view or step-off to a small anode on the lateral view to suggest a button battery.

The finding proved to be an ingested coin (illustration) lodged in the esophagus.

title: Membranous nephropathy
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (Jones silver stain; very high magnification)

Thickening of the basement membrane (indicated by yellow outlines) with spike formation (examples indicated by blue arrowheads) can be seen.

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

title: Life cycle of Naegleria fowleri
description:
1. Amebae encyst to withstand adverse environmental conditions (e.g., desiccation, cold, diminished food supply).

2. Infective stage: Amebae excyst and develop into trophozoites once environmental conditions improve (e.g., warm or hot, poorly chlorinated fresh water). Longer exposure to adverse environmental conditions trigger encystation.

3. Trophozoites temporarily change into a flagellated form when exposed to adverse environmental conditions. When these conditions persist, the amoeba reverts to the trophozoite and encysted form.

4. The amebae multiplies through promitosis during the trophozoite stage.

5. The trophozoites or flagellates enter the nose of a human (definitive) host through contaminated water (e.g., while diving, dipping underwater in a hot tub, or during sinus irrigation) and penetrate the nasal mucosa. Flagellates revert to trophozoite form shortly after entering the nasal cavity.

6. Diagnostic stage: Amebae migrate to the brain via the olfactory nerves, causing primary amebic meningoencephalitis. Trophozoites can be found in brain tissue and CSF, whereas flagellates are occasionally found only in the CSF. Naegleria fowleri does not encyst within a definitive host.

title: Plantar calcaneal spur
description:
X-ray (lateral view)

A bony outgrowth (green overlay) projects from the calcaneal tuberosity at the origin of the plantar fascia.

C: calcaneus

title: Zenker diverticulum
description:
Barium swallow (lateral view)

The sequence of images (left: early; right: late) shows contrast (green overlay) filling a pouch arising from the posterior hypopharynx.

The location of the pouch is consistent with a Zenker diverticulum, a posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx just proximal to the upper esophageal sphincter. The diverticulum occurs through a weakness in the muscular wall of the pharynx called the Killian dehiscence.

title: Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (PIGN)
description:
Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of renal tissue from a patient with non-HBV associated PIGN

A glomerular capillary containing a red blood cell (red overlay) and an epithelial foot process of a renal podocyte can be seen (green overlay). Multiple hump-shaped electron-dense deposits (arrows) are also apparent.

These subepithelial immune complex deposits may be present in PIGN.

Blue overlay: nucleus of endothelial cell

title: Temporal aspects of different study types
description:
Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

title: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy/dysplasia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s) of a patient recovering from sudden cardiac arrest

- Heart rate approx. 60/min
- Regular sinus rhythm
- Left axis deviation (R > S in I, R < S aVF)
- First-degree AV block (PR interval approx. 240 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 480 ms)
- Widened QRS complexes (> 120 ms) with RBBB morphology
- Low-voltage QRS complexes in limb leads II, III, aVR, aVL, aVF (QRS amplitude < 5 mm)
- Epsilon waves in leads V1–V4 (best seen in V2/V3, examples marked in red)
- T wave inversion in leads V1–V4
- Slight ST depression in leads V2–V4

Epsilon waves and T wave inversion in V1–V4 are highly suggestive of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (the Epsilon wave is the most specific finding in this condition).

title: Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular rhythm; heart rate ∼190/min.
– Normal cardiac axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Narrow QRS complexes (< 100 ms)
– No visible P waves (they are buried in the QRS complexes)
– Widespread ST segment depression, most prominent in V3–V5 (likely rate-related; indicated by red overlay)
– QRS alternans: QRS amplitude is normal throughout but oscillates (indicated by green line)

A regular, narrow-complex tachycardia without visible P-waves is characteristic of AVNRT. Rate-related ST depression and QRS alternans are also commonly observed.

title: Atrial fibrillation
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)

- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1

title: Posterior vitreous detachment
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

A thin, oval opacity (Weiss ring; yellow outline) can be seen in the vitreous. Retinal details are blurred due to the preretinal focus of the photograph. The patient reported seeing floaters.

These findings are typical of posterior vitreous detachment.

Circle: optic disc; M: macula

title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

title: Auer rods in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear (Wright-Giemsa stain, high magnification)

Promyelocytes with azurophilic granules can be seen as well as a myeloblast containing multiple violet, rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, known as Auer rods (examples indicated by yellow lines).

Auer rods are typically seen in certain types of acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., APL) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

title: IgA nephropathy
description:
Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

title: Burkitt lymphoma
description:
Photomicrograph of lymph node tissue (H&E stain, high magnification)

Large macrophages with clear cytoplasm (examples indicated by green overlays) are interspersed with numerous medium-sized, monomorphic neoplastic lymphocytes. This appearance is known as the starry sky pattern and is a characteristic feature of Burkitt lymphoma. Many of the lymphoma cells show mitotic activity (examples indicated by yellow overlays).

title: Acute pyelonephritis and renal calculi
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; venous phase; axial plane) of a patient with acute pyelonephritis

The left ureter and renal pelvis are slightly dilated (red overlay) and contain hyperdense calculi (white arrowheads). The left kidney is larger than the right and the left renal parenchyma (green overlay) shows reduced contrast enhancement. There is also perinephric stranding (yellow overlay and white arrow), which is an important sign of renal inflammation or obstruction.

V: inferior vena cava; A: aorta

title: Renal oncocytoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a renal tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

A solid nest of tumor cells (without formation of glands or other structures) can be seen. The large tumor cells have a granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (examples indicated by arrowheads). Two atypical cells with hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei (green overlay) are also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of a renal oncocytoma. It is a benign condition, even if a few degenerative cells with suspicious atypia are seen.

title: ARDS (acute exudative phase)
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

An alveolus lined by a prominent hyaline membrane (green overlay) can be seen in the center of the image, containing numerous leukocytes (examples indicated by blue arrowheads) and erythrocytes (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The surrounding interstitium is edematous and interspersed with a dense inflammatory infiltrate (examples of inflammatory cells indicated by yellow arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of the exudative phase of diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), which is the histopathological appearance of the acute exudative phase of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

title: Retinitis pigmentosa
description:
Fundus photography of a left eye

The retina shows pigmentary deposits (blue overlay) resembling bone spicules in the mid periphery of the fundus along with retinal atrophy (yellow overlay), enhancing the visibility of the choroid vessels (examples indicated by arrowheads). The macula (M) shows a circular depigmentation (green overlay). The retinal blood vessels are attenuated.

This is the typical fundoscopic appearance of retinitis pigmentosa.

Circle: optic disc

title: Trimalleolar ankle fracture
description:
X-ray ankle (right; AP view) after supination-external rotation injury

An oblique fracture of the distal fibula (yellow overlay and red line) is accompanied by an avulsion fracture (red lines) of the medial malleolus (green overlay). The ankle mortise has been disrupted. There is widening of the medial compartment (indicated by white arrow) and lateral displacement of the talus (indicated by a black arrow). A lateral view (not included here) showed a fracture of the posterior malleolus.

The findings indicate an unstable trimalleolar fracture that requires operative treatment. If classified based on the location of the fibular fracture (Danis-Weber classification), this would be a Weber type B injury.

title: Nickel patch test
description:
Mouth of a patient after a nickel oral mucosa patch test

The upper lip shows a circular, whitish spot, which is a local reaction to the previously applied nickel patch.

title: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma
description:
Transvaginal ultrasound (longitudinal and transverse planes)

The endometrium appears thickened. Compared to the surrounding myometrium, an iso-hyperechoic lesion can be seen (green overlay), which invades < 50% of the myometrium.

These findings suggest endometrioid adenocarcinoma. A biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

title: Pulmonary embolism
description:
CT chest (with IV contrast; axial plane)

Filling defects in the right and left descending pulmonary arteries (green overlay) represent pulmonary emboli.

SVC: superior vena cava; AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; MPA: main pulmonary artery; RPA: right pulmonary artery

title: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)
description:
X-ray chest (left: lateral view; right: AP view) of a patient with a medical history of untreated HIV

Chest x-ray reveals diffuse, patchy interstitial, and alveolar infiltrates bilaterally. The (left-sided) perihilar lung shadowing (also known as “bat wing” or “butterfly opacities”) in AP view is concerning for Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

title: Horner syndrome
description: Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

title: Lytic skull lesion
description:
X-ray skull (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of a child with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)

Well-defined lytic lesions without sclerotic margins are seen in the frontoparietal and high-parietal regions of the calvarium (example indicated by green overlay).

Various conditions can cause lytic skull lesions. LCH lesions are typically rounded or ovoid in shape and have nonsclerotic well-defined margins. Edges may be beveled as a result of uneven destruction of the inner and outer tables. Coalescence of enlarging lesions can produce a geographic appearance.

title: Optic atrophy
description:
Fundus photographs (a: left eye; b: right eye)

Optic nerve pallor, a characteristic manifestation of optic atrophy, is visible.

title: Obstructing ureteral calculus
description:
Excretory urography (AP view; left: pre-contrast; right: 2.5 hours post-contrast)

A calcification medial to the lower pole of the right kidney on the pre-contrast radiograph (red overlay) is shown post-contrast to be an obstructing proximal ureteral calculus (UC; red overlay). The right kidney is enlarged, with persistent enhancement (green overlay). There is pelvicaliectasis and poor contrast-filling of the right ureter (region indicated by dashed lines). The left renal collecting system is normal (purple overlay).

RP: renal pelvis, U: ureter; UB: urinary bladder

title: Hodgkin lymphoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a lymph node biopsy specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

A Reed–Sternberg cell (green overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. It is surrounded by numerous lymphocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This histopathological appearance is characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.

title: Infective endocarditis
description:
Photograph of a dissected heart specimen opened to show the endocardial aspect of left atrium and ventricle

The mitral valve is thickened (indicated by arrow) and shows numerous yellow vegetations on the atrial (superior) aspect of the valve (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This gross appearance is typical of infective endocarditis of the mitral valve.

title: Extension-type supracondylar humeral fracture
description:
X-ray elbow (lateral view) of a child with a history of recent trauma

A comminuted supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus (H) shows posterior displacement of the distal fragment and growth plate involvement (white arrow). Joint effusion is present, with elevation of the lucent posterior fat pad (white arrowheads).

H: humerus; R: radius; U: ulna

title: Vitreous hemorrhage
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

Fundus details appear blurred. Dark red flowing patches of blood (green overlay) are visible at the temporal edge and in the central fundus, completely covering the aspect of the retina.

This is the typical appearance of a vitreous hemorrhage.

White circle: optic disc

title: Acute central serous retinopathy
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

The macula appears elevated (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

Circle: optic disc

title: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; very high magnification)

The glomerulus shows a hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone (green overlay) with an inflammatory infiltrate (examples of macrophages indicated by arrowheads).

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

title: Plantar wart
description:
There is a solitary, well-defined, rough, flat hyperkeratotic lesion with dark spots (thrombosed capillaries; examples indicated by arrowheads) on the plantar aspect of the foot.

Plantar warts are caused by HPV infection, particularly types 1, 2, and 4.

title: Hyperpronation maneuver for reduction of a radial head subluxation
description:
Photograph showing hyperpronation technique for reducing a radial head subluxation (also known as pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow)

Step one (left image): the child's arm is supported at the elbow and wrist, with the examiner's thumb exerting moderate pressure over the radial head.

Step two (right image): the forearm is hyperpronated; a click may be felt as the ligament moves over the radial head

title: Falciparum malaria: immature trophozoite in Plasmodium falciparum infection
description: Compared to other forms of malaria, trophozoites of falciparum malaria are characterized by smaller and finer ring-shaped inclusions (green overlay). Plasmodium falciparum invades many erythrocytes, and one erythrocyte is typically invaded by more than one plasmodium, which is not the case in other forms of malaria.

title: Intraarticular body in the knee joint
description:
X-ray right knee (AP view)

An intraarticular body (loose body, joint mouse; arrow) is visible within the medial compartment of the knee joint.

Intraarticular bodies are comprised of cartilage or cartilage and bone and may be the result of injury or degenerative disease. In the case of osteochondritis dissecans, a donor site (not shown here) is sometimes seen along the convex articular surface of a femoral condyle following the separation of an osteochondral fragment.

title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc

title: Placental attachment disorders
description:
Placental attachment disorders are classified according to the depth of implantation of the trophoblast in the uterine wall:

– Left: Normal placentation
– Placenta accreta: chorionic villi attach to the myometrium rather than the decidua basalis (but do not invade or penetrate the myometrium)
– Placenta increta: chorionic villi invade or penetrate into the myometrium
– Placenta percreta: chorionic villi penetrate the myometrium, penetrate the serosa, and, in some cases, adjacent organs/structures

title: Colonic polyps
description: Types of colonic polyps are depicted from left to right in descending order of their incidence.

title: Lunate dislocation and radial styloid fracture
description:
X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view)

The lunate (dashed outline) is displaced and rotated volarly, creating the classic triangular piece-of-pie sign of lunate dislocation on the PA view. Widening of the scapholunate interval (yellow overlay) is also seen. Volar angulation and displacement of the lunate are also seen on the lateral view, producing the spilled teacup appearance.

A displaced radial styloid fracture (green overlay and red line) is also visible.

title: Bony sequestrum
description:
X-ray leg (left; AP view) of a child

A fragment of bone (green overlay) has separated from adjacent bone and is surrounded by a lucent rim (red outline).

A bony sequestrum is devascularized bone that may be seen in the setting of chronic osteomyelitis. A sequestrum may act as a nidus for ongoing infection.

title: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)
description:
A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).

This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

title: Nonobstructive renal calculus
description:
CT abdomen (with oral contrast; coronal plane)

A nonobstructive hyperdense calculus (red circle) is present in the left renal pelvis. Atherosclerotic calcifications (red arrowheads) of the abdominal aorta (red overlay) are also seen. Metal streak artifacts (white arrows) between the aorta and inferior vena cava (blue overlay) are caused by an internal spinal fixator.

K and dashed lines: kidney; Li: liver, Lu: lung; PM: psoas major muscle; S: stomach with oral contrast; UB: urinary bladder

title: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
description:
6-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ~135/min
– Irregularly irregular RR intervals (examples indicated by black overlay)
– Normal axis
– Absent P waves
– Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves; examples indicated by red overlay) can be seen between the QRS complexes. These are characterized by low amplitude, high frequency, and irregular morphology, and should not be confused with P waves or flutter waves.

The absence of P waves with irregularly irregular RR intervals and an elevated heart rate indicates atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

title: Normal chest radiograph (PA and lateral)
description:
X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of an adult female patient

The lung volumes are normal. No abnormal pulmonary parenchymal opacities are seen. The cardiac silhouette size and shape are normal. The costophrenic sulci are sharp, with no evidence of effusion. No concerning skeletal lesions are identified.

On the lateral radiograph (right), the patient's upper arms (black dashed lines) obscure the retrosternal space. Furthermore, the lower thorax is slightly rotated with the left side anterior; note the stomach bubble (S) under the left hemidiaphragm and the projection of the left posterior costophrenic sulcus (dashed yellow line) anterior to the right (dashed blue line).

A: aorta
PT: pulmonary trunk
LA: left atrium
S: stomach
SVC: superior vena cava
IVC: inferior vena cava
Dashed white lines: margins of superior and inferior vena cavae
White line: aortopulmonary reflection (aortic-pulmonary reflection)
Yellow overlay: right atrium
Green overlay: right ventricle
Red overlay: left ventricle
Blue overlay: left atrium
Blue incomplete circle: left main to left upper lobe bronchus continuum
Dashed green line: posterior wall of bronchus intermedius
Green line: posterior wall of left main bronchus
Red line: top of left pulmonary artery
Blue line: aortic arch
Yellow lines: edges of scapulae

title: Complex renal cyst
description:
Ultrasound kidney (longitudinal plane)

An approximately 2-cm wide cystic lesion in the lower pole has a thickened wall (red overlay) and thick septations (green overlay). These features are suspicious for renal cell carcinoma. Further workup is indicated; contrast-enhanced ultrasound (not shown) is also sometimes used to evaluate for vascularity in septae.

Although not currently used to determine Bosniak classification, ultrasound is considered an excellent modality for the detection and evaluation of cystic renal mass complexity.

Renal length: 6.59 cm

title: Plasmacytoma of the femur
description:
X-ray knee (AP oblique and lateral views) of a patient with a history of POEMS syndrome

An expansile lesion (green overlay) in the metaphysis of the distal femur shows a mixed, predominantly lytic pattern. The lesion involves both trabecular and cortical bone and is accompanied by some periosteal reaction (red overlay).

Biopsy confirmed a plasmacytoma. Of note, plasmacytomas in POEMS syndrome are typically sclerotic lesions.

title: Roth spots
description:
Fundus photography of a left eye

There are multiple red, white-centered lesions, which reflect small retinal hemorrhages with central accumulation of leukocytes or fibrin thrombocyte emboli (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Although these findings were formerly considered to be associated almost exclusively with infective endocarditis, they may actually occur in a variety of conditions, including hypertensive, diabetic, and HIV-related retinopathy; leukemia; and intracranial hemorrhage.

Circle: optic disc; M= macula

title: ECG findings in moderate to severe hyperkalemia
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼ 78/min
– Regular rhythm with no detectable P waves (examples indicated by green circles)
– Normal axis (R > S in I and aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼ 140 ms)
– Tall, peaked T waves (examples indicated by red circles)

The combination of tall, peaked T waves, QRS complex widening, and absent P waves suggests moderate to severe hyperkalemia. Note that there is only a weak correlation between serum K+ levels and the severity of ECG changes.

title: Sinus bradycardia
description:
ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 37/min
– PR interval normal (∼ 160 ms), QRS normal (∼ 110 ms), QT interval normal (∼ 480 ms; QTc = 380 ms)
– Morphologies of P wave, QRS complex, and T wave are physiologic. Note the U waves (occurring after the T waves).
– No signs of ischemia

title: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (slipped upper femoral epiphysis)
description:
X-ray pelvis ( AP view) of a 14-year-old boy

Widening of the right femoral growth plate (physis; blue overlay) is accompanied by inferior and medial displacement of the epiphysis (green overlay) on the femoral neck (red overlay), which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. Widening of the right hip joint is also seen (indicated by double-arrows). The left femur is also abnormal, with a widened neck. A line (Klein line; dashed lines) along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck on either side does not intersect the respective epiphysis.

GS: gonad shield

title: Erythema migrans in stage-I Lyme disease
description:
A large, primary lesion with circular erythema and central clearing on the posterior side of the right upper arm is visible.

This clinical picture is typical of erythema migrans (stage-I Lyme disease).

Illustration: Bull's eye sign

title: Septic pulmonary emboli
description:
X-ray chest (supine) of a 24-year-old patient with history of intravenous drug use and septic emboli

Numerous pulmonary nodules are present in both lungs (examples indicated by green overlay). Some nodules have lucent centers indicating cavitation (examples indicated by red overlay). Air-space opacities, which were better appreciated on a subsequent CT scan (not shown), obscure the margins of some nodules.
The cardiac silhouette appears prominent as a result of rotation of the patient to the left.

The differential diagnosis of causes of multiple cavitary lung nodules includes bacterial, tuberculous, fungal, and parasitic infections as well as several noninfectious causes (e.g., rheumatic diseases and malignancies).

Arrowheads: thoracic spine spinous processes; dashed lines: medial clavicles; yellow overlay: right central line

title: Foreign body (coin) ingestion
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of an 8-year-old child

A metallic foreign body is seen over the gastric bubble (green overlay) in the left upper quadrant. Its position in the bowel makes it appears oval rather than rounded on the radiograph. There is no double rim or halo, the presence of which would indicate a button battery.

The appearance of the foreign body is compatible with a coin.

title: Intraductal papilloma
description:
Digital breast tomosynthesis galactogram (left breast)

This imaging modality may reveal lesions (e.g., intraductal papilloma) to be identified as small filling defects (arrow).

title: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
description:
12-month-old infant

Typical white-gray blisters with a diameter of approx. 3–5 mm surrounded by an erythematous halo are seen on the fingers (top images). Another common finding, as seen here, is a disseminated macular and papular rash on the upper and lower legs (bottom left). In addition, there is a partially crusted papulovesicular rash in the perioral region (bottom right). However, the eponymous involvement of the mouth refers to the typically painful aphthous enanthem of the oral mucosa, which is not shown here.

title: Ulnar shaft fracture
description:
X-ray forearm (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a child

An isolated fracture of the mid ulnar diaphysis is accompanied by displacement of the distal fragment (indicated by arrows). There is no disruption of the distal radioulnar joint.

This type of fracture has been termed a “parry” or “nightstick fracture.” It occurs when the ulna is more exposed than the radius to injury. It may be the result of direct trauma (forearm raised in self-defense) or indirect trauma (fall).

Arrowheads: bracelet; R: radius; U: ulnar

title: Reinke's edema
description:
Laryngoscopy

Loose, enlarged vocal cord due to a subepithelial edema between the epithelium and the vocal ligament (Reinke's space; green overlay).

Diagnosis: moderate Reinke's edema

title: Continuous wave (CW) Doppler in aortic valvular stenosis
description:
Echocardiography (transthoracic; apical five-chamber view; with CW Doppler)

The aortic valve is hyperechoic due to calcification and fibrosis of the valve leaflets.Transaortic velocity measures 4.01 m/s and the mean aortic pressure gradient measures 42.2 mmHg. From these measurements, the aortic valve stenosis would be classified as stage C2.

title: Left atrial myxoma
description:
Echocardiography (transthoracic; apical 4-chamber view)

A rounded mass (green overlay) arises from the wall of the left atrium (LA).

LV: left ventricle; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle

title: Panlobular pulmonary emphysema
description:
CT chest (high-resolution; axial plane) of a patient with panlobular emphysema

Reduced attenuation of the lung parenchyma is the result of abnormal enlargement of distal air spaces accompanied by destruction of secondary pulmonary lobules. Some narrowed thick-walled bronchi are also seen (examples indicated by white arrows).

The pattern of destruction in panlobular (panacinar) emphysema (green overlay) is diffuse within the secondary pulmonary lobule and the structures of the lobule are generally poorly seen on CT. In contrast, centrilobular (centriacinar) emphysema preserves visualization of much of the anatomy of the secondary lobule.

title: Thrombus in the left atrial appendage
description:
Transesophageal echocardiogram in a 78-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation, aphasia, dysarthria, and numbness in the left leg (midesophageal short-axis view of the left atrium)

A hyperechoic structure (red overlay) fills most of the LAA (white arrow; green outline).

This finding is typical of a large thrombus in the left atrial appendage. Transesophageal echocardiography is highly sensitive for cardiac thrombus.

AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium; LAD: left anterior descending artery

title: First-degree atrioventricular block
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Normal sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼80/min
– Normal axis
– PR interval: ∼300 ms

The PR interval >200 ms indicates first-degree atrioventricular block.

title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
description:
X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a 7-year-old child with atraumatic right hip pain and limp

The right femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is fragmented (red lines) and smaller than the left epiphysis. There is flattening of its articular surface.

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis.

Dashed line: normal shape of femoral articular surface; GS: gonad shield

title: Normal posteroanterior (PA) chest radiograph
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of an adult male patient

The lungs are well expanded. No abnormal parenchymal opacities are seen. The cardiac silhouette is normal in size and configuration. The pulmonary hila and superior mediastinum are also normal. The lateral costophrenic recesses are sharp, with no evidence of effusion. No concerning skeletal lesions are visible.

Green arrowheads: right paratracheal stripe; green overlay: aortopulmonary (aortic-pulmonic) window
White arrowhead: example of a spinous process
White dashed lines: tracheal and bronchial outline
Yellow overlay: examples of vertebral pedicles
Red overlay: azygos vein
LDPA: left descending pulmonary artery (or left interlobar artery)
RDPA: right descending pulmonary artery (or right interlobar artery)

title: Post-primary tuberculosis
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Bilateral heterogeneous consolidations (green overlay) show an upper-lobe-predominant distribution. There are scattered small air space nodules (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and cavities (red overlay) are present within areas of confluent opacification. The leftward tracheal deviation (indicated by black dashed outline and arrow) confirms the presence of left upper lobe volume loss. The left apical cap (blue overlay) could be the result of pleural thickening, fibrosis, extrapleural fat, or a combination of these features. The left costophrenic angle blunting (indicated by the white dashed line) could represent pleural thickening or a small effusion.

The radiographic findings shown are common in post-primary tuberculosis.

title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
description:
X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the knee

The fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

title: Pericardial effusion with water bottle configuration
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lupus pericarditis

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and demonstrates a globular, or water bottle, configuration due to pericardial effusion (green hatched overlay).

title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newborn

The first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.

These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

An enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

title: Horseshoe kidney
description:
CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane)

The lower poles of the kidneys (green overlay) are fused across the midline by an isthmus of enhancing parenchyma (red overlay). Note the lack of parenchyma at the level of the left renal hilum (indicated by white arrow), which is directed anteriorly as a result of incomplete medial rotation of the kidney along its longitudinal axis.

This is a classic appearance of horseshoe kidney.

C: colon (with contrast)

title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
description:
Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical three-chamber view)

The walls of the left ventricle are asymmetrically hypertrophied. Compared to normal findings (green dashed outline), the interventricular septum (red overlay) is markedly thickened (green arrows). The lateral wall is also thickened, but not to the same extent as the interventricular septum.

These findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. To assess for left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction, the LVOT pressure gradient during systole should be measured.

LW: lateral wall; LV: left ventricle; IVS: interventricular septum; MV: mitral valve; AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium

title: Rituximab mechanisms of action
description:
- Complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC): The recruitment of proteins of the complement system (e.g., C1) results in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), disrupting the cell membrane and causing B-cell lysis.

- Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC): Effector immune cells (e.g, natural killer cells, macrophages) bind to the Fc tail of rituximab with their Fc receptors and kill the B cells.

- Direct apoptosis: The binding of rituximab to the CD20 receptor can also lead to direct induction of apoptosis.

title: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm

– Average ventricular rate is ∼ 144/min (24 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

title: Sinus bradycardia with sinus pause and junctional escape rhythm
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rhythm and rate (best seen in lead II rhythm strip): three sinus beats (rate ∼ 35/min), followed by a sinus pause of ∼ 3.8 s, after which a junctional escape rhythm takes over (QRS complex identical to sinus beats, but no P wave visible)
– Normal cardiac axis (leads I and II positive, lead aVF isoelectric)
– Wide QRS complexes (∼ 140 ms)
– Normal PR interval (∼ 180 ms) and corrected QT interval (∼ 430 ms)

title: Onset of ventricular tachycardia (1/2)
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

0 to 2.2 seconds:
– Sinus rhythm
– Rate: ∼ 55/min
– Axis: normal, between (-30°) and 0° (R > S in leads I and II, R < S in aVF)
– Normal narrow QRS complexes

2.2 to 4 seconds:
– Regular ventricular rhythm with atrioventricular (AV) dissociation (no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes). P waves are mostly obscured due to the high ventricular rate, but can occasionally be seen partially buried in the T wave.
– Rate: ∼ 160/min
– Axis: remains normal but has shifted rightwards, to between 60° and 90° (R > S in lead I, R < S in aVL)
– Wide (∼ 140 ms), monomorphic QRS complexes with LBBB morphology

This ECG shows the onset of ventricular tachycardia (VT) following two beats of normal sinus rhythm. Monomorphic VT with LBBB morphology suggests a right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) origin.

title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; 2 slices in the axial plane) of a young child with known Chiari II malformation

The ventricles are markedly enlarged (green overlay) due to the obstructed passage of CSF at the craniocervical junction. The subarachnoid space appears unremarkable.

title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
description:
MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)

There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.

Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

title: Mucormycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a maxillary sinus biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Broad, nonseptate hyphae with right-angle branching are visible (example indicated by green overlay). These are accompanied by numerous neutrophils indicating acute sinusitis.

This is the typical appearance of mucormycosis.

title: Gottron papules in dermatomyositis
description:
Ellipsoid scaling papules are visible at the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints (white arrows).

These findings in a patient with dermatomyositis are consistent with Gottron papules.

title: Cortical laminar necrosis
description:
MRI head (T1 weighted; axial plane) of a patient after status epilepticus

The cortex of the right parietal lobe shows hyperintense signal (arrow). The white matter appears normal.

Cortical neurons have higher metabolic activity than white matter neurons, making them more vulnerable to damage if oxygen or nutrient supply is reduced, such as during status epilepticus.

title: Infective keratitis
description:
Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

title: Mature cataract
description:
Slit-lamp examination of the left eye

There is cloudy white opacification of the entire lens (green overlay). As a result, the red reflex is absent.

An additional finding is a posterior synechia (arrow), as the superior part of the pupil is not completely round.

title: Atrial premature beats (APBs) with trigeminy
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm at a rate of approx. 55/min with an atrial premature beat (green overlay) after every two sinus beats (blue overlay); this is referred to as “trigeminy.”

- The ectopic P waves coincide with the preceding T-wave to produce a larger, notched wave (yellow overlay; best seen in rhythm strip II)

- QRS complexes are widened (duration > 120 ms) for both sinus and premature beats. There is aberrant conduction of the premature beats, with a right bundle branch block morphology: rSR′ in V1–V3 (example indicated by red overlay), with a wide, slurred S wave in the lateral leads.

- There is no full compensatory pause following the premature beat (RR interval between the preceding and the following sinus QRS complexes is less than twice the normal RR interval)

title: Bilateral pulmonary opacities
description:
X-ray chest (A: PA view; B: lateral view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Bilateral airspace and interstitial opacities are predominant in the perihilar regions of both lungs, in the left greater than the right (examples indicated by green overlay). The heart size is normal and there are no pleural effusions.

title: Hydrocephalus
description:
MRI head (FLAIR sequence; two axial planes) of a young child

Dilated lateral ventricles are seen in the center of both images (green overlay).

title: Birbeck granules
description:
Electron micrograph of a Langerhans cell

The Birbeck granules are visible as tennis-racket-shaped structures within the cytoplasm (illustration; examples indicated by green overlay).

Birbeck granules are a diagnostic marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

title: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a tissue sample from a salivary gland tumor (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

Infiltrative tumor cells with a nested growth pattern in sclerotic stroma can be seen. The tumor cells show two different morphologies. There are mucous cells with bright cytoplasm (examples indicated by green overlay) and intermediate cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (examples indicated by yellow overlay). The third cell type necessary to confirm the diagnosis (epidermoid cells, which resemble the cells of spinal cell carcinoma) are not depicted here.

title: Glioblastoma multiforme
description:
Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

title: Double duct sign in pancreatic head carcinoma
description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane; arterial phase) of a patient with pancreatic carcinoma

The common bile duct (green overlay) and pancreatic duct (yellow overlay) are both dilated due to obstruction at the level of the pancreatic head.

Simultaneous dilatation of the common bile and pancreatic ducts has been referred to as the “double-duct sign” and can result from both malignant and benign conditions.

Blue overlay: inferior vena cava; C: liver cyst; GB: dilated gallbladder; P: pancreatic head; red overlay: examples of dilated intrahepatic bile ducts

title: Dacryocystitis
description:
Right eye of a 54-year-old male patient

A solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.

These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

title: Plus disease of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
description:
Fundus photography of a right eye

The retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.

This finding is an example of plus disease, which indicates a risk for progression to ROP.

title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of Fallot

The cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.

White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

title: Invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast
description:
Photomicrograph of a breast tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 40x magnification)

Infiltrating malignant cells can be seen as single cells, narrow chords (examples indicated by green overlay), and characteristic single-file formations (examples indicated by blue overlay). The tumor cells are seen growing between distorted ductuli (D) and lobuli (L), surrounded by conspicuously pale connective tissue. There is no tubule formation of the tumor (as is commonly seen in other types of adenocarcinomas of the breast).

This is the typical appearance of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Click on the microscope icon (at the top) to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Osteosarcoma
description: Osteosarcoma (green overlay) of the distal femur with dorsal perforation of the cortical bone (red dashed line) and filling of the medullary cavity, the epiphysis, and the metaphysis. A hemorrhagic tumor mass is seen in the dorsal soft tissue (red overlay).

title: Transverse myelitis
description:
MRI cervical and thoracic spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus and sudden onset quadriplegia

Longitudinal hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay), extending from C2 to T2, reflects edema of the spinal cord.

title: Allman classification of clavicle fractures
description: The Allman classification divides the clavicle into three equal segments, according to which fractures are classified.

title: Basal cell carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin tissue specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

There are dermal nests of infiltrating epithelial cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with retraction spaces between the tumor nests and the dermal fibrous tissue (dotted red lines). Furthermore, the peripheral tumor cells show palisading nuclei (examples indicated by dotted black lines).

These are the typical histologic features of basal cell carcinoma of the skin.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Frank-Starling mechanism in different pathologies
description:
The Frank-Starling mechanism maintains cardiac output by increasing myocardial contractility in response to an increased preload (end-diastolic volume).

The Frank-Starling mechanism maintains cardiac output by increasing myocardial contractility and thus stroke volume, in response to an increased preload (end-diastolic volume). The autonomic nervous system is able to regulate the heart rate as well as cardiac excitability, conductivity, relaxation, and contractility.

title: Intervertebral disk herniation and nerve root compression
description:
Dorsal view of the lumbosacral spine, spinal cord (at level of conus medullaris/cauda equina transition), and nerve roots

(A) Posterolateral disk herniation (90% of cases): most commonly affects the nerve root below the level of the herniation (L3/L4 disk herniation causes L4 nerve root impingement)

(B,C) Central (posterior) disk herniation: depending on location and extent of herniation, may affect both lumbar and sacral nerve roots (B) or only the sacral nerve roots (C)
