(D,E) Far lateral disk herniation: usually affects the nerve root above the level of the herniation (D: L2/L3 disk herniation causes L2 nerve root impingement), and may affect two adjacent nerve roots (E: above and below the level of herniation)

title: Portocaval anastomoses
description:
Portocaval anastomoses are anastomoses between veins of the portal venous system (veins that drain directly/indirectly into the portal vein) and veins of the caval venous system (veins that drain directly/indirectly into the superior or inferior vena cava). Physiologically, there is minimal/no blood flow through these anastomoses. In portal hypertension, increased portal venous pressure causes shunting of blood from the portal system into the caval system, which increases the pressure within the caval veins, causing variceal dilation of the caval veins at the sites of portocaval anastomoses.

(1) Distal esophagus: anastomosis between the left gastric vein (portal system) and the azygous vein (caval system), which manifests as esophageal varices in portal hypertension

(2) Paraumbilical region: anastomosis between the paraumbilical veins (portal system) and the superior and inferior epigastric veins (caval system), which manifests as caput medusae in portal hypertension

(3) Colon: anastomosis between the colonic veins (portal system) and the retroperitoneal veins (caval system), which manifests as colonic varices in portal hypertension

(4) Rectum and anal canal: anastomosis between the superior rectal vein (portal system) and the middle and inferior rectal veins (caval system), which manifests as anorectal varices in portal hypertension

title: Lisch nodules
description:
Right eye

Multiple brown-yellow, well-defined, and partly confluent papules (hamartomas) are visible on the iris.

These lesions are called Lisch nodules and can be seen in the vast majority of individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

title: Apoptosis
description:
Apoptosis is a type of programmed cell death that is carried out by a set of intracellular protease enzymes known as caspases, which are activated via two pathways:

1. The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway involves the activation of caspases brought about either by the binding of certain ligands to their receptors (e.g., FasL to Fas) or by cytotoxic T cells introducing proteases (e.g., perforin, granzyme B) into cells. The ligand-receptor complex activates initiator caspase 8 and the proteases activate the initiator caspase 10.

2. The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway involves the activation of caspases by a wheel-like structure, known as an apoptosome. This pathway is initiated by DNA injury (e.g., radiation, toxins) or the withdrawal of cellular proliferating factors (e.g., IL-2), which activates pro-apoptotic factors (BAX and BAK) and inhibits anti-apoptotic factors (Bcl-2). Pro-apoptotic factors increase mitochondrial membrane permeability, thus releasing cytochrome C, which then binds to APAF-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor 1), forming an apoptosome that activates the initiator caspase 9.

3. Common pathway: The initiator caspases activate the executioner caspases (3,6,7), which then cause nuclear fragmentation and cytoskeletal disintegration, resulting in cell shrinkage and membrane blebbing. These blebs carrying disintegrated cellular material break away from the cell, forming apoptotic bodies that are phagocytosed by macrophages.

title: Embryological development of the pancreas
description:
The pancreas develops from the endodermal dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds. The dorsal pancreatic bud is a dorsal outpouching of the distal foregut and differentiates into the body, tail, and the anterior aspect of the head of the pancreas. The ventral pancreatic bud is an outpouching of the future common bile duct and differentiates into the uncinate process and posterior aspect of the pancreatic head. The rotation of the foregut (blue arrow) connects the two pancreatic buds, with fusion occurring around the 8th week of gestation.

In normal development (top right image), the distal portion of the dorsal pancreatic duct fuses with the ventral pancreatic duct to form the main pancreatic duct, while the proximal portion of the dorsal duct either degenerates or persists as the accessory pancreatic duct.

In pancreas divisum, a common developmental abnormality, the buds fuse but the ducts fail to do so and continue to drain separately (indicated by dashed red line).

title: Agonist vs partial agonist
description:
A: agonist
B: partial agonist

title: Congenital Zika syndrome
description:
Brain imaging of a 15-month-old child with microcephaly
Top row (A-C): CT head (without contrast, axial plane)
Bottom row (D-F): MRI head (T2-weighted, sagittal plane (D), coronal plane (E), axial plane (F))

Brain volume is markedly decreased with compensatory expansion of the CSF spaces, especially the lateral ventricles.
CT (A–C) shows multiple calcifications in the subcortical white matter and in the basal ganglia. MRI shows hypoplasia of the brainstem (D), dysplasia of the cerebellum (E), and reduced and broadened gyri (pachygyria; F).

title: Herpes esophagitis endoscopy
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple well-circumscribed, confluent ulcers (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible in the distal (lower) esophagus.

These findings are consistent with herpes esophagitis. Histopathology is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Crown-rump length
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal; transverse plane)

A gestational sac (red line) within the uterus contains an embryo with a crown-rump length of 11.7 mm (green overlay), indicating normal development.

title: Intramedullary nail (gamma locking nail)
description: Osteosynthesis of an intertrochanteric fracture using a gamma locking nail: An intramedullary nail is placed directly into the bone marrow through the greater trochanter and held in position using a distal fixation screw. A lag screw is then placed through the nail, which enters the neck and head of the femur. This nail also allows for compression (weight-bearing) of the fracture site. The combination of intramedullary nail and lag screw resembles the Greek letter "γ" (gamma), which is why it is called a gamma locking nail.

title: Pulmonary aspergilloma
description:
X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: right lateral decubitus view)

A solid ovoid mass (red overlay) in the dependent portion of a large right upper lobe cavity (blue outlines) seen on the PA radiograph moves to a dependent position on a subsequent right lateral decubitus radiograph.

Saprophytic (noninvasive) aspergillus develops in the form of aspergilloma (also called a fungus ball or mycetoma) in preexisting cavities, such as those resulting from tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. Surrounding air has a crescentic appearance (Monod sign; green overlay). Movement to a dependent location with a change in patient position supports the diagnosis of aspergilloma.

title: Breast cyst
description:
Ultrasound breast

An oval lesion with smooth, thin and regularly shaped walls is visible (green overlay). Since the lesion presents anechoic, it can be concluded that it is filled with fluid and contains no solid areas.

These findings are consistent with a benign breast cyst.

title: Optic disc edema
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye

Left image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.

Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.

Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

title: Action potential and ion flux in myocardial contractile cells
description:
Resting potential (approx. -90mV) relies primarily on potassium channels (inward-rectifier potassium channels), ensuring a steady potassium efflux (iK1).

Phase 0 (depolarization): Neighboring cells stimulate voltage-gated sodium channels within the cell, causing them to open briefly. This results in a sodium influx (iNa ), and, consequently, the membrane potential increases just beyond 0 mV (overshoot).

Phase 1 (partial repolarization): The brief influx of chloride and efflux of potassium (not shown here) causes membrane potential to decrease.

Phase 2 (plateau): The opening of voltage-gated L-type calcium channels causes an influx of calcium ions (iCa), counteracting the repolarization and keeping the membrane potential at approximately 0mV.

Phase 3 (repolarization): Rapid repolarization occurs via the opening of outward-rectifier potassium channels, resulting in a net efflux of potassium.

Phase 4 (resting potential): A steady efflux of potassium (ik1) occurs until the cell is stimulated again and the process begins again at phase 0.

title: Bilateral toe necrosis
description:
Feet of a patient treated with vasopressors for septic shock

Symmetrical necrosis of the toe tips and skin exfoliation is visible. These findings are consistent with peripheral gangrene due to prolonged treatment with vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine).

title: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor pathways
description:
Baroreceptors are stretch receptors that are located in the carotid sinuses and in the aortic arch of the aorta. Baroreceptors sense minute blood pressure (BP) changes and send afferent signals to the brain stem (nucleus tractus solitarius) via the vagus nerve from the aortic arch and the glossopharyngeal nerve from the carotid sinus. The brainstem modulates autonomic outflow to alter the heart rate and peripheral vascular resistance to normalize BP (i.e., ↓ BP → sympathetic stimulation → ↑ HR, ↑ peripheral vascular resistance → ↑ BP; ↑ BP → parasympathetic stimulation → ↓ HR and ↓ peripheral vascular resistance → ↓BP). This pathway is known as the baroreflex.

A prolonged decrease in BP also stimulates long-term homeostatic mechanisms of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone pathway (RAAS) and ADH secretion (↑ ADH release → ↓ water excretion by the kidneys → ↑ intravascular volume → ↑ BP).

Chemoreceptors detect minute changes in pH and partial pressures of respiratory gases. Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid body and aortic body, are stimulated by a fall in pH and pO2 or a rise in pCO2, which occurs in hypoxia. Chemoreceptors send afferent signals to the brain stem (dorsal respiratory group) via the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves, which stimulates the respiratory centers of the brain, resulting in an increase in the rate and depth of breathing. Chemoreceptor stimulation also increases the sympathetic outflow to the heart.

title: Tram track sign
description:
X-ray chest (PA view; right lung) and CT (coronal plane; lung window; right lung) of a patient with bronchiectasis

The right lung is diffusely abnormal. Numerous parallel lines (tram track sign; examples indicated by arrows and green lines) representing thickened bronchial walls demarcate lucent air within dilated bronchi. Some thick-walled bronchi are alternatively imaged in cross-section and are visible as circles with lucent centers (examples indicated by red overlay).

title: String of beads sign in fibromuscular dysplasia
description:
Angiography abdomen (right renal artery)

The caliber of the renal artery alternates between stenoses and aneurysms, creating a string of beads appearance that is characteristic of medial fibromuscular dysplasia.

title: Bronchiectasis
description:
CT chest (axial section)

Numerous bilateral dilated bronchi (bronchiectasis) show wall thickening and an increased bronchoarterial ratio. Several bronchi imaged in cross-section have a diameter greater than the accompanying pulmonary artery diameter (1; signet ring sign), while others imaged in long axis have parallel walls (2; tram track sign).

title: Spondylodiscitis (discitis-osteomyelitis)
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

The inferior endplate of L2 and superior endplate of L3 are osteopenic and the cortices appear fragmented (green ellipse). The intervening L2–3 disc space is narrowed.

title: Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosis

The pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.

Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

title: Double bubble sign
description:
X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a newborn with duodenal atresia

A nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric antrum. Gaseous distention of the stomach and pyloric channel (green overlay) and dilatation of the duodenal bulb (red overlay) are seen. Bowel distal to the duodenal bulb does not contain gas.

This appearance has been termed the “double-bubble sign.” This sign is seen with duodenal atresia and several other congenital and acquired causes of duodenal obstruction.

title: Noncaseating granuloma
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Multiple confluent granulomas (green overlay) are visible within the bronchial submucosa, narrowing the lumen (arrow). Note the absence of central necrosis in the granulomas.

This appearance is characteristic of a noncaseating granuloma in sarcoidosis.

title: Myocardial infarction (coagulative necrosis)
description:
Photomicrograph of a myocardial tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Early coagulative necrosis of the cardiomyocytes is visible (examples of myocytes breaking down are indicated by arrowheads). Moreover, the cytoplasm is partly hypereosinophilic (examples indicated by green overlay), and interstitial edema (examples indicated by red overlay) can be seen. Note that there is no neutrophilic infiltration, which would indicate an infarct older than ~24 hours.

These are the histological features of myocardial infarction without reperfusion (approx. 4–24 hours old).

title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
description:
X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

title: Spiculated lung mass
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

The lower right lung opacity (green overlay) has an irregular border with spiculation (sometimes referred to as “corona radiata,” “corona maligna,” or “sunburst”), raising suspicion for a malignant mass. In addition, the more opaque appearance of the right hilum (yellow arrow) compared to the left (white arrow) is of concern for lymphadenopathy, while the costophrenic angle blunting (indicated by red line) suggests pleural effusion.

Certain benign infectious and inflammatory lung lesions may also have spiculated margins.

title: Empty sella syndrome
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The sella turcica is slightly enlarged and filled with fluid that is isointense to CSF (green overlay). It is difficult to differentiate the pituitary gland (red overlay) from the bottom of the sella turcica.

These are the typical radiological features of empty sella syndrome, which is characterized by a dilation of the subarachnoid space into the sella turcica, leading to a compression of the pituitary gland.

title: Mammography in breast cancer
description:
Mammography (right breast; mediolateral oblique view)

A high-density mass (green overlay) with an indistinct margin and containing microcalcifications (examples indicated by red overlay) projects in the upper breast.

The features of this lesion are highly suspicious for malignancy.

title: Herpes zoster keratitis
description:
Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eye

Superficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).

In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

title: Lymphocytic colitis
description:
Photomicrograph of a colon tissue sample (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

Increased amounts of intraepithelial lymphocytes (examples indicated by green overlay) are dispersed between the enterocytes (example indicated by blue overlay), with > 20 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes visible. There are no neutrophils nor is there architectural distortion, which would indicate infectious colitis or inflammatory bowel disease, respectively.

Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes in the absence of neutrophils and architectural distortion is characteristic of lymphocytic colitis, a type of microscopic colitis.

title: Normal vulvar epithelium
description:
Photomicrograph of a vulvar tissue sample (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

The epidermis (green overlay) and dermis (yellow overlay) are both visible. Below the typical keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, there is a slightly increased amount of lymphocytes in the dermis (most likely subclinical inflammation; examples indicated by arrows).

title: Advanced degenerative arthritis of the great toe metatarsophalangeal joint
description:
X-ray anterior foot (bilateral; AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes can be seen at the left first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint and sesamoid articulations (indicated by red lines), with prominent MTP joint osteophytes (yellow overlay), subchondral sclerosis (green overlay), and joint space narrowing (blue line). There is lesser involvement of the right first MTP joint. No articular erosions can be seen.

title: Chronic pyelonephritis
description:
Photomicrophraph (H&E stain, 150x magnification) of an autopsy kidney specimen of a 60-year-old patient with prostate and bladder carcinoma

A chronic interstitial infilitrate (highlighted red) is seen in scarred fibrous tissue (highlighted green) replacing most of the renal parenchyma. Tubules are partly atrophic with flattened epithelia (arrowheads) or cystically dillated with colloid-like luminal material (so-called tubular “thyroidization” because of it's resemblance of thyroid follicles). A single normal glomerulum (marked "G") can be seen. The overall reduced thickness of the parenchyma speaks for a dilated renal pelvis and an obstructive problem (e. g. by tumor or after radiation).

These findings are consistent with chronic pyelonephritis.

title: Bite cells in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; 600× magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes are visible, some of which have an abnormally shaped membrane due to macrophage-mediated removal of denatured hemoglobin that precipitated at the cell membrane (examples outlined in green). They appear smaller, denser, and more contracted than normal erythrocytes (example outlined in red).

These abnormally formed cells are called “bite cells” and result from oxidative hemolysis, which is seen in G6PD deficiency.

title: Multilevel peripheral arterial disease of the lower limbs
description:
MR angiography lower limbs

Numerous stenoses (examples indicated by arrows) are present. Portions of several bilateral pelvic, femoral, and lower limb arteries are not visible.

title: Right internal carotid artery stenosis
description:
MRI angiography (carotid arteries)

There is high-grade stenosis of the origin of the right internal carotid artery (red overlay). Visible major neck vessels (green overlay) include the common carotid arteries (1), internal carotid arteries (2), external carotid arteries (3), right superior thyroid artery (4), and left vertebral artery (5).

title: Button battery impaction in esophagus
description:
X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a young child

A well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body is seen behind the trachea in the upper esophagus. On close inspection, a double rim (dashed lines), or halo (green overlay), is visible on the PA view, which indicates that it is a button battery. A step-off (arrows) to the small diameter anode (hatched green overlay) is seen on the lateral view.

Recognition of a button battery in the esophagus is a pediatric emergency. Radiographs can frequently differentiate button batteries from similarly sized coins and ascertain the direction of the anode, where the most severe damage from the battery occurs. The anode step-off (arrows) may not be visible on some very thin batteries.

title: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
description:
Photomicrograph of bone marrow aspirate smear (Wright staining; 1000x magnification)

Intermediate-sized blasts with dispersed chromatin, a moderate amount of cytoplasm, and indistinct nucleoli are seen alongside pale-stained erythrocytes.

These findings are consistent with precursor B-cell ALL.

title: Third-degree atrioventricular block (complete heart block)
description:
ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼ 83/min in all tracings. However, in third-degree AV block, there is no conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in an escape rhythm being generated by pacemaker cells in more distal sites. Ventricular rate and QRS morphology vary according to the site of origin of the escape rhythm: the more distal the site of impulse generation, the slower the rhythm and the wider the QRS complex.

Sinus rhythm (top): rate ∼ 83/min

Third-degree AV block with junctional escape rhythm (middle)
– AV dissociation (no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes)
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 45/min and narrow QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the AV node

Third-degree AV block with ventricular escape rhythm (bottom)
– AV dissociation
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 25/min and wide QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the bundle of His

title: Second-degree atrioventricular block
description:
ECG schematic of types of second-degree atrioventricular block (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼78/min in all tracings.
– Mobitz I/Wenckebach (top): There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.
– 2:1 block (middle): The PR interval is constant but only every second P wave is conducted to the ventricles to trigger a QRS complex.
– High-grade block (bottom): The PR interval is constant but ≥2 consecutive P waves are not conducted to the ventricles. In this example, only every third P wave triggers a QRS complex (a 3:1 block).

title: Types of ST-segment elevation
description:
ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

–Left: normal ECG
–Top right: upwardly convex ST elevation from descending limb of the R wave
–Bottom right: slightly upwardly concave (borderline horizontal) ST elevation from ascending limb of the S wave

title: First-degree atrioventricular block
description:
ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Top: normal PR interval
– Bottom (first-degree atrioventricular block): PR interval ≥0.2 s

title: Lumbar plexus
description:
A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the subcostal and first four lumbar nerves (T12–L4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the lumbar plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

title: Serology time course of acute and resolved hepatitis B infection
description:
Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

title: External fixation of a comminuted fracture of the tibia
description: External fixation is a method of immobilizing a fracture using devices (e.g., pins, screws, etc) that are secured outside the skin (in contrast to internal fixation, in which the devices are placed completely inside the body).

title: Overview of peripheral artery bypass surgeries
description:
There are two types of peripheral artery bypass: anatomical bypass (which follow the normal anatomical vascular pathways) and extraanatomical bypass (which circumvent them).

When naming these bypasses, the proximally located donor vessel is listed first, followed by the distally located recipient vessel.

title: Multiple sclerosis symptoms
description: The percentage indicates how frequently a specific finding is observed or reported in patients with multiple sclerosis.

title: Patient controlled analgesia (PCA) pump
description:
PCA pumps provide patient-controlled administration of opiates (epidural or intravenous) and local anesthetics (epidural). They may be used in the management of severe pain that is expected to be limited in duration, e.g., postoperative pain or malignancy pain.

The display shows the current settings of the pump, which can be adjusted by medical staff as required:
– Continuous rate: the dosage of opiates that is automatically infused
– The PCA dose: the bolus dose of opiates that the patient can inject using the blue button on the remote control
– PCA lockout: the minimum amount of time that has to pass after a bolus dose before the pump will allow a further bolus to be administered
– 1-hour limit: the maximum amount of analgesia that the pump will dispense over an hour

title: Sturge-Weber syndrome
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with Sturge-Weber syndrome

Marked, leptomeningeal contrast enhancement along the right parieto-occipital gyri and sulci can be seen (green overlay).

title: Gross classification of esophageal atresia
description:
Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

title: Cavitary lung lesion
description:
X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosis

A thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.

The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.

title: Ovarian follicular cyst
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (left ovary; transvaginal; sagittal plane)

A rim of ovarian tissue (green overlay) is visible along the margin of a 5-cm thin-walled unilocular simple ovarian cyst.

Follicular cysts are benign functional ovarian cysts. Ovarian follicles measure < 3 cm on ultrasound whereas follicular cysts measure ≥ 3 cm.

title: Cervical disk herniation
description:
MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Cervical disk herniation at C6–C7 (green overlay) produces a prominent anterior extradural impression with spinal canal narrowing and cord compression.

title: Pneumoperitoneum
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Free intraperitoneal gas (green overlay) is visible under both the right and left hemidiaphragms.

title: Transtheoretical model of behavioral change
description:
– Precontemplation stage (*): The individual denies or is unaware there is a problem
– Contemplation stage: The individual is aware there is a problem but not willing to make a change
– Preparation stage: The individual is ready/preparing to make a change
– Action stage: The individual demonstrates a change in behavior
– Maintenance stage: The individual maintains the behavioral changes. This may be permanent, or they may relapse.
– Relapse: The behavioral changes are reversed. The cycle may restart.

title: Final section of the bronchial tree
description: Branches of the pulmonary artery carry oxygen-depleted blood to the alveoli for oxygen enrichment (hence depicted in blue), while branches of the pulmonary vein carry oxygen-rich blood from the lungs to the heart (depicted in red).

title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.

1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

title: Anti-PD-1 antibodies
description: Anti-PD-1 antibodies remove negative signals and enhance the T cell-mediated killing of cancer cells.

title: Ascitic fluid analysis
description:
This illustration gives an overview of the differential diagnoses of ascitic fluid, based on appearance, SAAG, and ascitic fluid total protein. As illustrated, the ascitic fluid is usually obtained through a diagnostic paracentesis in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Note that while early Budd-Chiari syndrome will result in high ascitic protein levels, with progression to cirrhosis in late Budd-Chiari syndrome the ascitic protein levels decrease to < 2.5 g/dL.

LLQ: left lower quadrant; SAAG: serum-ascites albumin gradient

title: Colon in Crohn disease
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon

Multiple linear and serpiginous ulcerations covered with fibrinous exudate can be seen. The mucosa between the ulcerations is erythematous and has lost its normal vascular pattern.

These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.

title: Eosinophilic esophagitis
description:
Photomicrograph of esophageal epithelial tissue (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are a large number of eosinophils present (examples indicated by green overlay). Some of these are clustered into eosinophilic microabscesses (white arrowheads), which are characteristic of eosinophilic esophagitis and help to differentiate it histologically from reflux esophagitis (in which there may also be many eosinophils present). The dilated intercellular spaces (black arrows) are a non-specific feature that is also present in reflux esophagitis.

title: Calcified and noncalcified coronary artery plaques
description:
CT coronary angiography (curved multiplanar reconstruction; left anterior descending coronary artery)

Multiple calcified (green overlay) and noncalcified plaques (red overlay) are visible along the course of the left anterior descending coronary artery.

title: Hydatidiform mole
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal) of pregnant patient with abnormally elevated β-hCG level

There is no intrauterine gestation. An intrauterine mass (green outline) contains multiple cystic spaces (examples indicated by red overlay), which correspond to hydropic trophoblastic villi.

This vesicular appearance seen in a molar pregnancy has been described as a “snowstorm pattern”.

title: Box jellyfish sting
description:
Linear erythematous lesions in a cross-hatched, so-called "frosted-ladder" pattern are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of a box jellyfish sting.

title: Chancres on the labium in primary syphilis
description:
A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

title: Acute calculous cholecystitis
description:
Ultrasound gallbladder

The gallbladder is dilated and its wall (green overlay) is thickened and striated (alternate hyperechoic and hypoechoic layers) as a result of edema. A calculus within dependent sludge in the neck produces posterior acoustic shadowing (red overlay) and has a highly reflective echogenic anterior surface (green hatched overlay).

Ultrasound findings in acute cholecystitis include wall thickening, dilatation, pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign. The presence of multiple ultrasound findings increases diagnostic accuracy for cholecystitis.

L: liver

title: Perihilar opacities in Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)

Bilateral opacification of the lungs is visible in a perihilar (bat wing or butterfly) distribution (green overlay). This pattern of involvement can be seen in a variety of diseases, including pulmonary edema (cardiogenic and noncardiogenic), pneumonia, inhalational lung injury, pulmonary hemorrhage, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and malignancy. Low lung volumes and cardiac silhouette enlargement, which may accompany cardiogenic edema, are not present on this radiograph.

Bilateral perihilar opacification is a common presentation of PCP pneumonia and may have a granular, reticular, or airspace appearance on chest radiography. PCP may also present with lung cysts and pneumothorax. A ground-glass appearance is commonly described on CT. Nodules, cavities, lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusions are uncommon.

title: Superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMAS)
description:
Narrowing of the angle between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the aorta (aortomesenteric angle) may result in the third portion of the duodenum being compressed between the two vessels, and subsequently small bowel obstruction.

Note: This pathogenic mechanism may also cause nutcracker syndrome, in which the left renal vein (instead of the duodenum) is compressed between the SMA and the aorta.

title: Distribution pattern of osteoarthritis of the hand
description: Osteoarthritis of the hand affects especially the distal interphalangeal joints (Heberden nodes), proximal interphalangeal joints (Bouchard nodes), and the first carpometacarpal joint, between the trapezoid and the first metacarpal (Rhizarthrosis).

title: Molecular effects of glucocorticoids
description:
– Metabolic: mobilization of energy reserves through increased gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and protein catabolism; also increased bone resorption.

– Immunosuppressive and antiinflammatory: direct and indirect regulation of nuclear factor κ-B (NF-κB), which is a central proinflammatory transcription factor. Glucocorticoids bind to glucocorticoid receptors (1), resulting in increased transcription of the IκB gene, which codes for the antiinflammatory protein IκB. Indirect regulation thus occurs through IκB-binding of NF-κB (2), preventing its translocation to the nucleus. The glucocorticoid/GR complex can also directly inhibit the action of NF-κB within the nucleus. Both direct and indirect pathways result in decreased production of proinflammatory factors, e.g., IL-1, IL-2, TNFα.

– Catecholamine sensitivity: Glucocorticoids potentiate the effects of catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine by upregulating their receptors.

title: Adverse effects of glucocorticoids
description: Features not specifically highlighted as being caused by inhaled glucocorticoids or by both systemic and topical glucocorticoids are caused primarily by systemic glucocorticoid use.

title: Epinephrine autoinjector
description:
This epinephrine autoinjector (EpiPen) contains 0.3 mg of epinephrine (1:1000 dilution). It is intended for intramuscular injection into the anterolateral thigh in the case of anaphylaxis.

The autoinjector is stored in a carrier tube (not shown in this image). The blue safety release cap requires removing before application. The orange tip is then jabbed firmly into the anterolateral thigh to release the needle (until it clicks) and held in place for 3 seconds to allow the injection to complete.

title: Enlarged left atrial appendage
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

A convexity between the moguls produced by the main pulmonary artery (PA) and left ventricle (LV) suggests enlargement of the left atrial appendage (LAA; normal configuration indicated by dashed line). Breast shadow opacification (green overlay) simulates parenchymal airspace disease.

AA: aortic arch

title: Chiari I malformation
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Low-lying cerebellar tonsils (green overlay) extend below the foramen magnum (white line) to C2-level and abut the medulla oblongata.

The finding is consistent with a Chiari I malformation. There is no evidence of a syrinx or hydrocephalus.

title: Acute acalculous cholecystitis with sludge
description:
Ultrasound gallbladder (transabdominal; longitudinal plane)

The gallbladder is dilated and its wall (red overlay) is thickened. The layered appearance of the wall (hypoechoic stripe between two echogenic lines) is the result of inflammation and edema. Dependent biliary sludge (green overlay) is visible.

Many diseases cause gallbladder wall thickening. Ultrasound findings in acute acalculous cholecystitis can include mural thickening, dilatation, pericholecystic fluid, hyperemia, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign. The presence of several ultrasound criteria increases diagnostic accuracy for cholecystitis. In this case, the additional feature of gallbladder distention was helpful.

title: Canals and foramina of base of skull
description: Superior view of internal surface

title: Palpable lymph nodes
description:
Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

title: Interconnection of brainstem reflexes
description:
Simplified representation of the pupillary light reflex (II → IIIa), corneal reflex (V → VII), and vestibuloocular reflex (VIII → III)

(II = pretectal area (afferent part of the optic nerve); IIIa = Edinger–Westphal nucleus: III = oculomotor nucleus; V = trigeminal nerve nucleus; VII = facial motor nucleus; VIII = vestibular nucleus)

title: Scabies
description: Multiple erythematous, partly excoriated papules and burrows are visible on the back of the hand, the fingers, and the intertriginous area.

title: Acanthosis nigricans
description:
Hyperpigmented skin and hyperkeratosis are visible in this patient's left axilla. An erythematous patch is visible in between the hyperpigmented areas.

These findings are suggestive of acanthosis nigricans.

title: De Quervain tenosynovitis
description: Noninflammatory thickening of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis in the first dorsal compartment of the extensor retinaculum, overlying the radial styloid process.

title: Miliary lung nodules
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with miliary tuberculosis

Innumerable small nodules (∼ 2 mm in size; examples indicated by green overlay) are distributed diffusely throughout the parenchyma of both lungs. A laterally circumscribed convexity (red outline) representing adenopathy overlies the region of the right descending pulmonary artery.

A miliary pattern may be seen in several conditions, among them tuberculosis, fungal infections, and metastatic disease. The clinical presentation and associated imaging findings provide information essential to the differential diagnosis of miliary lung nodules.

title: Lumbar ankylosing spondylitis
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Marginal syndesmophytes (red lines) from ossification of the annulus fibrosis bridge multiple lumbar vertebrae (known as “bamboo spine”). So-called “shiny corners” (green triangles) at the superior and inferior margins of vertebrae represent reactive sclerosis in response to inflammatory Romanus erosions. Lower lumbar facet joints are fused (green lines).

title: Comminuted distal radius fracture with intraarticular extension
description:
X-ray wrist (left: lateral view; right: PA view)

A comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal radius (red overlay) is accompanied by radial displacement (red arrow) and volar angulation (red line and angle) with respect to a line perpendicular (green dashed line) to a line through the shaft (green line). An ulnar styloid fracture (green overlay) is also seen.

title: Esophageal perforation
description:
Fluoroscopy (Gastrografin swallow; frontal view) of patient after transesophageal echocardiography

Extravasated oral contrast (green overlay) through a perforation (red overlay) of the mid-esophagus parallels the distal esophagus in the mediastinum.

E: esophagus

title: Proximal and distal median nerve lesions
description: AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

title: Third-degree atrioventricular block
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate: ∼ 110/min
– Ventricular rate: ∼ 27/min (escape rhythm)
– QRS complex: ∼ 100 ms (normal)
– AV dissociation: P waves (black arrowheads) and QRS complexes (red arrowheads) both have regular rhythms, but the rhythms are unrelated because there is no conduction between the atria and ventricles. This results in some P waves being completely or partially buried in QRS complexes or T waves (green arrowheads).

AV dissociation with bradycardia is characteristic of third-degree atrioventricular block (complete heart block).

title: Acral lentiginous melanoma
description: Irregularly shaped, brownish-black macules are visible through the nail, consistent with melanonychia. The middle finger shows pigmentation of the proximal nail fold (Hutchinson sign), consistent with subungual melanoma.

title: Granulomatous sialadenitis
description:
Photomicrograph of a parotid gland tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Salivary gland tissue shows sclerotic changes and fatty degeneration. There is a nonnecrotizing granuloma composed of epitheloid cells and multinucleated giant cells at the center of the image surrounded by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate.

Granulomatous sialadenitis can have various infectious (e.g., mycobacteria, fungi, Bartonella henselae) as well as noninfectious causes (duct obstruction, sarcoidosis).

title: Overview of somatic and autonomic motor pathways and neurotransmitters
description:
Somatic motor neurons in the central nervous system (CNS) synapse directly onto skeletal muscle. In contrast, in most visceral (autonomic) motor pathways, a neuron in the CNS (preganglionic neuron) synapses onto a neuron in a peripheral ganglion (postganglionic neuron), which, in turn, synapses onto the target organ. The sympathetic ganglia are paravertebral and prevertebral, while the parasympathetic ganglia are located close to the target organs.

Somatic motor neurons release acetylcholine, as do all autonomic preganglionic neurons and parasympathetic postganglionic neurons. Most sympathetic postganglionic neurons release norepinephrine.

Exceptions (special variants):

- The adrenal medulla is directly innervated by preganglionic sympathetic neurons and releases catecholamines into the circulation, which exert hormonal effects on target tissues and organs.
- Sympathetic postganglionic neurons synapsing on eccrine sweat glands release acetylcholine.

title: Guttate psoriasis
description:
Multiple small scaly erythematous lesions are visible.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis and is most often precipitated by group A streptococcal infection.

title: Hypopyon
description:
Left eye

Massive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).

The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.

Dashed line: surrounds cornea

title: Lumbar spondylosis
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (left: AP view; right: lateral view)

There are degenerative changes, with large osteophytes (examples indicated by green overlay) projecting from the anterior and lateral aspects of several vertebral endplates. Some adjacent vertebrae are fused by bridging osteophytes (examples indicated by arrows).

title: ECG of a patient with pulmonary embolism
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal rate (approx. 90/min)
– Cardiac axis ∼ 90° (QRS complex is isoelectric in I and positive in aVF): borderline normal/right-axis deviation
– P pulmonale: P-wave amplitude ≥ 0.25 mV in II, III, and aVF
– PR interval normal (< 0.2 s)
– QRS duration 0.1–0.12 s (incomplete bundle branch block)
– QTc interval normal (∼ 0.4 s)
– Discordant T-wave inversion in III, aVR, V1, V3–V6
– SIQIIITIII-pattern: deep S waves in I (blue overlay), pathological Q waves in III (green overlay), and T-wave inversion in III (red overlay)

The SIQIIITIII-pattern and P pulmonale are both suggestive of pulmonary embolism, but neither of these findings is sensitive or specific for this diagnosis.

title: Psammoma body
description:
Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Psammoma bodies are concentric lamellar calcifications that are often seen within papillary thyroid carcinomas.

Other tumors with frequent presence of psammoma bodies include serous carcinoma of the ovary, high-grade serous carcinoma of the uterus, and meningiomas.

title: Anterior shoulder dislocation
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

MRI left shoulder (STIR and T1, coronal plane; PD FS, axial and sagittal plane)

On the fat-saturated sequences (STIR and both PD images), there is hyperintensity in the posterolateral humeral head and anteroinferior glenoid rim with corresponding hypointensity on the T1 image. These findings indicate contusion. In addition, a depression in the cortex of the affected region of the humeral head (Hill-Sachs depression fracture) is seen. There is also a fracture through the affected anteroinferior glenoid (osseous or bony Bankart Lesion).

This pattern of injury occurs during anterior dislocation as the humeral head externally rotates and descends inferiorly, impacting the anteroinferior glenoid rim with its posterolateral surface.

title: Cholelithiasis and choledocholithiasis
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial and coronal planes)

A laminated calcified calculus (red overlay) is present in the dilated gallbladder (green overlay), and a smaller calculus (yellow arrowhead) is seen in the distal common bile duct (blue overlay). A small gas-filled duodenal diverticulum (white arrowhead) is visible adjacent to the common bile duct calculus.

A cystic left ovarian lesion (yellow overlay) and numerous colonic diverticula (examples indicated by red arrowheads) are seen. There is extensive atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta (examples indicated by green arrowheads), coronary arteries, and several other arteries. A few subcentimeter hypodense lesions seen in the liver are likely cysts, and there is a small hiatal hernia.

title: Pulmonary fibrosis from occupational exposure
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest (with contrast; series 3: axial plane, mediastinal window; series 4: axial plane, lung window) of a patient with a history of work-related lignite and quartz dust exposure

There is evidence of chronic interstitial lung disease with extensive clustered cystic air space formation (honeycombing). Some areas show traction bronchiectasis. Enlarged reactive mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes are present. The main pulmonary artery is enlarged, which may indicate pulmonary hypertension. An indeterminate nodule is present in the right lung apex.

title: Lobar consolidation
description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest (with contrast; axial plane, mediastinal window; axial plane, lung window) of a patient with symptoms of pneumonia

Dense consolidation nearly completely opacifies the left lower lobe. Some areas of relative sparing are seen, especially within the superior segment. Reactive lymph nodes are present along the left superior mediastinum and central pulmonary vessels. There is a very small left pleural effusion .

title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Multiple areas of high attenuation in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci (examples indicated by green overlay) are characteristic of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage.

title: Acute tonsillitis
description:
Oral cavity of a child presenting with fever, dysphagia, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy

The pharyngeal tonsils are enlarged, erythematous, edematous, and have streaks of mucopurulent discharge bilaterally.

This is the typical appearance of bilateral acute tonsillitis.

title: Angiomyolipoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous mature adipocytes are visible, identifiable as large clear cells with a thin layer of eosinophilic cytoplasm and a peripherally placed basophilic nucleus (examples indicated by black arrowheads). Thick-walled blood vessels (green overlay) are scattered among the adipocytes. Bundles of transversely cut and longitudinally cut smooth muscle cells (red overlay) are visible on the right, and renal tubular architecture is visible on the extreme right.

The presence of mature adipocytes, blood vessels, and smooth muscle cells within the renal parenchyma is characteristic of renal angiomyolipoma.

title: Meningioma
description:
Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain; 400x)

Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (yellow overlay) and sheets. The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).

Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

title: Oligodendroglioma
description:
Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

title: Schwannoma (neurilemoma)
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a peripheral nerve tumor (H&E stain)

Antoni A area (A): area of high cellularity with Verocay bodies. The Verocay bodies consist of rows of pallisading nuclei (green overlay) interspersed with anuclear eosinophilic areas (red overlay).
Antoni B area (B): paucicellular area with unstained myxoid stroma

This is the typical histological appearance of a schwannoma, a benign tumor of the nerve sheath.

title: Heteronymous bitemporal hemianopsia
description:
Simulation of right and left visual field

Loss of vision in the temporal half of both the right and left visual fields can be seen. This can occur when the optic chiasma is compressed, often due to tumors of the pituitary gland or craniopharyngioma.

title: Medulloblastoma
description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.

These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

title: Ependymoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).

These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.

title: Pathophysiology of an epidural hematoma
description: Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
description:
There is an erythematous, grouped, papulovesicular rash with excoriations on the extensor surface of the shoulder.

This finding, in combination with pruritus, is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis.

title: Howell-Jolly bodies
description:
Peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Numerous erythrocytes (light pink disc-like structures with central pallor) can be seen throughout the image. Howell-Jolly bodies are visible as small circular basophilic inclusions in the cytoplasm of the three erythrocytes (red overlay). A neutrophil with a polysegmented basophilic nucleus (in the center) and a lymphocyte with a large central round nucleus and a rim of basophilic cytoplasm (on the right side) are also visible.

Howell-Jolly bodies are usually removed by the spleen. They are typically seen in asplenic patients but can also appear in individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes or megaloblastic anemia.

title: Distribution of data
description:
The middle graph shows a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data (bell curve). In such a distribution, all measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) have the same value.

The left graph shows a positive skew (outliers shifting the mean towards higher values), whereas the right graph shows a negative skew (outliers shifting the mean towards lower values).
The median and the mode are more resistant to outliers than the mean. Note that the mode does not change since it represents the most commonly measured value within the data set.

title: Hypersegmented neutrophils
description:
Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.

title: Urticaria
description: Erythematous, confluent plaques typical of urticaria that cover most of the skin on the antecubital fossa and the ventral side of the forearm.

title: Sideroblasts
description:
Photomicrograph of blood cells from a bone marrow sample (Prussian blue stain)

Image shows numerous mature and immature erythrocytes. Some of the immature RBCs feature round, basophilic inclusions (iron deposits; arrowhead) within their mitochondria (which mostly surround the nuclei). These cells are called sideroblasts (red overlay).

Sideroblasts are found in various diseases such as sideroblastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, and sickle cell disease.

title: Ludwig angina
description:
Chin and neck of a male patient

Large swelling of the submandibular region is visible.

This appearance is typical of Ludwig angina.

title: Bilateral hallux valgus
description:
X-ray of the feet (AP view)

Both the right and left hallux are curved outward, increasing angle 1 and decreasing angle 2 (overlay).

title: Target cells (codocytes)
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Hypochromic erythrocytes with a dark central area, a pale ring surrounding the center, and a dark outer rim can be seen (dashed red circles on overlay). Due to this “bullseye” appearance on light microscopy, they are called target cells. On electron microscopy, they would appear bell-shaped (overlay illustration; visual axis in light microscopy depicted in red).

The finding of target cells is nonspecific and may indicate various hemoglobinopathies, such as thalassemia, liver disease, or asplenia.

title: Acanthocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Numerous red blood cells are visible, some of which have unevenly spaced, abnormal protrusions on the surface (examples indicated by yellow overlay).

This is the typical morphology of acanthocytes.

title: Osteochondroma of the femur
description:
X-ray of the femur of a child (AP view)

A sessile bony outgrowth (green overlay) can be seen on the lateral metaphysis of the femur. The cartilage cap is irregular and shows arch-like calcifications.

title: Brainstem and origin of cranial nerves II-XII
description: Ventral view

title: Podagra
description:
X-ray of a left foot (AP and lateral views)

Joint space narrowing of the first metatarsophalangeal joint with multiple spiky periosteal appositions (green overlay). Both the first metatarsal bone and the first proximal phalanx also show the characteristic “punched-out” lesions (green arrowheads). There is marked soft tissue swelling on the lateral border of the foot (red overlay).

title: Bell curve and standard deviations
description:
Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.

Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.

(SD = standard deviation)

title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
description:
CT thorax (with contrast; axial plane)

A double lumen is seen within the ascending aorta. It is the result of an intimal dissection flap (yellow overlay), which divides the contrast-enhanced aorta into true (red overlay) and false (green overlay) lumens.

The findings are consistent with a Stanford type A aortic dissection.

title: Spigelian hernia
description:
Photograph of the anterior abdominal wall of a female patient

An ill-defined swelling is visible just lateral to the left rectus abdominis muscle (i.e., along the semilunar line). Examination of the mass showed a positive cough impulse.

This is the typical appearance of a Spigelian hernia, an uncommon ventral hernia.

title: Hairy cell leukemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (high magnification)

In the center of the image, a lymphocyte with an abnormal appearance is visible. Due to the villous extensions of its basophilic cytoplasm, it is referred to as a hairy cell.

This is the typical appearance of hairy cell leukemia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Multiple myeloma (bone marrow smear)
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mantle cell lymphoma (peripheral blood smear)
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Histopathology of liver cirrhosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (trichrome stain; high magnification)

A regenerative nodule composed of a cluster of hepatocytes (purple overlay), extensive fibrosis (stained blue), and the portal triad (yellow overlay) can be seen.

Regenerative nodules and fibrous septa are characteristic features of liver cirrhosis.

title: Crohn disease
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the cecum (H&E stain; low magnification)

Large numbers of lymphocytes, giant cells, and epithelioid cells are seen clustered around a large granuloma.

This is a typical histological finding in Crohn disease.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Esophageal varices
description:
Endoscopic view of the distal esophagus

Dilated, submucosal veins are visible, most prominently at the 2, 4, 7, and 11 o'clock positions. Several cherry-red spots are visible on the varices, suggesting a recent or impending variceal bleed.

title: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
description:
Photomicrograph of bone marrow smear (H&E stain)

Multiple lymphoblasts, identifiable as large basophilic cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and a large round nucleus with clumpy chromatin and prominent nucleoli, can be seen. The presence of > 20% of lymphoblasts within a bone marrow smear is diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The cells surrounding the lymphoblasts are erythroid precursors, mature erythrocytes, and mature neutrophils.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Smudge cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (peripheral blood smear)
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Follicular lymphoma (peripheral blood smear)
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Ventral view of the mediastinum (I)
description: Pleura and pericardium partially resected; removal of the thyroid gland reveals the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

title: Urea cycle
description:
The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

title: External hordeolum
description:
Right eye (temporal view)

There is erythema and swelling of the upper eyelid. A yellow pus point is visible at the lid margin near the base of the eyelash follicle.

This is the typical appearance of an external hordeolum.

title: Blepharitis
description:
Slit-lamp photography

There is crusting at the base of the eyelashes and the lid margin appears injected.

This is the typical appearance of blepharitis.

title: Cutis marmorata in decompression sickness
description:
Photograph of a 35-year-old male patient with type 1 decompression sickness

Violaceous reticulate macules in a marbled pattern are visible on this patient's abdomen (red ink used for tracking changes in size).

title: Coronary veins
description:
The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

title: Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

This specimen depicts anisocytosis, which are erythrocytes of different sizes (black circles), as well as poikilocytosis, which are erythrocytes of different shapes. Acanthocytes with thorny projections (light blue circles) and teardrop shaped dacrocytes (red circles) are present.

These findings suggest impaired erythropoiesis, which may be a result of impaired bone marrow hematopoiesis.

title: Hypertrophic scar
description:
A linear, erythematous raised scar is visible in the center of the image.

These features are characteristic of a hypertrophic scar, which results from abnormal wound repair (i.e., overgrowth of fibroblastic tissues during skin healing).

title: Synovial fluid crystals in pseudogout
description:
Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

title: Herpes simplex keratitis
description:
Slit-lamp photography with fluorescein stain and cobalt blue light filter

Dendritic lesions of the cornea appear green under cobalt blue illumination after fluorescein stain.

These lesions are characteristic of keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).

title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Histopathological changes in chronic hepatitis B
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland
description:
Photomicrograph of parotid gland tissue (H&E stain)

On the left, there is a hypercellular area made up of round epithelial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and narrow, spindle-shaped myoepithelial cells with flattened nuclei. On the right, there is a paucicellular area predominantly made up of hyalinized stroma (pink acellular material).

This mixed pattern of epithelial (epithelial and myoepithelial cells) and mesenchymal (stroma) components within a salivary gland tumor is pathognomonic for pleomorphic adenoma.

title: Whipple disease
description:
Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (H&E stain)

There are goblet cells (colorless cells; examples indicated by green overlays) within the columnar epithelial cells and immune cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads) within the lamina propria. There are numerous macrophages (single and in loose aggregates) within the lamina propria, causing blunting of the villi.

These findings are characteristic of Whipple disease.

title: Liver cirrhosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Nodules of regenerating hepatocytes surrounded by regions of collagenous fibers can be seen. The proliferation of bile ducts is also visible within the connective tissue.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Folliculitis
description: Multiple pustules with surrounding erythema can be seen emerging from the hair follicles.

title: Oligodendroglioma
description:
Cranial CT scan (axial view)

A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

title: Barrett esophagus
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Adenylate cyclase signal transduction
description: Once activated by a Gs protein (after GPCR activation), the second messenger cAMP is synthesized from ATP by adenylate cyclase. cAMP binds to protein kinase A (PKA), which is then activated. The signaling effect is terminated by phosphodiesterase, which transforms cAMP into AMP. Adenylate cyclases are inhibited by Gi proteins.

title: Protein elongation
description:
Protein synthesis occurs during elongation: One by one, amino acids are added to form a polypeptide chain. The ribosome (assembled during initiation) reads the mRNA in 5'→3' direction. Each base triplet of the mRNA is translated into an amino acid, which is then added to the C-terminus of the previous amino acid, resulting in a growing chain. The chain's N-terminus (featuring the free amine group) leaves the ribosome first.

1. At the start of elongation, a peptidyl-tRNA (yellow) is located at the P-site of the ribosome. An aminoacyl-tRNA (green) that matches the mRNA at the A-site of the ribosome forms a ternary complex with eukaryotic elongation factor 1 (eEF1) and GTP. If the tRNA anticodon is complementary to the mRNA codon, GTP is hydrolyzed and eEF1 and GDP are released. This process provides the energy for aminoacyl-tRNA to bind to the A-site.

2. The aminoacyl-tRNA (carrying the amino acid that will be added) is now located at the A-site of the ribosome, the peptidyl-tRNA at the P-site. Next, the peptidyl transferase catalyzes the formation of a peptide bond between the amino acids at the A- and P-sites. In the process, the growing polypeptide chain is transferred to the aminoacyl-tRNA at the A-site.

3. During the next step (translocation), the ribosome moves along the mRNA in the 5'→3' direction (for the length of exactly one triplet). Once again, the energy required is derived from GTP hydrolysis (catalyzed by eEF2). The tRNA that was in the A-site is now in the P-site, and the tRNA that was in the P-site is now in the E-site, where it is released.

4. The A-site is now free again and the cycle can be repeated.

title: Pathophysiology of retinoblastoma
description:
In most cases, retinoblastoma is caused by a loss of function mutation in both alleles of RB1 (tumor suppressor gene).

Hereditary retinoblastoma (top): Due to a germline mutation (more often de novo than inherited), one altered allele is present in all cells. Retinoblastoma develops if a mutation occurs in the second allele (“second hit”).

Sporadic retinoblastoma (bottom): Initially, both alleles are normal. A mutation must occur in both alleles in the same cell for retinoblastoma to develop.

title: Newborn with type C esophageal atresia
description: X-ray (AP view with contrast): contrast agent filling a blind-ended esophageal pouch (green overlay) that ends at the level of the third thoracic vertebra. Inside the pouch, a nasogastric tube can be seen (dashed lines). There is abundant gas in the gastrointestinal tract, indicating patent tracheoesophageal fistula.

title: Osteolytic metastasis
description:
X-ray femur (AP view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A lytic cortical lesion (red overlay) involves the middle third of the femur.

Metastases can be lytic, sclerotic, or mixed-density lesions. Osteolytic lesions are the most common and are usually metastases from carcinomas of the kidney, lung, breast, gastrointestinal tract, or thyroid gland.

title: Left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia
description:
Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.

Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

title: Osler nodes
description:
There are multiple raised nodular lesions on the palm and palmar aspects of the first and second digits. The lesions appear dark brown, indicating subcutaneous hemorrhages.

This is the typical appearance of Osler nodes.

title: Janeway lesions
description:
Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.

These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

title: Purpura in IgA vasculitis
description:
Photograph of the leg of an 18-year-old male patient

Multiple well-defined erythematous skin lesions (purpura) are visible. Some purpura have coalesced to form ecchymoses. Examination revealed the purpura to be palpable and nonblanchable.

The tetrad of purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and kidney impairment is typical of IgA vasculitis. Histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis of IgA vasculitis.

title: Purpura in IgA vasculitis
description: Maculopapular, reddish, non-blanching, palpable skin lesions (purpura) are seen on both the distal right arm and leg. On the lower leg, the lesions are partially confluent and present with scaling and erosion.

title: Owl-eye appearance in cytomegalovirus infection
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 500× magnification)

Multiple cells show basophilic, intranuclear inclusion bodies (green overlay), which are surrounded by a bright halo (white border). The cytoplasm is enlarged and contains additional inclusion bodies (arrowheads).

The owl's eye appearance indicates cytomegalovirus infection.

title: Thyroglossal duct cyst
description: There is a mass located in the patient's midline anterior cervical area near the thyroid cartilage.

title: Amanita phalloides (death cap mushroom)
description: Amanita phalloides, also called the death cap mushroom, has a yellowish-green to dark olive cap that is 4–12 cm in diameter and a 6–12 cm long stem with a bulbous base. The death cap mushroom can be found in deciduous and mixed forests from July until October. The mushroom is among the most toxic and can lead to life-threatening liver and renal failure.

title: Gallbladder with stones
description: The two larger gallstones in the neck of the gallbladder have an irregular consistency and yellowish-white to dark pigmentation, which indicates a high level of cholesterol. The stones located in the body and fundus are significantly smaller, darkly pigmented, and of different shapes, which is more suggestive of pigment stones due to bilirubin precipitation.

title: Cell junctions
description:
Cell junctions are points of cell-cell or cell-extracellular matrix contact most abundantly found between epithelial cells. There are three major classes of cell junctions:

1. Tight junctions are occluding junctions that close the gaps between epithelial cells and act as a diffusion barrier. They are typically found at the apical aspect of cells.

2. Anchoring junctions are mechanical connections between cells. Based on the anchoring structures and the type of connection, they are divided into:
- Zonula adherens: form cell-cell junctions via actin filaments
- Desmosomes: form cell-cell junctions via intermediate filaments
- Hemidesmosomes: anchor cells to the basement membrane (i.e., cell-extracellular matrix junction) via intermediate filaments and integrins

3. Gap junctions or communicating junctions are intercellular channels that allow the passage of ions and molecules between cells.

title: Rocky Mountain spotted fever rash
description:
Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).

title: The esophagus
description:
Esophagus and surrounding structures (anterior view)

The esophagus begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It first descends posterior to the trachea, and then posterior to the heart. At the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra, the aorta runs adjacent to the esophagus, pushing it slightly to the right. The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra and ends at the stomach after a brief stretch within the peritoneum.

The upper part of the trachea, lungs, and heart are not shown for clarity.

title: Signal transduction of nuclear receptors
description:
Schematic illustration of signal transduction via a nuclear receptor

The ligand of the receptors, usually a lipophile molecule, enters the cell and binds to its receptor in the cytosol. The hormone-receptor complex is then transported into the nucleus, where it dimerizes. Only a few receptors of the subclass four bind as monomers to the DNA. Next, the dimer binds on a hormone-sensitive area of the strand of DNA within a promoter sequence (hormone responsive element, HRE). This bond starts the transcription of the downstream gene and leads to the synthesis of RNA, which is then translated into the corresponding protein in the cytosol.

title: Detailed overview of cell junctions
description: The different cell junction types differ in their molecular structure; however, they all contain certain types of transmembrane proteins. The transmembrane proteins of the zonula adhaerens, desmosomes, and hemidesmosomes are connected to a component of the cytoskeleton, but also to structures external to the cell. The tight junction proteins claudin and occludin are linked to actin filaments of the cytoskeleton by additional proteins (not shown). Their extracellular domains interact with one another and close the gaps between epithelial cells. Gap junctions are similar to ion channels in that they are permeable to small molecules and alternate between open and closed states. In addition to their communication function, gap junctions support the adhesion of neighboring cells.

title: Selection of common pathological changes in serum protein electrophoresis
description: Deviations of the individual protein fractions from the normal finding (for comparison, upper left) are shown in red.
