title: Urushiol-induced contact dermatitis
description:
An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

title: Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites
description:
Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

title: Aschoff body and Anitschkow cells
description:
Photomicrograph of a myocardial tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A collagenous nodule (green overlay) is seen within the myocardial tissue. The nodule contains a loose lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and large eosinophilic cells with an ovoid nucleus (Anitschkow cells, arrowheads). Anitschkow cells are thought to be histiocytes.

These nodules, referred to as “Aschoff bodies,” are thought to represent myocardial granulomas, which are typically found in rheumatic heart disease.

title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertension

Hyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).

The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.

1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

title: Rectus sheath and linea alba
description:
Transverse section of the abdominal wall above (a) and below (b) the arcuate line

The fibrous rectus sheath is formed of the aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles. It encloses the rectus abdominal muscle. The exact composition of the anterior and posterior part of the rectus sheath depends on the relation to the arcuate line (above or below, a or b). The aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles fuse in the middle of the abdominal wall to form a fibrous line termed linea alba.

title: Silicosis
description:
Chest X-ray (lateral view) of an elderly male patient with progressive dyspnea and a history of working with sandblasting equipment for a number of years

Extensive heterogeneous, patchy, partially confluent opacities are visible, particularly in the upper lung fields (green overlay).

Those findings are consistent with silicosis (which, given the patient's history, is the most likely diagnosis).

title: Initiation complex
description: Translation starts with the initiation phase, during which the eukaryotic ribosomes (80S) are formed. Eukaryotic ribosome is a complex of the 60S and 40S ribosomal subunits. At the P site of the eukaryotic ribosome, the methionine-carrying initiator tRNA binds to the start codon of the mRNA transcript. This initiation complex is capable of linking the required peptide bonds during the subsequent elongation phase in translation, which allows for the synthesis of a peptide or protein.

title: Receptor tyrosine kinase signal transduction
description:
Tyrosine kinase receptors are enzyme-linked transmembrane receptors that are part of the second messenger system. They have a specific extracellular ligand-binding site and intracellular domains with kinase activity and tyrosine residues. Binding of a ligand (first messenger) to an inactive receptor (1) triggers dimerization of two receptors (2). The two tyrosine kinases, which are now adjacent, autophosphorylate one another's tyrosine residues (3). These now phosphorylated intracellular domains serve as binding sites for effector molecules (second messengers), the activation of which triggers a further signaling cascade (4). To terminate the signal, the activated phosphorylated receptors are endocytosed (5) and are either recycled or degraded into their constituent parts (6).

It is important to note that type 2 receptor tyrosine kinases (e.g., insulin receptors) can be inactive in the dimerized form.

title: JAK/STAT pathway
description:
The JAK/STAT pathway is comprised of three basic elements: a transmembrane receptor, a Janus kinase (JAK), and a signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT).

(1) Two receptor monomers are activated extracellularly via a specific ligand-binding site and dimerize.
(2) The JAKs of the receptor dimer phosphorylate each other intracellularly (autophosphorylation) and become activated.
(3) The activated JAKs phosphorylate tyrosine residues of their own receptor monomers. Those tyrosine residues become binding sites for the SH2 domains of STAT proteins.
(4) The bound STAT proteins are activated via phosphorylation.
(5) The STAT proteins dimerize and move through the cytosol into the nucleus.
(6) In the nucleus, the dimerized STAT proteins function as transcription factors for the genes regulated by JAK/STAT signaling.

title: Wobble position
description: During translation, the codon on mRNA is recognized by the anticodon on tRNA in the ribosome, resulting in incorporation of the correctly encoded amino acid in the growing polypeptide. For interaction between the codon and the anticodon, the first nucleotide of the anticodon (nucleotide at the 5' end) determines whether it can pair with one, two, or even three different nucleotides at the 3' end of the codon. The third position at the 5' end of the anticodon is termed wobble position, because of the certain degree of flexibility (“wobble”) in base pairing. The nucleotide inosine (I) is usually found at the wobble position.

title: Phospholipase C
description: Phospholipase C is a membrane protein that can be activated by the Gq protein or tyrosine kinases. In the activated state, phospholipase C hydrolyzes fatty acids from phospholipid PIP2, a minor component of the cell membrane. This cleavage forms two second-messenger components: IP3 (inositol triphosphate) from the head group of the phospholipid, which occurs as a solute in the cytosol, and DAG (diacylglycerol), which remains anchored to the cell membrane. Since the activation of phospholipase C by a Gq can result in numerous IP3 and DAG molecules, this step is referred to as signal gain. DAG activates protein kinase C, while IP3 binds to IP3 receptors on the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), which stimulates an influx of calcium ions into the cytosol.

title: Amelanotic melanoma
description:
A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

title: Frank-Starling mechanism
description:
For comparison, a normal pressure-volume diagram is shown on both sides (red).

Left diagram (increased preload): Because of an increase of the end-diastolic volume, the previous starting point is pushed to the right (1 → 1a). Larger volumes of blood in the ventricles stretch the cardiac muscle fibers, leading to an increase in the force of contraction. This results in a greater stroke volume (yellow bar), which roughly leads to normalization of the end-systolic volume again (4a ≈ 4).

Right diagram (increased afterload): When the heart has to eject its stroke volume against a greater aortic pressure from the same starting point (1 = 1a) on the end-diastolic pressure-volume relationship (EDPVR) curve (i.e., same stretching of cardiac muscle fibers), the stroke volume can't be ejected entirely (stroke volume drops: yellow bar < red bar). Subsequently, at the end of the first cycle (yellow), an increased end-systolic volume remains within the heart (4 → 4a), which leads to an increased end-diastolic volume (1b). The heart reacts to this increased preload by ejecting a greater stroke volume, just as in the left diagram.

title: Rotator cuff tear
description:
The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.

The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

title: Corkscrew esophagus
description:
Barium swallow

Helical contractions of the lower esophagus (green overlay), resulting in a corkscrew-like appearance.

Seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

title: Subacromial impingement syndrome
description:
The upper images shows the sectional plane and anatomy of the frontal cross-section of the shoulder. The lower images show the stages of impingement.

Stage 1, which is very painful, is characterized by irritation of the rotator cuff and bursa. Stage 2 involves fibrosis of the structures, leading to restricted function. Stage 3 involves the painful rupture of the rotator cuff, intermittent bursitis, and pseudoparalysis of the arm.

title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
description: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

title: Frozen shoulder
description:
Frontal cross-section of the shoulder and the three stages of frozen shoulder

Stage 1 (freezing stage): minimal synovitis with pain and limitation of motion
Stage 2 (frozen stage): proliferative synovitis with contraction of the capsule and adhesion of the axillary recess
Stage 3 (thawing stage): contracted capsule following the end of inflammation

title: Esophageal B-ring (Schatzki ring)
description: Barium swallow (lateral view): circular narrowing of the esophagus directly at the esophagogastric junction (Schatzki ring or B-ring). As opposed to A-rings (which are located just proximal to the EG junction), B-rings often can only be seen if there is a concomitant hiatal hernia. with which they are frequently associated (as is the case here).

title: Scleral manifestations of osteogenesis imperfecta
description: The sclerae show a distinct blue-grey tint.

title: Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome)
description:
Abdominal CT of a female patient (coronal view)

Intestinal loops are massively distended. Unlike in mechanical obstruction, there is no evidence of any anatomical structure or object blocking the intestinal passage. There is also no perforation.

title: Paradoxical (reversed) split of S2
description:
P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

title: Fixed split of S2
description:
A fixed split does not change with respiration and tends to be wide (i.e., the split is also audible during expiration). It may occur in atrial septal defect or severe right ventricular failure.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

title: Splitting of S2
description:
If the aortic and pulmonary valves do not close simultaneously, splitting of S2 can be heard on auscultation.

Types of split:
(A) Physiological split
(B) Wide split
(C) Fixed split
(D) Paradoxical (reversed) split

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

title: Hyaline membranes in ARDS
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The alveolar walls are lined by eosinophilic hyaline membranes (example indicated by green overlay). The normal basophilic alveolar epithelial lining is absent. Within the interstitium, there is an extensive inflammatory infiltrate, which is visible as numerous basophilic nuclei (large basophilic nuclei: macrophages; multilobed nuclei: neutrophils). There are numerous microthrombi, visible as extracapillary aggregates of RBCs. The capillaries appear congested.

Loss of alveolar epithelium, presence of alveolar hyaline membranes, and interstitial inflammation, edema, and congestion are the typical features of the acute exudative phase of ARDS.

title: Thyroglossal duct cyst
description:
Neck ultrasound (transverse section)

A circular, sharply demarcated, hypoechoic lesion (green overlay) is visible dorsal to the thyroid gland.

title: Ileal orifice and ileocaecal valve
description: The ileum invaginates into the cecum at the junction of the small and large intestine, forming the ileocecal valve. The valve consists of an ileocolic and an ileocecal lip. This enables flow from the ileum to the cecum (a) and prevents backflow of cecal contents, esp. bacteria (b). A defective valve may result in bacterial overgrowth of the small intestine.

title: Anal abscess
description:
There is a prominent area of erythema and swelling on the left buttock and perianal region.

This is the typical appearance of an anal abscess.

title: Ovarian endometriosis
description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Classification of internal hemorrhoids
description:
Internal hemorrhoids are located above the dentate line and are classified into the following grades based on the degree of prolapse:

Grade I: Hemorrhoids do not prolapse out of the anal verge.
Grade II: Hemorrhoids prolapse with straining, but reduce spontaneously.
Grade III: Hemorrhoids prolapse with straining and are only reducible manually.
Grade IV: Prolapse is irreducible.

title: Oral candidiasis
description:
There are extensive whitish patches that can be scraped off covering the tongue.

This is the typical appearance of pseudomembranous candidiasis, and diagnosis should be confirmed by microscopy and culture of mucosal swabs.

title: Microtubule polymerization
description:
In microtubule polymerization, GTP-tubulin dimers (each made up of an α-tubulin and a β-tubulin) accumulate at the plus end. The GTP of β-tubulin spontaneously hydrolyzes shortly afterwards, leading to loss of microtubule stability. Microtubules do not depolymerize if GTP-tubulin dimers are present at the plus end.

The minus end is usually located in the centrosome of the cell, the microtubule organizing center, where it is stabilized by γ-tubulin and capping proteins. In principle, tubulin dimers could also accumulate at the minus end; however, attachment would be very slow (e.g., when a microtubule breaks).

title: True diverticula and pseudodiverticula
description: True diverticula affect all layers of the intestinal wall, including the muscular layer, while pseudodiverticula are only covered by a layer of mucosa and submucosa. Pseudodiverticula protrude at weak points of the muscular layer and are likely due to previously perforated intestinal vessels.

title: Dermatofibroma
description:
A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).

This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

title: Epidermoid cyst
description: A small, solitary, flesh-colored, round, nodular lesion with a small central pore.

title: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
description:
There is diffuse edema and erythema of the right leg and foot. The diameter of the right calf is visibly greater than that of the left.

These features are typical of DVT. Clinical history and investigations (e.g., Doppler ultrasonography, D-dimer levels) help distinguish between DVT and cellulitis, which also manifests with a painful, warm, erythematous, and edematous leg.

title: Inflammatory breast cancer
description:
The right breast is swollen and shows diffuse erythema that extends over most of its surface. Conspicuous hair follicles produce the typical orange peel appearance (peau d'orange). The nipple is also markedly retracted.

Edematous swelling, orange peel appearance, and nipple retraction are all caused by blockage of lymphatic channels. The swelling and erythema distinguish inflammatory breast cancer from locally advanced breast cancer.

title: Blue toe syndrome
description: Dorsal view of the right foot showing blue/purple cyanotic discoloration of the toes

title: Granuloma inguinale (Donovaniosis)
description:
Exudate smear (Giemsa stain)

Coccobacilli are visible as inclusion bodies within macrophages (Donovan bodies). In some cases, the characteristic safety pin shape can be seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).

title: Pathomechanisms and therapeutic approach in malignant hyperthermia
description:
Approx. half of cases of malignant hyperthermia are associated with a mutation in the ryanodine receptor type 1 (RyR-1). RyR-1 is located in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of skeletal and cardiac muscle. Physiologically, activated RyR-1 in the skeletal muscle interacts with the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), which results in calcium release from the SR into the sarcoplasm.

(1) If a mutation in the RyR-1 is present, certain triggering substances may lead to a pathological stimulation of the receptor, which (2) results in uncontrolled opening and excessive release of calcium from the SR. The contractility of the skeletal muscle increases, which in return increases the metabolism. As the increased oxygen need can no longer be met, the cell's energy supply breaks down and the cell dies.

(3) The first-line treatment for malignant hyperthermia is dantrolene, which interacts with RyR1 and prevents the release of calcium from the SR of the skeletal muscle.

The mechanism shown here is simplified; research on the pathomechanism of the condition and the exact effect of dantrolene is ongoing.

title: Medulloblastoma
description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)

There is a mass in the posterior cranial fossa. It features solid parts (green overlay) and cystic parts (red overlay).

Location and appearance are typical of a medulloblastoma.

(D: diencephalon; P: pons; C: cerebellum; yellow outline: cerebellar tentorium)

title: Multiple myeloma - serum protein electrophoresis with M protein
description: Pathological protein electrophoresis in multiple myeloma: the monoclonal antibodies cause a peak in the gamma-globulin zone of the electrophoresis, which is termed M protein (also M component, myeloma protein, spike protein, and paraprotein).

title: Granuloma inguinale
description:
Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

title: Epithelioid mesothelioma
description:
Photomicrograph of visceral pleura (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Numerous epithelioid cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli can be seen at the visceral pleural surface in the upper part of the image. They represent a dysplastic in situ lesion (green overlay). Cells with the same morphology can also be seen below the basement membrane (marked by black line), representing an invasive component (white overlay).

The diagnosis of an epithelioid mesothelioma with a corresponding mesothelioma in situ lesion was confirmed by immunohistochemistry (calretinin and WT1 positive, BerEP4 negative).

title: Raynaud phenomenon (ischemic phase)
description: There is white discoloration of second to fifth fingers of both hands, extending from the fingertips to the distal or proximal interphalangeal joints.

title: Trendelenburg and Duchenne signs
description:
The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

title: Kayser-Fleischer ring
description:
Slit-lamp photography of a left eye

A brown ring is visible in the periphery of the cornea (Kayser-Fleischer ring; green overlay).

Kayser-Fleischer rings are typically seen in Wilson disease.

title: Atheroma
description:
Photomicrograph of a section of an arterial wall depicting an atheroma (H&E, highly magnified)

The inner layer of an atheroma is the single layer of endothelial cells of the tunica intima (the superior-most layer in this image).
The second layer is a fibrous cap, which is composed of lipid-laden macrophages or foam cells (the white arrowheads point to a few examples), a few smooth muscle cells, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
The core of the atheroma (green overlay) is composed of anuclear necrotic cells and cholesterol clefts (empty unstained spaced indicated with white arrows).

A collection of foam cells and cholesterol clefts with a fibrous cap and a necrotic core are the characteristic histological features of an atheroma.

title: Oral candidiasis
description:
Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

title: Exudative tonsillopharyngitis
description:
Pharynx and tonsils in a patient with infectious mononucleosis

The tonsils are massively hypertrophied, touching at the midline (known as “kissing tonsils”), and covered with gray-white exudate. The visible parts of the pharynx are erythematous.

title: Shingles of the upper extremity
description: Left arm of a child showing multiple, uniform vesicles on an erythematous base. The dermatomal distribution (C8 and T1) is characteristic of shingles. Patients complain of severe pain prior to the appearance of lesions.

title: Tonsillar and pharyngeal diphtheria
description: A gray-white pseudomembrane extends from the left palatine tonsil over the uvula to the hard palate. The pseudomembrane consists of fibrinous exudate as well as immune and epithelial cells and is characteristic of tonsillar and pharyngeal diphtheria.

title: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
description:
Hands and feet of a 36-year-old male patient

Macular and papular lesions are visible on the inner surface of the hands and feet.

The localization in conjunction with the enanthem of the mucous membranes is typical of hand, foot, and mouth disease.

title: Erythema infectiosum
description:
The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

title: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
description:
Soles of the feet of a child

Macular, vesicular lesions on an erythematous base are visible on the toes and the soles of the feet.

This rash is typical in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

title: Peritonsillar abscess
description:
Redness and swelling can be seen on the right side of the anterior palatal arch and of the soft palate. There is a slight left-sided deviation of the soft palate. The uvula shows a distinct redness and is slightly swollen.

These findings are suggestive of a peritonsillar abscess on the right side.

title: Chickenpox (varicella)
description: Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.

title: Diffuse maculopapular exanthema in toxic shock syndrome
description:
Multiple partly confluent macules and papules, measuring 1–5 mm in diameter, are visible on the skin of this patient's left arm.

This finding is consistent with a maculopapular exanthema (a diagnostic criterium of toxic shock syndrome) caused by staphylococcus aureus.

title: Cutaneous larva migrans
description:
Ankle of a patient with cutaneous larva migrans

Serpiginous marks (larval tracks) are visible here. However, in the case of a strong local inflammatory response, these marks may not be visible.

Serpiginous marks together with pruritus establish the diagnosis of cutaneous larva migrans.

title: Bullous impetigo
description: Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

title: Desquamation in toxic shock syndrome
description:
Desquamation of the skin over this patient's right thumb and palm is visible.

Desquamation of palms and soles is a late finding in staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS) that may occur 2–3 weeks after disease onset.

title: Head lice infestation
description: A single head louse is visible on this child's scalp.

title: Scarlet fever rash
description: Upper body of a child showing an elevated, maculopapular, fine exanthem, which is spread evenly over the patient's torso. Combined with characteristic findings such as tonsillopharyngitis, flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and a strawberry tongue, this finding indicates scarlet fever. The disease is caused by exotoxins produced by group A β‑hemolytic streptococci.

title: Chickenpox
description:
A vesicle filled with clear fluid on an erythematous base is seen on the skin of this patients.

This appearance is referred to as a "dewdrop on a rose petal" and, in combination with other skin lesions, indicates infection with varicella-zoster virus (chickenpox).

title: Vaginal discharge in gonococcal infection
description: Purulent discharge can be seen on this patient's vulva on external genital examination.

title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture
description:
A culture of M. tuberculosis in a petri dish on agar

After 3-4 weeks of incubation, characteristic rough, cauliflower-like, whitish-yellow colonies appear.

The complex waxy, lipid-rich cell wall of M. tuberculosis is hard to overcome for nutrients, which is why the reduplication time amounts to 12-18 hours and incubation lasts at least 3-4 weeks.

title: Acute ulcerative colitis
description:
Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

title: Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm)
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon

A worm is visible in the colon (green overlay). The surrounding mucosa's surface and vascular pattern appear normal.

title: Pseudomembranous colitis
description:
Endoscopic view of the colon

The colonic mucosa is erythematous and edematous. Fibrin exudate has formed partially confluent, yellow plaques over the mucosa (referred to as “pseudomembranes”).

These findings are diagnostic of pseudomembranous colitis.

title: Candida esophagitis
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple confluent, white-gray plaques in a longitudinal pattern are visible.

These findings are characteristic of Candida esophagitis.

title: Esophageal stent
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A newly placed self-expanding metal (nitinol) stent is visible. The stent holds the esophagus open as part of the palliative treatment for esophageal cancer.

title: Esophageal varices
description:
Endoscopic view of the distal esophagus

The esophageal lumen is narrowed by dilated submucosal veins (green overlay). Despite endoscopic insufflation, the varices still surpass the mucosal level by more than 5 mm but show no sign of recent or impending bleeding.

title: Duodenal ulcer: Forrest stage III
description:
Endoscopic view of the duodenal bulb

A duodenal ulcer with a smooth, fibrin-covered base (hatched overlay) and elevated edges (green overlay) can be seen. There are no signs of active or recent hemorrhage. Villi are normal on the surrounding duodenal mucosa.

title: Esophageal carcinoma
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagus

An exophytic, irregularly demarcated mass with raised edges (green line) and central ulceration (dashed line) is partially obstructing the esophageal lumen.

title: Pelvic ring fracture: Tile classification
description:
(A) stable or minimally displaced fracture (fracture of the pelvic edge, the anterior pelvic ring, or the sacrum/coccyx)
(B) rotationally unstable, vertically stable fracture (symphysis diastasis, diastasis of the sacroiliac joint)
(C) injury of the pelvic ring with rotational and vertical instability (anterior and posterior pelvic ring fracture with bilateral diastasis of the sacroiliac joint and symphysis diastasis)

The injuries are categorized according to severity (green = A, yellow = B, red = C). Green arrows indicate preserved vertical/rotational stability; red arrows indicate instability.

title: Cutaneous anthrax
description:
Forearm

An ulcer-like lesion with central, black necrosis and sporadic vesicles towards the left margin of the lesion can be seen.

title: Phalen maneuver and reverse Phalen maneuver
description: The Phalen sign is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The patient may carry out the test on their own by actively holding the wrist in full flexion (1) for the Phalen maneuver, or in maximal extension (2) for the reverse Phalen maneuver. If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

title: Tibial tuberosity in Osgood-Schlatter disease
description:
Left knee of a 31-year-old patient

The tibial tuberosity has remained prominent in adulthood (red overlay) secondary to Osgood-Schlatter disease in adolescence.

title: Bacillus anthracis (Gram stain)
description: The gram-positive (dark purple) bacteria Bacilli anthracis often form long chains. Each chain link is a single bacterium.

title: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
description:
Photomicrograph of alveolar tissue infected with P. jirovecii (Grocott's methenamine silver stain, high magnification)

The cysts of this fungus are located within the alveoli together with an inflammatory exudate (red overlay). The cyst walls are stained black in this silver stain.

title: Phalen maneuver supported by the examiner
description: The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

title: Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum)
description:
Photograph of a 9-month-old infant with recent high fever

A patchy, macular exanthem is visible on the trunk, neck, and behind the ears. Symptoms developed after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

title: Cysts of Pneumocystis jirovecii
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue infected with P. jirovecii (methenamine silver staining)

Six to eight spores grow within each cyst (darkly stained) and are released into the lung tissue when the cysts burst. The spores adhere to the alveoli and replicate.

title: Lightbulb sign (posterior dislocation of the humerus)
description:
X-ray shoulder (AP view; left: dislocation; right: post reduction)

Internal rotation of the humerus during posterior dislocation produces a contour resembling a lightbulb on the AP radiograph (overlay). In addition, poor congruency of the humeral head with the glenoid is seen in this patient. After reduction, the greater tubercle (tuberosity) is visible laterally and the humeral head is well-aligned with the glenoid fossa.

title: Pulmonary hyperinflation (1/2)
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

title: Tension pneumothorax with mediastinal and subcutaneous emphysema
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with left chest trauma

Acute fractures of the posterior left 3rd through 7th ribs are accompanied by tension pneumothorax, with depression of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by white arrow) and a rightward shift of the mediastinum (indicated by red arrow). The left lung is partially collapsed (green overlay). Pneumomediastinum, or mediastinal emphysema, is visible as vertically oriented linear lucencies in the mediastinum (examples indicated by yellow overlay). Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and left chest wall is the result of the dissection of mediastinal air into the soft tissues (examples indicated by blue overlay). Air outlining fibers of the pectoralis muscle produces the ginkgo-leaf sign (indicated by red overlay).

Healed fractures of the right 6th, 7th, and 9th ribs are also visible, and an ECG electrode projects over the anterior aspect of the right 2nd rib.

title: Pulmonary hyperinflation (2/2)
description:
Chest x-ray (lateral view)

Large lung volumes (outer green line and arrows) are accompanied by diaphragmatic flattening, hyperlucent lungs, and a prominent retrosternal space, indicating hyperinflation.

title: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pneumocystis pneumonia

Parenchymal opacification is seen in a predominantly perihilar distribution (green overlay)

Pneumocystis pneumonia frequently demonstrates as bilateral perihilar opacification with a fine reticular appearance that progresses to air-space consolidation. On CT, it may appear with a ground-glass appearance. Cystic lesions may also be seen. Atypical findings on imaging include nodules, lymphadenopathy, and effusions.

H: heart; SB: stomach bubble

title: Aspergillus endocarditis
description:
Photomicrograph of mitral valve vegetation (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A mycelium composed of PAS positive septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at a 30–45° angle is visible.

This is the classic finding of infection with Aspergillus spp., indicating Aspergillus endocarditis.

title: Lung mass
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window)

A spiculated mass (green overlay) is present in the right upper lobe. A small nodule is also visible medial to the mass.

title: Renal cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
description:
Left kidney

Multiple fluid-filled cysts of various sizes are visible.

title: Focal nodular hyperplasia
description: Histopathological liver section (Elastica van Gieson stain): circumscribed, central local scar, which appears as a central region of connective tissue (S). The surrounding liver parenchyma shows nodular changes (L) and resembles cirrhotic tissue.

title: Drug eruption (1/2)
description:
Ventral upper body of a patient presenting with a pruritic rash following the administration of amoxicillin

A diffuse rash composed of several fine erythematous papules is visible. This rash, known as a morbilliform rash because it resembles the rash seen in measles, is typical of a drug reaction.

title: Rheumatoid arthritis
description:
Female patient with rheumatoid arthitis

Swelling is seen especially of the proximal interphalangeal joints.

title: Illustration of right hip radiograph in osteoarthritis
description:
AP view

Findings of osteoarthritis include irregular joint space narrowing (1), osteophytes (2), subchondral sclerosis (3), and subchondral cyst formation (4).

title: T-sign in monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

Adjacent twins are separated by a thin membrane, which terminates at the placenta in a T configuration (T sign). This T sign is an indicator of a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy.

A monochorionic diamniotic gestation may alternatively create a black triangular space (known as black lambda sign) at the uterine wall. This should not be confused with the triangular projection of chorion, which creates the lambda sign of a dichorionic pregnancy.

title: Sliding hiatal hernia
description:
Endoscopic view of the esophagogastric junction

The Z-line (green line) marks the transition from the squamous epithelium of the esophagus (E) to the columnar epithelium of the stomach (S). The Z-line's physiological position (dotted line) is at the same level as the esophageal hiatus, recognizable by a slight narrowing of the lumen (N).

A Z-line located significantly proximal to this narrowing (as seen here) is diagnostic of a sliding hiatal hernia.

title: Sister Mary Joseph nodule
description:
A 2-cm, well-demarcated, protuberant, round, purple nodule is visible in the umbilicus. The lesion shows central ulceration and an accumulation of fluid can be seen in the umbilical crease.

This finding suggests a metastatic lesion of an intraabdominal or pelvic malignancy, referred to as a Sister Mary Joseph nodule. Blood tests, imaging, and histopathological analyses of biopsy materials are required to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Small pulmonary nodules
description:
CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with lung metastases from colon carcinoma

Multiple small, circumscribed nodules of varying sizes (examples indicated by green overlays) can be seen in both lungs. A few nodules (examples indicated by red overlays) contain small foci of air, which may represent small bronchioles or sites of early cavitation.

title: Hereditary hyperbilirubinemia
description: Defects in the bilirubin conjugation and excretion pathways within hepatocytes result in hyperbilirubinemia. Red indicators link hereditary hyperbilirubinemias with corresponding dysfunctional enzymes and transporters.

title: Pleural effusion with mediastinal shift
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a malignant pleural effusion in a patient with lung cancer

Complete opacification of the left hemithorax (green overlay) is accompanied by mediastinal shift to the contralateral right side (indicated by blue and red lines and arrows). This shift confirms that a space-occupying process, rather than volume loss, is the primary cause of the opacification.

The absence of air in the distal left main bronchus reflects bronchial obstruction and correlates with the patient's clinical history of bronchogenic carcinoma.

T: trachea; Green outline: trachea and main bronchi

title: Mechanism of action: gout drugs
description:
Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

title: Asbestos-related pleural disease
description:
Chest X-ray (PA view)

Bilateral pleural plaques (indicated by arrowheads), some of which are densely calcified, appear as curvilinear and irregular opacities.

The lung opacities (green overlay) raised concern for lung cancer, but biopsy established a diagnosis of cryptococcus infection.

title: Clinical courses of multiple sclerosis (MS)
description:
Relapsing-remitting (RR) MS (∼ 90 % of patients): either full recovery between exacerbations (left column) or increasing residual disability with each exacerbation (right column).

Secondary progressive (SP) MS: > 50 % of patients initially presenting with relapsing-remitting MS later develop a pattern of continuous progression (left column), which may also include further exacerbations (right column).

Primary progressive(PP) MS (∼ 10 % of patients): continuous worsening of symptoms from disease onset (left column), but may include phases of no progression or even mild clinical improvement (less pronounced than in relapsing-remitting MS; right column). Exacerbations may also occur (not depicted).

title: Spondylolysis (Scottie dog sign with collar)
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (45° oblique view)

The normal Scottie dog sign (green overlay) has a collar (red overlay) as a result of a defect in the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis).

title: Scaphoid fracture
description:
X-ray hand (PA view)

A nondisplaced fracture (red line) is visible through the waist of the scaphoid bone of the wrist.

title: Pulmonary nodules
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung metastases

Multiple pulmonary nodules with circumscribed margins can be seen in both lungs (examples indicated by green overlays). Differential diagnoses include malignant etiologies (metastatic disease, primary lung cancer, lymphoma) and benign etiologies (infection, embolism, autoimmune disease). An old healed fracture of the right clavicle (white arrow) is also visible.

title: Urine casts in acute tubular necrosis
description:
Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

Renal tubular epithelial cell casts (a) and muddy brown casts (b) were identified in this urine sample.

Both findings indicate damage of the kidneys, likely due to acute tubular necrosis.

title: Spondylolisthesis
description:
X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Anterior displacement (green overlay) of L4 on L5 is visible (Meyerding grade II). In addition, there is degenerative disk disease with narrowing of the L4–L5 disk space (red overlay), as well as hypertrophic changes of the L5 vertebral body.

title: Effects of epinephrine on glycogen metabolism
description:
In both liver and muscle, epinephrine binds a beta-adrenergic G protein-coupled receptor, activating a second messenger cascade that results in the promotion of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown) and inhibition of glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis).

An additional signaling pathway in the liver involves the binding of epinephrine to an alpha-adrenergic G protein-coupled receptor, which stimulates glycogenolysis and inhibits glycogenesis via the activation of a calcium/calmodulin second messenger system.

title: Focal uterine adenomyosis
description:
Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal; transverse plane)

Heterogeneous asymmetric thickening of the anterior myometrium (green overlay) is accompanied by a myometrial cyst (red overlay). There is an irregular interface between the endometrium (E) and the myometrial thickening. The additional small round hypoechogenic lesion (green hatched overlay) is a leiomyoma.

P: ultrasound probe
Dashed line: uterus

title: Trichomonas vaginalis
description:
Photomicrograph of trichomonas vaginalis trophozoites (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

The protozoan appears oval-shaped with flagella (examples indicated by arrowheads) and a nucleus (green overlay) located at the anterior end.

title: Rockwood classification of acromioclavicular injury (types I-VI)
description:
Key

• Strained ligaments = red area
• Ruptured ligaments = serrated red lines
• Detached deltoid and trapezius muscle = serrated blue lines
• Normal position of the clavicle = red line
• Dislocation of the clavicle = red arrow (Type II → not above the superior border of the acromion, type III → coracoclavicular distance < 25 mm, type IV → posteriorly displaced clavicle, type V → coracoclavicular distance > 25 mm, type VI → clavicle is inferiorly displaced below the coracoid)

Findings for each type

• Type I: Mild sprain of the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments (red shaded area).
• Type II: Ruptured acromioclavicular ligament and sprain of the coracoclavicular ligament (serrated lines); clavicle elevated, but does not extend above the superior border of the acromion (red arrow).
• Type III: The acromioclavicular ligament, coracoclavicular ligament, and joint capsule are ruptured (serrated lines); clavicle elevated above the superior border of the acromion (red arrow) and can be repositioned with minimal pressure, which is known as the piano key sign.
• Type IV: The acromioclavicular ligament, coracoclavicular ligament, and joint capsule are ruptured (red serrated lines). The trapezius and deltoid are detached (serrated blue lines). Posteriorly displaced clavicle (red arrow).
• Type V: Type IV plus marked elevation of the clavicle; coracoclavicular distance is > 25 mm. The piano key sign is present.
• Type VI: Clavicle is inferiorly displaced behind the coracobrachialis and biceps tendons; all ligaments are ruptured; the original position of the clavicle is indicated by the red lines.

title: Interstitial lung disease
description:
X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with history of amiodarone pulmonary toxicity

A coarse reticular pattern from pulmonary fibrosis is present diffusely in both lungs. Additional ill-defined opacities represent areas of consolidation, which would typically appear as high-attenuation lesions on CT.

Although a necklace is seen on the radiograph, jewelry is usually removed prior to imaging.

title: Mechanism of action: immunosuppressants
description:
Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

title: Transfusion reactions
description: TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury; Ag: antigen

title: Hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign in stroke
description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The left middle cerebral artery (green overlay) is hyperdense as a result of thromboembolic occlusion. Hypodensity with loss of gray-white matter differentiation in the left frontal, temporal, and parietal regions (red-dashed overlay) corresponds to an acute infarct in the middle cerebral artery distribution.

title: Mucormycosis
description:
Bilateral edema of the eyelid and purulent exudation from both eyes is visible. There are spotted areas of necrotic eschar, especially close to the inner canthus of the right eye, on the right eyelid, and on the nose.

These findings, especially in an immunocompromised patient, suggest Mucorales infection.

title: Thyroid scan hot nodule
description:
Nuclear medicine thyroid scintigraphy (Tc-99m pertechnetate)

The rounded area in the right thyroid lobe represents a so-called hot thyroid nodule, which shows increased radioisotope uptake compared to the rest of the thyroid gland.

title: Bronchogenic cyst
description:
Photomicrograph of a mediastinal cyst cross-section specimen (H&E stain; 450x magnification)

The lumen is lined by ciliated epithelium (green overlay; examples of cilia indicated by arrowheads) and layers of smooth muscle (yellow overlay) are visible, resembling upper airway tissue. Also, normal adipose tissue (examples of adipocytes indicated by black dashed outlines) can be found in the periphery.

The typical location (suprasternal, behind the manubrium, middle mediastinum) paired with the described histologic appearance indicates a bronchogenic cyst.

title: Foreign body aspiration
description:
X-ray chest (PA view)

Hyperinflation of the left lung appears hyperlucent, with depression of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and red arrow) and contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by green outline, green hatched overlay, and green arrows). There is no pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum. The left main bronchus and its branches are not well seen in this patient as they project over the spine.

Hyperinflation of a lung due to a ball valve effect is a common presentation of foreign body aspiration.

title: Helicobacter pylori
description:
Scanning electron micrograph of helicobacter pylori

Multiple spiral-shaped bacteria with a length of 3μm and flagella are visible.

title: Structure of MHC molecules
description:
MHC class I proteins consist of a heavy α chain and the stabilizing β2 microglobulin, which are held together by a noncovalent bond. The α chain is composed of three individual domains (α1–α3) and forms the antigen-binding groove (peptide-binding site).

MHC class II proteins consist of one α and one β chain, each of which is in turn composed of two domains (α1 and α2; β1 and β2). Each chain is independently anchored to the cell membrane via a transmembrane segment. Together, both chains form the peptide-binding site.

title: Pulmonary hamartoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from a pulmonary nodule (H&E stain, low magnification).

On the right side, normal lung tissue (green overlay) with air-filled spaces (parts of small airways, alveoli) can be seen. On the left side, condensed tissue appears with a mixture of pale-staining immature myxomatous tissue (examples indicated by blue overlay), connective and fat tissue (identifiable as large unstained lipid vacuoles; examples indicated by arrowheads), and multiple clefts lined by dark-staining epithelium (examples indicated by yellow lines).
Often hyaline cartilage can also be found in such pulmonary nodules (not present here).

In the absence of any signs of malignancy (e.g., cellular atypia, mitosis, necrosis), this abnormal mixture of multiple tissue components in the lung indicates pulmonary hamartoma (the most common type of benign lung tumor).

title: Small bowel obstruction
description:
CT abdomen (IV contrast; coronal plane)

Significant dilatation of mid and distal small bowel loops can be seen (asterisks).

These findings are typical of small bowel obstruction.

title: Stage 4 decubitus (pressure) ulcer
description: A decubitus ulcer with full-thickness skin and tissue loss is visible over the sacrum, exposing the bone. The ulcer is partly covered by eschar and surrounded by erythema.

title: Cranial nerve nuclei
description: Dorsal view of the brainstem

title: Regulation of gastric acid secretion
description: Gastric acid secretion (HCl) is stimulated by acetylcholine (in response to vagus nerve activity), gastrin (produced by G cells), and histamine (produced by ECL cells in response to vagus nerve activity). The decreasing pH of the gastric juice (due to HCl) acts as a negative feedback mechanism by stimulating D-cells to produce somatostatin, which directly inhibits G-cell activity. As gastric contents enter the duodenum, a variety of hormones are released (summarized at the bottom left of image), each with specific functions.

title: Capillary fluid exchange
description:
Capillary fluid exchange depends on the balance between the hydrostatic pressure gradient (Pc - Pi) and the oncotic pressure gradient (πc - πi).

Capillary hydrostatic pressure, which drives fluid out of the capillaries, decreases from ∼ 30 mm Hg at the arteriolar end of the capillary bed to ∼ 15 mm Hg at the venous end. In contrast, oncotic pressure, which drives fluid into the capillaries, increases along the length of the capillary due to increasing colloid concentration. Accordingly, at the arteriolar end of the capillary bed, the hydrostatic pressure gradient is usually greater than the oncotic pressure gradient, leading to filtration of fluid out of the capillaries into the interstitium. At the venous end, the hydrostatic pressure gradient is usually smaller than the oncotic pressure gradient, leading to the reabsorption of fluid from the interstitium into the capillaries.

Approximately 90% of the filtered volume is reabsorbed into the capillaries and the remaining 10% is absorbed by lymphatic vessels, reentering the vascular system at a later point.

Pc: capillary hydrostatic pressure, Pi: interstitial hydrostatic pressure; πc: plasma colloid (oncotic) pressure; πi: interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure

title: Dextrocardia in Kartagener syndrome
description:
CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)

The base-to-apex cardiac axis is directed to the patient's right (dextrocardia). The right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) are reversed. This patient also presented with right to left reversal of the morphologic atria and abdominal organs (situs inversus; not shown).

Dextrocardia with situs inversus is part of the triad of manifestations seen in Kartagener syndrome, which also includes chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.

title: Reaction of alanine aminotransferase
description: Alanine aminotransferase transfers the amino group (red) from alanine to α-ketoglutarate to yield pyruvate and glutamate. This transamination reaction is reversible and requires the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

title: Negative pressure (vacuum-assisted) wound therapy: principles
description:
Cross-section of a vacuum dressing

The wound cavity is filled with a foam dressing. (The cavity shown here extends into muscle tissue; cavities may also be limited to subcutaneous tissue or extend to the bone.) An airtight adhesive dressing covers the foam dressing and surrounding skin. The adhesive dressing is perforated centrally and the opening covered by an adhesive pad, which is connected via a drainage tube to the vacuum pump. The pump creates negative pressure, drawing off wound exudate (red arrows) via the foam dressing and drainage tube into a collection device.

title: Types of Aphasia
description: The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

title: Myasthenia gravis autoantibodies
description:
Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

title: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Large atypical lymphoid cells (black arrowheads) with enlarged, eccentric nuclei, vesicular chromatin, and amphophilic cytoplasm can be seen. This appearance raises suspicion for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Immunophenotyping (evaluating the expression of CD20, CD10, MUM1, and BCL6) is required to confirm the diagnosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Chondrocalcinosis
description:
X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).

title: Naegleria fowleri
description:
Photomicrographs of Naegleria fowleri specimens obtained from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples

A: Multiple trophozoites in axenic (pure) culture
B: Trophozoite stage (Giemsa stain)
C: Flagellate stage (Giemsa stain)

title: Solid thyroid nodule with microcalcifications
description:
Ultrasound thyroid (longitudinal plane)

A solid nodule in the upper pole has ill-defined margins and contains multiple microcalcifications.

The presence of microcalcifications increases suspicion for malignancy

title: Apple core sign
description:
Fluoroscopy (barium enema; lateral view)

An apple core sign (also called napkin ring sign; green overlay) is seen in the distal descending colon. It is the result of annular constriction by a colorectal carcinoma.

title: Biosynthesis and breakdown of catecholamines
description:
Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

title: Anterior shoulder dislocation surface anatomy
description:
Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation. Axillary nerve palsy is a known complication of both shoulder dislocation and reduction. Axillary nerve function should be evaluated before and after attempting reduction, by testing sensation over the lateral surface of the shoulder (yellow overlay).

title: Hand affected by amniotic band syndrome
description: Partial congenital amputation of the digits is seen on the right hand of this infant. The third and fifth digits are particularly affected.

title: Giardiasis
description: Giardia lamblia is usually transmitted through the ingestion of cysts in contaminated drinking water or food, although fecal-oral transmission is also possible. In the gastrointestinal tract, Giardia lamblia cysts turn into trophozoites, which adhere to intestinal walls and rapidly multiply. While excreted trophozoites die, the excreted cysts are the infectious form of the pathogen and able to survive in most environments.

title: Life cycle of schistosomes
description: An infected human, the definitive host of schistosomes, excretes schistosome eggs in urine or feces (yellow and brown arrow). The eggs hatch in water and release miracidia. These flat, ciliated larva penetrate specific freshwater snails, which then act as intermediate hosts. In the snail, the miracidia develop into sporocysts, which reproduce asexually to form cercaria. Cercaria are then released back in the water. When humans come in contact with contaminated water, cercaria can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. As they lose their tail, the cercaria develop into schistosomula, which then mature into adult schistosomes in the venous system. At this point, a male and female adult worm mate and migrate to the veins of the target organs (liver, intestine, bladder). The female worm lies folded in the longitudinal cleft (schist) of the male worm and lays eggs, which causes inflammation of the organs. As a result of the inflammation, the eggs can penetrate the wall of the organ and enter the lumen of the intestine or bladder (depending on the species), and they are then eliminated in feces or urine.

title: Pathophysiology of homocystinuria
description:
Methionine synthase deficiency or MTHFR deficiency: impaired conversion of homocysteine to methionine
Cystathionine synthase deficiency or reduced affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate: impaired conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine

Both result in accumulation of homocysteine.

Substances shown in blue text are enzymes (e.g., MTHFR). Substances shown in parentheses and blue shading are cofactors in enzymatic reactions (e.g., FAD). Substances shown in beige shading are B vitamins, highlighted here because treatment of homocystinuria may involve B vitamin supplementation.

PLP: pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B6); MTHFR: methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; FAD: flavin adenine dinucleotide (derived from vitamin B2); THF: tetrahydrofolate (derived from vitamin B9)

title: Inclusion conjunctivitis
description:
The tarsal conjunctiva appears edematous with developing follicles (examples indicated by green overlay).

These findings are consistent with inclusion conjunctivitis due to Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

title: Schistosoma mansoni egg
description:
Photomicrograph of Schistosoma mansoni egg (high magnification)

The Schistosoma mansoni egg has the typical oval shape with a tapered anterior end and the characteristic lateral spine near the posterior end.

title: Aortic dissection
description: A tear in the tunica intima (entry tear on illustration) allows blood to enter into the tunica media. The column of blood then extends longitudinally, most commonly in the outer half of the tunica media. This creates a false lumen, which may rupture back into the true lumen of the aorta (reentry tear on illustration) or rupture through the tunica adventitia.

title: Histoplasmosis fact sheet and US endemicity map
description: (Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

title: Regulation of calcium and phosphate metabolism
description:
When serum calcium levels decrease, parathyroid chief cells secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium levels via the following mechanisms:

1. PTH activates osteoclasts, which degrade bone, thereby releasing calcium and phosphate.
2. In the kidneys, PTH stimulates calcium reabsorption in the distal tubule and decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
3. PTH increases the expression of 1α-hydroxylase in the kidneys, an enzyme required to synthesize calcitriol. Calcitriol, in turn, stimulates renal and intestinal reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate. In contrast to PTH, calcitriol promotes the mineralization of bone using calcium and phosphate.

title: The chemotox woman
description: A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

title: Bacterial conjugation F+ to F-
description:
Conjugation is a process of gene transfer from one bacterium to another that occurs through direct contact via a sex pilus.

Top right: F factor is a plasmid that encodes genes for sex pili. F+ bacteria (donor) contain the F factor plasmid and F- bacteria (recipient) do not.

Left: The F plasmid in an F+ bacterium initiates the growth of the sex pilus that connects to an F- bacterium, forming a bridge between the two bacteria (mating pair).

Center: A strand of the F plasmid is transferred to the F- bacterium through the bridge.

Right: Each bacterium now has a single strand of F plasmid that creates a complementary copy of itself, resulting in two F+ bacteria, each with its own F plasmid.

title: Tinea capitis
description:
A round lesion with central hair loss and peripheral scaling is visible on the right parietal region of this child's head.

This finding is typical of tinea capitis.

title: Neuroblastoma of the adrenal gland
description:
CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane)

A large heterogeneous mass (green overlay) with little to no vascular enhancement is present in the area of the right adrenal gland.

This is a common CT appearance of adrenal neuroblastoma. Although not present on this CT, accompanying calcifications are common.

title: Coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever) fact sheet and US endemicity map
description: (Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

title: Psoas abscess
description:
CT lumbar spine (without contrast; axial plane; soft tissue window)

The left psoas muscle is enlarged by a hypodense mass (green overlay). Involvement also extends to the level of the adjacent neural foramen and posteriorly to obliterate fat planes of the paraspinal musculature.

Findings represent a psoas abscess with paraspinal extension.

title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
description:
MRI Head (A: T2 weighted, B: T1 weighted with contrast; axial plane)

A T2 hyperintense lesion without mass effect (image A, green overlay) in the left cerebellar hemisphere does not enhance on the T1 weighted sequence (image B). Other enhancing foci (red overlay) are seen in B, although such enhancement is uncommon in PML.

PML lesions typically involve parietooccipital subcortical and periventricular white matter, are T2 hyperintense, do not enhance, and produce little or no mass effect.

title: Newborn with congenital syphilis
description:
A face of a newborn infant with perioral fissures (rhagades; indicated by black arrow) and nasal discharge (indicated by white arrow) can be seen.

These clinical features are characteristic of congenital syphilis.

title: Anterior shoulder dislocation
description:
X-ray left shoulder (AP view (left); lateral (scapular) Y-view (right))

There is an anterior and slightly inferior displacement of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa.

Green overlay: scapula
Red overlay: proximal humerus

title: Splicing
description:
Splicing is a posttranscriptional modification of a newly synthesized pre-mRNA molecule. Noncoding gene sequences (introns) are excised from the pre-mRNA molecule and the protein-coding regions (exons) are joined together.
The process involves two transesterification reactions: The first occurs between the 5′ splice site and the 2′ OH of the branch point (A). The second transesterification occurs between the 5′ splice site and 3′ splice site. The process is catalyzed by snRNPs (U1–U6), which together form the spliceosome. The excised intron is released in a lariat structure and the exons are ligated together.

title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis
description:
Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

title: Blastomycosis fact sheet and US endemicity map
description: (Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

title: Conglomerates of Actinomyces in actinomycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of an oral tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Two Actinomyces filament conglomerates (drusen) are visible (indicated by white dashed outlines). Filaments can also be seen protruding radially and branching out of the conglomerate (examples indicated by yellow arrowheads). The drusen are surrounded by an infiltrate of neutrophils (examples indicated by red arrowheads).

Actinomyces are commonly found in nasal and pharyngeal tissue (e.g., tonsils) and their presence has no clinical significance unless accompanied by certain clinical findings (e.g., abscess formation, tissue fibrosis, or a tissue mass mimicking a tumor) and Actinomyces drusen.

title: Regions of the brain with embryological derivation
description:
The illustration depicts the regions of the mature brain (names in parentheses) and their embryological derivation from the 3 primary vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon) and 5 subdivisions (telencephalon, diencephalon, mesencephalon, metencephalon, myelencephalon). Note that this nomenclature is not always consistent, as some sources also refer to the regions of the mature brain using the embryological terminology (e.g., “prosencephalon” instead of “forebrain,” etc).

Note also that while the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) is a downgrowth of the diencephalon (and therefore shown in orange), the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis) is separately derived as an upgrowth of the oral ectoderm (therefore shown in white).

title: Lichen simplex chronicus
description: A markedly thickened, well circumscribed, oval lesion with exaggerated skin markings is visible on this patient's hand.

title: Tinea pedis
description:
There is erythema and scaling between the second and third toes.

This is a typical finding in interdigital tinea pedis, which is usually associated with severe pruritus.

title: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
description: There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

title: Angles of anteflexion and anteversion of the uterus
description:
The terms flexion and version are used to describe the position of the uterus.

Flexion refers to the angle between the axis of the uterine body (blue line) and the axis of the cervix (yellow line).
Version refers to the angle between the axis of the cervix and the axis of the vagina (green line).

The uterus is usually anteflexed by approx. 100° (AF) and anteverted by approx. 90° (AV), depending on how full the bladder is.

title: Malrotation with midgut volvulus
description:
Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)

The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.

The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

title: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
description:
Electron micrographs of mycoplasma pneumoniae cells (A: scanning electron micrograph; B: transmission electron micrograph)

– A: filamentous M. pneumoniae
– B: flask-shaped M. pneumoniae (M), attached to ciliated mucosal cells via the tip organelle (arrow)

title: Ichthyosis vulgaris
description: Lines of fine scaling, forming a network in between dry and coarse skin (xerosis cutis), are visible on this patient's shins and feet.

title: Earlobe keloid
description: The left earlobe (lobule) bears a well-defined lesion that extends well beyond the boundary of the initial defect (most likely an ear piercing).

title: Oxygen dissociation curve for carbon monoxide poisoning
description: The pink line shows the normal change in blood oxygen content (O2 bound to hemoglobin (Hb)) in the presence of increasing partial pressure of O2 in arteries (PaO2). When carbon monoxide (CO) is bound to 50% of hemoglobin (green line), the maximal volume of O2 bound to hemoglobin decreases and there is a left shift in the graph, reflecting the increase in O2 affinity of hemoglobin.

title: Visual pathway
description:
1. Retina: The visual pathway begins at the retina. The temporal field of vision is projected onto the nasal portion of the retina and the nasal field of vision is projected onto the temporal portion of the retina.
2. Optic nerves: The axons of the retinal ganglion cells merge to form the optic nerve, which carries the nasal and temporal fibers of the ipsilateral retina.
3. Optic chiasm: The two optic nerves meet at the optic chiasm, where the nasal fibers of each retina cross over to the contralateral side. The temporal fibers remain uncrossed.
4. Optic tracts: Each optic tract carries contralateral nasal fibers and ipsilateral temporal fibers (i.e., the right optic tract carries the nasal fibers of the left eye and the temporal fibers of the right eye). I.e., each optic tract carries the contralateral visual field of each eye.
5. Lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN): The optic tracts synapse onto the ipsilateral LGN.
6. Optic radiation: consists of neurons that carry visual information from the ipsilateral LGN to the ipsilateral primary visual cortex
7. Primary visual cortex: The visual pathway terminates at the primary visual cortex, which is located at the posterior aspect of the occipital lobe. It is responsible for the perception of sight. The right visual cortex receives visual information from the right nasal field and the left temporal field of vision, i.e. the left visual field of each eye.

title: Overview of the ascending and descending pathways of the spinal cord
description:
Illustration depicting the arrangement of the spinal cord pathways within the white matter of the spinal cord

Ascending sensory tracts (blue)
1) Dorsal columns: relay conscious proprioception, pressure, vibration, and fine touch to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
2) Spinocerebellar tract: relays unconscious proprioception to the ipsilateral cerebellum
3) Anterolateral spinothalamic tract: relays pressure, crude touch, pain, and temperature to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
4) Spino-olivary tract: responsible for relaying unconscious proprioception (mainly for balance) to the olivary nucleus in the ipsilateral medulla and, from there, to the ipsilateral cerebellum

Descending tracts (red)
5) Pyramidal tract: controls voluntary movement by transmitting impulses from the precentral gyrus of the brain to the contralateral side of the body
6) Extrapyramidal tract: regulates involuntary movements and reflexes by transmitting impulses from the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum to the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
Somatotopic organization: C = cervical, T = thoracic, L = lumbar, S = sacral

title: Vancomycin flushing reaction
description: Erythema of the skin is visible, especially on the patient's cheeks and nose. This symptom usually resolves within minutes after treatment. Vancomycin flushing reaction is not a true allergic reaction, but rather a rate-dependent hypersensitivity reaction. It can be avoided by slow infusion.

title: Myelomeningocele on fetal ultrasound
description:
Ultrasound of 21-week fetus (sagittal plane)

A myelomeningocele sac (green overlay) is identified at the lumbar region. The sac contains anechoic fluid and some solid neural elements.

T: thorax

title: Transient neonatal pustular melanosis
description: Multiple pustules and erosions are visible on this neonate's trunk.

title: Dacryocytes
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Multiple dacryocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, are visible among normal erythrocytes throughout the image (examples indicated by green overlay). Dacryocytes are seen in conditions associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, or splenomegaly).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: The cardiac cycle (left ventricle)
description:
Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

title: Galactose metabolism
description:
Illustration of the galactose metabolism in the liver

Galactose is added to the glucose metabolism by activating it through galactokinase at the C1 atom via phosphorylation. A UDP molecule is then transferred to the resulting galactose-1-phosphate. This molecule is provided by UDP-glucose and transferred through Gal-1-P uridylyltransferase; in this process, glucose-1-phosphate is released that can be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and introduced to the glycolysis. Next, UDP-glucose 4-epimerase can transfer UDP-galactosis to the UDP-glucose; then, it can be either directly used for the glycosynthesis or react with another molecule to galactose 1-phosphate.

title: Life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii
description: The life cycle of toxoplasmosis involves transmission to a human host through the ingestion of cat feces particulate that contains oocysts or ingestion of meat (i.e., pork) containing Toxoplasma cysts. Cross-placental transmission is possible after the initial infection of pregnant women.

title: Metabolic fuel usage
description:
During the first seconds of exercise, cells are powered by stored ATP and creatine phosphate.

After approx. 10 seconds, the levels of ATP and creatine phosphate drop, and ATP synthesis is maintained by anaerobic glycolysis of muscle glycogen.

After approx. 1 minute of exercise, ATP synthesis occurs under aerobic metabolism using either glucose (from glycolysis) or fatty acids (from β-oxidation).

Oxidation of fatty acids provide larger quantities of ATP but at a slower rate than the one obtained by glycogen oxidation, and they start to be used when the glycogen is not totally consumed. The simultaneous use of both fuels ensures a good compromise between velocity and amount of ATP synthesis.

The sequential activation of the different sources during exercise results in a performance level (dotted line) that decreases as the duration of exercise increases.

title: Endocervical adenocarcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of an endocervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei are visible (green overlays). There is an abundance of neutrophils (as a sign of inflammation secondary to neoplasia; yellow overlays) within the subepithelial stroma indicating an invasive tumor. Parts of the invasive component can be seen in the center and at the bottom of the image (red overlays).

This appearance is characteristic of endocervical adenocarcinoma.

title: Ischemic ulcers
description:
Photograph of left foot

Numerous ulcers are visible on this patient's foot.

This appearance is suggestive of ischemic ulcers in peripheral arterial disease.

title: Oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve
description:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shows the partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) in blood in relation to the percentage O2 saturation of hemoglobin (HbO2), i.e., the binding affinity of Hb for O2. The curve is sigmoidal (S-shaped), starting with a gradual increase, then rising steeply before plateauing (blue curve).
