Factors that decrease the affinity of Hb for O2 (e.g., ↑ pCO2) shift the curve to the right (green curve). This increases P50 (the partial pressure of oxygen needed to maintain 50% of Hb saturated). These factors facilitate the release of O2 to the tissues.

Factors that increase the affinity of Hb for O2 (e.g., ↓ pCO2) shift the curve to the left (purple curve), with a concomitant decrease in P50.

The variation in the binding affinity of Hb for O2 represented by the sigmoidal shape of the curve is clinically significant, since it means that a decrease in pO2 does not lead to a corresponding linear decrease in % HbO2. Instead, HbO2 initially drops very slowly, but with further decrease in pO2 then drops precipitously:

(A) A pO2 of 90 mmHg corresponds to an HbO2 saturation of ∼ 97%.
(B) A decrease of pO2 to ∼75 mmHg corresponds to a decrease in % HbO2 of only ∼3% (to 94%).
(C) A further decrease of pO2 to 50 mmHg corresponds to a further decrease in % HbO2 of ∼ 10% (to 84%).

title: Urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
description:
Endoscopic view of the bladder

A lateral bladder wall lesion is visible during bipolar transurethral resection.

title: Intrapulmonary and intrapleural pressure during respiration
description: Static compliance is a measure of elastic airway resistance without changes in airflow, while dynamic compliance is a measure of airway resistance during times of airflow. Inspiration requires a negative intrapulmonary pressure, which is achieved through expansion of the lungs via contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. During exhalation, the intrapulmonary pressure becomes positive as the elastic recoil of the thoracic wall compresses the lungs and expels the inhaled air.

title: Thyroglossal duct cyst
description:
CT head (without contrast; a: axial plane; b: sagittal plane)

A hypodense mass (green overlay) with a fluid density value (mean 20 HU) is present anterior to the hyoid bone (arrows).

title: Supraspinatus tendon tear (rotator cuff tear)
description:
MRI right shoulder (fluid sensitive fat-suppressed sequence; coronal plane)

A tear of the hypointense supraspinatus tendon (white arrow) has resulted in tendon retraction proximally. Fluid (red arrow) inferior to the acromion (green overlay) in the subacromial-subdeltoid space appears hyperintense and communicates with joint effusion along the rest of the humeral head.

These are MRI features of a full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon

a: deltoid muscle; b: clavicle; c: trapezius muscle; d: supraspinatus muscle; e: subscapularis muscle

title: Deep lymph nodes
description: Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

title: Huntington disease
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

This condition is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo. These findings in a patient with chorea are consistent with Huntington disease.

title: Coccidioides immitis
description:
Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

title: Café-au-lait spot
description:
There is a flat, hyperpigmented, irregularly shaped macule visible on the patient's forearm. These macules are also known as “café-au-lait spots.”

Unilateral café-au-lait spots in patients with precocious onset of puberty suggest McCune-Albright syndrome.

title: Babesiosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes infected with Babesia species are visible. Common formations of this parasite are the Maltese cross (example indicated by green overlay) and the intraerythrocytic ring formation (arrow).

This hematological appearance is characteristic of babesiosis.

title: Hepatitis B antigens
description: The hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is found on the outer wall of the virions lipid bilayer and confirms the presence of the virus in the blood. HBsAg is the first indicator of infection and can be detected as early as 1 week after infection. An infected hepatocyte may also release the hepatitis B envelope antigen (HBeAg), a protein produced by the virus that serves as an indicator of active viral replication.

title: Cervical plexus
description:
Lateral view of the right cervical plexus

The hypoglossal and accessory nerve (gray) are not part of the cervical plexus and are provided here as anatomical landmarks only.

The branches of the cervical plexus (gray) make up the ansa cervicalis and innervate the infrahyoid muscles.

title: Median section of the male pelvis with detail of a testicle
description:
The penis is composed of three cavernous bodies: the corpus spongiosum, which contains the urethra, and two corpora cavernosa, each containing a deep artery of the penis.

The male accessory glands are:

- The prostate
- The paired seminal glands
- The bulbourethral glands (paired)
- The small glands of the spermatic duct (not shown)

The testicles and accessory glands are responsible for the production of sperm and androgens, primarily testosterone.

title: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
description:
Photomicrograph of eosinophilic vasculitis (H&E stain; high magnification)

Two blood vessels (white outlines) with necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophil infiltration of the media (indicated by arrows in the detail) are visible. Extravascular accumulations of eosinophils cause the characteristic tissue eosinophilia (examples indicated by arrowheads).

These findings are consistent with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

title: Acne vulgaris
description:
Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

title: Subconjunctival hemorrhage
description:
Left eye

A small subconjunctival hemorrhage is visible adjacent to the temporal inferior limbus.

This is the typical appearance of subconjunctival hemorrhage.

title: Hormonal feedback control of ADH secretion
description:
(1) Receptors in the hypothalamus measure plasma osmolality. If the osmolality exceeds a set point, ADH is released in the hypothalamus.
(2) ADH travels from the hypothalamus to the posterior pituitary via the neurosecretory hypothalamo-neurohypophyseal tract.
(3) ADH is released from the posterior pituitary into the bloodstream.
(4) ADH increases renal reabsorption of water (inclusion of aquaporins in the collecting tubules).
(5) Reabsorption of water results in decreased urination.
(6) Receptors in the hypothalamus detect falling osmolality and reduce ADH secretion.

title: Chediak-Higashi syndrome
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Inclusion bodies (examples indicated by arrows) and polymorphous nuclei (green overlay) can be seen within the leukocytes.

These findings are consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

title: Testing the vestibuloocular reflex with oculocephalic maneuver
description:
Normal: The eyes remain fixed on an object despite rapid, passive movement of the patient's head.

Pathological: The eyes remain midorbit during rapid, passive movement of the patient's head; this indicates a defective brainstem reflex.

title: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema
description:
Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is triggered by increased levels of the proinflammatory vasodilator bradykinin, which can build up via several different mechanisms.

Top left: The rare hereditary angioedema (HAE) type III (normal levels and function of C1-INH) can be caused by several different gene mutations; illustrated here is a mutation resulting in increased Factor XII activity, which leads to increased bradykinin generation.

Center left: In HAE type I (low levels of normal C1-INH), HAE type II (normal or high levels of dysfunctional C1-INHI), and acquired angioedema (acquired low levels of C1-INH), the normal inhibitory function of C1-INH on the kallikrein-kinin system is reduced, resulting in increased bradykinin generation.

Bottom left: In ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, reduced bradykinin breakdown due to inhibition of ACE results in the build-up of bradykinin.

C1-INH: C1 inhibitor; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; HMWK: high-molecular-weight kininogen; HAE: hereditary angioedema

title: Area under the curve of bioavailability graphs
description: The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over a period of time, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally. The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields the bioavailability (F) of a substance.

title: Melasma
description:
Multiple hyperpigmented, irregularly shaped maculae are visible across this patient's forehead. Smaller spots of hyperpigmentation are visible above the right eyebrow.

These findings are indicative of melasma.

title: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve
description:
The ROC curve illustrates the relationship between the sensitivity and specificity of a test.

The more closely the curve follows the Y axis, the more accurate the test. The more close the curve is to the diagonal dotted line (x = y), the less accurate the test.

When choosing a cutoff value, an upward shift on the ROC curve indicates increased sensitivity, and a shift to the right indicates decreased specificity.

title: Dysgerminoma
description:
Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Sheets of uniform cells with a fried-egg appearance (large nucleus and clear cytoplasm) are visible throughout (examples indicated by green overlay). These sheets of cells are separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic infiltration.

These findings are consistent with dysgerminoma.

title: Anaplasmosis
description:
Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear, sheep (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Neutrophile granulocytes with morulae (intracellular bacterial inclusion bodies; example indicated by arrow) can be seen. Furthermore there are erythrocytes, platelets and a monocyte (right) .

Morulae within granulocytes are characteristic of anaplasmosis, a tick-borne infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum.

title: Cystine crystals
description:
Photomicrograph of cystine crystals from a canine urine sample (1000x magnification)

A clump of multiple, clear, hexagon-shaped crystals is visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of cystine crystals.

title: Pyruvate metabolism
description:
Pyruvate is a key intermediate in various metabolic pathways of the body.

- Glycolysis: Pyruvate is generated from glucose, with the last step catalyzed by pyruvate kinase.
- Pyruvate can also originate from glucogenic amino acids.
- Gluconeogenesis: Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which serves as a substrate for the generation of glucose.
- Citric acid cycle: Pyruvate dehydrogenase converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, which serves as a substrate for ATP generation in the citric acid cycle.
- Glucose-alanine cycle: Pyruvate can be generated from or converted into alanine.
- Cori cycle: Pyruvate can be generated from or converted into lactate.

title: Neutrophils in acute inflammation
description:
Photomicrograph of a tissue biopsy sample (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Perivascular infiltrates of neutrophils (examples indicated by black arrows) are visible.

title: Cryptococcus neoformans
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (mucicarmine stain; high magnification)

A widened alveolar septum with inflammatory cell infiltration (white arrowheads: macrophages; black arrowhead: neutrophil granulocyte) and yeasts of Cryptococcus neoformans (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

title: Pathophysiology for different types of gallstones
description:
Cholesterol stones arise only in the gallbladder but can be transported into the cystic duct as well as the common bile duct and cause obstruction and stasis.

Pigmented gallstones contain varying amounts of calcium bilirubinate and can arise anywhere in the biliary tree. Black pigment stones arise mostly in the gallbladder (due to increased hemolysis; e.g., in sickle cell disease), whereas brown pigment stones typically arise in inflamed portions of the biliary duct (e.g., due to bacterial or parasitic infections).

title: Celiac disease etiopathogenesis
description: The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

title: Left hemicolectomy
description:
Extent of resection (left): between the distal third of the transverse colon and sigmoid colon (blue dashed lines). The arterial blood supply to this section, including the inferior mesenteric artery and the left branch of the middle colic artery, is ligated (purple dashed lines). Malignancy (lesions shown in gray) is a common indication for this procedure.

Reconstruction (right): typically achieved via end-to-end colorectal anastomosis

title: Internal capsule lesion in neurotoxoplasmosis
description:
MRI head (T2-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with cerebral toxoplasmosis

A small nodule (hatched overlay) in the right internal capsule is accompanied by hyperintense perilesional edema (solid overlay).

Neurotoxoplasmosis more commonly manifests with multiple lesions and it has a propensity for the corticomedullary junction, thalami, and basal ganglia. It is a leading cerebral opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS.

title: The lac operon
description: Operons are functional units of DNA (one or several genes, controlled by a single promoter). The lac operon is the classic example of an operon found in many bacteria (e.g., E. Coli) that contacts the regulatory gene for encoding enzymes responsible for the transport and metabolism of lactose. The operon contains a promoter sequence and an operator sequence that overlaps with the promoter. Depending on the relative levels of lactose and glucose, either the repressor protein binds to the operator (preventing gene transcription) or lactose binds to the repressor protein, which is then inactivated and dissociates from the operator (enabling transcription).

title: Thyroid scintigraphy
description:
Overview of radioactive iodine uptake patterns in hyperthyroidism

Toxic MNG: Toxic multinodular goiter

title: Resorptive phase of wound healing
description: Macrophages release growth factors and cytokines that recruit other immune cells and stimulate fibroblast proliferation. Lymphocytes promote cellular immunity, and neutrophils and macrophages phagocytose pathogens and cellular debris.

title: B cell affinity maturation
description: Activated mature B-cells become either plasma cells or memory B cells. After proliferation and mutation in the dark zone of the germinal center, the activated B-cells (centrocytes) undergo class switching via cytokine stimulation by T-helper cells.

title: Mechanism of action: renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitors
description:
Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

title: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
description: Photomicrograph of ileum tissue (H&E staining; very high magnification) showing densely arranged poorly differentiated cells.

title: Acid-base nomogram
description:
This nomogram can be used for the interpretation of an arterial blood gas analysis in the context of acid-base disorders.

PCO2 is on the x-axis and the concentration of HCO3- (cHCO3-) is on the y-axis; both are displayed logarithmically, allowing the pH to be displayed on parallel straight lines. The important areas for acid-base disorders are highlighted and labeled. The oval area in the middle around PCO2 = 40 mm Hg and cHCO3- = 24 mEq/L represents the reference range.

title: Mechanisms of action - cytostatics
description: Overview of common chemotherapeutic agents and their molecular targets.

title: C3 deposits in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
description:
Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

title: Choriocarcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of testicular tumor specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Cytotrophoblasts are visible throughout the tumor in the form of polygonal-shaped cells with pale cytoplasm, enlarged oval nuclei, and distinct cell borders (examples indicated by arrowheads). Syncytiotrophoblasts are visible as multinucleated cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (examples indicated by green overlay) surrounding the mononuclear cytotrophoblasts.

These findings are suggestive of choriocarcinoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemical findings (positive for β-hCG).

title: Enterobius vermicularis eggs
description:
Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

title: Causes of atelectasis
description:
1. Obstructive atelectasis: foreign body aspiration results in airflow obstruction, poor ventilation, and atelectasis.

2. Non-obstructive atelectasis:
A) Compression atelectasis: A pleural effusion causes increased intrathoracic pressure actively forcing air out of the alveoli.
B) Relaxation atelectasis: A pneumothorax disrupts the contact between the visceral and parietal pleurae, resulting in passive atelectasis.
C) Cicatrization atelectasis: Generalized parenchymal fibrosis impairs full expansion of the right lung.
D) Adhesive atelectasis: Increased surface tension due to a deficiency of surfactant leads to generalized alveolar collapse.

title: Telangiectasia
description:
Small dilated blood vessels with a threadlike appearance are visible.

This is the typical appearance of telangiectasia.

title: Eye signs in leptospirosis (conjunctival suffusion)
description:
The bulbar conjunctiva is diffusely erythematous bilaterally, which is characteristic of conjunctival suffusion. There are areas of subconjunctival hemorrhages, especially in the perilimbal regions. Yellowing of the sclera is also visible, indicating scleral icterus. There is no evidence of ocular discharge.

Conjunctival suffusion and icterus, with or without subconjunctival hemorrhages, are characteristic ocular manifestations of leptospirosis.

title: Collagen synthesis
description:
Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

title: Maturation phase of wound healing
description: Scar tissue formation occurs as type I collagen replaces type III collagen in the connective tissue. The scar tissue is covered by epidermis, but it lacks melanocytes and skin appendages such as hair follicles or cutaneous sweat glands.

title: Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis
description:
Photomicrograph of a thyroid biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

A noncaseating granuloma composed of inflammatory cells (examples indicated by white arrowheads) engulfing colloid (acellular, pink, glassy substance; green overlay), numerous multinucleated giant cells (examples indicated by blue overlay), and a rim of fibrous tissue (yellow overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. The follicles in the region of the granuloma have been destroyed. Normal thyroid follicles (examples indicated by black arrowheads) are visible on the left.

This granulomatous destruction of thyroid tissue is characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis).

title: Proliferative phase of wound healing
description: Granulation tissue develops during the proliferative stage. It consists of macrophages, fibroblasts, and lymphocytes. Granulation tissue is abundant in blood capillaries and type 3 collagen fibers. Epidermal stem cells at the wound margins proliferate to renew the epidermis at the wound site. Secretion of collagenase facilitates clot degradation. Wound contraction occurs as collagen synthesis increases and pulls the wound edges together. This process is facilitated by myofibroblasts.

title: Leishmania major
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Ovoid, dark purple inclusions (examples indicated by white arrows) are visible within macrophages. The nuclei (green overlay) appear normal.

This appearance is typical of amastigotes, the intracellular, nonmotile form of the parasite Leishmania major.

title: Pathophysiology of transudate versus exudate
description:
Normal: Capillary hydrostatic pressure (driving fluid out of capillaries) and capillary oncotic pressure (keeping fluid within capillaries) are roughly balanced.

Transudate is extravascular fluid caused by increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (e.g., in congestive heart failure) or decreased capillary oncotic pressure (e.g., in hypoalbuminemia). Transudate has a low protein and cell content and, therefore, tends to be clear.

Exudate is extravascular fluid caused by increased capillary permeability (e.g., secondary to inflammation or malignancy). Exudate has a high protein and cell content and, therefore, tends to be yellow or cloudy.

title: Giardia lamblia
description:
Photomicrograph of a laboratory culture (Giemsa stain; 100x magnification)

Eleven pear-shaped trophozoites, each with four pairs of flagella (black arrows), two nuclei of equal size (green overlay), and one or two median bodies (hatched green overlay), are visible.

These features are characteristic of Giardia lamblia trophozoites.

title: Insulin receptor activation
description:
Binding of insulin to the insulin receptor (tetrameric receptor tyrosine kinases of two α subunits and two β subunits):

(1) Resting state

(2) Binding of an insulin molecule to the extracellular α subunits → receptor undergoes conformational change → activation of tyrosine kinase domains (β subunit), which self-phosphorylate (autophosphorylation)

(3) Tyrosine kinase domains activate insulin receptor substrate (IRS) → activation of intracellular signal transduction pathways, especially Ras and protein kinase B (PKB)

title: Mechanism of action: drugs used in Parkinson disease
description:
Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

title: Ligaments of the knee
description:
A: anterior cruciate ligament
B: lateral meniscus
C: fibular collateral ligament
D: posterior cruciate ligament
E: medial meniscus
F: tibial collateral ligament

title: Mechanism of action: anticonvulsant drugs
description: Anticonvulsants act to either reduce excitatory signals (left) or amplify inhibitory signals (right).

title: Receptor-mediated endocytosis
description:
(A) Receptor-mediated endocytosis:
(1) Extracellular ligands bind to phagocyte membrane receptors.
(2) The ligand-receptor complex mediates clathrin-pit formation.
(3) Clathrin molecules attach to the membrane via adapter proteins and the clathrin-coated vesicle is internalized.
(4) Clathrin molecules detach from the vesicle and are recycled back to the cell membrane.
(5) Cell membrane ligands and receptors dissociate and separate into two endosome vesicles.
(6) The endosome containing the foreign particles is transported to the lysosomes or Golgi apparatus for processing.
(7, 8) The membrane proteins (i.e., receptors) from the empty endosome are recycled back into the cell membrane.

(B) Clathrin structure: Clathrin is composed of three heavy and three light chains, which together form a triskelion (three-legged shape).

(C) Clathrin-coated vesicle: Clathrin molecules form a three-dimensional network around the vesicle. The protein dynamin assembles as a ring around the neck of the bud, which is then pinched off as a vesicle.

title: Basal ganglia (coronal section)
description: Coronal section; frontal view

title: Amino acid derivatives
description: Important cofactors and constituents appear in blue boxes.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy sample (H&E stain) from a blister

Epidermis (purple region on the superior aspect; E):
– Suprabasal cleft (yellow overlays): A split above the basal layer of the epidermis that has led to blister formation is visible.
An unruptured blister can be seen on the right; a ruptured blister is visible on the left.
– Acantholysis: detached free-floating cells within the blisters
– Tombstone effect (green outlines): Keratinocytes of the basal layer are arranged in a single row of dark blue cells lining the inferior aspect of the blisters.
– An inflammatory infiltrate is visible through all layers of the epidermis.

Dermis (pink region on the inferior aspect; D): intact with minimal inflammatory infiltrate

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris, which is caused by a loss of desmosomes and thus cell adherence.

title: Acute pyelonephritis
description:
Photomicrograph of a renal tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain, very high magnification)

Areas of neutrophilic infiltration are visible throughout the renal interstitium (example indicated by hatched green overlay), especially in the tubules (example indicated by green overlay), which appear dilated.

These findings suggest acute pyelonephritis.

title: Goblet cells in the small intestine
description:
Photomicrograph of jejunal mucosa (periodic acid-Schiff stain; 200x magnification)

Intestinal villi (indicated by green overlays) are visible as finger-like projections. Crypts of Lieberkuhn (intestinal glands) can be seen as epithelial invaginations (indicated by red overlays) into the lamina propria. The villi and crypts are predominantly lined by simple columnar cells (examples indicated by white arrowheads) with basophilic basal nuclei.
Interspersed between the columnar epithelial cells are goblet cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads), which contain mucus that has been stained deep purple.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Aphthous ulcers
description:
Two ulcers covered by a white membrane and surrounded by a red halo are visible on the oral mucosa.

Aphthous ulcers typically begin as erythematous macules.

title: Angle-closure glaucoma
description:
Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

title: Angiodysplasia
description:
Endoscopic view of the stomach

A superficial, cherry-red vascular lesion with a fern-like pattern can be seen on the gastric mucosa. There are no signs of active or recent bleeding. In the upper half of the image, a semicircular optical artifact is visible.

Blood vessels arranged in a fern-like pattern are characteristic of angiodysplasia.

title: Peyronie disease
description: Photograph of an erect penis showing an abnormal downward curvature.

title: Direct and indirect inguinal hernias
description:
Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

title: Renal oncocytoma
description:
Gross pathology specimen of a kidney (sagittal section)

A well-circumscribed, mahogany-brown tumor (green overlay) with a central scar (hatched green overlay) is visible.

These findings are characteristic of a renal oncocytoma.

title: Neuroendocrine tumor
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Multiple nests of small, round, monomorphic cells can be seen throughout the tissue (green hatched overlay). Some of these cells are arranged in rosette formations (green overlay). The chromatin is finely grained in the monomorphic cells (known as "salt-and-pepper chromatin"). Hyperemic capillaries between the cell nests indicate rich vascularization (examples indicated by green arrowheads).

These findings are consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor.

title: Hepatic cirrhosis with splenomegaly
description:
CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane)

Atrophy and nodularity (indicated by white arrows) are seen along the anterolateral margin of the liver. The spleen is enlarged (green overlay).

The findings are consistent with hepatic cirrhosis with portal hypertension and splenomegaly.

An additional finding is a small hypoattenuating lesion in the lateral segment of the left lobe.

title: Trichinella spiralis
description:
Photomicrograph of a striated muscle tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple encysted Trichinella spiralis larvae are visible throughout the sample. Most of the parasites are shown in cross-section (green overlay), some are visible in longitudinal section (green arrowhead).

title: Changes in liver metabolism due to risky alcohol use
description:
Risky alcohol use leads to an increased ratio of NADH to NAD+ (gray) and results in the following:

A) Fasting hypoglycemia: inhibition of the TCA cycle (green) due to impaired conversion of malate to oxaloacetic acid (OAA) results in impaired gluconeogenesis (red)
B) Lactic acidosis: ↑ conversion of pyruvate to lactate (yellow)
C) Ketoacidosis: Acetyl-CoA is shunted into the ketogenesis pathway (Blue) away from the now impaired TCA cycle (green).
D) Hepatosteatosis: ↑ fatty acids and ↑ glycerol-3-phosphate from acetyl-CoA and dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP), respectively, results in ↑ triglycerides (purple)

title: Mechanisms of action: antithyroid drugs
description:
Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.

Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.

title: Relative concentrations along proximal tubules
description: The graph illustrates the ratio of the concentration of a given substance (tubular fluid; TF) in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) in proportion to its concentration in the plasma (P) along the length of the PCT (expressed as percent of distance). The substance inulin is neither secreted nor absorbed, and the concentration of TF:P increases as water is reabsorbed from the PCT.

title: Attachments of menisci and cruciate ligaments of the knee
description:
Left: The menisci are anchored centrally in the intercondylar area (orange). The attachment points of the anterior (green) and posterior (blue) cruciate ligaments are also marked.

Right: The attachment points of the cruciate ligaments are marked.

title: Dashboard injury
description: Dashboard injuries occur when a force is directed posteriorly towards an internally rotated, flexed, and adducted hip. Potentially resulting damage includes posterior dislocation of the hip; damage to the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee; fracture of the acetabulum, femoral head, or patella; and sciatic nerve injury.

title: Extensor and flexor tendons of the finger
description: The extensor tendons are connected by the intertendinous connection. Annular ligaments stabilize the flexor tendons, which cross one another. The superficial flexor tendons attach to the middle phalanx and the deep flexor tendons to the distal phalanx.

title: Cholesteatoma
description: A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium that grows from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or mastoid. The presence of abnormal epithelium triggers an inflammatory response that can destroy surrounding structures such as the ossicles.

title: Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN)
description:
Fluorescence microscopy (immunofluorescence staining for C3; high magnification)

Granular deposits of C3 are visible, resulting in a starry sky pattern.

title: Comparison of the clearance levels of glucose, inulin, creatinine, and PAH
description: Clearance describes the assumed plasma volume that has been cleared by a substance within a certain period. It is a sensitive indicator for the assessment of kidney function.

title: Colorectal carcinogenesis pathways
description:
Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

title: Etiopathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease
description: The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

title: Regulation of iron metabolism
description: Intraluminal ferric iron (i.e., dietary iron or heme) is converted to ferrous iron (Fe2+) by ascorbate ferrireductase and transported into the enterocyte via the DMT-1 transporter. Fe2+ is then either stored as ferritin or transported to the circulation (shaded red area) to contribute towards hematopoiesis. This circulating Fe2+ from dietary or other sources (i.e., apoferritin stores in the liver, breakdown of hemoglobin) is then recycled to form new hemoglobin molecules within the medullary and extramedullary sites of hematopoiesis or exported and stored as ferritin within the hepatocytes. Iron metabolism is controlled by the hepcidin protein, which is produced in response to increased levels of plasma iron, inflammation, or the HFE protein, and acts to inhibit iron uptake into the circulation.

title: Direct and indirect Coombs tests
description:
A test used to detect hemolytic antibodies bound to RBCs (direct Coombs test) or freely circulating in the serum (indirect Coombs test).

1. The direct Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic antibodies or complement bound to the surface of a patient's erythrocytes. It is used to differentiate between autoimmune and nonimmune hemolytic anemias and to diagnose hemolytic diseases of the fetus and newborn.

2. The indirect Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic anti-RBC IgG antibodies (against foreign RBC antigens) present in a patient's serum. It is used to screen for maternal anti-D IgG antibodies (detection of hemolytic disease of the newborn) and to crossmatch blood before transfusions.

title: Minimal change disease
description:
Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus are intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is a typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.

title: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
description:
Electron micrograph

Ultrastructural findings of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis showing podocyte foot process effacement (thin black arrows) and protein reabsorption droplet (white arrow). Endothelial cells show tubuloreticular inclusions in the upper right-hand corner (star)

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is commonly seen in electron microscopy samples of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

title: Bilirubin metabolism
description:
(1) Hemoglobin is broken down into heme and globin in the spleen and, to a lesser extent, in the bone marrow.
(2) Macrophages break heme down into unconjugated bilirubin. Bound to albumin, unconjugated bilirubin is transported in the bloodstream and taken up by the liver.
(3) Bilirubin is conjugated in the liver and secreted in bile.
(4) In order to be secreted, conjugated bilirubin enters the blood to reach the hepatocytes with a direct connection to the bile canaliculi. At this stage, conjugated bilirubin is detectable in the blood.
(5) Bilirubin reaches the intestine via the bile. Intestinal bacteria convert bilirubin to urobilinogen.
(6) Most of the urobilinogen is converted into stercobilinogen and then stercobilin. Stercobilin is excreted via the stool, giving it its characteristic brown color.
(7) A smaller portion of urobilinogen is reabsorbed and follows two different paths:
→ (8) Most of it undergoes hepatobiliary recirculation, while the rest is filtrated in the kidney.
→ Or: (9) The remainder gets filtrated in the kidneys. in the urine, urobilinogen is oxidized to urobilin, which is responsible for the characteristic yellow color.

title: Fat metabolism
description:
Substances of energy excess (e.g., glucose, malonyl-CoA, citrate) ultimately inhibit pathways leading to energy production (e.g., beta-oxidation and the citric acid cycle) through activation of several key molecules: Increased levels of insulin and/or citrate → activation of the acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) enzyme via protein phosphatase 2 (PP2) or directly → formation of malonyl-CoA → inhibition of beta-oxidation within the mitochondria.

Substances of energy deficiency (e.g., glucagon, catecholamines, AMP/ADP) act to increase energy production via the upregulation of AMP-kinase (AMPK). AMPK acts to inactivate the ACC enzyme and promotes energy production via beta-oxidation.

title: Procoagulation-anticoagulation balance
description:
Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

title: Pyramidal tract
description: Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.

title: Hyperinflation due to foreign body aspiration
description: The foreign body functions as a one-way valve, allowing air to enter the lung during inspiration but blocking the passage of air back out during exhalation. This leads to hyperinflation of the lung on the side of the obstruction.

title: Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
description: Flowchart summarizing the biochemical and physiological effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and current pharmacological inhibitors (overlay).

title: HIV replication and mechanism of action of antiretroviral drugs
description:
1. Attachment: The viral envelope glycoprotein gp120 (cap) binds to CD4 receptors, which are present on certain cells. The gp120-CD4 complex then binds to the host chemokine receptor 5 (CCR5).
– CCR5 antagonists prevent viral attachment to the host cell.

2. Penetration: Viral binding to CCR5 causes a conformational change in the envelope gp41 (stalk), which enables HIV to fuse with and release its capsid into the host cell.
- Fusion inhibitors competitively bind to gp41 and prevent viral fusion with the host cell.

3. Uncoating of the viral capsid to release viral RNA

4. Reverse transcription: Viral RNA is transcribed into viral DNA by viral reverse transcriptase enzymes.
– Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI), nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NtRTI), and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) inhibit the viral reverse transcriptase enzyme.

5. Integration: Newly transcribed viral DNA is integrated into host DNA by viral integrase.
– Integrase inhibitors inhibit viral integrase.

6. Transcription: Newly integrated DNA is used as a template to create copies of viral RNA that will encode for viral proteins.

7. Translation: Newly transcripted viral RNA acts as templates for the synthesis of new viral proteins synthesis. Viral protease enzyme cleaves the long polypeptide chains into shorter, functional viral proteins (e.g., envelope proteins, enzyme proteins).
– Protease inhibitors inhibit viral protease and prevent the generation of functional viral proteins.

8. Release: New viral RNA and viral proteins use a portion of the host cell membrane as a viral envelope and then leave the host cell.

title: Brain herniation
description: Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

title: Mechanism of action: antimycobacterial drugs
description:
Rifamycin and streptomycin: inhibit RNA polymerase → reduction in protein synthesis
Dapsone: inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid, via competition with para-aminobenzoate → reduced nucleic acid synthesis
Isoniazid: a prodrug converted into the active form isoniazid by catalase-peroxidase (KatG), which prevents cell wall synthesis via inhibition of mycolic acid production
Pyrazinamide: mechanism unknown
Ethambutol: inhibits arabinosyltransferase → prevention of mycobacterial cell wall synthesis (bacteriostatic effect)

title: Anterior pelvic tender points
description:
Psoas major: two-thirds between anterior superior iliac spine and midline

Iliacus: one-third between the anterior superior iliac spine and the midline

Low ilium (psoas minor): anterior-superior aspect of the pubic ramus ∼ 2 inches lateral to the pubic symphysis

Inguinal: superior pubis near the medial end of the inguinal ligament

Low ilium flare-out: inferior-medial surface of the descending ramus of the pubic bone

title: Mechanism of action: nitrates and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors
description: Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

title: Location and microscopic anatomy of the adrenal gland
description:
Photomicrograph of the adrenal cortex (Ladewig trichrome stain; 100x magnification)

The adrenal gland consists of three layers.
– Zona glomerulosa: located directly beneath the capsule; consists of ovoid cells, which are arranged in clusters and produce mineralocorticoids
– Zona fasciculata: consists of cells that are arranged in bundles and produce glucocorticoids
– Zona reticularis: consists of cells arranged in cords, giving it a net-like structure; produces androgens

The adrenal medulla consists of cells that produce catecholamines.

title: Pressure-volume loops of the left ventricle in systolic and diastolic dysfunction
description:
The pressure-volume (P-V) loop in systolic dysfunction (yellow): Loss of contractility in systolic dysfunction reduces the slope of the line depicting the end-systolic P-V relationship. Therefore, the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) appears increased compared to the normal P-V loop (green). The end-diastolic volume (bottom right corner of P-V loop) is also increased because of normal venous return to a high end-systolic volume. This higher end-diastolic volume partially increases the stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

The P-V loop in diastolic dysfunction (blue): Increased stiffness of the ventricle in diastolic dysfunction means that the line depicting the diastolic P-V curve is shifted upwards and to the left. For any given diastolic volume, the ventricular pressure is higher in a dysfunctional heart compared to a healthy heart (green loop), and the end-diastolic volume is reduced compared to a healthy heart (bottom right corner of P-V loop). Reduced end-diastolic volume with preserved ejection fraction means that the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) will be reduced compared to a heart with normal diastolic function.

title: Posterior Chapman points (osteopathy)
description:
Posterior Chapman point locations

*Anterior vagina/clitoris Chapman point is shown on the posterior side.

title: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord
description:
Left illustration: anatomy of the inguinal canal and spermatic cord
The inguinal canal extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.
– Anterior wall: aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique muscle
– Posterior wall: the transversalis fascia
– Roof: the transversalis fascia, transversus abdominis muscles, and the internal oblique muscle
– Floor: inguinal ligament
– Content: in men, the ilioinguinal nerve, genitofemoral nerve, and spermatic cord; in women, the round ligament of the uterus
The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, three arteries (testicular artery, artery to the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery), the pampiniform plexus, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Right illustration: the three coverings of the spermatic cord
From superficial to deep, the coverings are the external spermatic fascia (orange), cremasteric fascia (blue), and internal spermatic fascia (green).

title: Trachea
description:
The trachea (windpipe) connects the larynx to the main bronchi. It is composed of the horseshoe-shaped cartilage rings that are held together dorsally by a plate of muscle and connective tissue (not shown). At the tracheal bifurcation, the trachea splits into the right and left main bronchus, with the latter following a more horizontal trajectory to accommodate the heart.

Note that the left lung main bronchus splits into two lobar bronchi and that the number and position of bronchopulmonary segments varies between the two lungs.

title: Tumor lysis syndrome
description: Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

title: Coronary blood supply
description: The obtuse marginal artery is also known as the left marginal artery, and the acute marginal artery is also known as the right marginal artery.

title: Posterior rib tender points
description: PR1–PR12: posterior rib angle of each named point

title: Smith fracture
description: Fracture of the distal radius with volar displacement of the distal radial fragment and dorsal angulation at the fracture site.

title: Colles fracture (distal radius fracture)
description: Fracture of the distal radius with radial and dorsal displacement. Commonly a result of falling onto the extended wrist.

title: Claw hand deformity
description:
The ulnar nerve supplies all the interossei, the 3rd and 4th lumbrical muscles, the hypothenar muscles, and the adductor pollicis.

Atrophy of the interossei in chronic ulnar nerve palsy causes guttering of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st webbed space. The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints, resulting in an ulnar claw hand, which is caused by a paralysis of the 3rd and 4th lumbricals.

title: Mechanism of action: depolarizing muscle relaxants
description:
Illustration of a neuromuscular junction

1. Normal neuromuscular transmission.
On receiving a neural impulse, the vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane of the motor neuron and release ACh into the synaptic cleft. The nicotinic ACh receptors, located on the postsynaptic membrane, are ligand-gated ion channels. When two ACh molecules bind to a nicotinic ACh receptor, the ion channel opens and Na+ influxes into the muscle cell, increasing its membrane potential. This depolarizes the muscle cell, thereby transmitting the nerve impulse to the muscle. Cholinesterase, present on the motor endplate, cleaves ACh into acetate and choline. Choline is taken up by the motor neuron and reused in the synthesis of more ACh.

2. Mechanism of action of a depolarizing muscle relaxant
Depolarizing muscle relaxants are ACh-receptor agonists. They bind to the ACh receptors and transmit the nerve impulse to the muscle cell, similar to normal neuromuscular transmission (see above). As they are not metabolized by cholinesterase, depolarizing muscle relaxants remain bound to the ACh receptor, which stays open, inhibiting repolarization of the muscle cell and resulting in persistent depolarization of the motor endplate and flaccid paralysis of the skeletal muscles.

3. Cessation of the effect of depolarizing muscle relaxants
Depolarizing muscle relaxants are cleared off by blood. With the next neural impulse, ACh is released into the synaptic cleft, which binds to the ACh receptor, thereby allowing normal neuromuscular transmission.

title: Mechanism of action: nondepolarizing muscle relaxants
description:
Illustration of a neuromuscular junction

1. Normal neuromuscular transmission
On receiving a neural impulse, the vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane of the motor neuron and release ACh into the synaptic cleft. The nicotinic ACh receptors, located on the postsynaptic membrane, are ligand-gated ion channels. When two ACh molecules bind to a nicotinic ACh receptor, the ion channel opens and Na+ influxes into the muscle cell, increasing its membrane potential. This depolarizes the muscle cell, thereby transmitting the nerve impulse to the muscle. Cholinesterase, present on the motor endplate, cleaves ACh into acetate and choline. Choline is taken up by the motor neuron and reused in the synthesis of more ACh.

2. Mechanism of action of a nondepolarizing muscle relaxant
Nondepolarizing muscle relaxants are competitive antagonists of ACh receptors. They compete with ACh to bind with nicotinic ACh receptors at the motor endplate and block the receptors. The ion channels do not open and the nerve impulse is not transmitted to the muscle cell (nondepolarization block).

3. Cessation of effect of nondepolarizing muscle relaxants on administering a cholinesterase inhibitor
Cholinesterase inhibitors bind to the cholinesterase enzyme and inhibit the breakdown of ACh within the synaptic cleft. ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft increases because there is less ACh breakdown. ACh is able to bind to ACHRs, allowing for normal neuromuscular transmission. The nondepolarizing muscle relaxants are removed by blood and lymph.

title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
description: Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

title: Ketone metabolism
description: Acetyl-CoA is metabolized within hepatocytes to produce ketone bodies (i.e., acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through the process of ketogenesis. The lack of thiophorase in hepatocytes prevents the consumption of ketone bodies within the liver. During states of ketosis, excess acetoacetate undergoes spontaneous decarboxylation into acetone, a volatile organic acid that can be eliminated through the respiratory system.

title: Examples of direct sympathomimetic drugs
description:
Norepinephrine exerts a greater effect on α-receptors than β-receptors. This causes an overall increase in systolic blood pressure (SBP; blue line), diastolic blood pressure (DBP; green line), and mean arterial pressure (MAP; yellow line), which results in a widened pulse pressure. A net increase in BP with minimal activation of β-receptors results in a decrease in heart rate (HR), known as reflex bradycardia.

Epinephrine activates α-receptors and β-receptors equally, causing an increase in SBP and MAP. Activation of β2-receptors results in an overall decrease in peripheral resistance (PR), resulting in a decrease in DBP. The action of epinephrine on β1-receptors leads to an increase in HR.

Isoproterenol has greater selectivity for β-receptors than α-receptors, resulting in an unopposed β2 decrease in PR and subsequent decrease in DBP. The large drop in PR triggers an increase in HR, known as reflex tachycardia. This increase in HR is further enhanced by isoproterenol action on β1-receptors.

title: Anterior lumbar tender points
description:
AL1 (internal oblique): medial to the anterior superior iliac spine

AL2 (external oblique): medial to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL3 (iliopsoas): lateral to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL4 (iliopsoas): inferior to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL5 (rectus abdominis): anterior surface of the pubis

title: Nasal meatuses and recesses
description: Lateral view of the left nasal cavity; turbinates removed

title: Anterior cervical tender points (osteopathy)
description:
AC1: high on the posterior edge of the mandibular ramus between the earlobe and angle of the mandible

AC2–AC6: anterolateral tip of the anterior tubercle of each named transverse process

AC7: superior surface of the clavicle (clavicular attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

AC8: medial head of the clavicle (sternal attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

title: Resting tension curve of the lung
description:
The combination of the resting tension curve of the lung (blue line) and the thorax (orange line) form the resting tension curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple line). The pressure-volume relationship apply to passive changes in the lung volume with relaxed respiratory muscles

All of the curves run in an S-like shape. However, in normal respiration, the shape is only noticeable in the curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple). In each of the curves, the compliance is highest at the steepest part of the curve (advantageous for resting breathing).
At the upper white dot, where the resting tension curve of the thorax passes by 0 in pressure, the thorax is in resting position. At the lower white dot, where the resting tension curve of the respiratory tract passes by 0 in pressure, the elastic forces of the thorax and of the lung are balanced (respiratory rest position).

With maximum expiration, the resting tension curve of the lung reaches 0 in pressure. Negative qualities would only occur with a collapse of the alveoli.

TV=tidal volume; FRC=functional residual capacity; VC=vital capacity; RV=residual volume

title: Femoral canal
description: Topographic anatomy of the femoral canal region and surrounding regions. The femoral ring (yellow outline) forms the base of the femoral canal and is bounded by the inguinal ligament (anteriorly), lacunar ligament (medially), pectineal ligament (posteriorly), and fibrous septum of the femoral vein (laterally). The canal is wider in women. The cribriform fascia is not depicted in order to better visualize the saphenous opening.

title: Flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar junction
description:
Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

title: Vertical shears at the sphenobasilar junction
description:
Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

title: Torsion at the sphe­nobasilar junction
description:
Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

title: Compression at the sphenobasilar junction
description:
Demonstration of compression (restriction of motion) at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis.

In compression, the movement of the sphenoid and occiput is restricted. Lateral compressions can also be present that cause unilateral impaction.

title: Lateral shears at the sphe­nobasilar junction
description:
Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

title: Autonomic nervous system (overview)
description: Depicted here are the subtypes of adrenergic receptors (α and β) and cholinergic receptors (M: muscarinic, N: nicotinic), which trigger the organ response described when activated. The sympathetic chain is represented by the yellow chain of ganglia to the left of the spinal cord. Also depicted are cranial nerves (CN III, VII, IX, X) emerging from the brainstem.

title: Horseshoe kidney
description: Congenital abnormality of the kidney. Ventral view.

title: Clavicle fracture
description:
The junction of the medial second third and the lateral first third is the most common site of clavicle fractures, as depicted here. Distracting forces cause a downward dislocation of the lateral fracture fragment and an upward dislocation of the medial fracture fragment, resulting in the following clinical features:

- Sagging of the ipsilateral shoulder due to downward distracting force of the weight of the upper limb on the lateral fracture fragment
- Shortening of the ipsilateral shoulder due to the medial distracting force of the pectoralis major on the lateral fracture fragment
- Tenting of the skin over the fracture site due to the upward distracting force of the sternocleidomastoid on the medial fracture fragment

title: Lifecycle of Plasmodium falciparum (Malaria)
description:
Malaria is caused by plasmodia transmitted via the saliva of female Anopheles mosquitoes. During development, there is a generational (asexual/sexual reproduction) and host change (between mosquito and human).

Human host
Liver (exoerythrocytic) stage: Following a bite from an infected mosquito, sporozoites (spindle-shaped, infective pathogen) reach the liver via the blood or lymphatic system and mature into schizonts within the hepatocyte. Asexual propagation produces thousands of daughter cells (merozoites), which are transmitted to the bloodstream via merosomes. Plasmodium Vivax and Ovale are associated with the development of dormant stages (hypnozoites) which persist for several years in hepatocytes and later develop into schizonts.

Blood (erythrocytic) stage: Merozoites infect erythrocytes and develop into trophozoites, which then mature into schizonts. Asexual propagation produces merozoites, which are then released into the bloodstream via merosomes. This cycle repeats itself over a course of 48-72 hours causing periodic decay of erythrocytes and the resulting pathognomic spiking fevers of malaria.

Mosquito host
Ingested gametocytes mature into flagellated microgametes (♂) or macrogametes (♀) within the gastrointestinal tract of the mosquito. The mature sexual forms merge into a mobile zygote, which in turn develops into a sporozoite-containing oocyst. The sporozoites are released, enter the salivary glands, and may eventually be transferred to a new host.

title: Primary hemostasis
description:
(1) Tissue injury results in the release of von Willebrand Factor (vWF) from Weibel Palade bodies (WPB) in endothelium and α-granules in platelets. VWF subsequently binds to exposed collagen at the site of injury. Vasoconstriction (not shown here) occurs through both a neural stimulation reflex and a release of endothelin from damaged endothelial cells.

(2) Platelets bind to exposed vWF at the site of injury and undergo a conformational change.

(3) Activated platelets release a combination of factors, including adenosine diphosphate (ADP), calcium ions (Ca2+), and platelet-activating factor (PAF). ADP binds to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, inducing a translocation of GpIIb/IIIa receptors to the cell surface. These receptors are promoted by Ca2+ ions.

(4) The expression of GpIIb/IIIa receptors allows activated platelets to crosslink with fibrinogen as an intermediary. The action of PAF along with thromboxane A2 (TXA2) further promotes platelet aggregation.

Platelet plugs are reinforced with fibrin during secondary hemostasis.

title: Mechanism of action: drugs acting against primary hemostasis
description: Drugs that affect primary hemostasis interfere with platelet aggregation. They achieve this either by decreasing the expression of GpIIb/IIIa receptors using P2Y12 receptor antagonists, interfering with GpIIb/IIIa receptors directly using GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors, or by decreasing TXA2 production using cyclooxygenase inhibitors.

title: Congenital disorders affecting primary hemostasis
description: Red indicators link syndromes with their associated defective or absent molecules, according to which phase of primary hemostasis is affected (i.e., adhesion or aggregation)

title: Ventricular system of the brain
description: Within the brain, there are several interconnected CSF-filled spaces (ventricles). The largest of these are the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles), which are located within the cerebral hemispheres. The third ventricle lies in the diencephalon, between the two thalamic hemispheres, and has several recesses. The fourth ventricle is located in the rhomboid fossa (dorsal to the pons/medulla oblongata). The lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramina. The third ventricle is connected to the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct. The fourth ventricle also connects the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space (which is also filled with CSF) via several openings (e.g., the median aperture).

title: Cystic fibrosis sweat test
description: Sweating is induced using pilocarpine and an electrical current, and collected using preweighed filter paper covered with plastic wrap (to prevent evaporation) for up to 30 minutes. The concentration of chloride is measured and compared to reference ranges. A chloride concentration of ≥ 60 mmol/L reflects a likely diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

title: Cystic fibrosis pathophysiology
description: A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

title: Ocular ochronosis in alkaptonuria
description:
Areas of dark discoloration are visible on the sclera and episclera of both eyes.

Ocular ochronosis is a typical symptom of alkaptonuria.

title: Genital embryology (male)
description:
(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Mullerian ducts and differentiation of the Wolffian ducts
(3) Fully developed male urogenital organs

title: Genital embryology (female)
description:
(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Wolffian ducts and differentiation of the Mullerian ducts
(3) Fully developed female urogenital organs

title: Veins of the leg (dorsal aspect)
description:
The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~ 4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Small saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posteroior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins.
- Femoral vein: is the continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

title: Pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis
description:
(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

title: PAS-positive foam cells in Whipple's disease
description:
Photomicrograph (very high magnification, Periodic acid-Schiff stain) of a duodenal biopsy

Within the cytoplasm of the macrophages, granular PAS-positive material is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of Whipple disease, which is caused by Tropheryma whippleii.

title: Calcium phosphate crystals
description: Photomicrograph showing crystals with the appearance of wedge-shaped prisms (can also be described as blunt-ended needles), some bound together forming a rosette.

title: Corneal abrasion highlighted by fluorescein staining
description:
Slit-lamp photography of the left eye with fluorescein staining

A small area of green staining (black arrow) confirms a corneal abrasion. Significant conjunctival injection is also visible.

title: Cutoff value of an optimal screening test
description:
Graph showing the sensitivity and specificity of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: negative test result; red: positive test result)

- True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
- True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
- False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
- False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the disease

The cutoff value (i.e., the threshold at which a test is considered positive or negative) determines the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a test. A test is considered ideal for screening when its cutoff value balances the FP and FN rates, as depicted here.

title: Cutoff value of a highly specific test
description:
Graph showing the results of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: positive test result; red: negative test result)

- True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
- True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
- False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
- False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the disease

The cutoff value (i.e., the threshold at which a test is considered positive or negative) determines the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a test. Here, the cutoff value of the diagnostic test includes all the TNs (and no FPs), indicating that this is a highly specific test.

title: Cutoff value of a highly sensitive test
description:
Graph showing the sensitivity and specificity of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: positive test result; red: negative test result)

– True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
– True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
– False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
– False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the disease

The cutoff value of the diagnostic test includes all the TPs (and no FNs), indicating that it is a highly sensitive test.

title: Mechanisms of action of antibiotics on the bacterial ribosome
description:
Schematic indicating how various antibiotics inhibit the protein synthesis activity of the bacterial ribosome by their actions during the initiation phase (left) and the elongation phase (right). Note that the details of some of these interactions vary across the literature.

Interactions at the 50S bacterial ribosome subunit:
- Oxazolidinones block the formation of the initiation complex.
- Macrolides and lincosamides primarily act by blocking translocation (solid markers) but also block the formation of the initiation complex (dotted markers indicate that this is not their main mechanism of action).
- Amphenicols block the enzyme peptidyl transferase

Interaction at the 30S bacterial ribosome subunit:
- Aminoglycosides block the formation of the initiation complex, cause codon misreading, or inhibit translocation.
- Tetracyclines and glycylcyclines block aminoacyl-tRNA from binding to the ribosome acceptor site

title: Posterior thoracic tender points
description: PT1–PT12: the spinous and transverse processes of each named point

title: Copper metabolism in normal hepatocyte and hepatocyte affected by Wilson disease
description:
Left (physiologic):
(1) Copper ions are absorbed in the intestine and transported via the portal vein to the liver sinusoids, where they are taken up by the hepatocytes. (2) In the hepatocytes, copper ions enter the Golgi complex via the Wilson protein (ATP7B). (3) In the Golgi complex, the copper ions bind to apoceruloplasmin, thereby forming ceruloplasmin. (4) Excess copper is excreted into the bile via the Wilson protein. (5) Ceruloplasmin is secreted into plasma and spread throughout the body. (6) A small amount of unbound copper ions passes directly into the blood and is available as free serum copper.

Right (Wilson disease):
In Wilson disease, the Wilson protein is dysfunctional. Copper ions can neither be taken up by the Golgi complex (3) nor excreted into the bile (4). As a result, copper ions accumulate in the hepatocytes, which leads to hepatic damage.
