A large amount of excess, unbound copper ions passes directly into the bloodstream (6) raising the free serum copper concentration. This results in copper deposition in other organs.

title: Medial winging of the scapula
description:
When the patient is asked to place both palms against a wall and push, the medial border of the right scapula is abnormally prominent.

This is the characteristic appearance of scapular winging. It indicates a palsy of the serratus anterior, which is most commonly due to an injury of the long thoracic nerve.

title: Intracerebral mass with midline shift
description:
MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with primary CNS lymphoma

A mass with its epicenter in the region of the right basal ganglia shows intense contrast enhancement. There is a large amount of perilesional vasogenic edema. Mass effect has effaced the anterior horn of the right lateral ventricle and caused contralateral shift of the midline structures.

title: Pathophysiology of subclavian steal syndrome
description: Under normal conditions, the subclavian artery distributes blood equally to the arteries in the brain and arms (A). If there is stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, this leads to hypoperfusion of the upper extremities on the affected side (B). This is compensated by a contralateral circulation, in which there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side to the affected side via the vertebral arteries. As a result, there is hypoperfusion of the vertebrobasilar territory and corresponding central nervous system symptoms.

title: Tension pneumothorax
description: A tension pneumothorax develops secondary to one-way valve mechanism, which is caused by an injury to the lung parenchyma or chest wall and allows air to enter the pleural space during inspiration (valve open) but not escape during expiration (valve closed). Progressive accumulation of air within the pleural space causes an ipsilateral increase in intrapleural pressure, leading to ipsilateral lung collapse and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side. The mediastinal shift compresses the vena cavae, trachea, and the contralateral lung, leading to hemodynamic instability and hypoxia.

title: Arterial supply of the nasal septum
description:
The nasal septum is supplied by the following arteries:
- Anterior and posterior ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery
- Sphenopalatine branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery
- Superior labial branch of the facial artery (not shown here), which is also a branch of the external carotid artery

The Kiesselbach plexus is formed by the anastomoses between the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries. It is located in the anteroinferior region of the nasal septum and is the most common site of epistaxis.

title: Electro- and pharmacomechanical coupling of smooth muscle cell contraction
description:
Left: Different stimuli (neural, hormonal) cause calcium influx via calcium channels of the sarcolemma and sarcoplasmic reticulum in smooth muscle cells. Calcium binds to intracellular calmodulin and forms the calcium-calmodulin complex (Ca/CmC), which binds to the myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK), resulting in its activation. MLCK phosphorylates the light chain of the myosin filaments (under cleavage of ATP). This enables interaction between actin and myosin.

Right: A decrease in the intracellular calcium concentration results in a predominance of myosin light-chain phosphatase (MLCP) activity, which dephosphorylates myosin filament light chains, preventing interaction between actin and myosin. MLCP can also be activated by nitric oxide (NO), cGMP, or protein kinase G (PKG). It can be inhibited by Rho kinase and protein kinase C (PKC).

title: Development of the face and palate
description:
Top: In the 5th week, the stomatodeum is surrounded by the unpaired frontal process (pink), the paired upper jaw (yellow) and the paired lower jaw (blue). Two olfactory placodes form at the frontal process and develop into two olfactory pits, each bounded by the medial (green) and lateral nasal bulge (purple), in the 6th week. The medial nasal cavities merge to form the bridge of the nose, the philtrum, the nasal septum, and the primitive palate. The lateral nasal cavities develop later to form the sides of the nose (7th and 10th week).

Bottom: The secondary palate develops from the two palatal plates of the maxillary bulge. These eventually merge medially with each other and ventrally with the primitive palate.

title: Ulnar nerve neuropathy
description:
Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

title: Otosclerosis audiogram
description:
Audiogram of a patient with otosclerosis in the right ear.

Air conduction is reduced in the affected ear by approx. 35dB. Bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch). These are characteristic findings of otosclerosis, a condition that causes conductive hearing loss due to the fixation of the stapes to the oval window.

title: X-linked dominant inheritance
description: X-linked dominant inheritance, one copy of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. Both males and females can be affected. Affected males usually develop a severe, sometimes nonviable phenotype (as shown in the left half of the image) because they only have one X-chromosome. In an affected male, all the daughters (who receive X-chromosome from their father) but none of the sons (who receive Y-chromosome from their father) will be affected.

title: Sensorineural hearing loss
description:
Pure tone audiogram

Both ears show a parallel decrease of air and bone conduction in the higher frequencies. This finding indicates cochlear or retrocochlear damage (often seen in presbycusis).

title: Pyogenic granuloma
description:
Photograph of the left thumb

A 2-3 cm dark red, round, shiny mass can be seen at the interphalangeal joint.

This appearance is characteristic of a pyogenic granuloma.

title: Newborn with albinism
description: Absence of melanin results in white hair and very light skin. The eyes appear red because the absence of melanin in the iris and retinal pigment epithelium allows the underlying blood vessels to shine through in the right lighting conditions.

title: Dandy-Walker syndrome
description:
Cranial MRI of a young child (T2 weighted, sagittal view)

The posterior fossa and the pons appear cystic and hyperintense. The cerebellum also appears hypoplastic and the posterior fossa is enlarged.

This radiographic appearance suggests Dandy-Walker syndrome.

title: Sexual differentiation
description: Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia

title: Structure of renal parenchyma
description:
The kidney is divided into functional units called renal lobes, which consist of the cortex and the (outer and inner) medulla.

The nephron is the smallest functional unit of the kidney and consists of the renal corpuscle and tubule. Each tubule consists of several segments that extend from the cortex into the medulla and back up to the cortex.

title: Layers of the pelvic floor
description:
The pelvic floor is composed of three layers.
– Innermost (deep) layer: contains the pelvic diaphragm (levator ani and coccygeus)
– Middle layer: contains the urogenital diaphragm (the deep transverse perineal muscle)
– Outermost (superficial) layer: contains the external anal sphincter and the superficial transverse perineal, ischiocavernosus, and bulbospongiosus muscles

The pelvic floor has two openings: the anterior urogenital hiatus (through which the urethra and vagina pass) and the posterior rectal hiatus (through which the rectum passes).

title: Cross-section of skull and meninges
description:
From the outside in:
1. Scalp
2. Periosteum
3. Skull
4. Dura mater
5. Arachnoid mater
6. Pia mater

Diploic veins lie within the inner and outer tables of the skull. Dural venous sinuses lie between the inner and outer layers of the dura mater and are connected to the extracranial veins by emissary veins. Falx cerebri (as well as the falx cerebelli and tentorium cerebelli not shown in this image) are extensions of the dura mater. Arachnoid trabeculae are strands of delicate connective tissue that extend between the arachnoid and pia mater. Arachnoid granulations (villi) are finger-like projections of the arachnoid mater that invaginate into the dural venous sinuses.

title: Classifications of aortic dissection
description:
Stanford classification
– Type A: dissection involves the ascending aorta or aortic arch
– Type B: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)

DeBakey classification
– Type I: dissection involves the ascending and descending aorta
– Type II: dissection involves only the ascending aorta (up to the brachiocephalic artery)
– Type III: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)

Surgical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving the ascending aorta (i.e., Stanford A and DeBakey types I and II). Medical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving only the descending aorta (i.e., Stanford B and DeBakey type III).

title: Energy metabolism in a muscle cell
description: ATP production in muscle cells is predominantly achieved through glucose and fatty acid catabolism during aerobic conditions. ATP concentration within cells is maintained through phosphorylation of ADP by creatine kinase and adenylate kinase.

title: Anatomical snuff box
description:
A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.

Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)

The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.

title: Acute pericarditis
description: Inflammation of the pericardial layers of the heart that is often associated with pericardial effusion.

title: Testicular torsion and manual detorsion
description:
Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord containing testicular blood vessels, leading to testicular ischemia. Testicular torsion most commonly occurs in the medial direction.

Manual detorsion may be attempted before definitive surgical therapy (orchidopexy) if the duration of symptoms is less than six hours. This involves untwisting the spermatic cord by rotating the testis in a lateral direction.

title: Mechanisms of endobronchial obstruction in asthma
description: Endobronchial obstruction and the characteristic clinical presentation of asthma (i.e., dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, and persistent cough) are caused by bronchospasm, mucosal edema, and increased mucus production (bronchial hypersecretion).

title: Muscles of the pharynx
description:
The muscles of the pharynx can be divided into two groups:
- Pharyngeal constrictors (intrinsic muscles): the circular muscles, which include the superior, middle, and inferior pharyngeal constrictors. Sequential contraction of the constrictors during deglutition pushes the bolus into the esophagus.
- Pharyngeal elevators (extrinsic muscles): the longitudinal muscles, which include the stylopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus, and the salpingopharyngeus. Contraction of the elevators during deglutition elevates the larynx against the epiglottis, which protects the airway as well as widens and shortens the pharynx to make room for the bolus.

The pharyngeal muscles are supplied by the vagus nerve, with the exception of the stylopharyngeus, which is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

title: Superficial extensors of the forearm
description:
Right forearm; dorsal view

Other muscles that are part of the superficial extensor compartment of the forearm but not depicted here are the extensor carpi radialis longus muscle, extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle, and brachioradialis muscle.

title: Major salivary glands
description:
There are three paired salivary glands.

The parotid gland is pyramidal in shape, located below the external auditory meatus, and extends dorsally into the retromandibular groove and ventrally onto the anterior surface of the masseter. The parotid duct (Stenson duct) emerges from the anterior edge of the gland, turns medially at the anterior edge of the masseter, and enters the oral cavity adjacent to the second maxillary molar after piercing through the buccinator muscle. Accessory parotid glands are common, are most commonly located anterosuperior to the main parotid gland, and drain into the main parotid duct.

The submandibular gland is located in the submandibular triangle and wraps around the posterior free edge of the mylohyoid, which divides the gland into superficial and deep parts. The submandibular duct (Wharton duct) arises from the deep part of the gland and opens into the oral cavity on either side of the lingual frenulum.

The sublingual gland is located beneath the tongue, between the mandible and the genioglossus. It drains into the oral cavity through numerous small ducts (ducts of Rivinus) that open into the floor of the mouth and through a large duct (Bartholin duct) that drains into the submandibular duct.

title: Hematopoiesis and important cytokines
description: Hematopoiesis is the process by which pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow differentiate into two main blood cell lineages: myeloid and lymphoid. The most important cytokines involved at various stages of the process are depicted here.

title: Gastroprotective therapy
description:
Therapeutic approaches include:
– Direct (e.g., proton pump inhibitors) and indirect (e.g., H2 blockers, somatostatin analogs, prostaglandin analogs, atropine) suppression of parietal cell acid production
– Acid neutralization (e.g., antacids)
– Gastric mucosal barrier reinforcement (e.g., prostaglandin analogs)
– Direct coating of gastric mucosal surfaces (e.g., sucralfate, bismuth)
– Disruption of parasympathetic innervation via vagotomy

title: Arterial blood supply of the scaphoid bone
description:
The scaphoid is supplied primarily by branches of the radial artery. As illustrated here, the superficial palmar branch penetrates the bone from the palmar side and the dorsal carpal branch from the dorsal side, both at the distal pole. There may, however, be significant variation, both in which radial branches are the principal contributors and in their branching patterns.

Because the arterial blood supply of the scaphoid flows from the distal pole to the proximal pole, more proximal scaphoid fractures are at higher risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.

title: Deep flexors of the forearm
description: Right forearm; ventral view

title: Ringed sideroblast
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Prussian blue stain; very high magnification)

A large nucleated red blood cell precursor with a perinuclear ring of granules is visible in the center of the image. These are most likely iron granules that have stained a bright light blue with the iron-specific Prussian blue stain. Several nucleated red blood cells are also visible at the periphery of the image.

A perinuclear ring of iron granules in a red blood cell precursor is the characteristic appearance of a ringed sideroblast.

title: Kernig sign
description: The Kernig sign can be assessed using two methods. In the first method (A), the extended leg is passively elevated at the hip joint. If there is pain, there is reflex flexion of the knee. Alternatively (B), the Kernig sign can be assessed by flexing the hip and knee at a 90° angle. Subsequent extension of the leg causes stretching of the nerve roots or meninges, which can result in pain and muscle guarding against extension.

title: Reactive gliosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a brain biopsy sample (H&E stain)

Numerous deeply staining nuclei surrounded by unstained areas are visible throughout the microscopic field. This “naked nuclei” appearance is characteristic of astrocytes on an H&E stain.

Astrocytic proliferation and hypertrophy (astrocytosis) indicate reactive gliosis (or CNS scarring), which occurs secondary to CNS injury.

title: Purine nucleotide degradation
description:
Purine nucleotides are degraded in several steps into uric acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Purine nucleotides (e.g., AMP, IMP, XMP, and GMP) are converted into purine nucleosides. This conversion occurs through hydrolytic cleavage of the phosphate residue and is catalyzed by nucleotidases.

Purine nucleosides are then cleaved into free bases (e.g., hypoxanthine, xanthine, and guanine) by nucleoside phosphorylases.

Xanthine is then oxidized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, the uric acid is partially reabsorbed, and the rest is excreted in the urine.

title: Overview of purine and pyrimidine bases
description: The bases of the nucleic acids DNA and RNA are derivatives of purine and pyrimidine. DNA consists of the purine bases adenine and guanine and the pyrimidine bases cytosine and thymine. RNA contains the pyrimidine base uracil instead of thymine, with the remaining three bases being the same as those found in DNA. Purine bases also include hypoxanthine and xanthine, which are not DNA components, but represent intermediate products of purine base degradation.

title: Insulin secretion pathway
description:
Insulin secretion is stimulated by an increase in blood glucose levels.

Glucose enters pancreatic β cells via GLUT2 transporters and is metabolized to generate ATP. Intracellular ATP binds to and blocks ATP-sensitive K+ channels, increasing the intracellular K+ concentration and raising the membrane potential until depolarization occurs. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels open in response to depolarization and Ca2+ enters the pancreatic β cells. Increased intracellular Ca2+ concentration triggers the fusion of insulin-containing secretory granules to the cell membrane, resulting in exocytosis of insulin into the bloodstream.

title: Brachial plexus
description:
A: Upper trunk
B: Lower trunk
C: Long thoracic nerve
D: Posterior cord
E: Axillary nerve
F: Radial nerve
G: Musculocutaneous nerve
H: Median nerve
I: Ulnar nerve

title: Carpal tunnel syndrome
description:
Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).

It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

title: Open and closed pneumothorax
description:
Open pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through an unsealed defect in the thoracic wall (e.g., following penetrating trauma).
Closed pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through a breach in the visceral pleura (e.g., ruptured pulmonary bulla).

title: Muscles of mastication
description:
Origin and insertion of the muscles responsible for movement of the jaw at the temporomandibular joint (origin → insertion)

1. Temporalis: temporal fossa → mandible (ramus and coronoid process)
2. Masseter: zygomatic arch → mandible (ramus, angle, and coronoid process)
3a. Medial pterygoid: maxillary tuberosity and palatine bone (superficial head), sphenoid bone and palatine bone (deep head) → mandible (medial surface, angle, and ramus)
3b. Lateral pterygoid: infratemporal fossa (superior head) and pterygoid plate (inferior head) → mandible (neck and temporomandibular joint)

title: Etiological classification of pneumothorax
description:
1. Spontaneous pneumothorax: The accumulation of air within the pleural space without an external precipitating event.
– Primary spontaneous pneumothorax: no known underlying lung disease (e.g., rupture of a previously asymptomatic subpleural apical bleb).
– Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax: A complication of known, underlying lung disease (e.g., emphysema, Pneumocystis pneumonia).
2. Traumatic pneumothorax: The accumulation of air within the pleural space; secondary to chest trauma.
3. Iatrogenic pneumothorax: The accumulation of air within the pleural space; secondary to an iatrogenic intervention (e.g., thoracocentesis, pleural/lung biopsy).

title: Superficial flexors of the forearm
description: Right forearm; ventral view

title: Respiratory (oxidative) burst
description:
I: Activation of NADPH oxidase produces superoxide radicals, a process known as a respiratory or oxidative burst
II: Superoxide dismutase catalyzes superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
III: Myeloperoxidase, released by azurophilic granules, converts H2O2 to hypochlorous acid (HClO), a potent antimicrobial agent.
IV–VI: Superoxides are detoxified through a series of redox reactions, replenishing the NADPH consumed during the respiratory burst.

title: Epigastric hernia
description: Herniation of intraabdominal contents through the linea alba, between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus.

title: Diastasis recti
description: There is an abnormally large separation (>2 cm) between the two rectus abdominis muscles. This results in protrusion of intra-abdominal contents through the linea alba on straining (e.g., coughing, sitting up from a reclined posture), causing a midline bulge. The abdominal fascias (not shown here) remain intact.

title: Phases of gastric acid secretion
description:
Gastric acid secretion is increased in response to the thought, sight, and smell of food (cephalic phase), the entry of food into the stomach (gastric phase), and, to a lesser extent, by the entry of chyme into the small intestine (intestinal phase). Acetylcholine, gastrin, and histamine are the main stimulators of HCl secretion.
Gastric acid secretion is predominantly inhibited in the intestinal phase by the secretion of counterregulatory hormones (somatostatin, secretin, GIP, and cholecystokinin) by the enteroendocrine cells of the small intestine.

title: ABO blood group system
description: The ABO blood group system classifies four blood types (ABO phenotypes): O, A, B, and AB. These blood types are determined by the presence of antigens A and/or B on the surface of RBCs and the presence of antibodies against the antigens that are absent from the surface of an individual's RBC. Specific genes (ABO genotype) determine the expression of A and B surface antigens. ABO antibodies can cause potentially life-threatening agglutination and hemolysis upon contact with their corresponding antigen (e.g., the anti-A antibody will react with antigen A).

title: Coronal section of the brain
description:
Gross specimen of a brain (coronal section)

A: thalamus
B: substantia nigra
C: caudate nucleus
D: internal capsule
E: putamen

title: Types of breech presentation: complete breech
description: Both hips and knees are flexed with the feet close to the buttocks.

title: Cholelithiasis, cholangitis, and biliary pancreatitis
description:
Cholelithiasis: the presence of gallstones within the gall bladder
Cholangitis: ascending biliary tract infection (orange shading) secondary to choledocholithiasis
Biliary pancreatitis: Pancreatic outflow obstruction secondary to choledocholithiasis allows for activation of pancreatic zymogens, resulting in pancreatic inflammation (orange shading).

title: Reactive lymphocytes in infectious mononucleosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (H&E staining; high magnification)

Two reactive lymphocytes (example indicated by arrowhead) are visible in the center of the image. These lymphocytes are abnormally large and have an irregular border (black dashed outline) due to their increased friability. They also have deeply basophilic cytoplasm and large nuclei (yellow overlay), which may be clefted.

Reactive lymphocytes are typically seen in viral infections such as infectious mononucleosis (most common), CMV infection, and HIV, but they can be seen in bacterial infections and drug reactions as well.

title: Constrictive population pyramid
description:
This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.

This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.

title: Sacral plexus
description:
A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the last two lumbar nerves and the first four sacral nerves (L4–S4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the sacral plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

Note that the nerve roots of the pudendal nerve are variably described in the literature as S2-S4 or S1-S4 (as depicted here).

title: Oxygen dissociation curves for hemoglobin and myoglobin
description: The oxygen dissociation curves of hemoglobin and myoglobin show different affinities for O2 in venous blood from peripheral tissues. Increasing partial oxygen pressure (pO2) corresponds with a sharp increase in the O2 affinity of myoglobin (red curve). The increase then levels off. In venous blood from peripheral tissue, myoglobin O2 affinity is high. While the oxygen affinity for myoglobin sharply increases at low partial oxygen pressure levels, the hemoglobin curve (green curve) has a sigmoidal shape (s shape). At low partial oxygen pressure levels, the curve increases gradually, whereas it is significantly steeper at higher partial oxygen pressure levels, as in venous blood from peripheral tissue. The hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve then reaches a plateau at higher partial oxygen pressure levels. In arterial blood from the lungs, the partial oxygen pressure level is rather high, which corresponds to a high oxygen affinity in both myoglobin and hemoglobin.

title: Expansive population pyramid
description:
This population pyramid has a wide base, which indicates a greater proportion of individuals in younger age categories than in older age categories.

This distribution reflects a population with high birth rates and low life expectancy, which indicates rapid population growth.

title: Bohr and Haldane effects
description:
The Bohr and Haldane effects are essential for CO2 and O2 transport within the blood and the appropriate exchange of these gases in the lungs and peripheral tissues. The key mechanism of both effects is the fact that Hb affinity to O2 changes depending on the environment.

Bohr effect: The affinity of Hb for O2 decreases as concentrations of CO2 and/or H+ increase. This typically occurs in peripheral tissues and allows O2 to be supplied more easily to the tissue (since O2 is more readily released from Hb).

Haldane effect: Deoxygenated Hb has a higher affinity for CO2 than oxygenated Hb. Since deoxygenated Hb is typically present in peripheral tissue (rather than in the lungs, where pO2 is high), uptake of CO2 is facilitated there. CO2 is then transported to the lungs, where it easily dissociates from Hb and is exhaled.

title: Biosynthesis of vitamin D
description:
Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is mainly synthesized in the body, but it can also be taken up with food and supplements.

Endogenous vitamin D synthesis involves a series of steps:
1. provitamin D3 (7-dehydrocholesterol) is synthesized from cholesterol in the liver and the skin.
2. provitamin D3 is converted in the skin with the help of UV radiation to vitamin D3.
3. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) in the liver (by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase)
4. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3, which is biologically active) in the kidneys (by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase). Parathyroid hormone and cAMP promote this last step by stimulating 1α-hydroxylase. Calcium, phosphate, and FGF-23 inhibit 1α-hydroxylase.

title: Blood supply and lymphatic drainage of the anal canal
description:
Illustration depicting the dual lymphovascular supply of the anal canal

The anal valves form the pectinate line (seen as a longitudinal scalloped line), which divides the anal canal into upper and lower parts.

Arterial supply
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal artery (a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery)
- Middle rectal artery (a branch of the internal iliac artery)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal artery (a branch of the internal pudendal artery)

Venous drainage (site of porto-systemic anastomosis)
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal vein (drains into the inferior mesenteric vein, which drains into the portal vein)
- Middle rectal vein (drains into the internal iliac vein, a systemic vein)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal vein (drains into the internal pudendal vein, a systemic vein)

Lymphatic drainage
Above the pectinate line: into the internal iliac and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
Below the pectinate line: into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes

title: Types of placenta previa
description:
Schematic frontal section of the uterus (above) and speculum examination with view of the external cervical os (below). Placenta previa is classified based on how much of the cervical os is covered by the placenta.

Low-lying placenta: The lower edge of the placenta is ≤ 2 cm from the internal cervical os.
Marginal placenta previa: The placenta reaches the internal cervical os.
Partial placenta previa: The placenta partially covers the internal cervical os.
Complete previa (total previa): The placenta completely covers the internal cervical os.

title: Peritoneal localization of abdominal organs
description:
- Intraperitoneal organs: enveloped by visceral peritoneum; the intraperitoneal organs of the alimentary canal are attached to the mesentery.
- Primary retroperitoneal organs: not covered by visceral peritoneum and not attached to the mesentery.
- Secondary retroperitoneal organs: organs that were intraperitoneal in utero but became retroperitoneal after fusion of the mesentery with the posterior abdominal wall.
- Subperitoneal organs: partially covered by visceral peritoneum.

title: Sympathetic innervation of the adrenal medulla
description:
Innervation (left) and synaptic signaling of chromaffin cells (right) in the adrenal medulla.

1 and 2: Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the thoracic spine directly innervate the chromaffin cells, which are neuroendocrine cells similar in structure to sympathetic neurons.
3. An action potential opens a voltage-gated calcium channel.
4. The increased calcium ion concentration within the synaptic cell triggers the release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.
5. The nicotinic ACh receptors on the chromaffin cells are ligand-gated ion channels. The influx of sodium ions triggers depolarization of the cell, which leads to the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels.
6. The increased calcium ion concentration within the chromaffin cell triggers the secretion of norepinephrine and epinephrine from the secretory granules into the bloodstream. Approx. 80% of chromaffin cells produce epinephrine, while only 20% produce norepinephrine.
7. The predominant serum catecholamine is norepinephrine (80%). This increase in serum norepinephrine occurs because norepinephrine is also secreted as a neurotransmitter by the postganglionic fibers from the sympathetic trunk, while epinephrine is produced almost exclusively by the adrenal gland.

title: Blood supply of the thyroid gland
description:
Arterial supply: two paired arteries and a third inconsistent artery
- The superior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the external carotid artery and enters the thyroid gland at the superior pole.
- The inferior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the thyrocervical trunk (a branch of the subclavian artery) and enters the thyroid gland posteriorly.
- The solitary thyroidea ima artery (unpaired) is present in < 5% individuals. It may arise directly from the subclavian artery (as shown here) or from the aortic arch or the brachiocephalic artery. It enters the thyroid at the inferior border of the isthmus.

Venous drainage occurs via a venous plexus on the anterior surface of the thyroid (plexus thyroideus impar) that is drained by three paired veins:
- The superior thyroid veins drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The middle thyroid veins also drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The inferior thyroid veins drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

title: Anatomy of the lymph node
description:
The parenchyma of the lymph node is divided into a B-cell zone (cortex), a T-cell zone (paracortex), and the marrow. The cortex contains primary and secondary lymph follicles with germinal centers, which allow affinity maturation of B cells. At the hilum (concave side), blood vessels enter and efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node. The entering artery and vein branch into a large capillary network. Special high endothelial venules in the paracortex allow for lymphocyte extravasation.

Afferent lymphatic vessels enter through the capsule at many points in the periphery and open into the subcapsular sinus. The cortical sinus runs from the cortex via the paracortex to the medullary sinus, which then drains into the efferent lymphatic vessel.

title: Competitive antagonism
description: Competitive antagonists are substances that decrease the potency of an agonist without altering its efficacy. The curve on the left illustrates the potency of the receptor agonist alone (A). The curve on the right illustrates the effect of a competitive antagonist (B) on a receptor agonist. In the presence of a competitive agonist (A+B), a higher dose of the receptor agonist is required to achieve the effect of the agonist.

title: Transduction (bacterial genetics)
description:
Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.

title: Lateral view of the cerebral lobes
description:
The 4 lobes of each cerebral hemisphere are separated by 3 main sulci:
–The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe.
–The lateral sulcus separates the temporal lobe from the frontal lobe and the parietal lobe.
–The parieto-occipital sulcus separates the parietal lobe from the occipital lobe.

title: Actinic cheilitis
description:
Four photographs of the lips of different patients (A. B, C, D)

In all patients, there is a loss of distinction of the vermillion border either focally (lower lip in C) or circumorally.
The angles of mouth (oral commissures) are characteristically spared.

A - A brown scaly lesion is visible on the lower lip.
B - The lower vermillion border is edematous. A grayish-white macule can be seen on the lower lip. Superficial ulceration with crusting is visible on the mid-upper and lower lips. Scaling and fissuring are also visible.
C - The lower vermillion border is edematous. The lower lip appears dry and brownish scales are visible laterally.
D - Multiple brown macules can be seen.

These features depict the various presentations of actinic cheilitis, a precancerous lesion of the skin caused by chronic sun damage.

title: Tarsal tunnel (malleolar canal) with flexor retinaculum of the foot
description:
Left foot (medial view)

The tarsal tunnel is composed of the calcaneus and the flexor retinaculum, which is a thick, oblique band of fascia that extends from the medial malleolus to the medial aspect of the calcaneus. It contains the following structures:
– Posterior tibial vein and artery
– Tibial nerve
– Tendons of the deep flexors of the lower leg: tibialis posterior muscle, flexor digitorum longus muscle, and flexor hallucis longus muscle

The plantar chiasm is where the tendon of the flexor digitorum longus muscle crosses the tendon of the flexor hallucis longus muscle.

title: Cryptorchidism
description:
Failure of one or both testicles to descend to their natural position in the scrotum. Most common variations (from top to bottom):

– abdominal testis (blue): the testicle is located proximal to the internal inguinal ring
– inguinal testis (green): the testicle is located inside the inguinal canal between the external and internal inguinal ring, preventing adequate mobilization (90% of cases)
– suprascrotal testis (purple): the testicle is located distal to the internal inguinal ring and above the scrotum

title: Lumbar hernias
description:
Superior lumbar hernia (Grynfeltt hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the superior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the 12th rib, the erector spinae muscle, and the internal oblique muscle

Inferior lumbar hernia (Petit hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the inferior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the iliac crest, the latissimus dorsi, and the external oblique muscle

title: Ligaments of the ankle and foot
description: Lateral view

title: Hammer toe and claw toe
description:
Common deformities of the lesser toes

Hammer toe: PIP flexion; DIP and MTP extension
Claw toe: PIP and DIP flexion; MTP extension
Mallet toe: DIP flexion; PIP and MTP extension

title: Peritoneal cavity (sagittal section)
description: The peritoneal cavity is the space between the parietal peritoneum, which lines the abdominopelvic cavity, and the visceral peritoneum, which invests the intraperitoneal organs. The visceral peritoneum also forms the mesentery, the greater omentum, and the lesser omentum. Intraperitoneal organs lie within the greater sac that extends from the diaphragm to the pelvis. The lesser sac (omental bursa) lies posterior to the stomach and the lesser omentum.

title: Lipogenesis in adipocytes
description:
Chylomicrons and VLDLs are lipoproteins that are particularly rich in triglycerides/triacylglycerols (TAGs). They carry TAGs from ingested food or the liver to the adipocytes, where membranous lipoprotein lipases (LPLs) break down the TAGs into free fatty acids, glycerol, and lipoprotein remnants.

The free fatty acids enter the cell by means of fatty acid transport proteins (FATPs), which also have an acyl-CoA synthetase activity (here shown in two steps). The resulting acyl-CoA and glycerol-3-phosphate (from glycolysis) are esterified into TAGs again.

To a lesser extent, acetyl-CoA generated in glycolysis also contributes to the intracellular synthesis of fatty acids and, thus, of TAGs.

GLUT4 = glucose transporter 4; GAP = glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate; DAP = dihydroxyacetone phosphate

title: Arterial supply of the brain
description:
Caudal view

The circle of Willis is formed around the pituitary stalk by the following paired arteries:
- Anterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the internal carotids)
- Internal carotid arteries (proximal to the origin of the middle cerebral arteries)
- Posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the vertebral arteries)

The anterior communicating artery (ventral to the optic chiasm) connects the anterior cerebral arteries.

The posterior communicating artery (a branch of internal carotid artery; lies on the lateral aspect of the pituitary stalk) connects the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery.

The basilar artery, formed by the fusion of the two vertebral arteries, lies in the midline groove of the dorsal aspect of the pons. Pontine and labyrinthine branches arise from the basilar artery.

The anterior spinal artery, formed by the fusion of the branches of the vertebral artery, lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord.

title: Iron deficiency anemia
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald-Giemsa stain)

Erythrocytes with different sizes (anisocytosis) and, in some instances, abnormal shapes (poikilocytosis, examples indicated by green overlays) are shown. Many erythrocytes have an increased zone of central pallor. There is a lymphocyte in the center of the image (large purple cell, red overlay) and multiple platelets throughout (smaller purple cells, examples indicated by black arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Transformation (bacterial genetics)
description:
Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

title: Transposition (bacterial genetics)
description:
Bacterial transposition is a process by which genetic information is exchanged between bacteria or within the genome of the same bacterium via transposons.

Transposons (transposable elements or jumping genes) are DNA segments that can be excised from one location of the genome and re-inserted into another, thereby altering genetic expression (e.g., antibiotic resistance). Their action is brought about by transposase enzymes.

First step: The transposase enzyme binds to inverted repeat sequences (IR) flanking the transposons.
Second step: Transposase catalyzes the excision of the transposon sequence from the bacterial genome.
Third step: The target insertion site is recognized by transposase enzymes, which also catalyze the re-insertion of the transposon at this site.

title: Pulmonary embolism: thrombus formation and embolization
description: Pulmonary emboli typically arise from thrombosed deep veins of the calf and travel toward the lungs through the inferior vena cava, right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary arteries. An embolus can lodge anywhere along its course toward the lungs or within the pulmonary arterioles, depending on its size. Common sites of embolism include the bifurcation of the pulmonary arteries (saddle thrombus), within the right and/or left pulmonary artery, and within the lobar, segmental, or subsegmental branch of the pulmonary arteries. The degree of hemodynamic compromise is proportional to the size of the vessel occluded by the pulmonary embolism.

title: Basal ganglia
description: Transverse section; cranial view

title: Oogenesis and spermatogenesis
description:
Primordial germ cells migrate to the gonads in utero and become oogonia (♀) or spermatogonia (♂).

Oogenesis: Within the ovaries, oogonia undergo mitosis in utero to form primary oocytes. After birth, primary oocytes undergo meiosis, which is arrested in prophase I until puberty. Meiosis I resumes shortly before ovulation and the resulting secondary oocyte remains arrested in metaphase II. Meiosis II is only completed shortly after fertilization to form an ootid. Each oogonium results in the formation of one ootid and three degenerating polar bodies during oogenesis. In the absence of fertilization, the secondary oocyte degenerates.

Spermatogenesis: Within the testes, spermatogonia remain inactive until puberty. At puberty, spermatogonia undergo mitosis to form primary spermatocytes, which then undergo meiotic division to form four spermatids within a time span of 64 days. Spermatids develop into spermatozoa under the influence of testosterone (spermiogenesis).

title: Mechanism of action: botulinum toxin
description:
Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

title: Varicose veins
description:
Photograph of the medial aspect of the ankle

Multiple dilated and tortuous veins are visible around the medial malleolus.
Numerous bluish telangiectasias can be seen toward the inferior spect, while reddish-brown pigmentation can be seen adjacent to the Achilles tendon.

These are typical features of chronic venous insufficiency due to varicose veins.

title: Anterior shoulder dislocation skeletal anatomy
description:
Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation.

title: Warfarin-induced skin necrosis
description:
A well-demarcated area of necrotic skin (eschar) on the dorsum of the thigh. The underlying skin is hyperemic and friable.

In a patient who recently received warfarin, such findings are characteristic of warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

title: Location of esophageal diverticula
description:
Esophageal diverticula can be classified according to location.

The upper esophageal diverticula are pharyngoesophageal pulsion diverticula. The upper esophageal diverticula at the Killian triangle, which lies between the thyropharyngeal and cricopharyngeal parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, are the most common type.

Middle esophageal diverticula are located at the tracheal bifurcation and are traction diverticula.

Lower esophageal diverticula are epiphrenic pulsion diverticula.

title: Papillary urothelial carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a bladder tumor biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

A thick papilla with a fibrovascular core (red overlay) can be seen in the center.
The urothelium (green overlay) appears hyperplastic and the normal stratification of the urothelial cells is absent.
The nuclei of the urothelial cells are large and deeply staining (nuclear atypia).
The basal cells of the urothelium are not in contact with the basement membrane (loss of polarity).

These features are characteristic of papillary urothelial carcinoma.

title: Mesoderm derivatives
description:
Adult derivatives of mesoderm (not all derivatives are shown)

Paraxial mesoderm derivatives include the vertebrae, annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral discs, and ribs.

Lateral plate mesoderm derivatives include the heart.

Intermediate mesoderm derivatives include the kidneys.

Somatic (somatopleuric) mesoderm derivatives include parietal (outer) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

Splanchnic mesoderm derivatives include connective tissue and smooth muscle of the intestinal wall, and visceral (inner) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

title: Renal infarction
description:
Photomicrograph of a renal biopsy sample (H&E stain)

The cells of the tubules and glomeruli show clumped and highly eosinophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells are either absent or palely staining. There is debris in some tubular lumens and thrombi are visible in the capillaries on the lower right. The main outlines of the tubules and glomeruli are still intact.

title: Wernicke encephalopathy
description:
Cranial MRI (T2-weighted; axial view)

Bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities are visible on the medial portions of the thalamus (green overlay).

This finding is characteristic of Wernicke encephalopathy.

title: Respiratory tree
description:
The trachea divides into two main bronchi that further divide into the lobar bronchi. The lobar bronchi then split into to the segmental bronchi that divide into the subsegmental bronchi. The walls of these sections consist of three layers: the respiratory epithelium, the cartilage plates, and the submucosa.
In the following sections of the respiratory tree, the cartilage plates are replaced by a strong layer of smooth muscle. The absence of cartilage defines the bronchioles. The terminal bronchioles branch into respiratory bronchioles, which eventually end in alveoli.

title: Olecranon bursitis
description: There is significant inflammation of the soft tissue overlying the left olecranon process, which appears erythematous and swollen.

title: Parasympathetic ganglia
description:
Parasympathetic nervous system with the most important ganglia and target organs:

The preganglionic neurons are located in the brainstem (cranial nerve nucleus) and the sacral spinal cord. Unlike the sympathetic ganglia, the parasympathetic ganglia are generally located near to or directly in the wall of their target organs.

In the cranial space, the preganglionic neurons are interconnected in the 4 head ganglia: ciliary ganglion (behind the eye), pterygopalatine ganglion (pterygopalatine fossa), submandibular ganglion (submandibular gland), or otic ganglion (base of skull).
The fibers are led by the oculomotor nerve, facial nerve, or glossopharyngeal nerve. The fibers of the 4th parasympathetic cranial nerve (vagus nerve) are switched in several other ganglia (not shown here).

In the caudal space, the parasympathetic nerve fibers are led with the splanchnic nerves and switched in the pelvic ganglion (= inferior hypogastricus plexus).

title: Arterial supply of the duodenum, pancreas, and spleen
description: Branches arising from the superior pancreaticoduodenal (celiac trunk) and inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (superior mesenteric artery) supply the pancreatic head and neck. These vessels also supply the duodenum. The dorsal pancreatic artery and the greater pancreatic artery supply the tail of the pancreas. The splenic artery supplies the spleen.

title: Hepatocellular adenoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a hepatic nodule (H&E stain)

Sheets of hepatocytes arranged in two-cell thick cords are visible.
The cytoplasm of most hepatocytes is pale or clear, indicating intracytoplasmic glycogen accumulation.
There is no nuclear atypia.
The normal hepatic architecture of hexagonal lobules with a central vein and surrounding portal triads is absent.

This disorganized mass of benign hepatocytes is the characteristic histological appearance of a hepatocellular adenoma.

title: Pressure curves of the left ventricle, left atrium, and aorta
description:
1: The mitral valve closes and ventricular contraction begins (ventricular systole).
1–2: There is an isovolumetric contraction of the left ventricle until its pressure is higher than that of the aorta.
2: The pressure within the left ventricle (blue line) exceeds that of the aorta, causing the aortic valve to open.
2–3: The ventricle continues to contract and ejects blood into the aorta, increasing the ventricular and aortic pressures.
3: The aortic valve closes when the ventricular pressure falls below the aortic pressure, marking the beginning of diastole.
3–4: Ventricular pressure falls rapidly with ventricular relaxation. There is a small upstroke in aortic pressure (yellow line) after the aortic valve closes (dicrotic notch), followed by a more gradual decrease in pressure because of its inherent vascular resistance.
4: The mitral valve opens when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and ventricular filling begins.

The atrial pressure curve (green line) shows three upstrokes.
– a wave: just before 1, when the left atrium contracts
– c wave: just after 1, due to transmitted pressure from the contracting ventricle
– v wave: at 4, when the atrium receives blood from the vena cava

title: Fetal and postnatal circulation
description:
Fetal circulation (left) is connected to the maternal circulation via the placenta. The umbilical vein delivers oxygen-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus, and the umbilical arteries return the blood to the placenta for oxygenation. Blood bypasses pulmonary circulation entering from the right to the left atrium via the foramen ovale. Deoxygenated blood entering the right atrium through the superior vena cava bypasses pulmonary circulation via the ductus arteriosus, which connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta.

Postnatal circulation (right) is formed under the influence of postnatal pulmonary ventilation and the disconnection of umbilical vessels. These alterations cause a change in pressure within the circulatory system, leading to the opening of the pulmonary circulation and obliteration of the umbilical vessels and bypass structures.

Blue: deoxygenated blood; Red: oxygenated blood; Pink: mixed blood

title: Pharyngeal arch derivatives
description: Clockwise from top left: nerve, skeletal structure, muscle, and artery derivatives of the pharyngeal arches.

title: Atrial flutter with a variable atrioventricular block
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Atrial rate of ~ 375/min and a ventricular rate of ~100/min
- Irregularly irregular rhythm (variable AV block with 3:1 and 4:1 conduction in a nonfixed pattern)
- Normal axis (R > S in leads I and II, R < S in aVF)
- Sawtooth P wave morphology (flutter waves), seen best here in V1
- Normal QRS complex morphology

These findings are consistent with atrial flutter with a variable atrioventricular block.

title: Curschmann spirals
description:
Photomicrograph of a sputum sample

Dark, spiral-shaped casts of mucus (Curschmann spirals) are visible.

Curschmann spirals are typically seen in the sputum samples of patients with bronchial asthma.

title: Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis regulation by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
description: Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate plays a central role in regulating glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. In the fed state, the level of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate produced from fructose 6-phosphate increases. Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate facilitates glucose breakdown by activating phosphofructokinase 1 (key enzyme of glycolysis). At the same time, it inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. In the fasting state, the level of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate decreases because it is converted to fructose 6-phosphate that forms part of the metabolic pathway of gluconeogenesis.

title: Femoral hernia
description:
Femoral hernia passes through the vascular lacuna (internal hernial orifice), below the inguinal ligament and usually medial to the femoral vein and runs through the femoral canal until it reaches the saphenous opening (external hernial orifice; approx. 2cm caudal).

The saphenous opening typically contains loose connective and fatty tissue as well as inguinal lymph nodes.

Due to the increased width of the female pelvis, and therefore larger vascular lacuna, femoral hernia occurs predominantly in women.

title: Mycosis fungoides
description:
Multiple, well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous patches are visible on the posterior thighs.

This appearance is typical of mycosis fungoides.

title: Pilocytic astrocytoma
description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar tissue (H&E stain)

There are numerous bipolar cells, composed of a central basophilic nucleus with eosinophilic pilocytic processes (examples indicated in green) arising from either end. The pilocytic processes are arranged in bundles, which resemble matted hair. The bright red-pink bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions (examples indicated by black arrowheads) in astrocytes and indicate intense gliosis (Rosenthal fibers).

These are the characteristic features of pilocytic astrocytoma.

title: Anatomy of the intercostal neurovascular bundle
description:
Illustration of the intercostal artery, vein, and nerve (forming the intercostal neurovascular bundle) within the costal groove

As the pathway of these structures follows the inferior edge of the ribs, medical interventions (e.g., chest tube insertion) are always performed along the superior edge of the rib. The order of the structures of the neurovascular bundle can be remembered using the acronym “VAN”: the intercostal vein (V) is superior, the artery (A) is in the middle, and the nerve (N) is inferior.

title: Lichen planus
description:
Ventral forearm of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules and plaques can be seen.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

title: Ventricular septation
description:
I: Development of the muscular interventricular septum and interventricular foramen
- The primary ventricle is a single cavity that is separated from the atrial cavity by the endocardial cushion. Ventricular septation begins with the formation of a muscular interventricular septum, which arises from the floor of the primitive ventricle and grows cranially toward the endocardial cushion. The interventricular foramen is the space between the endocardial cushion and the growing edge of the muscular interventricular septum and it allows for interventricular communication.

II: Development of the aorticopulmonary septum
- The aorticopulmonary septum develops from ridges of tissue derived from neural crest cells within the ventricular outflow tract (truncus arteriosus). These ridges are continuous with the bulbar ridges of the bulbar cordis (not shown here).

III: Development of the membranous interventricular septum and closure of the interventricular foramen
- The membranous interventricular septum develops from the bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
- The caudal end of the aorticopulmonary septum fuses with the muscular interventricular septum and closes the interventricular foramen.

IV: Division of the ventricular outflow tract
- The aorticopulmonary septum fuses and rotates 180°, dividing the outflow tract into the aorta (from the left ventricle) and pulmonary trunk (from the right ventricle).

title: Muscles of the hip and gluteal region
description: Dorsal view

title: Actinomycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain, high magnification)

An aggregate of basophilic bacteria with radially branching filaments is visible at the center, which has a cauliflower-like appearance (yellow overlay).
The bacteria are surrounded by numerous granulocytes, resulting in a lesion with a rosette-like pattern (green overlay).

This is the typical histopathological appearance of a yellow “sulfur granule” caused by actinomycosis.

title: Aortic arch derivatives
description:
The aortic arches develop in craniocaudal order, with the first two arches obliterating early. Not shown: a remnant of the first aortic arch forms part of the maxillary artery, and a remnant of the second aortic arch forms the hyoid artery. The second arch also forms the stapedial artery, which typically regresses around week 10 of development.

The third aortic arch gives rise to the common carotid and proximal internal carotid.

On the right, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to the proximal right subclavian artery. On the left, the fourth aortic arch gives rise to a portion of the aortic arch from left common carotid to left subclavian.

The fifth aortic arch either never develops or obliterates without giving rise to a vessel.

On the right, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the right pulmonary artery. On the left, the sixth aortic arch gives rise to the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus.

title: Fetal hematopoiesis
description:
Diagram of embryonic, fetal, and postnatal erythropoiesis

The graphs illustrate the various types and amounts of hemoglobin subtypes (ζ, ε, γ, β, and α) produced in different organs (yolk sac, liver, spleen, and bone marrow) during fetal development.

One important feature of fetal hemoglobin (HbF = α2 γ2) is its higher affinity for O2 due to reduced binding of 2,3-BPG, resulting in O2 being transferred from maternal hemoglobin (HbA1 = α2 β2 ) across the placenta to fetal hemoglobin.

title: Cheyne-Stokes respiration
description:
The respiratory amplitude graph (top panel) depicts inspiration as upstrokes and expiration as downstrokes, with the peak-to-peak amplitude of a single waveform representing the tidal volume of a single breath. In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, a crescendo-decrescendo pattern of tidal volumes alternates with periods of apnea.
The lower panel depicts the corresponding oscillation in oxygen saturation.

title: Innervation of the parotid gland
description:
Fibers supplying parasympathetic innervation originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and run with branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) before synapsing in the otic ganglion. Postsynaptic fibers join the auriculotemporal nerve (branch of mandibular nerve, V3) to reach the parotid gland.

Fibers supplying sympathetic innervation originate at spinal segments T1/T2 and join the sympathetic trunk before synapsing with postsynaptic neurons in the superior cervical ganglion. Postsynaptic fibers then reach the parotid gland with branches of the external carotid artery.

Some of the autonomic fibers also run with branches of the parotid plexus of the facial nerve in their further distribution within the gland. While the branches of the facial nerve pass through the parotid gland, sensory innervation is actually supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve.

title: Posterior mediastinal tumor
description:
CT of the thorax (axial view, with IV contrast)

A large mass (green overlay) is visible in the posterior mediastinum.

The most common posterior mediastinal mass is a neurogenic tumor (biopsy is necessary for confirmation).

title: Spigelian hernia
description:
CT abdomen (with IV and oral contrast; axial plane)

An anterior abdominal wall hernia (yellow overlay) containing fat is seen lateral to the left rectus abdominis muscle.

A Spigelian hernia occurs through a defect in the linea semilunaris, a curved vertical line at the lateral margin of each rectus abdominis muscle. Spigelian hernias are usually found in the region of the arcuate line, a horizontal line that demarcates the lower extent of the posterior layer of the rectus sheath.

title: Meningioma
description:
Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain)

Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (purple overlay) and sheets. A mass of disorganized cells is visible in the top right corner (yellow overlay). The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).

Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

title: Mechanism of action: antifungals
description:
Polyenes bind to ergosterol in the cell membrane, creating pores that disrupt the electrolyte balance, which results in cell death.
Echinocandins inhibit the enzyme β-glucan synthase, which is essential for fungal cell wall synthesis.
Allylamine derivatives and azoles inhibit the synthesis of ergosterol, the main steroid of the fungal cell membrane.
Griseofulvin disrupts fungal mitosis by interfering with the function of microtubules.
Flucytosine, which is converted to 5-fluorouracil within the fungal nucleus, is an antimetabolite, as it inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA.

title: Splenic laceration
description:
Abdominal CT scan (axial section; IV contrast) of a patient involved in a motor vehicle collision

There is a large splenic laceration (red overlay), identifiable as an irregular hypodensity within the spleen (white overlay).
The splenic capsule has ruptured posteriorly and anterolaterally, resulting in contrast extravasation (hyperdensities marked by a green overlay posteriorly and white arrowhead anterolaterally) and a subcapsular splenic hematoma (isodense fluid marked by a white dashed outline). Contrast extravasation indicates active hemorrhage.

This is the typical radiological appearance of a splenic laceration with a splenic hematoma.

title: Disease progression in type 2 diabetes
description: Early in the disease, there is an increase in β-cell function and insulin production as the body compensates for elevated glucose levels due to increasing insulin resistance. With time, compensatory mechanisms fail and β-cell insulin production falls, resulting in a steady increase in both post-meal and fasting glucose levels. Complications occur as a result of elevated blood glucose levels. Macrovascular complications can occur throughout the disease course, whereas microvascular complications typically occur after years of hyperglycemia.

title: Inclusion body myositis
description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy sample of striated muscle tissue

Vacuoles (dotted white outlines) are present within the muscle fibers. The fibers vary in size, from smaller atrophic (green overlay) to larger hypertrophic (yellow overlay).
There is an abundance of inflammatory cells between the fibers.

These are typical histological findings in inclusion body myositis.

title: Sarcomere structure
description:
A: I band
B: A band
C: H zone
D: M line
E: Z line

title: Neuroendocrine tumor of colon
description:
Photomicrograph of a colon tumor (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are numerous nests of small, round, monomorphic cells, primarily in rosette-like patterns (dashed outlines, yellow marked central lumen). The cells show peripheral palisading of the nuclei. Finely grained chromatin (also referred to as "salt-and-pepper chromatin," indicated by red overlay) is seen in some cells.

These findings are characteristic of a neuroendocrine tumor.

title: Call-Exner bodies
description:
Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.

title: Schiller-Duval body
description:
Photomicrograph of a testicular tumor sample (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A central blood vessel (red overlay) is surrounded by tumor cells (blue overlay) with enlarged nuclei and coarse chromatin, resulting in a glomerulus-like appearance (Schiller-Duval body).

Schiller-Duval bodies are a classic finding in yolk sac tumors. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemical findings (positive for α-fetoprotein and glypican 3).

title: Shigella dysenteriae
description:
Photomicrograph of a stool sample

Rod-shaped bacteria (examples in blue overlay) that also occasionally form short chains are visible. Erythrocytes (arrowheads indicate examples) and an inflammatory leukocytic exudate (examples in green overlay) can also be seen.

These findings are consistent with Shigella dysentery.

title: Stage 2 decubitus (pressure) ulcer
description: An erythematous, blue-purple area of skin measuring approx. 10 cm x 5 cm is visible over the sacrum with a small area of superficial (epidermal) skin loss near the lower edge.

title: DNA replication in bacteria
description:
Replication of the circular, bacterial genome starts at the origin of replication (ori), which is a specific DNA segment of approx. 250 base pairs. At the start of the replication process, the ori sequence binds to a protein complex and unwinds the DNA double-strand, allowing DNA replication to proceed. Replication occurs in two directions (bidirectional). Two identical DNA molecules are formed, each consisting of one template DNA strand (red) and one new partner strand (blue). This process is termed semiconservative replication.

In eukaryotes, replication is also bidirectional and semiconservative. However, eukaryotes do not have a circular genome.

title: Hemoglobin electrophoresis
description: A technique used to separate and quantify the different types of hemoglobin in a sample of blood based on their electrical charge. Hemoglobin is negatively charged at an alkaline pH and migrates toward the anode, forming a band. The degree of negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule determines its migration speed and distance. HbA migrates the fastest and, therefore, the greatest distance, followed by HbF, HbS, and HbC. This illustration depicts the presence and relative concentrations of different types of hemoglobins in health (adult and fetal) and in common hemoglobinopathies.

title: Ash-leaf spots
description:
Four ellipsoid, hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots) are located on the back of the patient (green overlay).

The presence of more than three ash-leaf spots is characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.

title: Reliability and validity
description:
Illustration of the principles of reliability (precision) and validity (accuracy)

The crosses represent data points from repeated measurements taken using the same instrument, and the target represents the true value of the attribute being measured.

Reliability refers to how similar the data points are to each other: when reliability is low, the data points are more widely dispersed. When reliability is high, the data points are more close together.

Validity refers to how close the data points are to the true value: when validity is low, the data points do not approximate the true value.

title: Thoracic sarcoidosis
description:
Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

title: Follicular thyroid cancer
description:
Micrograph of a histological section of thyroid (H&E stain).

Multiple uniform follicles of similar sizes with an absence of papillary nuclear features. Additionally, these lesions must demonstrate capsular or vascular invasion.

This appearance is typical of a well differentiated follicular thyroid cancer.

title: Pseudofolliculitis barbae
description: Multiple small, hyperpigmented papules are visible in the area of hair growth on the neck.

title: Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
description:
Visual field test (perimetry)

There is a bilateral loss of right lateral visual fields (black areas) with sparing of the macula (hatched overlay). Bilateral impairment of a unilateral visual field in each eye is known as homonymous hemianopia.

title: Antibiotics interfering with folate/tetrahydrofolate synthesis
description: Sulfonamides and dapsone inhibit dihydropteroate synthase (present in bacteria). Trimethoprim and pyrimethamine inhibit the dihydrofolate reductase (present in bacteria and humans).

title: General structures of different virus particles
description: Viruses can be distinguished based on whether there is an envelope and the form of the capsid. The genome, consisting of either DNA or RNA, may be single-stranded (ss) or double-stranded (ds).

title: Translocation of ribosomes to the endoplasmic reticulum during translation
description:
Some proteins, e.g., secretory proteins, possess a signal sequence (amino acid sequence of 9–12 amino acids) by which they are transported to their destination during synthesis (cotranslational transport).

(1) Translation begins on free ribosomes in the cytosol, with the assembly of ribosomal subunits on mRNA.

(2) Synthesis of a signal sequence results in its binding to a signal recognition particle (SRP).

(3) SRP stops translation and binds to the SRP receptor on the ER membrane.

(4) SRP and the SRP receptor are bound to GTP, which is hydrolyzed to GDP after binding. In this way, the ribosome is transferred to the translocon, a protein complex traversing the ER membrane that subsequently opens like a canal. SRP is released and can be recycled.

(5) Translation continues and the protein is directly synthesized in the ER lumen.

(6) During translation, the signal sequence is cleaved from the growing protein. The resulting peptide exits the translocon laterally into the membrane, where it is subsequently degraded.

(7) After termination of translation, the ribosome is released into the cytosol.

(8) The translocon channel closes and the synthesized protein remains in the ER.

Lysosomal proteins and membrane proteins are synthesized similarly in the rough ER. However, membrane proteins exit the translocon laterally, directly into the ER membrane, as insoluble proteins.

title: Sinus vein thrombosis
description:
CT head (with IV contrast; coronal section; venous phase)

There is a contrast filling defect within the superior sagittal sinus (red overlay), which is hypodense with hyperdense borders (empty delta sign). The transverse sinuses (blue overlay) are hyperdense, which is their normal appearance.

This appearance is suggestive of a sinus vein thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus.

title: Pulmonary granuloma in sarcoidosis
description:
Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Multiple granulomas (examples indicated by green overlays) showing no central necrosis, known as noncaseating granulomas are visible.

Noncaseating granulomas on lung biopsy are a typical finding in pulmonary sarcoidosis.

title: Cells and structures of lungs and airways
description:
Overview of the different types of respiratory epithelium and components of the airway walls

The height of the epithelium decreases steadily from the trachea to the alveolar sacs and the distribution and prevalence of cell types and extracellular components changes throughout the airways.

(Note: The length and width of the bars indicate the approximate relative distribution and prevalence of the structures shown but do not represent absolute numbers or metric data.)

title: Antigen presentation
description:
MHC class I antigen presentation: Intracellular proteins are degraded to small peptide fragments by the proteasome and released into the cytosol. The cytosolic peptides enter the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) via the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) to form a complex with MHC class I molecule. The newly formed MHC class I antigen complex undergoes post-translational modification within the Golgi apparatus and enters the cell surface for presentation to cytotoxic CD8 T-cells.

MHC class II antigen presentation: Extracellular proteins are ingested by the antigen-presenting cell and held within the endosome. The protein is degraded into small peptides by the lysosome, which then forms a complex with the MHC class II protein. The new MHC class II antigen complex is transported to the cell surface for presentation with CD4 T-cells.

title: Gaucher cell
description:
Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear from a patient with bilateral femoral neck necrosis (PAS stain)

A large cell (yellow overlay) with an eccentric nucleus (green overlay) can be seen. The cytoplasm shows a striated pattern.

This is the typical appearance of a Gaucher cell, as seen in Gaucher disease.

title: Acoustic neuroma
description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial view)

An intensely contrast-enhancing, homogeneous mass (green overlay) is visible in the right cerebellopontine angle.

This is the typical appearance of an acoustic neuroma.

title: Salvage pathway
description: The salvage pathway is the pathway along which purine nucleotides are recycled (adenine, guanine, and hypoxanthine) and reconverted to nucleotides through phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP)-dependent reactions.
