The enzymes involved in the purine salvage pathway are adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) and hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Both enzymes are inhibited by their end products.

title: Lipofuscin
description:
Photomicrograph of cardiac myocytes (H&E stain; 100x magnification)

Lipofuscin (green overlay) is visible as fine, yellow-brown granules in the perinuclear region of the central cardiac myocyte.

The finding of lipofuscin usually indicates the physiological aging of cells.

title: Pemphigus vulgaris
description:
Photomicrograph (direct immunofluorescence using anti-IgG antibodies)

There is intercellular IgG deposition within the epidermis and acantholysis of the cells near the floor of the blister (resulting in a “row of tombstones” appearance).

title: Cherry-red spot of the macula
description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a child with Tay-Sachs disease

The fovea centralis is visible as a deep red spot (cherry-red spot; blue overlay). Surrounding the fovea, the retina appears paler than normal because of accumulation of gangliosides within the retinal cells.

Differential diagnosis of a cherry-red spot in children include Niemann-Pick disease, in which this appearance is caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin within the retinal cells. In adults the diagnosis is most likely central retinal artery occlusion.

title: Angiokeratomas
description:
Multiple red/purple lesions are visible along the left groin of this adult male. Upon examination, these spots are palpably elevated.

This appearance is characteristic of angiokeratoma, which is caused by dilated dermal capillaries and hyperkeratosis of the overlying skin. Multiple diffusely-occurring angiokeratomas are a feature of Fabry disease.

title: Beta-oxidation of even-numbered fatty acids (mitochondria/peroxisomes)
description:
Beta-oxidation of even-numbered fatty acids requires four enzymatic reactions, eventually yielding acyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA through cleavage of two carbons per cycle. This process is nearly identical in mitochondria and peroxisomes, except for some minor differences.

In peroxisomes, FADH2, which is generated during the first reaction, cannot undergo conversion to FAD through the respiratory chain but has to transfer its electrons onto oxygen. This reaction yields H2O2, which will subsequently be broken down into water and oxygen.

Moreover, beta-oxidation in peroxisomes does not allow for complete breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. Instead, carbon groups may only be cleaved off up to a chain length of at least eight remaining carbon atoms (octanyl-CoA). These fatty acids are then released into the cytosol and transferred to the mitochondria for complete breakdown. Acetyl-CoA generated in peroxisomes is also released into the cytosol to be used as substrate for other reactions, e.g., the mitochondrial citrate cycle.

title: Cardiac myxoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a sample of a mass removed from the wall of the left atrium (H&E stain; 20x and 40x)

Scarce cells are dispersed in abundant hyaline stroma mainly comprised of mucopolysaccharides (homogeneous, pale-pink, amorphous substance).
Erythrocytes are seen in some areas of the tissue, indicating marked hemorrhage.
At 40x magnification, multiple spindle cells with oval nuclei are visible.

title: Femoral hernia
description:
Sagittal view of the male inguinal region at the level of the superior pubic ramus, medial to the epigastric vessels

There is a protruding hernial sac (comprised of the transversalis fascia and parietal peritoneum) below the inguinal ligament but above the pubic bone, which, in the example shown, contains intestine.

title: Digital clubbing
description: There is bulbous enlargement of the distal phalanges and the nail curvatures are markedly increased.

title: Neurofibromatosis type 1
description:
Multiple light brown macules with irregular borders (café-au-lait spots) are visible on the upper left arm, shoulder, and back.

This presence of multiple café-au-lait spots is highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1.

title: Meningioma
description:
Cranial MRI, axial view (T1-weighted; with contrast)

Round, sharply delimited, homogeneously enhancing, hyperintense lesion (snowball appearance) in the interhemispheric region of the frontal lobe (green overlay).
The lesion displaces brain tissue. The dura is connected to the meninges of the frontal bone (dural tail sign) by a thick, hyperintense strand. A thin rim separates the lesion from surrounding brain parenchyma (CSF cleft sign).

These are characteristic radiologic features of a meningioma.

title: Branches of the celiac trunk
description: The celiac trunk and its three major branches: the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery

title: Arterial supply of the gastrointestinal tract
description:
The gastrointestinal tract is supplied by the three anterior branches of the abdominal aorta.
- Celiac artery: artery of the foregut (lower esophagus, stomach, proximal duodenum, liver, gall bladder, pancreas)
- Superior mesenteric artery: artery of the midgut (distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon)
- Inferior mesenteric artery: artery of the hindgut (distal third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum, anal canal proximal to the pectinate line)

title: Mucormycosis
description:
Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

title: Pineal germinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of a pineal tumor biopsy sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Large tumor cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei can be seen (examples marked by green overlay). Additionally, the tumor tissue contains numerous intermixed lymphocytes (comparatively small cells with round dark nuclei).

These histopathological findings are consistent with a pineal germinoma, which was confirmed by immunohistochemistry; ovarian dysgerminomas and testicular seminomas have a very similar appearance.

title: Herpetic whitlow
description:
A cluster of three nonpurulent vesicles on an erythematous base is visible on the distal phalanx. The surrounding skin is intact.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic whitlow.

title: Action potential
description:
A: threshold potential
B: depolarization
C: overshoot
D: repolarization
E: hyperpolarization
F: resting potential

title: Adrenal gland
description:
Photomicrograph of normal adrenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Layers from top to bottom:

– Fibrous adrenal capsule (dashed line)
– Glomerular zone (Gz): composed of cells that produce mineralocorticoids
– Fascicular zone (Fz, white overlay): large pale cells produce glucocorticoids
– Reticular zone (Rz, green overlay): eosinophilic cells produce sex hormones
– Medulla (M): composed of adrenaline and noradrenaline-producing cells

No abnormalities are present.

title: Type III hypersensitivity reaction
description:
Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) are formed in the circulation and get deposited in tissues, preferably within the vascular endothelium, certain organs (e.g., kidney, lung), and the serosal membranes (e.g., synovium, pleura, pericardium).

The deposited immune complexes activate the complement cascade, resulting in chemotaxis (recruitment of neutrophils). The antigen-bound IgG bind to the Fc receptors (FcR) on the surface of neutrophils that then release lysosomal enzymes, which damage the local tissues.

The site of immune complex deposition determines the clinical features of a type III hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., Arthus reaction, vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, synovitis, pneumonitis).

title: Type I hypersensitivity reaction
description:
IgE is typically bound to Fc receptors (FcR) on the surface of immune cells, such as mast cells and basophils. Crosslinking of an allergen with the IgE signals the immune cells to degranulate, releasing inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine) that instantly trigger a hypersensitivity reaction.

This is the pathophysiology of type I hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, food allergies, drug reactions), which can be severe enough to result in anaphylactic shock.

title: Barr body and aberrant nuclear projection
description:
Peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; 100x magnification)

Two neutrophils can be seen among numerous RBCs. Within one of the neutrophils (dashed outline), a Barr body (yellow overlay) and an aberrant barbed-wire nuclear projection (red overlay) are visible.

Barr bodies and aberrant nuclear projections are seen in chromosomal trisomy (e.g., in Klinefelter syndrome).

title: CD4-mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction
description:
Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antigen-specific T cells, unlike all other hypersensitivity reactions, which are antibody-mediated. T helper cells (CD4+ cells; Th cells) mainly act by cytokine-mediated recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of the target cells.

T-cell receptors (TCR) present on sensitized CD4+ cells recognize and bind to specific exogenous antigens (e.g., bacteria, viruses). These antigens are bound to the major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC II), a transmembrane protein present on the surface of antigen-presenting cells, like macrophages. Th cells are divided into two subsets based on the cytokines they produce:
- Bacterial and viral infections predominantly activate Th1 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit neutrophils and macrophages (e.g., IFNγ, TNFα). Activated macrophages release reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitric oxide (NO), which aid in the destruction of phagocytosed pathogens.
- Helminthic or parasitic infections predominantly activate Th2 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit eosinophils (e.g., IL5). Activated eosinophils release major basic protein (MBP), which aids in the destruction of helminths and signals mast cells to release histamine.

Cytokines, ROS, and MBP recruit more inflammatory cells to the site of the reaction and amplify the inflammatory response, which typically becomes evident ∼ 48 hours after antigen-exposure (i.e., delayed hypersensitivity).

title: Hamartomatous polyp
description:
Photomicrograph of a colonic polyp (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

Hyperplastic smooth muscle cells (uninucleated spindle-shaped cells) are visible as broad pink bands arranged in a tree-like pattern. Glandular hyperplasia without distortion of the normal tissue architecture is also visible.

These features are consistent with a hamartomatous polyp, which is typically seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

title: Telomerase mechanism of action
description: Telomerase binds to the single-stranded overhang on the 3′-end lagging strand (1) and extends it by using its reverse transcriptase function and an RNA template that is complementary to the telomeric overhang sequence (2). Once the newly synthesized single strand reaches a certain length, telomerase activity is inhibited and a DNA primer is synthesized and then elongated by DNA polymerase (3; polymerase not shown).

title: Pituitary gland tumor
description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)

A hyperintense, round mass with clearly defined borders (green overlay) is seen in the sella turcica (directly above the nasal pharynx).

These are typical radiological features of a pituitary adenoma.

title: Sézary Cell
description:
Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa staining)

In the center, there is an atypical lymphocyte. The cell is large (approximately twice the size of the surrounding erythrocytes) with light purple (basophilic) cytoplasm, and a convoluted or “brain-like” (cerebriform) dark purple nucleus.

This is the typical appearance of a Sézary cell, a lymphocyte that occurs in Sézary syndrome (a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma).

title: Flow cytometry
description:
Flow cytometry is a technique for the identification, quantification, and sorting of single cells in a cell suspension, often with the use of fluorescent-tagged antibodies to detect the presence of specific target antigens (as illustrated here).

Inside the nozzle, a fluid (sheath fluid) focuses the cells into a narrow stream, causing them to pass across the laser beam in single file. As the laser hits each cell, the light scattered varies in accordance with its size, shape, and intracellular and cell surface molecules. Cells containing the target antigen also have the fluorescent-tagged antibody bound to them, which emits light of a specific wavelength when activated by the laser beam (yellow and blue, in this image).
A detector directly opposite the laser beam measures the amount of forward scatter, and detectors placed perpendicular to the laser beam measure side scatter and fluorescence.

The collected data can then be plotted as a histogram (yellow graph and blue graph) or a scatter plot (bottom right graph). Histograms measure a single parameter, displaying a large number of events (cells) as a spike. Scatter plots measure two parameters simultaneously, representing each event (cell) as a single point and clustering events with similar fluorescence intensities. In the case illustrated, the gray cells do not possess the target antigens and are marked as events at low fluorescence intensity on both axes in the scatter plot. By contrast, green cells possess two target antigens and are represented as high fluorescence intensity events on both axes.

title: Renal embryology (stages)
description:
The pronephros is the first nephric stage in humans but does not contribute to the development of the kidney. It degenerates by the 5th week of intrauterine life.

The mesonephros functions as a temporary excretory system during the first trimester. It degenerates once the fetal kidneys have developed. The mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) persists, developing into the ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens, epididymis, and seminal vesicles in males. The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric duct and branches into the metanephric kidney to form the collecting tubules, the renal pelvis, and the ureter.
The metanephros arises from the intermediate mesoderm caudal to the mesonephros in the 5th week of development and differentiates into the functional kidney.

title: Protein metabolism and resorption
description:
In the stomach, gastric acid denatures dietary proteins, and pepsin cleaves the denatured proteins into peptides of various lengths.

In the duodenum, peptides are cleaved by exopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds at terminal ends, e.g. Carboxypeptidase A and B) and endopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds within the polypeptide chain, e.g. Trypsin, Chymotrypsin, Elastase).

Oligopeptides are broken down to di-/tripeptides by oligopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border. Some di-/tripeptides are absorbed into the enterocyte via a proton symporter (PepT1), and some remain in the intestinal lumen are broken down to amino acids in the intestinal lumen. Oligopeptides are also broken down to amino acids by aminopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border.

Within the enterocyte, dipeptides/tripeptides that were absorbed by the enterocyte are broken down to single amino acids by dipeptidases/tripeptidases.

Single amino acids within the intestinal lumen are absorbed by the enterocyte via Na+-coupled carrier proteins for specific amino acid groups (e.g. basic, neutral, acidic).

Single amino acids are transported out of the enterocyte (via basolateral transporters) into the bloodstream and travel to the liver via the portal vein.

title: Emmetropia, myopia, and hyperopia
description:
Deviations in eye anatomy that affect refractory media (e.g., axial length of the eye, cornea curvature) can result in refractive errors.

Emmetropia: The axial length of the eye and refractive power are balanced, resulting in a focal point on the retina.

Myopia: An increased axial length of the eye or increased refractive power results in a focal point anterior to the retina. Near objects can be seen clearly but distant objects are blurred. This can be corrected using a concave (diverging) lens.

Hyperopia: A decreased axial length of the eye or decreased refractive power results in a focal point posterior to the retina. Distant objects and even near objects may be seen clearly depending on the ability of the lens to accommodate (generally, the younger the individual, the greater the ability to accommodate) and the degree of hyperopia. Hyperopia can be corrected using a convex (converging) lens.

title: Cross section of the spinal cord
description:
Cross section at approx. the C6–7 level

(A) Left fasciculus gracilis
(B) Left fasciculus cuneatus
(C) Left lateral corticospinal tract
(D) Left dorsolateral column
(E) Left dorsomedial column
(F) Right dorsomedial column
(G) Right dorsolateral column
(H) Right lateral corticospinal tract
(I) Right fasciculus cuneatus
(J) Right fasciculus gracilis

title: Tributaries of the hepatic portal vein
description: The splenic, superior mesenteric, and inferior mesenteric veins drain blood from the spleen and digestive organs (with the exception of the lower rectum) and merge to form the hepatic portal vein. The hepatic portal vein thus transports blood to the liver that is rich in nutrients but deoxygenated (therefore represented in blue). Following metabolization in the liver, the blood then passes via the hepatic veins to the inferior vena cava to join systemic circulation.

title: Neurulation
description:
Left: overview of the main embryonic structures at approx. day 18

Right: cross-sections of the embryonic disc at several heights, showing the neural fold, the neural crest, and the neural tube

title: Cryptococcus neoformans
description:
Photomicrograph of a fungal culture

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes are visible, with the polysaccharide capsules appearing in darker blue.

title: Innervation of the lower extremity (ventral view)
description:
The femoral nerve is the main nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh. The saphenous nerve and the medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh originate from the femoral nerve.
The obturator nerve is the main nerve of the medial compartment of the thigh and exits the pelvis ventrally through the obturator foramen.
The iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal, genitofemoral, and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves are pure sensory nerves that arise directly from the lumbar plexus.
The common fibular nerve (a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve) branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves at or just below the neck of the fibula.

Cutaneous innervation of the foot is supplied by the saphenous nerve medially and the sural nerve laterally.
Cutaneous innervation of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by branches of the superficial fibular nerve, with the exception of the first interdigital space, which is supplied by a branch of the deep fibular nerve.

title: Escherichia coli
description:
Photomicrograph of a bacterial culture (Gram stain; high magnification)

E. coli is a rod-shaped and gram-negative bacterium.

title: Central pontine myelinolysis
description:
Cranial MRI (axial section; T2-weighted)

A hyperintense signal in the central pons is visible (green overlay). This hyperintensity has a characteristic trident shape that is pathognomonic of central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), which predominantly affects the transverse pontine fibers and spares the corticospinal tracts. CPM is caused by the rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.

title: Sporothrix schenckii (mold form)
description:
Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)

title: Pretibial myxedema
description:
Photograph of the left knee and lower leg

There are numerous irregular nodules and plaques on the pretibial surface, and the skin has a red-brown discoloration. The hair follicles are prominent, resulting in an orange-peel (peau d'orange) appearance.

These are characteristic features of pretibial myxedema.

title: Histoplasma capsulatum (mold form)
description:
Photomicrograph of a soil specimen at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)

Numerous septated hyphae are visible throughout the image. The large, knobbly (tuberculated), dark blue spherical structures are the macroconidia. The small, smooth, pink spherical structures are the microconidia.

This is the typical appearance of Histoplasma capsulatum in mold (mycelial) form. At temperatures > 37°C, Histoplasma capsulatum exists in a yeast form.

title: Malassezia furfur
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin scraping

Throughout the image, there are multiple short, septated hyphae (filamentous structures) and spherical spores. These different morphological forms are responsible for the “spaghetti and meatballs” pattern (hyphae being the spaghetti and yeast being the meatballs), which is a typical finding of Malassezia furfur.

title: Blastomyces dermatitidis (mold form)
description:
Photomicrograph of a sputum specimen at 22°C (scale bar = 10 μm)

Several thick-walled, circular fungal cell bodies with filamentous structures containing germ tubes and hyphae are visible. The filaments indicate fungal germination, which only occurs at temperatures < 25°C.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in mold form (at room temperature, ∼ 23°C). At body temperature (37°C), this dimorphic fungus exists in yeast form.

title: Hematoma of the upper arm
description:
Photograph of the upper left arm of a male adult

There is an ovoid, yellow-green and, in some regions, red discoloration of the skin on the left upper arm.

This appearance is characteristic of a hematoma due to blunt trauma. The yellow-green color indicates that the trauma occurred a few days ago.

title: The crossbridge cycle
description:
The crossbridge cycle describes the calcium-dependent interaction of actin and myosin during muscle contraction (myosin head = pink; actin = blue).

1.) Released state: the myosin binding site on the actin filament is blocked by tropomyosin → no interaction between myosin and actin. The myosin head is in a low-energy 45° position with ATP bound to it.

2.) Cocked state: ATP is hydrolyzed, yielding ADP and phosphate → cocking of myosin head (high-energy 90° position). The myosin binding site remains blocked.

3.) Crossbridge state: activation of muscle cell with influx of calcium. Binding of calcium to troponin → tropomyosin is displaced from myosin binding site on actin filament → myosin head binds to actin filament (crossbridge formation).

4.) Power stroke: release of the phosphate bound to the myosin head → power stroke of myosin head → myosin head moves along the actin filament. This action results in muscle contraction and/or tension, depending on the situation. Afterward, the myosin head returns to the low-energy 45° position.

5.) Detached state: release of ADP → binding and hydrolyzation of a new ATP molecule and subsequent release of the myosin head. If the calcium concentration remains high, the crossbridge cycle starts again. If the calcium concentration decreases, the myosin binding site is once again blocked by tropomyosin and the crossbridge cycle ends.

title: Electromechanical coupling in skeletal muscles
description:
(1) Formation of an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) by sodium influx via the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
(2) Depolarization of the muscle cell membrane and opening of further voltage-dependent sodium channels
(3) Formation of an action potential that spreads over the sarcolemma to the T-tubules
(4) Conformational change of the membranous dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR)
(5) Direct protein-protein interaction leads to opening of the coupled ryanodine receptor (RyR1).

Subsequently, an influx of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the sarcoplasm takes place. The resulting increase in calcium concentration is essential for the crossbridge cycle.

title: Cranial nerve nuclei
description: Sagittal section of the brainstem

title: Effect of ADH on the kidney
description:
ADH is essential for the regulation of fluid balance as it stimulates the water reabsorption in the collecting duct system of the kidney. ADH is produced in the hypothalamus, from where it travels to the posterior pituitary, over an axonal transport, and is released when required.

ADH secretion is stimulated through an increased blood osmolarity and an increased angiotensin II as well as low blood pressure or low blood volume, whereas it is inhibited through ethanol.
If ADH is released in the posterior pituitary, it becomes effective in the kidney by binding to an ADH receptor (V2 receptor) in the collecting duct system, which then leads to a stimulation of adenylate cyclase (= catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP).

The increased cAMP level activates the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA), which phosphorylates and activates aquaporin 2 with several intermediate steps. Aquaporin 2 exists in vesicles in the cytoplasm – if it is activated, it reaches the luminal cell wall and they merge together. Water can now flow into the cell through the aquaporin 2 channels, which then reaches into the interstitium of the kidney through aquaporin 3 and 4 channels.

title: Radial nerve neuropathy
description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

title: Pinch sign (anterior interosseous syndrome)
description:
The anterior interosseous nerve is a pure motor branch of the median nerve. It supplies the flexor pollicis longus, the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (and the pronator quadratus).

Pinch sign: an inability to flex the DIP of the index finger and IP joint of the thumb when asked to make an “OK” sign that is caused by a lesion or entrapment of the anterior interosseous nerve

title: Motor homunculus
description: The motor homunculus is a map of the primary motor cortex (located in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobes) that illustrates which areas of the brain process the motor output to which part of the body. The distorted representation of the body and the size of the correspondingly labeled cortical areas illustrate the proportional amount of motor output sent to the individual parts of the body. Accordingly, since areas like the tongue, face, and hands receive most motor innervation, these areas are represented as disproportionately large compared to other areas, like the trunk and lower limbs.

title: Hyperplastic polyp
description:
Photomicrograph of colonic polyp tissue (H&E stain)

The luminal crypt epithelium shows prominent serration (sawtooth pattern). Goblet cell hyperplasia appears as vacuous bubbles in the crypt epithelium due to the mucin content. There is crowding of cells at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn (basal hyperplasia).

title: Pseudopolyp
description:
Photomicrograph of colonic polyp tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple dilated and slightly tortuous crypts (crypt hyperplasia) are visible (example indicated by red dashed outline). In the top left corner, epithelium with numerous mitotic figures can be seen, corresponding to epithelial regeneration (examples indicated by yellow overlay). There is an inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria (seen as numerous dark blue dots; example marked by black arrowhead). Two crypt abscesses can be seen in the center and on the right (green overlays). Crypt abscesses contain neutrophils (blue dots) and epithelial debris (pink substance) within their lumen. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

Epithelial regeneration, mucosal inflammation, crypt hyperplasia, and crypt abscesses are characteristic features of an inflammatory pseudopolyp that occurs due to the recurrent mucosal ulceration and healing that typically occurs in ulcerative colitis.

title: Venae cavae and azygos vein
description:
Chest, neck, and abdomen (coronal section, ventral view)

The veins depicted here ultimately drain into the superior and the inferior vena cava.

title: Phonocardiogram of systolic heart murmurs
description:
Systolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:
(A) Mitral/tricuspid regurgitation and/or ventricular septal defect (holosystolic murmur)
(B) Aortic/pulmonary stenosis (crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(C) Aortic/pulmonary stenosis with an ejection click
(D) Mitral valve prolapse (midsystolic click followed by crescendo murmur)
(E) Pulmonary stenosis with a split second heart sound

title: Distal row of carpal bones
description: The carpal bones are numbered consecutively, with the distal row highlighted in blue.

title: Keratin pearls in cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC)
description:
Photomicrograph of a skin tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 10x magnification).

Keratinization of the tissue with the presence of atypical but still relatively well-differentiated cells.
A few prominent, singular nests of concentric keratin layers (keratin pearls; examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible.

Diagnosis: cSCC

title: Nitric oxide signaling
description:
NO (nitrogen oxide) is a small reactive molecule with a half-life of only a few seconds that diffuses freely across membranes and serves a unique role as signaling messenger. NO is mainly released by endothelial cells, where it is synthesized from L-arginine by NO synthase, which is activated by an increase of calcium levels in the cell.
Once synthesized, NO can activate the soluble enzyme guanylate cyclase, which is present in the cytosol and converts GTP into cGMP, in downstream cells (e.g., muscle cells). cGMP acts as a messenger and activates protein kinases (e.g., PKG) until it is transformed into GMP by a phosphodiesterase and thus deactivated.

title: Hormonal feedback control of nontropic hormones
description:
The nontropic releasing hormones are released in the hypothalamus (A) to the portal vascular system of the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis , 2), where the nontropic hormones growth hormone (GH), melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and prolactin are released (2). These trigger the secretion of hormones in the target organs: GH leads to the secretion of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the liver, which has an anabolic effect on the muscles and bones (3). In the skin, MSH stimulates the production of melanocytes (4). Prolactin triggers growth and lactation in the mammary glands (5). The inhibiting hormones are also released in the hypothalamus and subsequently reach the anterior pituitary gland, where they inhibit the release of nontropic hormones.

(GHRH = growth hormone-releasing hormone, TRH = thyrotropin-releasing hormone, MSH-RH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-releasing hormone, MSH-IH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-inhibiting hormone, Dop = dopamine)

title: Kaposi sarcoma
description: Violaceous nodules and papules are visible beside several black-crusted plaques on the lower leg of this patient with Kaposi sarcoma.

title: Intracellular viral replication cycle of a RNA virus
description:
In the viral life cycle, the genome of the RNA virus is released into the host cytoplasm after uncoating. In the host cytoplasm, the viral RNA is replicated and, based on its polarity, either directly translated into the amino acid sequence of a polypeptide or transcribed into mRNA through an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Unlike with DNA viruses, the genome of the RNA virus does not enter the nucleus.

title: Intracellular viral replication cycle of a DNA virus
description:
In the viral life cycle, the genome of the DNA virus enters the nucleus after uncoating. In the nucleus, the viral DNA is integrated into the host DNA and is subsequently transcribed and replicated by the host cell machinery.

Nuclear entry, which does not occur in the RNA virus life cycle, is the distinguishing feature of the DNA virus life cycle.

title: Charcot-Leyden crystal
description:
Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain)

Lumen of a bronchus filled with mucous and inflammatory exudate.
A bipyramidal hexagonal structure (yellow overlay) is visible in the center of the image.

This structure is known as a Charcot-Leyden crystal, a histopathologic finding in patients with eosinophilic inflammation and/or proliferation (e.g., asthma, parasitic infections).

title: Michaelis-Menten plot
description:
X: This graph represents the enzyme kinetics of a given enzyme alone (i.e., without drug interference).

A: Linear graphs are never seen on Michaelis-Menten plots; a maximum reaction velocity will always be reached because there is only a limited number of enzymes. (Linear graphs are seen on Lineweaver-Burke plots, though, since they are double reciprocal plots.)
B: This graph represents the effect of an allosteric activator (higher affinity).
C: This graph represents an increase in enzyme concentration (higher maximum reaction velocity) plus the effect of a competitive inhibitor (lower affinity).
D: This graph represents the effect of a competitive inhibitor (lower affinity).

title: DNA replication
description:
Overview of the molecular processes during DNA replication.

DNA replication undergoes three basic stages: initiation, elongation, and termination. The exact mechanisms and molecules used differ between prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

Initiation starts at specific DNA sequences (oris) where the enzyme helicase separates and unwinds the DNA strands (yielding a leading and a lagging strand). This process is bidirectional, resulting in two roughly Y-shaped structures (the replication forks) moving in opposite directions along the DNA (the illustration shows only one direction, i.e., one of the replication forks). Several enzymes (e.g., topoisomerase) and other molecules are required in the process.

Elongation takes place simultaneously on both strands and always begins with the synthesis of a short RNA primer. Because DNA strands are antiparallel and a free 3′OH group is needed for adding new deoxynucleotides, DNA synthesis occurs continuously in the leading strand and discontinuously in the lagging strand (where Okazaki fragments are produced as a result). Further steps during elongation include proofreading, removal of primers (and filling of the respective gaps), and joining of newly synthesized DNA fragments.

Termination of replication occurs via binding of termination proteins to specific termination sequences on the DNA.

title: Lichtenberg figures
description:
Faint erythematous cutaneous markings in a fern leaf pattern (Lichtenberg figures; example indicated by arrow) are visible on the lower left leg.

Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic of lightning injury.

title: Transport in the connecting tubule and collecting duct
description:
The connecting tubule is the most distal part of the distal tubule. The physiological function of the connecting tubule and the collecting duct is to fine-tune the composition of the urine, which can also be regulated by hormones (not shown here). There are different types of cells:

1) Principal cells (upper part of the image) reabsorb water via aquaporins and contribute to sodium resorption via aldosterone-controlled sodium channels.

2) Intercalated cells mainly participate in the regulation of blood pH and are divided into Type A/α and Type B/β cells. α-Intercalated cells (middle part of the image) secrete protons into the lumen and transport bicarbonate into the Interstitium. β-Intercalated cells (lower part of the image) transport protons into the Interstitium and secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

title: Michaelis-Menten kinetics
description:
This diagram illustrates the reaction velocity (v) of a certain enzymatic reaction in relation to its substrate concentration ([S]) in an otherwise stable environment. It yields a solubility curve with an initial steep rise with subsequent plateauing (hyperbolic solubility curve).

The maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) is indicated by the plateau phase which is achieved at maximum substrate concentrations. KM is defined as the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity equals 50% of Vmax. Generally speaking, Michaelis-Menten kinetics demonstrate that the reaction velocity of an enzymatic reaction with steady enzyme concentrations is primarily dependent on substrate concentrations. This means, that low substrate availability results in a decreased likelihood of a successful enzymatic reaction since diffusion off the enzyme diminishes reaction velocity. However, a surplus of substrate results in negligible diffusion that allows the enzyme to work at maximum speed. Further increase of substrate concentrations would fail to increase reaction velocity since all enzymes are already saturated.

title: Action potential and ionic conductivity
description:
Upper chart: Illustration showing changes in membrane potential over time (during a single action potential). A neuronal cell membrane with a resting potential of approx. -70 mV (teal) depolarizes slowly until it reaches its threshold potential of approx. -50 mV (yellow), at which point it depolarizes abruptly (orange). Depolarization ends with a brief positive polarization of the membrane (overshoot; peak approx. 30 mV; red), after which a rapid repolarization phase begins (green) and the membrane potential becomes negative again. The membrane potential very briefly (for approx. 2 ms) drops below the resting potential (hyperpolarization; approx. -90 mV; blue) before returning to baseline (resting potential; approx. -70 mV; teal).

Lower chart: The changes in membrane potential shown above occur due to changes in membrane ionic conductivity, particularly for sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions. At baseline, membrane conductivity for K+ (purple) is far greater than that for Na+ (blue). This changes abruptly during the depolarization phase, as voltage-dependent Na+ channels open. With some delay, membrane conductivity for potassium also increases as voltage-dependent K+ channels open (while Na+ channels begin closing again). This leads to the repolarization and subsequently hyperpolarization of the membrane.

(Note that the specific values for membrane potentials differ between cell types and that some cell types do not have a stable resting potential.)

title: Breast fat necrosis
description:
Photomicrograph of breast lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Necrotic adipocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible as adipocytes with indistinct, irregular borders and absent nuclei. Unstained, lipid-filled cystic spaces are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). An inflammatory infiltrate is present (example indicated by arrowhead).

These findings are characteristic of fat necrosis of the breast. At a higher magnification, cholesterol clefts, foam cells, and multinucleated giant cells would also be visible.

title: Gastric acid secretion
description: Gastric acid (HCl) is secreted by the parietal cells of the gastric glands, which is stimulated by histamine, ACh, and gastrin. Cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrase converts CO2 and H2O into H+ and HCO3-. Intracellular HCO3- is exchanged for Cl- through the basolateral membrane. The H+/K+-ATPase pumps on the apical cell membrane of parietal cells secrete H+ ions into the lumen. H+ and Cl- are secreted into the gastric lumen as HCl. HCO3- is secreted into the gastric lumen in exchange for Cl- by the mucous neck cells of the gastric glands.

title: Cellular adaptation
description:
Cells demonstrate particular adaptive changes in response to environmental changes or increased or decreased tissue requirements.

Cells can increase in size but not in number as a response to increased demand, which is termed hypertrophy (e.g., in skeletal muscles as a response to muscle training; top of the image). Hyperplasia is an increase in cell number with unaltered cell size (e.g., the thyroid in persistent iodine deficiency; middle left). There are two types of atrophy. Atrophy (bottom left) is a decrease in cell number, whereas hypotrophy (cellular atrophy; bottom right) is a decrease in cell size. If cell differentiation is affected as a result of cellular adaptation, this is termed metaplasia (e.g., transformation of squamous epithelium into cylindrical, mucosal epithelium in chronic gastric acid reflux in the esophagus; middle right).

title: Conduction of action potentials
description:
Continuous conduction (top left) occurs in non-myelinated nerve fibers. Action potentials migrate along the entire cell membrane, as depolarization of one section initiates depolarization of the next and the refractory period prevents backpropagation.

Saltatory conduction (bottom left) occurs in myelinated nerve fibers. These have intermittent gaps in the insulating myelin layer, called nodes of Ranvier. Action potentials skip along the cell membrane, as depolarization in one node initiates depolarization of the next, resulting in higher conduction velocities than possible through continuous conduction.

Conduction velocity (right) is increased by myelination (saltatory conduction) and increasing nerve fiber diameter.

title: Structure of tRNA (cloverleaf model)
description: During protein synthesis, tRNA serves as an adapter between the mRNA template and the amino acids encoded on that particular mRNA. To bind to the corresponding mRNA codon, the tRNA features a specific anticodon composed of the three complementary bases. The corresponding amino acids are bound to the acceptor stem of tRNA via its 3'OH group. Approx. half of the nucleotides comprising the tRNA form base pairs. The remaining bases form loops, resulting in a cloverleaf structure (when represented in two dimensions). The loops are usually named according to their function and/or their uncommon bases (e.g., dihydrouridine or Ψ/psi pseudouridine).

title: Blastomyces dermatitidis (yeast form)
description:
Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.

title: White dermatographism
description:
The skin of the arm is visibly white in the area where the patient scratched their skin.

The phenomenon known as white dermatographism is a result of capillary vasoconstriction and is associated with atopic dermatitis.

title: Arteries of the pelvic cavity
description: Longitudinal section of the pelvis

title: Train-of-four stimulation (phase I blockade)
description:
Train-of-four stimulations are done by delivering four successive supramaximal stimuli (at 500 ms intervals) to a peripheral nerve. Those groups of four stimulations are repeatedly delivered to evaluate the resulting pattern of muscular response.

Normally, the resulting muscular responses (as measured via electromyography) should be equally strong (both within groups of four consecutive responses and over a succession of consecutive groups of such responses).

If nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs (e.g., rocuronium) are administered, the amplitude of muscular responses decreases within a group of four consecutive responses (that the amplitude of the fourth response is significantly lower than that of the first one of the same group). This phenomenon is also referred to as “fade.”

The effects of depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs (e.g., succinylcholine) are subdivided into two phases: In phase I, the drug binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, inducing a single, persistent depolarization. Electromyographically, each of the individual responses in a group of four will be decreased by the same percentage, and the overall muscular responsiveness between consecutive groups of stimuli steadily decreases over time. If depolarizing neuromuscular agents are administered over a prolonged amount of time or a high dose is given, phase II may occur. In this phase, there is a fade in the muscular response, resembling the phenomenon seen in nondepolarizing agents. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) potentiate the effects of depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs during phase I.

title: Schistosoma haematobium egg
description:
Photomicrograph of urine concentrate (wet mount; 500× magnification)

An oval-shaped egg (green overlay) with a transparent shell (red outline), a small protrusion at one pole, and a sharp terminal spine (blue line) is pictured.

This is the characteristic microscopic appearance of a Schistosoma haematobium egg, which is excreted in the urine (or feces) of an infected host.

title: Rosacea
description:
There is erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules localized to the nose and cheeks.

These are characteristic features of rosacea.

title: Innervation of the lower extremity (dorsal view)
description:
The nerves of the lower extremity arise from the lumbar and sacral plexuses.
The sciatic nerve (L4–S3), inferior gluteal nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and pudendal nerve exit the pelvis dorsally through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis muscle. The superior gluteal nerve is the only nerve that exits the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.
The sciatic nerve branches at the popliteal fossa into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

The cutaneous nerves penetrate through the deep fascia and enter the subcutaneous plane to supply their dermatomes.
The sural nerve is a cutaneous nerve formed by the union of the medial sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the tibial nerve) and the lateral sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the common peroneal nerve).
The medial and lateral plantar nerves are the cutaneous terminal branches of the tibial nerve.

title: Pituitary gland and cavernous sinus
description: The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is completely surrounded by the cavernous sinus. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of the cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerve are located towards the lateral wall of the sinus.

title: Heart murmur in ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation
description: Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

title: Heart murmur in mitral valve prolapse
description: High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

title: Heart murmur in aortic and pulmonary insufficiency
description: Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
Erythema is visible on the cheeks, nasolabial folds, and chin. Overlying scaling is also present.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
Well-defined erythematous plaques are visible on the scalp.

This appearance is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
Chest of a male patient

Erythema with fine scaling is visible between and underneath the breasts.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Seborrheic dermatitis
description:
There is marked erythema extending from the philtrum to both nasolabial folds, along both sides of the nasal bridge, and on the labiomental groove. There is also minor scaling of the skin on both sides of the nasal bridge.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

title: Arteries of the pelvis
description:
Ventral view of important branches of the external iliac artery and femoral artery

After passing the inguinal ligament, the external iliac artery becomes the femoral artery. At this point, the profunda femoris artery emerges from the femoral artery and gives of the medial and lateral circumflex femoral artery.

title: Pathophysiology of the development of cervical cancer
description:
Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by an infection of the transformation zone (rectangular box) with high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).

HPVs infect the stem cells of the basal cell epithelium. Cell proliferation and migration of virus-infected daughter cells into the suprabasal cell layer allow the infection to spread. At the beginning of the process, the DNA of the virus is episomal. As the disease progresses, the DNA is integrated into the cervical epithelium's DNA. A noninvasive precursor lesion, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), may develop from an HPV infection over months to years, which may ultimately progress to invasive carcinoma.

In most cases, complete recovery will occur during the early stages of an HPV infection.

title: Cerebellum
description: Dorsocaudal view (without brainstem)

title: Incorrectly placed central venous catheter
description:
Chest x-ray (AP view)

There is a central venous catheter in the left subclavian vein. Its tip is resting against the wall of the superior vena cava (arrows).

When placed correctly, the catheter's distal end should lie in the center of the lumen of the superior vena cava, at the level of the carina.

title: Transporters in the proximal tubule, pars recta
description: The pars recta of the proximal tubule is referred to as thick descending limb of the loop of Henle. It is particularly responsible for the mainly paracellular absorption via leaky tight junctions or solvent drag. Hereby, mainly Cl− is transported out of the lumen, resulting in positive potential in the tubular lumen. In addition, specific glucose transporters (SGLT-1) carry Na+ and glucose via symport from the tubular lumen to the cell interior.

title: Asbestosis
description:
Gross specimen of diaphragmatic pleura

Partially confluent, fibrous plaques with a verrucous appearance are visible.

Histological examination revealed pleuropulmonary asbestosis.

title: Serology of chronic hepatitis C infection
description: HCV RNA is continuously detectable throughout chronic hepatitis C infection, with levels peaking at approx. 6 weeks and lower spikes occurring episodically thereafter. Transaminase levels follow the pattern of HCV RNA with a slight delay of approx. 1 week. Antibody production begins at 2 months after infection and plateaus at approx. 4 months, thus not corresponding to HCV RNA and transaminase levels.

title: Serology of hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection
description:
Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are detectable ∼ 5–10 days after infection (5–10 days before clinical symptoms develop), with peak levels ∼ 1 month after infection. Levels typically become undetectable within 3–6 months post infection. Assessing for the presence of anti-HAV IgM antibodies is the standard diagnostic test for active hepatitis A.

During HAV infection, anti-HAV IgG antibodies are typically detectable when clinical symptoms develop and subsequently persist indefinitely. They are also produced in response to vaccination and are a marker of immunity to reinfection.

HAV RNA can be detected in stool and serum samples in patients with hepatitis A. This test is not routinely used but can be helpful during outbreaks, as HAV RNA can be detected as early as the first week after infection.

title: Veins of the leg (ventral aspect)
description:
The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg:
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Short saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posterior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg:
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins
- Femoral vein: continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

title: Hormonal feedback control of the adrenal hormones
description:
(1) Stimuli such as pain, stress (physical/psychological), pyrogens, epinephrine, histamine, hypoglycemia, and hypotonia cause the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) in the hypothalamus.

(2) In the anterior pituitary gland, CRH stimulates the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which stimulates the secretion of glucocorticoids and androgens in the adrenal cortex. Glucocorticoids inhibit the secretion of CRH and ACTH via a negative feedback loop.

title: Types of hemorrhage in placental abruption
description:
The type of hemorrhage depends on the location of the abruption.

Concealed hemorrhage occurs if the placenta separates from the uterine wall in the middle, but is still attached at the margins. This results in a concealed, retroplacental hemorrhage into the artificial space created between the placenta and the uterus.

Revealed hemorrhage occurs if the placenta separates at the margins, leading to vaginal bleeding.

Mixed hemorrhage: combination of retroplacental hematoma and revealed vaginal hemorrhage

title: Placental abruption prior to delivery
description:
Left: Normal placental implantation
Right: Placental abruption with retroplacental hematoma

In normal implantation, oxygenated blood from maternal vessels of the decidua fills the intervillous space. The fetomaternal gas exchange occurs between the maternal blood in the intervillous space and the fetal vessels (contained in chorionic villi; not shown here).

An abruption damages the maternal vessels in the decidua, causing a hematoma to develop between the placenta and uterus wall. The retroplacental hemorrhage can exacerbate the abruption and result in a complete placental separation. In addition to maternal blood loss, the placental perfusion and thus fetal oxygen supply is reduced because of the ruptured maternal vessels and compression of the intervillous space.

title: Action potentials of pacemaker cells in the sinus node
description:
Depolarization:

Blue (if): Hyperpolarization triggers the opening of funny channels (if), resulting in an influx of cations into the cell and their depolarization to the threshold potential of -40 mV.

Violet (iCa): Voltage-gated calcium channels (iCa) open at approx. -40 mV, resulting in an influx of calcium cations into the cell and their depolarization to the threshold potential of approx. +20 mV.

Repolarization:

Green (iKs+Kr): The calcium channels close and the delayed outward rectifier potassium channels open (iKs+Kr). This causes an outflow of potassium ions out of the cell until it returns to -60 mV again. This leads to the closure of the potassium channels and the opening of funny channels, thus initiating a new excitation cycle.

title: Types of insulin
description: The graphs depict onset, peak, and duration of effect.

title: Trichotillomania
description: There are patches of hair of varying length. The hair density is normal (including new hair growth).

title: Alopecia areata
description: There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

title: Ascaris lumbricoides fertilized egg
description:
Photomicrograph of a wet mount of human feces

A yellowish-brown, round ovum with a knobby (mammillated) outer layer is visible.

This is the typical appearance of an Ascaris lumbricoides egg (the round shape indicates that it is fertilized).

title: Foam cells
description:
Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)

Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

title: Trichuris trichiura eggs
description:
Photomicrograph of a wet stool mount (very high magnification)

Barrel-shaped, thick-walled eggs with bipolar hyaline protuberances are visible, which are characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

title: T cell activation
description: As soon as a T cell receptor (TCR) encounters a fitting MHC-antigen complex, a strong, antigen-dependent bond between the T cell and the antigen-presenting cell (here an interdigitating dendritic cell, IDC) occurs. The first activating signal (signal 1) establishes the interaction between the MHC-antigen complex of the IDC and the TCR of the T cell. CD4 and CD8 function as coreceptors in the process. At the same time, the T cell binds the CD40 receptor of the IDC with the help of its CD40 ligands (not shown here). The second signal required for activation (signal 2) occurs via B7/CD28 interaction.

title: Maturation of T cells in the thymus
description: Migration from the outer cortex to the thymic medulla occurs during maturation of T-cells. (1) Precursor T-cells from the bone marrow enter the subcapsular compartment of the cortex. (2) T-cells, negative for CD4 and CD8, form a dysfunctional pre-TCR (double negativity). (3) Proliferation with subsequent expression of both, CD4 and CD8 molecules on the cell surface (double positivity). The pre-TCR undergoes completion and is now fully functional. It will now be expressed as CD3/TCR-complex on the cell surface. These T-cells start migrating into the corticomedullary junction, at which point epithelial cells initiate interaction with T-cells in order to validate their immune competency. Association between MHC molecules and the TCR-complex is required to pass through. (4a) Specifically, CD4 allows interaction with MHC-II, (4b) while CD8 does so with MHC-I. (5) Failure to bind either results in apoptosis.

title: Adenoid cystic carcinoma in parotid gland
description:
Photomicrograph of parotid gland specimen (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Normal parotid tissue with serous acini and intermixed fat tissue is seen on the left quarter of the image. The center and right of the image show tissue of an infiltrating parotid tumor composed of ductal and myoepithelial cells arranged in a gland-like cribriform to tubular, partially cystic (examples indicated by green overlays) architecture. The cystic gland-like structures often contain amphophilic material (examples indicated by asterisks) and feature hyaline stroma interspersed between them (yellow overlay).

This is the typical appearance of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

title: Male pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia)
description:
Non-scarring hair loss can be seen at the temporal scalp.

This is the characteristic pattern of male pattern hair loss.

title: V(D)J recombination (generation of immunoglobulin diversity)
description:
Immunoglobulins are synthesized by B cells and are composed of two heavy chains and two light chains. V(D)J recombination refers to the random rearrangement of immunoglobulin gene segments that occurs during the maturation of B cells from lymphoid stem cell precursors within the bone marrow. This process ensures the diversity of immunoglobulins expressed on the surface of B cells.

Rearrangement of three genetic segments (V: variable; D: diversity; J: joining genes) occurs first on the heavy chain locus of immunoglobulin DNA in the following sequence:
– D-J rearrangement: deletion of DNA between the D and J segments, followed by D-J recombination
– V-DJ rearrangement: The V gene segment joins the combined D-J segment.

Pre-mRNA is transcribed from the rearranged DNA. Introns are spliced from pre-mRNA, resulting in the formation of mature mRNA. Mature mRNA then translates the protein synthesis of immunoglobulin heavy chains.

Rearrangement of light chain gene segments occurs later in B cell maturation. Light chain DNA lacks the D segment. The V segment combines with the J segment (V-J rearrangement), which then undergoes transcription, intron splicing, and translation of light chain proteins.

Disulfide bonds bind the heavy chains and light chains to form immunoglobulins that are then expressed on the surface of B cells and are referred to as B cell receptors (BCR).

Note: This process is antigen-independent (unlike the activation and differentiation phase of B cells into plasma cells, which are both antigen-dependent).

title: B cell activation
description:
1. The B cell recognizes the antigen with the aid of the B cell receptor (BCR) and the BCR/antigen complex is then internalized. At the same time, the MHC II molecules (produced in the endoplasmic reticulum) are pinched off to form vesicles above the Golgi apparatus (not shown in detail). At this time, the MHC II molecules still possess an additional invariant chain (li chain), which prevents the premature binding of proteins to the molecule. The Golgi apparatus is also responsible for the formation of primary lysosomes, which are essential for later antigen processing.

2. After uptake of the BCR/antigen-complex, there are at first several individual compartments (BCR/antigen complex in the endosome, proteases in primary lysosomes, and MHC II molecules in vesicles).

3. Merging of the individual compartments to one large lysosome makes antigen processing possible. The lysosomal proteases break down the antigens into small fragments. These are then loaded with MHC II molecules to be presented at the cell surface.

4. Interaction between the B cell and the T helper cell (Th cell) activates the B cell. The first signal is the binding of the T cell receptor (TCR) and its coreceptors (CD3, CD4) to the MHC II/antigen complex. The binding of CD40 to the CD40 ligands (CD40L) is the second signal (leading to the release of cytokines, particularly IL-4, which stimulate proliferation of the B cell).

5. Stimulation allows the B cell to mature into a plasma cell (PC) that releases antibodies that are specific to the particular antigen that was recognized.

title: Kidneys, lungs, and liver within thoracic skeleton
description: The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

title: Neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer disease
description:
Photomicrograph of cerebral tissue (Gallyas silver stain)

Intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (neurofibrillary tangles) are visible in multiple neurons (examples indicated by green overlay).

Neurofibrillary tangles are a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease but are also found in other conditions.

title: Gastric gland
description:
The gastric mucosa is composed of numerous gastric glands that lie within the lamina propria.
Gastric glands are lined by specialized cells:
- Chief cells: located at the base of the glands (secrete pepsinogen)
- Parietal cells: located in the middle of the glands (secrete HCl and intrinsic factor)
- Enteroendocrine cells: located adjacent to parietal cells (secrete histamine and serotonin)
- Mucous cells: located at the neck of the gastric glands (secrete mucus)
- Stem cells: located at the neck of the gastric glands (differentiate into various gastric mucosal cells)

title: Comparison of MRI images in healthy control, Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia
description:
Image A is a transverse MRI (flair sequence) showing normal brain structure.

Image B is a transverse MRI (flair sequence) of a patient with Alzheimer's disease (AD). The image shows considerable tempero-parietal cortical atrophy and deepening/widening of the sulci. There is also considerable enlargment of the ventricles due to global atrophy.

Image C is a transverse MRI (flair sequence) of a patient with vascular dementia. The image shows areas of periventricular hyperintensity indicating small vessel disease. There is noticable deepening of the sulci and global cortical atrophy. There are two area of hypodense brain tissue in the tempero-occipital regions which may indicate infarcted tissue.

title: Glucose Clearance (ENG)
description:
With a plasma glucose concentration less than 10 mmol/L (180mg/dL), all glucose is filtered from the glomerulus into the tubular lumen and then completely reabsorbed (through cotransport with sodium ions) in the proximal convoluted tubule through sodium-glucosecotransporters (SGLT2) such that the urine concentration of glucose is zero.

Above 10 mmol/L (180mg/dL) plasma glucose concentration, not all of the glucose can be reabsorbed by the proximal convoluted tubule. The maximum secretion rate (Tm 380mg/min) is reached above this blood glucose threshold, and some glucose will be excreted in the urine (glucosuria) at a concentration proportional to the plasma concentration of glucose.

title: Williams syndrome
description:
Photograph of a child with a broad forehead, midfacial hypoplasia, a short nose (with a flat nasal bridge), an everted lower lip, full cheeks and lips and low-set ears.

This appearance is often described as “elfin” facies and commonly seen in Williams syndrome, although definitive diagnosis would require genetic testing.

title: Muscles of the anterior compartment of the thigh
description: The left illustration shows the sartorius and the quadriceps femoris. If you remove the sartorius and the rectus femoris the vastus intermedius can be seen in the right illustration.

title: Clearance of inulin (ENG)
description: The relationship between plasma concentration of inulin and urine concentration is linear: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubular system. The amount of inulin in the urine represents the amount that is filtered by the kidneys.

title: Heme synthesis and corresponding diseases
description: Overview of heme synthesis and its key enzymes as well as the molecular causes of several diseases that interfere with heme synthesis.

title: Histopathological grades of cervical cancer
description:
LSIL: low-grade squamous intraepithelial neoplasia
HSIL: high-grade squamous intraepithelial neoplasia
CIN: cervical intraepithelial neoplasia

title: Congenital malformations of the anterior abdominal wall
description:
Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.

Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.

Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.

Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

title: Brugada syndrome
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼62/min
– Normal axis: R > S in I and aVF
– First-degree AV block: PR interval ∼240 ms
– Coved ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST-changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1/V2.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

title: Hypospadias
description: The external urethral meatus is located on the ventral aspect of the penile shaft instead of its normal location on the glans penis.

title: Acanthosis nigricans
description:
Hyperpigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and numerous skin tags (papillomatosis) are visible on the right axilla.

These findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

title: Capillary hemangioma of the skin (cherry angioma)
description:
Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.

This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

title: Seborrheic keratosis
description:
A sharply demarcated darkly pigmented papule with a greasy nodular surface is visible. The papule appears to be stuck onto the skin.

This is the typical appearance of seborrheic keratosis, a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in the elderly.

title: Myofibrillar disarray
description:
Photomicrograph of myocardial tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is loss of the normal striated histological architecture of myocardial tissue, with most of the cells arranged in swirls or clusters (myofibrillar disarray).

Myofibrillar disarray is seen in a number of diseases, including hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

title: Livor mortis
description:
Photograph of a deceased patient

Purple discoloration of the skin is visible in the dependent parts of the body.

This is the typical appearance of livor mortis. The intensity of the discoloration and color depends on the cause of death.

title: Fallopian tube with an ectopic pregnancy
description:
Left fallopian tube of a 25-year-old patient after salpingectomy

An amniotic sac with embryonic structures (approx. 6th week conceptional age/8th week gestational age) is visible on the enlarged fallopian tube. Looking closely one can identify the developing extremities, heart, eyes, and brain of this embryo.

title: Legionella pneumophila
description:
Colorized electron micrograph of bacteria grown own a buffered charcoal yeast extract agar culture plate

Multiple legionella pneumophila bacteria are visible.

title: Lysosomal storage disease
description:
The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.

GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

title: Functional organisation eukaryotic genes
description:
This eukaryotic gene, which codes for a protein, can be subdivided into a promoter area and an Exon-Intron area.

The promoter is a specific DNA region, which contains the transcription start site (TSS). It sits upstream (before the gene) and regulates the transcription.

The area between TSS and transcription terminal side is read to build mRNA. Then in a splicing-process, the Introns are cut off. The remaining Extron sequence between translation initiation site and translation termination site is translated into a protein sequence.

title: Muscles of the posterior thigh (hamstring muscles)
description:
Hamstring muscles and the popliteus (dorsal view)

Left: an overview of the posterior thigh muscles

Right: semitendinosus and biceps femoris removed

title: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (liver)
description:
Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (PAS diastase stain; approx. 450x magnification)

PAS-positive and diastase-resistant globular cytoplasmic inclusions (green overlay) can be seen within periportal hepatocytes. The periportal fibrous tissue has been highlighted for orientation (white overlay).

These are the characteristic histopathological findings in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Additional immunohistochemical staining should be performed to confirm that the inclusions contain alpha-1 antitrypsin.

title: Localized myxedema in Graves dermopathy
description:
Dorsal aspect of the palms and ventral aspect of the legs in a patient with Graves disease

Hands: The dorsal aspect of the hands and fingers appears swollen. This is known as thyroid acropachy.
Legs: Multiple thickened nodules and plaques can be seen on the ventral aspect of the legs. This is known as pretibial myxedema.

These features are characteristic of Graves dermopathy, which occurs secondary to deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the dermis by dermal fibroblasts that are hyperstimulated by circulating TSH receptor antibodies.

title: Atypical nevi (dysplastic nevi)
description: Macules of varying sizes with irregular, ill-defined borders and variable pigmentation (pink, brown). Some of these lesions feature a central papular component, which is responsible for the typical fried-egg appearance.

title: Spongiotic dermatitis
description:
Photomicrograph of the skin (H&E stain, high magnification)

Tissue layers from top to bottom:

1. Stratum lucidum
2. Stratum granulosum
3. Stratum spinosum
4. Stratum basale
5. Papillary dermis

The dermal/epidermal junction is visible in the center of the image (green dashed line). The interstitium between keratinocytes is dilated due to edema (examples in yellow overlay). Dermal papillae are filled with keratinocytes.

title: Yersinia pestis
description:
Photomicrograph of a blood smear (Wright's stain; very high magnification)

There are numerous sporeless, rod-shaped bacteria without flagella. Dark staining is visible on the bipolar ends of the bacteria ("closed safety pin" appearance; examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This appearance is characteristic of Yersinia pestis.

title: Motor unit
description: Innervation of muscles occurs via the α-motor neurons. After dividing into several branches, the α-motor neuron axons (shown in red or blue) and individual muscle fibers form the motor endplate, where impulses are transmitted to the muscle. In this area, the axon further divides into several axon terminals, where neurotransmitters are released. The sum of all muscle fibers innervated by a single α-motor neuron is called a motor unit (analogous to the α-motor neurons shown here in red and blue).

title: Amyloid deposits in medullary thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Green overlay: amyloid deposits
Red: exemplary tumor cells

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mitochondrion
description:
A mitochondrion (bottom left, cross section) and its most important functions: Mitochondria are cell organelles made up of a smooth outer membrane, an inner membrane with an increased surface area as a result of folds (cristae), and the matrix, which harbors mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes and is the site of numerous metabolic processes.

Upper left: One of the most important functions of the mitochondria is supplying energy through the electron transport chain, which is integrated into the inner mitochondrial membrane. The phospholipid cardiolipin enables the close arrangement of individual complexes of the electron transport chain.

Upper right: The outer membrane is rich in pores and therefore permeable to numerous substances, whereas the inner membrane can only be permeated via specific transporters.

Bottom right: Proteins must be unfolded before transport in and out of the mitochondrion. Translocases of the inner and outer membranes (TIM and TOM) transport unfolded proteins across the membranes.

title: Hyperthyroidism (Graves disease)
description:
Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Green overlay: papillary infoldings of hyperplastic thyroid follicles

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Fibroadenoma of the breast
description:
Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Fibrocystic disease of the breast
description:
Photomicrograph of breast tissue affected by fibrocystic disease

Cystic ducts (black dashed lines) and fibrosis of mammary tissue, i.e., increased collagen fibers in the stroma (green overlay), are visible. Apocrine metaplasia can also be seen in association with the fibrocystic changes (white overlay). For comparison, the regular terminal duct lobular unit of the breast is visible on the right (white dashed lines).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Urothelial carcinoma of the bladder (transitional cell carcinoma)
description:
Photomicrograph of bladder tissue (H&E stain, 75x magnification)

Green overlay: deepest invasive tumor front
Black arrow: urothelium
White arrow: bladder muscularis of bladder

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Chronic anal fissure
description:
A longitudinal section of the anal canal with features of a chronic anal fissure, characterized by a longitudinal ulcerated wound in the anoderm extending from the dentate line to the anocutaneous line. Wound margins commonly show scarring and fibrosis.

Secondary changes commonly associated with chronic fissures are also visible, including a sentinel skin tag at the distal end of the fissure and a hypertrophic anal papilla located proximally near the dentate line, within the region of the anal columns.

title: Reduction and oxidation reactions of glutathione
description:
In its reduced form (GSH), glutathione detoxifies free radicals and peroxides (here hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, on the right). This reaction is catalyzed by the glutathione peroxidase and results in oxidized glutathione (GSSG) and water (H2O). To convert the GSSG back to GSH, the catalyzing enzyme glutathione reductase requires NADPH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate hydrogen).
