One possible pathway that yields NADPH for reductive reactions is the pentose phosphate pathway (hexose monophosphate shunt). The enzyme glucose-6-P-dehydrogenase (G6PD) oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate and reduces NADP to NADPH.

The reduced glutathione is particularly important for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage. In its absence (e.g., due to G6PD deficiency), RBCs become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in hemolytic anemia.

title: Tympanosclerosis
description:
Otoscopy of a right ear

A white, grape-shaped, calcified plaque (green overlay) is visible in the 3rd quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

This is the typical appearance of tympanosclerosis.

title: JC virus in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
description:
Photomicrograph of a brain biopsy specimen of a patient with PML (immunohistochemistry stain; 400x magnification)

Glial cells infected with the JC (John Cunningham) virus are highlighted in dark brown.

title: Pellagra
description:
There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

title: Hyaline cast
description:
Urine sediment microscopy (left: unstained; right: Sternheimer stain, 400x magnification)

Left: A translucent, cylindrical, acellular structure is seen.
Right: The stain has enhanced the protein matrix, which appears light blue.

These features are typical of hyaline casts, which are composed of a mucoprotein matrix of Tamm-Horsfall protein and contain neither cells nor debris.

Hyaline casts are a nonspecific finding on urinalysis as they are also seen in healthy individuals.

title: Sporotrichosis (lymphocutaneous form)
description:
Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

title: Bullous pemphigoid
description:
A: Microscopy (100x magnification) with immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the basement membrane of a skin tissue sample.

B: Microscopy (200x magnification) with indirect immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the epidermal junction of a skin tissue sample.

title: Axillary lymph node swelling due to plague
description:
Right axilla of a male patient diagnosed with plague

The axilla appears swollen secondary to underlying lymph node enlargement due to infection with Yersinia pestis.

This disease is rare but if diagnosed requires immediate antibiotic treatment.

title: Methionine cycle
description:
Methionine is an essential amino acid that generates sulfur-containing amino acids (i.e., cysteine, homocysteine, and taurine) as well as S-adenosyl methionine (SAM), a coenzyme of several methylation reactions, through the methionine cycle.

ATP donates adenosine to methionine, converting it to SAM. SAM then loses its methyl group to form S-adenosylhomocysteine, which loses its adenosine molecule to form homocysteine. Homocysteine can then enter three pathways: It can be converted to succinyl CoA (which enters the citric acid cycle), cysteine (from which taurine is generated; not shown here), or back to methionine. Methionine synthase catalyzes the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine in the presence of vitamin B12 and N5-methyltetrahydrofolate (N5-methyl-THF).

title: Types of hemolysis
description:
Bacterial culture (grown on Columbia horse blood agar)

Left: α-hemolysis
Partial hemolysis produces a greenish intermediate product. α-hemolytic Streptococcus species are called viridans streptococci (from Latin “viridis,” green), the most common being S. pneumoniae.

Middle: β-hemolysis
Complete hemolysis manifests as translucent agar. β-hemolytic Streptococcus species can be classified according to Lancefield groups (clinically relevant: A and B), S. pyogenes (group A) being the best known.

Right: γ-hemolysis
The term γ-hemolysis is a misnomer, as, in fact, no hemolysis takes place. The best known γ-hemolytic species are those of the Enterococcus genus.

title: Leiomyoma
description:
Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E stain, 250x magnification)

Green overlay: leiomyoma tissue; transverse section
White overlay: leiomyoma tissue; longitudinal section
Black arrows: mitotic figure
White arrows: blood vessels

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Acute anal fissure
description: A longitudinal section of the anal canal with typical features of an acute anal fissure. A longitudinal tear in the anoderm extending from the dentate line to the anocutaneous line can be seen. The wound margins are smooth, and the surrounding mucosa appears unremarkable.

title: Melanoma
description:
Photomicrograph of skin tissue section (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

Green overlay: tumor cells in dermis
Black arrows: pigmented tumor cells in cornified layer of epidermis

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Mature mRNA
description:
Mature mRNA is the product of post-transcriptional modifications and consists of the following parts:
- 5' cap: composed of 7-methylguanosine
- 5' UTR (untranslated region)
- Coding sequence that begins at a start codon (AUG) and ends at a stop codon (UGA)
- 3' UTR
- Poly(A) tail composed of several adenine nucleotides (polyadenylation)

title: Auricular keloids
description: The right pinna bears two well-defined, round, red swellings with a smooth surface. The swellings extend well beyond the boundary of the original defects (i.e., piercings in the scapha of the pinna).

title: Atopic dermatitis
description:
Erythematous papules and lichenified skin are visible adjacent to the popliteal fossae of this child.

This appearance is typical in acute and chronic atopic dermatitis.

title: Actinic keratosis
description:
Right hand of an older patient

Multiple scaly lesions on erythematous skin are visible.

These lesions and their location (sun-exposed area) are typical of actinic keratosis.

title: Vitiligo
description: Irregular, sharply delimited, whitish (depigmented) patches can be seen on both upper eyelids and inner corners of the eye. There are no signs of inflammation.

title: Erythema migrans
description:
A circular erythematous rash with a central clearing (“bulls-eye” rash) is visible on the upper back.

Erythema migrans is typically seen in the early localized stage of Lyme disease.

title: Xanthelasma
description:
Well-defined yellow plaques (xanthelasma) are visible on the medial aspect of the upper eyelids bilaterally.

These cutaneous lipid deposits are a common finding in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

title: Melasma
description:
Hyperpigmented brown, irregularly shaped patches are visible on both sides of the upper and lower cutaneous lip.

These features are characteristic of melasma, which typically has a centrofacial distribution.

title: Mechanism of esophageal diverticula formation
description:
Pulsion diverticula are false diverticula: only the mucosa and submucosa bulge through weak points in the muscularis propria as a result of increased intraluminal pressure. They are typically located at the upper (Zenker diverticulum) or lower esophageal sphincter (epiphrenic diverticulum).

Traction diverticula are true diverticula: all layers of the esophageal wall protrude. The protrusion results from inflammation of the mediastinum with scarring and retraction. Traction diverticula are commonly located at the tracheal bifurcation.

title: Gas gangrene
description:
Photograph of the right thigh of a male patient

There is tense edema of the right thigh and knee. Diffuse purplish-black patches are visible on the right inguinal region, thigh, and knee. Tense blebs of varying sizes filled with dark hemorrhagic fluid are present on the upper thigh and the knee.

These are the characteristic features of gas gangrene.

title: Hyperpigmentation in Addison disease
description:
Left: bronze-toned facial hyperpigmentation before treatment
Right: after treatment with glucocorticoid replacement therapy

title: Medullary thyroid carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 300x magnification)

Green overlay: tumor cell nests
Black arrows: fibrous bands with prominent vascularity

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Receptor binding
description:
This image shows different ways that pharmaceuticals can interact with a cell receptor (top):

Agonist pharmaceuticals have the same efficacy as natural transmitters. Partial agonists (right) also bind like natural transmitters but are less effective than agonists (due to structural differences).
Antagonists, however, have an effect that differs from the natural transmitter, regardless of whether they are competitive (i.e., have the same receptor binding site as the natural transmitter, left) or non-competitive (i.e., do not have the same receptor binding site as the natural transmitter, center).

Additionally, the effects of the different pharmaceuticals are shown in diagrams (bottom):

With the administration of a competitive antagonist (left), the agonist or natural transmitter must be provided in much higher concentration than is the case without an antagonist, if a similar effect is to be reached (right shift of the curve).
With the administration of a non-competitive antagonist (center), the achievable maximum effect decreases with an agonist or natural transmitter, and cannot be balanced out by increasing the concentration (compression of the curve in y-direction).
Agonists and partial agonists (right) are both effective (shift of the curve in x-direction and compression in y-direction).

title: Plaque psoriasis
description: Confluent erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor surface of the upper limb.

title: Steroid skin atrophy
description: The skin appears thin and translucent and the veins are unusually prominent. Purpura is visible in several places.

title: Linea nigra and polymorphic eruption of pregnancy
description: Linear hyperpigmentation that runs vertically down the midline of the abdomen (linea nigra) is visible. This physiological change is commonly seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. In addition, an erythematous, urticarial rash with papules and plaques is visible in the periumbilical upper thigh region (polymorphic eruption of pregnancy).

title: Most common routes of metastasis with TNM classification
description:
Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.

title: Human genome packaging
description:
The human genome is present as chromatin in the nucleus. Chromatin contains DNA, which is bound to histones as well as non-histone proteins. Chromatin structure is initially determined by interaction between DNA and histones. DNA winds approx. twice around the nucleosome core particle that consists of eight histones (two histones each of types H2A, H2B, H3, and H4). H1 is located on the nucleosome and binds to linker DNA, which is located between nucleosomes.

In the presence of physiological salt conditions, 30 nm fibers are formed by folding of the nucleosome chain to a left-handed helix. Chromatin is further condensed by various proteins such as cohesin and topoisomerases. Chromatin is in its most condensed form in the chromosome during metaphase in mitosis. During each condensation step, the chromatin structure is altered through modifications and protein binding.

title: Lactic acid cycle and alanine cycle in skeletal muscle and liver
description:
The lactic acid (Cori) cycle regenerates glucose from lactate. In the muscle, glucose is first broken down to pyruvate (glycolysis) and then to lactate. Lactate is transported to the liver via the bloodstream. Here, it is transformed into pyruvate, from which glucose is regenerated via gluconeogenesis. The glucose is transported back to the muscle to provide energy.

In the alanine (Cahill) cycle, amino groups from the breakdown of proteins in skeletal muscle are transported to the liver, bound to alanine. In skeletal muscle, amino acids are degraded into α-ketoacids: the amino group is passed on to α-ketoglutarate, which converts into glutamate. From glutamate, the amino group is transaminated to pyruvate to form alanine. Alanine is then transferred to the liver, where it is deaminated into pyruvate again, passing the amino group to α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate. Finally, glutamate introduces the amino group into the urea cycle in the form of ammonia.

To aid tracking of the amino group, the molecules containing them have been shaded in gray.

title: Blood supply of the esophagus
description:
The three different portions of the esophagus are supplied and drained by different vessels:

The cervical esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the inferior thyroid artery and drains via esophageal veins into the inferior thyroid vein.

The thoracic esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches from the thoracic aorta and drains via esophageal veins into the azygos and hemiazygos veins.

The abdominal esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the left gastric artery and drains via the esophageal veins into the left gastric vein.

title: Vein with valves
description:
Longitudinal section of a vein with valves

Valves are flaps lined by intima that allow blood to flow in the direction of the heart (left illustration) but prevent the reflux of blood to the periphery (right illustration). If blood flows backward, the flaps are filled with blood, press against each other, and close the lumen of the vein.

title: Rheumatoid nodules
description:
Photograph of the hand of an elderly patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

Multiple erythematous subcutaneous nodules are visible at the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints. Involvement of the distal interphalangeal joints and redness are possible but uncommon in patients with RA.

title: Lipomas
description:
Several large, ovoid, lobulated nodules are visible on the flexor surface of the forearm.

The size, shape, location, and distribution of the lesions are consistent with lipomas.

title: Sialolithiasis of the submandibular gland
description: There is marked swelling of the right submandibular region (arrow). The location of the swelling suggests sialolithiasis of the submandibular gland.

title: Sialadenitis of the submandibular gland
description: There is massive swelling of the left submandibular region. The unilateral location and the marked erythema suggest bacterial sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

title: S-Adenosyl methionine (SAM)
description: The coenzyme S-Adenosyl methionine (SAM) is composed of three parts: methionine (red), ribose (blue), and adenine (black). It plays an important role as a cofactor in methylation reactions.

title: Acute pericarditis
description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

Sinus tachycardia with a frequency of approx. 107/min.
Normal heart axis (R > S in both I and aVF).
P waves have normal morphology. Diffuse PR depressions with reciprocal, concave ST elevations (best seen in aVL) and PR elevations in aVR. Note the notching at the end of the QRS complexes (creating the “fish hook” morphology; best seen in aVL). Discordant T wave in V1.
PR interval normal (approx. 120 ms), QRS interval borderline narrow (approx. 80 ms), QT interval prolonged (approx. 400 ms; QTc = 534 ms).

These findings are typical for stage 1 in acute pericarditis.

title: Coagulative necrosis in renal infarction
description:
Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (H&E stain; 150x magnification)

A large area of necrosis (green overlay) is visible. Necrotic glomeruli (green arrowheads) are also visible within a highly dense area of leukocytes (white overlay). This is in contrast to the appearance of a normal glomerulus (black arrowhead).

These findings are consistent with coagulative necrosis caused by renal infarction.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma
description:
Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (H&E stain, 350x magnification)

The renal tubules (black circles) can be seen within the renal parenchyma on the left. The tumor cells have spread beyond the renal capsule (faded area) and have an enlarged cytoplasm that appears clear due to high lipid and glycogen content.

This is the typical histological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Seminoma
description:
Photomicrograph of testicular tumor (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is a solid growing tumor (green overlay) that consists of spermatogonia-like cells with clear to slightly granulated cytoplasm and large nuclei (white arrowheads). A tumor-associated lymphocytic infiltrate is visible (white overlay). For comparison, a normal testicular tubule (black outline) with normal spermatogonia (black arrowheads) is shown.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

title: Krukenberg tumor
description:
Ovarian resection specimen

The ovary appears diffusely enlarged and has a smooth surface. The heterogeneous tissue contains streaks of cystic, mucoid tissue.

Krukenberg tumors are usually secondary to gastric signet ring cell carcinoma or breast cancer.

title: Apertures of the bony orbit
description:
Frontal view of the left orbit showing the nerves and vessels that enter the orbital cavity.

The common tendinous ring is the origin of all the rectus muscles and of the superior oblique muscle; it encloses all the structures that enter through the optic canal and four of the cranial nerve branches passing through the superior orbital fissure (nasociliary nerve, abducens nerve, and the superior and inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve).

title: Thyroid hormone production
description:
Thyroglobulin (TG) is produced in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the follicular cells. In the Golgi apparatus, TG is packed in vesicles and released into the colloid via exocytosis.

Iodide (I-) is taken up in the follicular cells via the basolateral Na+/I- symporter, which is driven by Na+/K+-ATPase. Iodine diffuses to the apex of the cell and is transported into the colloid via the Pendrin transporter.

The enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the biosynthesis of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4 and their precursors monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are all attached to the TG molecule stored in the colloid.

For the release of thyroid hormones, TG is taken up by the follicular cells via endocytosis. Following fusion with a lysosome, proteolytic enzymes cleave TG to release T3, T4, DIT, and MIT. T3 and T4 are released into the blood (via the MCT8 transporter). Deiodinase removes the iodine from the MIT and DIT; iodine is then re-added to the intracellular I- pool.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland stimulates the basolateral uptake of iodine, as well as the biosynthesis and release of thyroid hormones.

title: Meiosis
description:
During the course of meiosis, four gametes develop from one mother cell.

For the recombination of genetic material, two processes occur in meiosis I. The original mother and father chromosomes are randomly distributed to the daughter cells. During prophase I, a crossing-over of the homologous chromatids occurs (formation of chiasmata), resulting in an exchange of genetic material.

title: Exon-intron boundaries
description:
Exon-intron boundaries (splice sites) are specific nucleotide sequences (GU at the 5′ end; AG at the 3′ end in this image) in a newly transcripted pre-mRNA. They are recognized by spliceosomes that excise the non-coding introns and join the coding exons together.
Introns also contain pyrimidine-rich sequences (polypyrimidine tract) at the 3′ splice site that regulate alternative splicing.

title: Cranial nerve nuclei of the medulla oblongata
description:
Transverse section

Typically, the efferent cranial nuclei are located medially while the afferent nuclei are located more laterally.

title: Mechanisms of fructose intolerance
description:
(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.
